text:
The project will see one work of fiction from a different writer being added to a collection each year, until they are all published in 2150, by which time 251 stories will have been published. All of the stories will be set in the same universe, and the collection of stories will have been published between the years 1950 and 2150; in other words, the stories will be set 200 years in the past and 200 years in the future of their publication.

The 2011 work of fiction was submitted by writer Michael Swanwick and his story is called “The Tower Of The Elephant King.”

text:
Police fired tear gas and water cannon at protesters at a march called by the main pro-Kurdish party, the HDP.
A number of areas in the south-east have been put under curfew as security forces battle Kurdish PKK militants.
Violence has surged after a ceasefire broke down earlier this year.
The protesters had assembled to voice opposition to the curfew imposed in the city's Sur district for almost two weeks.
It was imposed days after prominent pro-Kurdish lawyer Tahir Elci was shot dead in Diyarbakir during a battle between police and unidentified gunmen in which two policemen also died.
A ceasefire between the army and the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July and dozens have since been killed in violence

text:
Twelve homes were evacuated on Wednesday after the hole opened in back gardens of Magdalen's Road in Ripon.
IAN WALKER, a neighbour, said the hole was about three metres across but he feared it could grow to 16 metres in the centre of the garden.
After 50 years of farming Mr and Mrs Walters said they plan to retire.
Their home is on a site where one of the family's own farmhouses stood. "We have farmed here for 50 years, I was born and bred on a farm and this has been a part of my life," said Mr Walters.
He said the family had taken the difficult decision to quit farming because "times are tough" for farmers with high grain costs, rising debt and no land available to expand into.
Mrs Walters, 61, a former primary school head teacher, said: "We have been

Sambo Dasuki was charged on 19 counts of fraud, money laundering and criminal breach of trust at the high court in Abuja on Tuesday, May 17.

Nigeria's former national security adviser, Sambo Dasuki, is on trial for allegedly diverting $2.1 billion allocated for the procurement of arms for the military.

Dasuki is charged on 19 counts of fraud, money laundering and criminal breach of trust at the high court in Abuja, where the trial started on Tuesday, May 17.

text:
The spending watchdog said the resources of Scottish Enterprise and Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE) were possibly being spread too thinly.
It also said that despite spending cuts since 2008-09 there had been "little change" in the agencies' work.
The Scottish government said it would consider recommendations made in the report.
Audit Scotland said that by failing to change the way they worked, Scotland's two enterprise bodies were at risk of spreading resources "over too broad a range of activities".
It added that "this might not be the most efficient use of their funding and expertise".
Scottish Enterprise and HIE spent Â£398m between them on their work to support economic growth in 2014-15.
But between 2008-09 and 2014-15, Scottish Enterprise's spending fell by 16%, Audit Scotland said.
While HIE spending rose by 3% over the period, the report said this was due to extra government cash for extending

text:
But when Wycombe Abbey, a girls' boarding school in Buckinghamshire, opens its doors in China in September, it will be the first of its kind in the country, offering a full boarding school experience as part of its UK-based sister school, a school spokesperson told CNN.

"China has a reputation for sending students overseas for study, but now an increasing number are choosing to have a boarding school experience in their own country -- an experience that is widely associated with the UK," she said.

"We believe the time is right for this unique school which will not only give Chinese students access to an English speaking education, but also an authentic boarding school experience."

He was then bundled into a car by three masked men and taken to a flat.
He was able to escape and was found by police in the Barrack Street area of Lisburn at approximately 01:30 GMT.
He received hospital treatment for his injuries which are not believed to be life threatening.
Police have appealed for witnesses.

Gong Lijiao of China won gold with a final-round throw of 21.73m, while 19-year-old Anita Marton of Hungary won silver with a PB of 19.79m on her final attempt.

In the women's hammer, the Chinese duo of Wang Zheng and Zhang Wenxiu claimed gold and silver after the former broke the world under-20 record with 75.38m.

His vehicle was being driven at “excessive speed” and was being driven “extremely close” to a marked police vehicle with its blue lights flashing, police said.

Officers tried to stop the vehicle but it sped away in an attempt to “evade apprehension”, the Met said.

Ross O'Sullivan, 25, from Cardiff, started the 220-mile (354km) swim of the River Severn at the source near Llanidloes, Powys, on 1 June.
On Saturday, he completed the challenge after reaching the Severn Beach at about 14:00 BST.
"I was completely drained. But it was a great sense of achievement," he said.
He was forced to walk the first three days as the water was too shallow, but after reaching Pool Quay, where he met his fiancee Caitriona Hurley and the support team, Mr O'Sullivan said "the adventure really started".

text:
Mrs Danczuk, who found fame posting "selfies" on Twitter, is hoping to be chosen to stand for Labour in the marginal Rochdale seat she lives in at the next General Election.

She is currently second favourite to be selected to run for the party but is in direct competition with the current Labour MP for Rochdale, Simon Danczuk, who has been an MP since 2010.

The 31-year-old mother-of-two said her desire to enter politics comes from the fact she was a lone parent on a low wage for much of her twenties.

Kate, who has two children with Mr Danczuk, told the Mirror: "People in positions of authority in this country don't know anything about what it's like to be poor.

“I want to fight for ordinary people in Rochdale."

The 33-year-old, who has won seven Grand Tours, has spent the last six years with Tinkoff but they are folding at the end of this season.
Contador is one of only six riders to have won all three Grand Tours, although he has not won the Tour de France since 2009.
"The big objective is to try and win the most important races - first and foremost the Tour de France," he said.
"Trek-Segafredo is a very attractive and ambitious project that really inspires me. I am convinced that this team can provide me with the best structure and bring me in the best conditions to the races."

text:
The towns of Amatrice, Arquata, Accumoli and Pescara del Tronto, where many of the 268 dead in central Italy lived, were at the epicentre of the latest earthquakes, but smaller towns and villages such as Capitignano, Preci, Campi, Monteprandone, and Pieve di Farfa, were also very badly hit.

“What is happening is really a disaster. Many houses, the historic centre and the churches are completely devastated,” a Vatican official told the AFP news agency on August 25 after visiting the worst-affected areas.

text:
Mr Romney and the Republicans  
          raised $106m (Â£68m)
, $35m more than Mr Obama and the Democrats,  
          who raised $71m
.
Both camps raised more than in May, when the Romney bid took in $77m and the Obama camp $60m.
The totals exclude millions raised by independent groups that support each candidate.
The Obama campaign released its June numbers in an email to donors.
"If we lose this election, it will be because we didn't close the gap enough when we had the chance," the email says, issuing another call for donations.
Mr Obama's campaign has been regularly warning supporters that he is in danger of becoming the first sitting president in history to be outspent by his opponent.
Super PAC rise
Mr Romney and the Republican National Committee have an estimated $160m cash in the bank to spend on the campaign, they confirmed on Monday.
About 20% - or $22.8m - of money raised by the two groups in June were from donations of $250 or less. The campaign said it received donations from all 50 states and from Washington DC.
Their rivals, the Obama campaign and the Democratic National Committee, had previously reported a combined $140m cash on hand at the end of May.

A 25ft (7.6m) model triceratops had to be removed from High Street in Godshill on the Isle of Wight after it became stuck in a manhole.

The giant model, which was being moved to a new location, became wedged after it fell into the hole on Friday afternoon.

After the Isle of Wight Council’s highway agency was called, the model was secured to a flatbed lorry and hauled out by a crane on Saturday morning.

Paul Barton, operations director of the council’s highway agency, said the dinosaur was found blocking the sewage system.

For 26 long years this internationally-recognised collection was tucked away in the Reference Room of Walsall Library. text:
On Wednesday the chancellor unveiled plans to tax soft drinks manufacturers who put large amounts of sugar in their products.
But people with jobs in the food and drink industry have reacted angrily, describing the levy as “discriminatory”.
The idea, which was first raised by David Cameron in his 2016 New Year address, will see 18p added to the price of a 330ml can of cola with a sugar content over 5 grams per 100 ml, and 24p on one with over 8g per 100ml.

Victims have spoken for the first time of senior cadet leaders covering up complaints, and pressurising families against going to the police.
Overseen by the Ministry of Defence, the cadets is one of the UK's largest youth bodies with 130,000 members.
The MoD has paid more than Â£2m to cadet abuse victims, and says it has "robust procedures in place to protect cadets".
According to Freedom of Information requests, in the last five years 363 sexual abuse allegations - both historical and current - have been made across the UK for the Army, Air and Sea Cadets.
Some 282 cases have been referred to the police and 99 volunteers have been dismissed.

In papers filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, the singer claims Jonathan Schwartz transferred money to his own accounts without permission.
"Morissette was completely unaware of these cash transfers and had not authorised them," the complaint says.
The singer, whose hits include Ironic and You Oughta Know, is suing for breach of duty, fraud and negligence.
Schwartz handled Morissette's finances between 2009 and 2016. He was responsible for collecting income, managing investment accounts and paying bills on her behalf.
According to the complaint, she fired him in March after which her new business manager, Howard Grossman, uncovered the suspicious withdrawals - 116 in all - totalling more than $4.7m (£3.25m).

The 17-year old passenger of the silver car was seriously injured and was taken to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary.
Police have confirmed that he died as a result of his injuries. Another three people were also taken to hospital.
Part of the route was closed but has now reopened.
Crews from the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and the Scottish Ambulance Service were also in attendance.

text:
A new year is upon us and I for one wonder what the fuss is all about - why the fireworks, the endless parties, the hangovers, the New Year's resolutions.

As a teenager I worked in a nightclub in the city centre, it was a lively joint in the 1970s with a 1.30am licence. At that time the police in Nottingham were very keen to stop pubs and clubs from closing at 11pm, after which time the bars would be thronged with drunks who were very often looking for trouble.

It was a very different time and one I can't help but think has been lost, along with civility and respect. As a bartender there was rarely a need to call the police, certainly nothing too serious that required a copper's attention, but that's not to say that on many nights we were not kept

The World War Two Mustang "Miss Velma" suffered suspected engine failure during an air show at Duxford on Sunday afternoon and landed in a nearby field.
While it was being taken for repairs, the wingspan turned out to be too wide to fit through a set of traffic lights.
It took more than an hour to get the carriageway clear, police said.
Beds, Cambs & Herts Roads Policing Unit took to Twitter to describe the scene as "carnage".
"Recovered plane just won't fit through gap!" the unit wrote when the vehicle transporting the plane became stuck at about 15:35 BST.

Archaeologists believe the faeces were left by dogs or cats that helped to control vermin towards the end of occupation of the roundhouse.

The 2,700-year-old animal faeces or “coprolite” was found as part of the excavation of the Iron Age roundhouse on South Street, Bath, as part of a development scheme by The Bath Preservation Trust.

It could be the oldest coprolite ever found on a building site in England and was probably left by either a cat or a dog and is likely to have been used as part of efforts to control rats and fleas that were known to have been a real nuisance to the people who lived there, say archaeologists.

text:
A former education minister, he has promised to create jobs, boost the economy and improve education and healthcare.
His party, the Jamaican Labour Party will have a slim one-seat majority in parliament.
He beat Portia Simpson Miller, Jamaica's first female head of government in elections last week.
He was sworn in by the Governor-General of Jamaica, Sir Patrick Allen.
Among the challenges for Jamaica's new government is a youth unemployment rate of 38% and dealing with the country's heavy debt.
In his inaugural address, Mr Holness said he wanted to make Jamaica "the centre of the Caribbean" for finance, trade, commerce, arts and culture.
"My dream is to fulfil your dream. We must create a Jamaica where there is hope and opportunity, where we can encourage our children to dream big."

Protests have spread from Johannesburg's Wits University, closed last week after thousands demonstrated on campus, to the universities of Rhodes and Pretoria.

They have also spread into South Africa's cities.

In Cape Town, protesters have erected barricades made of burning tyres across roads to stop traffic.

Police have responded with stun grenades and rubber bullets.

Many believe the issues underpinning the protests go beyond the original demands at Wits for free education, but have been stirred by the broader social and economic inequalities South Africans continue to face.

## What do they want?

The protests began after Wits students and other groups demanded the university free up more bursaries for students from previously disadvantaged backgrounds.

As the protests widened in scope, the main demand became "free decolonised education".

text:
Energy firm Cuadrilla is appealing against Lancashire County Council's refusal to let it extract shale gas at Little Plumpton and Roseacre Wood.
Planning inspector Wendy McKay has sent her report to Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government Greg Clark to scrutinise.
The decision is expected by 6 October.
Lancashire County Council rejected both planning applications for the Fylde sites last year on the grounds of noise and traffic impact.
Cuadrilla disputed those reasons at an inquiry chaired by Ms McKay in Blackpool earlier this year and said night-time noise would be short and affect only a handful of homes.
The secretary of state said he will make the final decision, as opposed to the planning inspector, because the proposals were "of more than local significance".
Anti-fracking campaigners claim the process is harmful to the environment.

The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) said it was combating the "vulgar culture" of using names like Barack Hussein, which President Obama used while growing up, on Weibo, a microblogging service resembling Twitter that China created.

"The names 'Adolf Hitler' and 'Barack Obama' and other such vicious and offensive words and expressions ... have recently appeared widely on social media sites," the CAC said in a notice posted on its website late Wednesday and quoted by the China Daily, a state-run newspaper. The CAC also told users to stop using names like "Junior Soldier 666." text:
You might think, therefore, that the crash in the price of oil must be dealing a potentially fatal blow to renewable power.
An illustration from recent history seems to back that up.
When the oil price spiked in the 1970s, the then US president Jimmy Carter had solar panels fixed to the White House roof, only to see his successor Ronald Reagan rip them off when the oil price tumbled.
Fast forward to the past few months and at first sight a similar effect appears to be happening as the share prices of many renewable energy companies take a hit.
However, things are not so straightforward. The world of energy has changed.
For a start, oil does not compete with wind or solar power. They perform different roles - oil is still dominant in transport while renewables generate electricity.
Since the 1970s, the use of oil at power stations has dwindled. It was replaced by

text:
A scheme to resettle unaccompanied children around the UK starts in July.
The government has agreed to take in more child migrants after a surge in people making the perilous journey to the UK.

Ministers say they will welcome in 300 child refugees as part of a new, voluntary scheme.

They will be matched with councils that want to resettle them over the coming years.

There was also further good news on the Syrian migrant crisis after the European Union said it would accept 160,000 refugees and economic migrants this year.

Downing Street said the scheme to take in child refugees was the first step in a process that will see thousands of children brought to the UK.

The agreement with the Home Office came at the end of a three-day visit to Britain by the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Antonio Guterres.

text:
Originally an innovation for television coverage of cricket, Hawk-Eye has become a trusted tool for officials in cricket, tennis and now football.

It's an easy game to officiate at the amateur level, football. In a fast-paced, physical and competitive game, however, it's an incredibly difficult and subjective task for human referees.

But with the use of new technology such as Hawk-Eye, the game is becoming more precise and the quality of refereeing in football has never been better.

We look at the benefits of the new system in detail.

Hawk-Eye uses a series of HD cameras mounted around the perimeter of a ground to record data via a ball tracker device. Data points are captured at each phase of the ball trajectory. This technology is capable of tracking the movement of the ball with unmatched precision, within a few centimetres.

text:
The Stop Online Piracy Act (Sopa) aims to slash the amount of pirated content on the internet.
But signatories to an open letter, including the Open Rights Group and the British Computer Society, say the bill is overly restrictive and will undermine internet freedom.
The UK government supports the bill. It is due to be discussed in Congress this week.
Sopa is a proposed law aimed at shutting down sites that facilitate or engage in copyright infringement.

## How does it work?

A website that can be accused of copyright infringement would be taken offline if a copyright holder requests a court order.
The law also allows the US attorney general to take action against overseas websites that allegedly host or facilitate copyright infringement.

## What's the problem?

It is feared that the bill would give the US government and copyright holders too much power over the internet.

A website that can be accused of copyright infringement would be taken offline if a copyright holder requests a court order. The law also allows the US attorney general to take action against overseas websites that allegedly host or facilitate copyright infringement.

text:
The plan would see a giant man-made lagoon generating power to run 120,000 homes for 120 years.
Talks will focus on the amount of subsidy the scheme will get from a guaranteed price for its power.
In December, Energy Secretary Ed Davey announced "in-depth discussions" on the project had started.
Following confirmation on Wednesday that commercial negotiations had begun, Mr Davey said: "Tidal lagoons could provide 8% of our electricity needs, replacing foreign fossil fuels with clean, reliable home-grown electricity and creating fantastic economic opportunities."
His department said the negotiations would establish whether a guaranteed price for power generated by the lagoon would be "affordable and value for money", adding that the project was still subject to a planning decision.

text:
The protesters, who have been trying to oust the government for six months, are moving their camp close to parliament and say they will not leave until their demands are met.

The opposition alliance, known as the Jasmine revolution, has issued a list of seven demands to the government including: reducing the power of the Prime Minister; limiting MP’s terms to two; cutting the number of seats in parliament from 135 to 100; banning party whips and banning the use of slates in voting.

Earlier this month, opposition groups staged a demonstration in the Jordanian capital. The protest was reportedly peaceful and there were no reports of injuries.

The demonstration was the first major protest since Amman imposed new security measures in January 2012. Since then, security forces have raided the country’s largest mosque and arrested activists, sparking outrage among political groups.

text:
The Tamar class lifeboat - John D Spicer - began its journey to north Wales from the RNLI's headquarters in Poole, Dorset on the morning of Thursday 18 July.

On the morning of Friday 19 July it arrived at her new home in Holyhead after making the crossing from Holyhead Marina.

The John D Spicer will be stationed at Holyhead Lifeboat Station, taking up the all-weather lifeboat role on Saturday 20 July following her official handover.

Roger Couch, Lifeboat Operations Manager at Holyhead Lifeboat Station, said, "We're so excited to be welcoming this new lifeboat. She is absolutely fantastic and I know our crew and the people of Holyhead can't wait for her to arrive so she can be called into service for the first time.

"The whole station has a massive amount of work to do in the meantime

Mils Muliaina, 34, who plays for the Connacht province in Ireland, was arrested following a match in Gloucester on December 21.

Another man was arrested, but was later released without charge.

It's believed they were questioned about an incident in which a woman was allegedly attacked in the street in Gloucester earlier in December. The woman suffered minor injuries.

Mr Muliaina was initially held on suspicion of rape.

Gloucester police have now revealed details of his arrest after a freedom of information request was lodged with the force by the UK Telegraph.

text:
But the rest of Europe has been caught short too.
There's been a cacophony of contradictory political statements across the EU since Friday morning.
There have been demands the UK must give immediate official notice to the EU that it is leaving; except it doesn't. There have been alarm bells that the EU is disintegrating, set off by determined insistences that the bloc is more united than ever.
Now that the dust is settling, a bit, German Chancellor Angela Merkel is attempting to take control, as she tends to in most things EU.
Her priorities: to get Britain out smoothly, as soon as is practical (ensuring German trade interests, of course) and also to safeguard the future of the EU.
For her, Brexit now is all about damage limitation.
Monday's meeting in Berlin with the leaders of France and Italy is as much about image as content.
It's a signal and a
paraphrased_text: german Chancellor Angela Merkel is attempting to take control. she wants to get Britain out smoothly, as soon as is practical and to safeguard the future of the EU. but it's also a signal and a warning that the bloc is disintegrating.

text:
Domestic abuse and sex offences now make up 18.6% of CPS cases, with prosecutions and convictions at record highs.

The CPS says that, in the last 12 months, it has brought more prosecutions and secured more convictions for the crimes than ever before.

In 2017-18 it dealt with 33,241 prosecutions for domestic abuse and 14,427 for sexual offences. It secured 76% of domestic abuse prosecutions and 73% of sex offence prosecutions as convictions.

CPS figures also show:

- In the last year, a domestic abuse conviction has been secured on average every 30 minutes

- The number of prosecutions and convictions for rape and child sex offences has

Charlotte Johnson and Aniela Jurecka drugged horses and ponies and sold them as suitable for children from farms in Stapleford, near Chesterfield, police said today.

Both admitted causing unnecessary suffering to an animal and possession with intent to supply Class C drugs when they appeared at Derby Crown Court.

Johnson was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment, suspended for two years with a requirement to undertake 180 hours unpaid work and to undergo 25 days of rehabilitation.

She was also banned from keeping horses for 15 years and ordered to pay court costs of £1,800.

Jurecka, 19, was ordered to undertake 300 hours unpaid work and banned from keeping horses for 10 years, and ordered to pay court costs of £1,750.

She will join for three years and conduct around a dozen concerts a year, all over Wales and at the Proms.
The Chinese conductor is the first woman to be appointed to lead one of the BBC's orchestras.
Zhang, who has already conducted in two seasons with the orchestra, said: "They are a fantastic group of musicians who genuinely love making music".
She is a regular conductor in the United States and her native China but is currently living in Milan, where she is conductor with the Orchestra Sinfonica di Milano Giuseppe Verdi.
Zhang, who will also become music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra next year, has been a regular conductor with the London Symphony and Royal Concertgebouw orchestras.

Under Secretary of State for Transport Claire Perry was answering East Anglian MPs' questions on service performance.
Network Rail said suicides had stayed at about 30 a year since 2009 but delays in minutes lost had fallen from 40,000 to an average of 30,000.
Train operator Abellio Greater Anglia has started an initiative with the Samaritans.
The charity is training station staff to deal with people suspected of attempting suicide.
Platform gates and blue lighting, pioneered as a successful deterrent in Japan, are also being introduced.
Ms Perry said: "Suicides are a tragedy for the families involved, and they are an awful tragedy for the drivers and other staff.

Llanbedr Airfield Estates (LAE) said its 2,300m runway can handle larger drones than Aberporth, Ceredigion.

Built in 1938 and used during World War Two, the airfield was used for drone testing by the military before it closed.

A court in the Libyan city of Misrata found Ahmed Ibrahim guilty of undermining national security and plotting to kill government officials and sentenced him to eight years in prison.

It also fined him the equivalent of about £13,000 ($25,000).

Ibrahim, who goes by the nickname “Abu Zein”, is a well-known jihadist commander from Derna in eastern Libya.

He was arrested late last year by the militia of Misrata, Libya’s third city.

Monaghan was the first boxer from the city to win a world title, becoming flyweight champion in 1948.

He claimed three world titles across a 19-year professional career, which also saw him lose to Floyd Patterson in a 1954 fight that saw Monaghan knocked out in the 12th round.

Floyd Patterson said of the fight: “It was the greatest punch I ever received. It was an awful, awful punch. I was on the way up with that punch and I got in the way of a shot I was landing and bam – he hit me with one of the greatest shots I’d ever seen.”

It said owners should have to prove how they will keep their dogs in control of the lead at all times, or they will not receive a license.

The council had received more than 100 complaints about dogs off leads over the last 12 months.
The new conditions also include a £40 charge for the license, increased from £10 to £20, and a ban on dogs with a history of aggression or biting to be off leads in public open spaces.

All of Daventry’s green spaces are covered by public open space orders, which means dogs must be kept on leads at all times.

The ship took around 3,400 tonnes of ammunition from a harbour near the border with Gaza and will deliver the consignment to its final destination in Norway at the end of the month.

His funeral is due to take place on Monday.

More than 200 officers work on the UK's major child abuse investigations including those being examined under Operation Hydrant

## What is Operation Hydrant?

Operation Hydrant is a team of specialist officers from across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, led by the National Police Chiefs' Council
The officers are made up of detectives from different force areas with specific knowledge of child protection and child abuse
It was set up in 2014, and the aim is to coordinate and monitor investigations into historic sexual abuse in the UK
Operation Hydrant currently includes about 233 officers across the UK and about 875 other staff
Those officers are working on over 4,000 investigations into abuse that happened 40 years ago, 30 years ago

text:
Paul Campbell, 37, was arrested in Portadown railway station on Sunday.
His address was given as The Mills, Coalisland.
The charges relate to an IRA grenade attack on Coalisland police station in March 1997.
Two men threw an improvised bomb at the station, but almost immediately an undercover unit of SAS soldiers returned fire.
One of the pair, Gareth Doris, was wounded.
Before the soldiers could detain him, they were surrounded by a crowd of several hundred people.
They fired a number of warning shots before the RUC arrived and used baton rounds to push back the crowd, allowing the SAS men to leave the area.
By this time, the second IRA man had escaped.
He had apparently climbed into the back seat of a car being driven by a local priest, Fr

text:
The decision was part of an "ongoing comprehensive review" of security measures at the White House and its surrounding grounds, the agency said.

The review was prompted in part by a breach in September in which a man with a knife scaled a White House fence and managed to get to the first floor of the building.

The new fence will use high-tensile steel cable and be topped with razor wire, officials said.

"The new fence design has taken into consideration several factors, including the aesthetics of the fence," said the Department of Homeland Security, which is responsible for securing the executive mansion.

"It is expected to have a similar appearance as the current fence."

Work on the fence, which is made from steel tubes and has 3.7 metres of the fence covered in razor wire at the top of the fence, will begin on September 28 and finish in the

text:
The Asian company’s support means the jet-cum-rocket racer now has the financial means to go and break the land speed record

Land Speed Record-seeking company Bloodhound has received a £15.5 million investment in exchange for a majority shareholding, from Chinese energy company Weichai Power.

The deal means that Bloodhound will now have enough financial backing to go ahead with its plans to set a new world Land Speed Record of over 1000 mph.

This investment comes on top of the £2 million received from the UK government last year, which the Bloodhound Team says was matched with a £2 million of private investment.

The investment will allow development of the Bloodhound jet-car to continue, and means that it can go ahead with plans to start running the jet engine on the car. The new 135,000hp EJ20

text:
Nigel Mentzel, 70, collapsed and died at his home in Penylan, Cardiff, in January.
The inquest heard he had tried a synthetic marijuana "legal high" at his home but died from cannabis poisoning.
The coroner recorded a narrative conclusion and warned it was more dangerous than banned drugs.
The inquest heard the retired Cardiff council planner was a leading collector of colourful psychedelic posters inspired by the mind-bending drugs of the sixties and seventies.
He was also interested in mind-altering substances and started using a synthetic drug called "Cherry Bomb", which he bought legally from a shop in the city centre.
Pathologist Dr Sarah Winstanley told the inquest patients who experienced the effects of synthetic cannabinoids reported worse agitation and hallucinations as well as a faster heart rate.
His partner Julie Garner told the inquest she

text:
Images published in a newspaper in the Maldives show several small objects it said had been found on one atoll.
But Malaysian Transport Minister Liow Tiong Lai said it was too soon to say if they were connected to flight MH370.
The Malaysia Airlines plane carrying 239 people veered off its course from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing in March 2014.
The plane is long believed to have crashed into the southern Indian Ocean - though no evidence was initially found despite a massive search operation.
The reports in the Maldives come just days after debris found on the remote French Indian Ocean island of Reunion were confirmed to be from the missing plane.
"We will be dispatching a team to the Maldives to view the debris as well as conduct preliminary verification of the debris," Mr Liow said

He had linked rubbish problems in Rhondda Cynon Taff to immigrants.

text:
Like it was for many who grew up in the town of Port Talbot, the dystopian mesh of pipes, turrets, and stacks belonging to Tata Steel's giant Port Talbot works was a defining feature of our lives. The steelworks dominated the town's skyline, cast a shadow over the local football and cricket club, and loomed behind the housing estates, schools, and local pubs where we spent much of our time.

In recent years the steelworks, once the world's largest integrated steel plant, has been hit by a perfect storm of cheap global steel competition, the rising cost of energy, and a sluggish British construction industry. Today the Port Talbot steelworks are a shadow of their former selves. Much of the plant is closed and the local economy in the region is suffering badly, as my constituents living in the area tell me every day of the week.

But despite the current
paraphrased_text: our lives. It was a defining feature of our lives. It loomed behind the housing estates, schools, and local pubs where we spent much of our time. But in recent years the steelworks have been hit by a perfect storm of cheap global steel competition, the rising cost of energy, and a sluggish British construction industry.

text:
In 1985 a fresh-faced Gascoigne made his league debut for Newcastle United at the age of 17 as a substitute against West Ham United.

Having joined the club at eight he became a first team regular the following year scoring in his fifth consecutive match.

His early potential was immediately realised by his country being called up to the England Under 21 team when he was still just a teenager.

A year later Gascoigne was a regular for the full side making his debut against Turkey in October 1988.

He was named in Bobby Robson’s squad for the World Cup the following year when he played in all three matches.

A year later and Gascoigne was voted Newcastle’s Player of the Year having scored 10 goals.

As a native Hawaiian, he has special interest in the second and as a medic is shocked by the fact that most of those who have so far contributed to the study of human genes are of European descent.
The Human Genome Project, which set out to identify and map all of the genes in a human body was completed in 2003 and since then there has been an explosion in the way medicine has used genetic sequencing to help treat and identify diseases.
"I started to study those things and I noticed some staggering trends. 96% of people who have their genes sequenced are of European ancestry," said Mr Fox.
"That means that the future of medicine, moving towards using genome sequencing as a tool for prediction, prevention and personalisation of disease and treatments is not going to include minority people. You begin to set the scene for social stratification, and the gap in health disparities will widen."

Karen Lamplugh's Facebook post went viral as she tried to find the woman who gave train tickets to the pair, who had been at the Ariana Grande concert.
The post by Ms Lamplugh, from Holytown, was shared more than 4,000 times.
She later posted an update to say it had helped her identify the Good Samaritan as Joanna Forrester.
The post said: "Asking for fb help here to find the kind woman from today as many of you know my daughter Nicola Lamplugh and her best friend Chelsea Aitchison were at the Ariana Grande concert in Manchester arena last night.
"This very kind lady who is from this area Glasgow/Lanarkshire who gave them her tickets to Glasgow central as her husband was driving down to Manchester to pick her and her 2 daughters up.

text:
Donald's unbeaten 44 helped Glamorgan beat Somerset on Friday to seal their place in the quarter-finals.
The 19-year-old, who scored the joint-fastest first-class double-century in his previous outing, hopes the Welsh county can reach the T20 finals day for the first time since 2004.
"We're just trying to carry all this momentum," Donald told BBC Radio Wales.
"We had a couple of bad games but we parked that behind us, learnt from them and we're just on a roll.
"It's difficult tailing off in the last couple of games like we did but we bounced back and that's what a quality team does. Hopefully we can carry it right through."
Glamorgan's win against Somerset followed T20 defeats against Hampshire and Gloucestershire, having lost only one of their previous nine matches in this year's competition.

text:
Passport Office chief executive Paul Pugh said 170,000 passports had been issued in the past week, a slight increase on a normal week.

He said: "We are operating to normal service levels. We have been very careful in the last few weeks to plan for all eventualities.

"We have done this by managing our workloads, making sure we were fully staffed and we did not take on extra temporary staff."

Mr Pugh said he did not expect the Passport Office to run out of passports if Britons were to make last-minute applications in the run-up to next month's deadline.

There were no immediate signs that there was likely to be a backlog of applications after the expiry date, despite warnings from Labour that people may be unable to get passports before they need them.

One Passport Office call centre employee said the agency was receiving normal levels of

text:
It says it is the biggest investment in broadband infrastructure in the UK for more than a decade.
Virgin said the investment would also create 6,000 new jobs of which 1,000 would be apprenticeships.
Virgin Media currently has five million customers.
The company is already in the process of expanding its network to 110,000 homes across east London, Glasgow, Sunderland and Teesside.
Virgin Media said the additional £3bn in broadband investment would be worth £8bn in terms of stimulating UK economic activity.
However, the money will be spent on filling in gaps in its existing network rather than widening the network to rural areas, which critics say has long been neglected by communications companies such as Virgin and BT.
Speaking to the BBC, Virgin chief executive Tom Mockridge said it was BT's job to do more to bridge the so-called "digital divide".

It is thought she was killed by a 16ft (5m) great white shark, ABC (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) has reported.
Her husband David Collyer said she was a "beautiful person" and "loving wife".

text:
The study, reported in Nature Neuroscience, found that the chemical was released at moments of peak enjoyment.
Researchers from McGill University in Montreal and Emory University in Atlanta have discovered that dopamine, the feel-good chemical, surges in the reward areas of the brain in response to the thrill of a close shave.

"We found that when participants came close to missing a catch, dopamine was released," said senior author Read Montague, of McGill.
"This is the first time this has been measured in the human brain."

In the new research, 14 volunteers were placed into a brain scanner and told to catch an object as it appeared on a screen.
At random, a cue would appear and the person's hand, hidden from the screen, would twitch.
If they caught the object before it touched the screen they earned money.
If not, the object passed through to

"This is the first time this has been measured in the human brain," said senior author Read Montague, of McGill. "This is the first time this has been measured in the human brain."

text:
Chatbots or virtual assistants are creeping into all aspects of our lives - from boxes in the home, such as Amazon's Alexa, which can tell you your bank balance, to bots that pop up on messaging services or websites to help with your mortgage or order you a pizza.
Add to that weather bots, news bots, shopping bots, personal finance bots and scheduling bots, and it becomes clear why chatbots are rapidly becoming the "poster child of AI".

Campaigners have worked for 25 years to get the Grade II listed walled garden on the Penllergare Estate repaired and reopened to visitors.
Now, Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) has earmarked money to help turn it into an "escape from hectic city life".
HLF said it could become "a significant tourist destination".
Terry Jones of the Penllergare Trust said the group was "really excited" the garden would be saved from "dereliction and inappropriate development".
Work will include the refurbishment of the garden's orchid house, which is currently in a state of serious disrepair.
The funding follows £2.3m of lottery money already provided to restore Penllergare Valley Woods.

text:
The twins had their DNA tested after their family noticed they looked different, said local reports.
The occurrence, known as heteropaternal superfecundation, is rare.
But the results confirmed that their mother had conceived the boys with two different men, said reports.
The boys’ mother had separated from one partner when she conceived the twins. She then started seeing another man who gave her a positive pregnancy test shortly after.
The woman took a second test, which returned negative.
The twins were born one week apart, according to Newsflare.
“It was so strange,” said a family member, who asked not to be named.
“They are identical, except that one has green eyes and one has blue eyes.”
Identical twins occur when a single fertilized egg, called a zygote, splits and forms two embryos.

Michael Lane, 27, of Portslade, East Sussex, said he was scared and panicked about being blamed for killing Shana Grice.
Miss Grice, 19, was found dead in her bedroom in Portslade last August.
During seven police interviews Mr Lane, who denies murder, continuously changed his story, Lewes Crown Court heard.
Jurors were told he altered his account of where he had been and what he was doing that morning before admitting he had gone to her house and discovered her body.
When asked why he thought it better to lie, Mr Lane said some of his behaviour in the months preceding her death "didn't look good".

text:
Prof John Beetlestone founded the science discovery centre in Cardiff in 1985.
It announced on Friday he had died aged 79, after a long illness.
Born in London, he studied at Cambridge and went on to become a research fellow, then professor of biochemistry.
But he became frustrated by the lack of research into how science works as an educator rather than as a theorist.
“He took a real stand and was very brave to say, ‘Let’s go and teach people how to do science for themselves rather than have to wait for someone to tell them’, says his daughter, Dr Susan Beetlestone, a former GP who is now research and evaluation director at the centre.

The British Heart Foundation (BHF) said more than 30,000 people in Wales have been diagnosed.
Nearly a third of patients admitted to hospital could die within 12 months, the BHF said.
Heart failure is most commonly caused by a heart attack which causes irreparable damage, and the charity said more research is urgently needed.
More than 500,000 people have been diagnosed with heart failure across the UK - and 75,000 were under 65, the BHF said. The only hope for some with severe heart failure is a transplant.

Australia's most senior Catholic is presenting evidence from Rome via video link over several days to an Australian Royal Commission into child sex abuse.
On Tuesday, Cardinal George Pell gave a 75 minute evidence on camera to the Royal Commission from a Vatican residence.
The Archbishop of Sydney testified that while he was in charge of child abuse at the Vatican he had "failed to create a culture of reporting".
The Royal Commission is trying to establish whether the Catholic Church could have done more to stop abuse at the hands of priests in Australia.
Cardinal Pell became Pope Francis's chief financial officer in 2014. In a written submission earlier, he said the Vatican bank "is not the place to look for evidence" of the church's handling of sexual abuse cases.
He also denied trying to keep files on priests under investigation in Australia from reaching authorities.

Charlotte Johnson and Aniela Jurecka drugged horses and ponies and sold them as suitable for children from farms in Staplehurst and Marden, in Kent.
The pair recommended vet David Smith, 66, to buyers, who would then give the animals a clean bill of health.
All three are due to be sentenced at Maidstone Crown Court on 11 July.
Jurecka, 28, of Prospect Place, Collier Street, in Tonbridge, Johnson, 28, of Tollgate Way, Sandling, and Smith, of The Street, Finglesham, Deal, were found guilty of conspiracy to commit fraud by false representation following a 14-week trial.

Lady Charlotte Peel was 10 years old when she joined family mourners on the train during the state funeral in 1965.
The refurbished train is on show at the National Railway Museum in York to mark the 50th anniversary of the funeral.
Lady Peel said the train had brought back memories that the "whole day was enveloped in sadness for us".
She said her family were proud of her grandfather and "how he gave strength to people in the war".
Winston Churchill was appointed prime minister in 1940 during World War Two.
Lady Peel recalled the day of her trip on the train in 1965 as "grey and cold" and described a "nation's outpouring of grief" on the death of her grandfather.

Economy Minister Edwina Hart said there was a "significant question around the viability" of the Circuit of Wales project which could take up to 7 years to complete and was heavily dependent on EU finance.

Ms Hart told BBC Wales Today the project would require between £400m and £500m in private money to begin.

The government has already offered £11m and the Welsh Assembly has agreed in principle to invest £5m a year for four years.

Ms Hart said she hoped to receive a firm investment announcement by the end of 2015.

On 5 March 1966 a coffin with the words "S&D died today" was loaded on to the very last train from Euston to leave during the Beeching cuts. The station's then-owner Richard Beeching had declared a quarter of the network unnecessary and had ordered the closure of over 2,000 stations. The following month all the tracks were taken up, the buildings demolished and the station site became a car park.

The watchdog NICE says although there is limited evidence, transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) may help ease symptoms in some patients.
It says that the procedure is still relatively new and that more data is needed about its long-term safety and efficacy.
But it may be useful for patients for whom other treatments have failed.
Migraine is common - it affects about one in four women and one in 12 men in the UK.
There are several types - with and without aura and with or without headache - and several treatment options, including common painkillers, such as paracetamol.
Although there is no cure for migraine, it is often possible to prevent or lessen the severity of attacks.

text:
In 2010-2011, 143 days were lost at Plymouth Hospitals NHS Trust due to staff being assaulted, and 84.8% of hospital staff were victims of violence or threats.

Now, for the first time, the trust has launched a campaign to say NO to violence.

Hospital trust staff and police officers visited the children’s wards at Derriford Hospital today to talk to staff and children about what violence looks like, and how violence and abuse can be stopped.

The staff visited the wards in bright yellow ‘No to Violence’ t-shirts, while police officers talked about staying safe and reporting incidents to the police.

The children in the wards had a quiz and prizes about the subject, while Plymouth Live was there to quiz them.

The trust has also created a ‘stop violence’ badge

Col Gen Sergei Karakayev said pontoon technology meant nuclear missiles could now be moved to new areas and "overcome practically any kind of obstacles".

"All of this makes it possible to create new strategic nuclear facilities, including in areas that were previously unavailable for strategic nuclear forces," he told Russia's parliament.

In addition, he said, "all modern, land-based and sea-launched strategic systems are able to move and operate practically any time".

He did not explain why this was happening now or if it was linked to the Ukraine war.

## War in Ukraine

Russia's invasion of Ukraine has led to accusations that Moscow plans to use nuclear arms - something the Kremlin denies, saying it is only for defensive reasons.

Russia has sent its Iskander ground-to-ground missile system to Ukraine, where it has been used to strike Ukrainian military

More than 12,000 people signed a petition criticising Debenhams in Commercial Road after a Facebook post by Russell Allen went viral.

The 24-year-old from Southsea launched the petition after seeing a notice that the store wanted to close for just four days, between March 15 and 19, for a "restock."

However, after the outcry and backlash on social media, it has now emerged that the closure will only affect its beauty salon.

A spokeswoman from the company said: "To ensure Debenhams’ staff are fully up to date with the latest product knowledge, the Debenhams Beauty department is closed for two days, Monday 13th March and Tuesday 14th March.

The patent, belonging to a firm called eDekka, related to "methods of storing information" which included the use of labels - but the judge said this could apply to routine activities.
The US patent system allows companies to acquire the rights to inventions and demand money for their use, without making products of their own.
Critics call it "patent trolling".
However, in the case of eDekka against online retailer 3balls.com judge Rodney Gilstrap ruled that "the claimed idea represents routine tasks that could be performed by a human" and was therefore not worth protection by patent law.
The District of East Texas has traditionally been favourable towards patent claimants, in part because of its rules on swift litigation processes, which can put pressure on defendants to settle disputes quickly, according to the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF).

Her third album's long-awaited release on streaming services has also helped it claim a 13th week at number one.
In the singles chart, Drake's continued dominance saw One Dance become the third longest-running number one ever.
Only Bryan Adams and Wet Wet Wet have spent more consecutive weeks in the top spot than the Canadian rapper.
Adams' (Everything I Do) I Do It For You spent 16 consecutive weeks at number one in 1991, while Wet Wet Wet enjoyed a 15-week reign with Love Is All Around in 1994.

The man, who was a passenger in the car, was shot in the head in West Bromwich shortly after 14:30 GMT, West Midlands Police said.
The victim, who was in his 30s, died at the scene in Dartmouth Street and police have opened a murder investigation.
Police said the junction of High Street and Dartmouth Street was cordoned off while forensic inquiries took place.
A post-mortem examination is due to take place.
Det Insp Martin Slevin said: "The investigation is at an early stage, my officers are currently carrying out inquiries at the scene and house to house and CCTV. There will also be extra reassurance patrols in the local area."
He appealed for witnesses to come forward.

Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said it would include fruit, vegetables, meat, fish, milk and dairy imports.
Australia is Russia’s fourth-biggest agricultural supplier by revenue.

Russia has not imported fruit from Australia since the ban in 2010, but Australian dairy, beef and pork industries are estimated to be worth $100m-$200m to the country.

But the news is likely to see exports rise as Russia has been keen to boost importation of dairy to help bolster ailing domestic production.

Russian agricultural minister Nikolai Fyodorov said that there was still a ‘lot of work to do’ before the deal would be ratified but that Australia could start exporting dairy products again next year and beef in 2016.

Chairman Gareth Davies has written to each of the Union's 320 member clubs.
"The changes we are making are part of our continued aim to modernise the way in which the game is governed in Wales," he said.
"We have created four new 'sub-boards' which will meet to discuss specific areas of governance, prior to full Board meetings."
Davies added: "All sporting bodies are being scrutinised closely on their governance structures and composition of their management boards, and, partly in response, but mainly as it is the right thing to do, we have recently reviewed our internal structures."
Four new sub-boards have been created to discuss specific aspects of governance prior to full board meetings, with the aim of streamlining the decision-making process in Welsh rugby.

The law invalidated several local anti-discrimination measures that protected gay and transgender people.
It also requires people to use public toilets that correspond to the sex listed on their birth certificates.
The governor has responded by accusing the justice department of "overreach".
His office must confirm by Monday that the law will not be implemented, the department said.

"The right and expectation of privacy in one of the most private areas of our personal lives is now in jeopardy," Mr McCrory said.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, and the leader of the Catholic Church in Ireland, Eamon Martin, were among those attending Sunday's service.

He praised the contribution that Corrymeela had made to Northern Ireland.

Now his photos will be on show at a Birmingham exhibition.

Edinburgh-based Ness operates 10 stores in Scotland and five in England, as well as four concessions.
Administrators from accountancy and business services firm BDO said all the stores would remain open while a buyer was being sought.
Ness employs 105 staff, all of which are being retained for the moment.
BDO business restructuring partner James Stephen said: "Notwithstanding the improving sales trend, with like-for-like sales up 12% over the last 12 months, the company experienced working capital difficulties.
"Nevertheless, Ness is a unique brand and remains a highly-popular shopping destination for its loyal customer base in towns across Scotland and England and we are confident of securing a sale of the company as a going concern."

Not only were the Harambee Starlets, as they are known, up against tough competitors on the field, they also faced opposition off the field - from their compatriots.

The British Hospitality Association (BHA) said that thousands of businesses are facing having to drastically reduce their dependence on EU workers.
Staff shortages are being seen across Britain’s hospitality businesses, despite the government’s decision last month to double the number of visas available under the Tier 2 visa route in a last-ditch effort to plug the hole.
“The situation is becoming increasingly critical; our industry has been short staffed for a long time,” said Julie Hughes, chief executive of the BHA, who has been warning of a critical staffing crisis facing the hospitality industry. “What this new data demonstrates is the scale of the crisis for the first time, and we would urge the Home Secretary to consider the full scale of the impact. Sir Jon told the BBC he wanted to see how inflation pressures evolved before deciding to raise interest rates from a record low 0.25%.
He also wanted to watch and see if improvements in business investment and exports could compensate for a consumer slowdown.
At its last rate rise meetings, three out of eight members of the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) surprisingly voted to raise interest rates, jolting financial markets.
The 5-3 vote by the Bank's policymakers was the closest for a rate rise since 2007, and came with inflation close to a four-year high of 2.9%.
Inflation is now well above the Bank's target rate of 2%.

Officials said the six men who had stormed the transport ministry facility and taken several hostages were killed.
Two policemen who had been guarding the building also died, they added. But one security source put the toll at 18.
No group has claimed responsibility, though Sunni militants linked to al-Qaeda have mounted similar attacks.
Violence has surged across Iraq in the past year, reaching levels not seen since the height of the sectarian insurgency in 2007.
The United Nations says 7,818 civilians and 1,050 members of the security forces died in 2013. More than 900 people are reported to have been killed since the start of the year.

A second man is said to have been distracting staff.

CCTV footage shows the group leaving the shop with the charity shop worker's mobile phone stuffed down the child's trousers and ladies' clothing which had not been paid for.
For more on this story and others in London

text:
Forget the mental image you might have from seaside holidays of an azure sea whose rippling waves beckon you in for a cooling dip.
I joined a migrant rescue mission out on the Mediterranean last week in the Aquarius, a search-and-rescue vessel nearly 77m long.
And it shuddered and groaned from bow to stern as it thrashed through the 3.5m swells that suddenly whip up in these treacherous waters.
So pity the plight of thousands of migrants setting out in a flimsy inflatable, most of whom are unable to swim and are weak from standing up for 10 hours on their perilous voyages.
Deaths at sea have risen ninefold since October 2014, according to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) charity.
And yet in the first three months of this year, 18,000 migrants attempted the crossing from Libya - 8,000 more than in the same period last year.
The untold story of Europe's drowned migrants
Migration to Europe explained in seven

In the first three months of this year, 18,000 migrants attempted the crossing from Libya - 8,000 more than in the same period last year. In the first three months of this year, 18,000 migrants attempted the crossing from Libya - 8,000 more than in the same period last year.

Police say a 15-year-old boy, who was initially arrested as part of a murder investigation, has since been released.

Officers also confirmed that no other arrests have been made but the search for the perpetrators continues.

An area near a busy main road on the outskirts of the city has been sealed off for forensic examination following the "serious" incident.

text:
Colonies of several hundred ants show consistent differences in the way they behave, just like individual people do.
Certain behaviours go together - for example, a colony that explores more widely for food also tends to respond more aggressively to an intruder.
Such a colony has a more "risk-taking" personality and this was more common in the north, where the climate is colder.
"I'm really interested in why personalities exist," said Sarah Bengston, a PhD student at the University of Arizona who led the research. Her study is published in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B.
Ms Bengston explained that although we know most animals have personalities, we do not yet understand why these evolved.
"Sometimes individuals behave differently from one another, and when they do that repeatedly through time, we say that they have a personality."
As such, there is nothing to stop a colony of
paraphrased_text: a colony that explores more widely for food also tends to respond more aggressively to an intruder. Such a colony has a more "risk-taking" personality and this was more common in the north, where the climate is colder. "I'm really interested in why personalities exist," said Sarah Bengston, a PhD student at the University of Arizona who led the research.

text:
University of California researchers found tumour cells that stuck less to surrounding cells are more likely to migrate and invade other tissue.
They hope this could lead to new treatments and ways to detect cancer more effectively.

As part of the study, published in the journal PLOS One, the researchers used biochemistry, biophysics and computer modelling to learn more about how tumour cells travel around the body.

They focused on epithelial ovarian cancer, the most lethal form of the disease.

The scientists said they hope the work will eventually lead to improved treatment and ways to detect ovarian cancer earlier in life, when chances of cure are best.

Ovarian cancer has an exceptionally high mortality rate.

More than half of all new cases of the disease are diagnosed at an advanced stage, and five-year survival rates are below 45% for many women.

The
paraphrased_text: PLOS One, the ovarian cancer, the most lethal form of the disease. The researchers focused on epithelial ovarian cancer, the most lethal form of the disease. Ovarian cancer has an exceptionally high mortality rate.

The family of five were travelling along the A39 near Dijon in eastern France at about 07:00 local time on Thursday.

Their car was struck by a lorry, which was forced on to the motorway after crashing into a van in a roundabout in the nearby village of Bételaine.

The victims, from Bretagne and named locally as the Baudoin family, were declared dead at the scene by medical teams who arrived shortly after the accident.

The driver of the lorry was treated for minor injuries at the scene, and a police investigation into the crash has been opened.

It is the latest tragedy to hit the A39, a major north-south route through Burgundy.

The motorway has been the scene of a series of fatal accidents involving foreign lorry drivers in recent years.

Prof Mike Richards has contacted health watchdog Monitor over his concerns.
A Care Quality Commission (CQC) inspection between 30 June and 2 July found services were "only just" safe.
The Mid Staffordshire Foundation Trust has already said about 60 beds will be cut - partly due to staffing.
Prof Richards's letter, which was also sent to the Trust Development Authority and the Trust Special Administrator, said senior managers were having to spend "inordinate amounts of time" ensuring individual nursing shifts were adequately filled.
"To date, they have been able to do this. But I would emphasise the word just," he said.
The trust, which has been in administration since April 2013, is due to be dissolved in November with some services being moved to neighbouring hospitals.

Airbus also said the cabin had been optimised to allow up to 80 extra seats "with no compromise on comfort".
The move has been seen as a way of boosting flagging sales of the A380.
There has been a dearth of orders for the plane as more airlines opt for smaller twin-engine jets, which cost less to fly and maintain.
The European plane maker said the new version would burn up to 4% less fuel thanks to its new winglets, which are designed to reduce drag.

They argue that the GM trees are desperately needed to deal with an upsurge in forest diseases and pests.
What they term "misguided" concerns about genetic engineering have slowed progress to a crawl.
But environmental campaigners say the technology is risky and the long-term safety unproven.
Genetically modified trees were developed in the 1980s amid hopes that the technology could tackle persistent problems such as pest infestations.
It was also hoped that new fast-growing strains would be developed that would be attractive for commercial companies.
Earlier this year a rapidly growing variety of eucalyptus was approved for use in Brazil  - these trees can sprout five metres per year and they produce 20% more wood than conventional varieties.
But approval to grow only came after almost 10 years of field trials.

text:
On 28 March, 1979, a combination of mechanical failure and human error led to a partial meltdown at the nuclear plant near the town of Three Mile Island, Pennsylvania, in the United States. It is considered the worst nuclear accident in U.S. history. The disaster had many causes. Plant operator David Lochner entered a faulty command to cool the plant and then tried to make up for the error, which caused the shutdown of the two reactors. It was not clear at the time that his actions had been the direct cause of the disaster. A chain of failures and errors led to confusion and, ultimately, the disaster.

This is often the case in business.

Labour's James Kelly will begin work on a Member's Bill to repeal the Offensive Behaviour at Football and Threatening Communications Act.
The Glasgow MSP said it was time to axe the "hated" law now that the SNP no longer had a majority at Holyrood.
First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said it was a "strange priority" for opposition parties but she would discuss concerns.
She said: "I think it's a strange priority for opposition parties to almost have as their first objective to get rid of legislation which is about tackling sectarianism.
"That's not something which I think should be the priority of the opposition parties.

They were later able to identify them as episodes of Zoo Quest – although the film was badly fading, and was in black and white, making it difficult for the BBC to edit it for television.

The Solar Impulse craft is a day into what was expected to be a 130-hour journey from China to Hawaii.
However, meteorologists say the forecast is worsening.
They have asked the pilot to stay in a holding pattern while they decide whether he should continue or turn back towards land.
They will reassess the situation at a team briefing at 08:00 GMT Monday.
This is the seventh leg in an attempt to circumnavigate the globe using just the energy of the Sun.
The experimental craft, which is covered in 17,000 solar cells, took off from Abu Dhabi in March.

The team has already had to wait for a month in Nanjing for the right weather conditions to take off.

text:
The use of sound as a weapon is not new, but what about unheard sound attacks?
If you've ever heeded a "ringer", that's a loud ringing in your ears caused by a
sudden loud noise, well you know it's hard enough to hear with that. What if you didn't
even hear the source of the sound? And that sound was not the loud ring in your ears,
but something else that could damage your hearing without you ever hearing it?

That's the question that we should ask when looking at the history of sonic weapons.
Weaponized sound has been used for many years as a means of disrupting, harassing or
causing harm to someone without any visual trace of the perpetrator.

In the military world, sonic weapons are known as LRADS and are being deployed in
combat zones where a single sound source

Douglas Costa scored for Brazil after 39 seconds before Renato Augusto doubled their lead on 26 minutes.
Edinson Cavani pulled one back before Suarez struck just after half-time.
Suarez, who captained the side at the Itaipava Arena Pernambuco, bit Italian defender Giorgio Chiellini during Uruguay's final group match of the World Cup on 24 June 2014.
He was given a nine-game ban from competitive internationals, as well as a four-month ban from all football-related activity.
The former Liverpool forward missed Uruguay's subsequent World Cup defeat by Colombia, the entire 2015 Copa America and four games of qualifying for the 2018 World Cup.

text:
William Smith's 1815 depiction of the geology of England, Wales and part of Scotland is a seminal piece of cartography and natural history. Smith's map is the first geological map of any kind.

The map, and the accompanying book, were published in 1815, and show in extraordinary detail how the counties of England, Wales and Scotland (the first two only as far as the Tweed) were constructed. The map is a classic example of how human geography, geology, physical geography and land use can be combined in a single representation to help us understand how the landscape is put together.

There is an excellent overview of the map here, including an extensive bibliography of literature on it.

And thanks to Chris Smith's blog post, there are some fascinating examples of the map's use in cartography.
paraphrased_text: William Smith's 1815 map of England, Wales and Scotland is a seminal piece of cartography and natural history. Smith's map is the first geological map of any kind.

Dr Lesley Wilkie will examine how many women have suffered complications as a result of receiving implants to treat incontinence.
Dr Wilkie will start work next month and is due to report early next year.
All health boards have been asked to suspend the use of implants while the review is underway.
Mr Neil announced the review during an appearance before MSPs on 17 June.

Transvaginal mesh implants are usually used to treat a prolapsed bladder and relieve incontinence, often as a result of childbirth.

Whatever bridges have been or are being built, Brussels' day of terror threatens to blow them all away. And that, to be sure, is exactly what the attackers in Zaventem airport and the Brussels subway meant to do.
As the police sirens wailed around my office all morning, I was overwhelmed, rendered speechless.
That was not the case for everyone. Was it just the temptation to vent anger, or a pent-up polarisation, that filled Twitter and Facebook with such noxious opinion? Sweeping generalisations, calls for exclusion, purging, a police state.
Like whiplash after a collision, first you hit the steering wheel, then you get thrown back - twice broken.

Why was Brussels attacked?

It's the sixth consecutive day of declines and the longest losing streak since early May.

Earlier, China's central bank said Monday it would lower its benchmark lending rate in a surprise move to try to spur economic growth and support slumping markets.

The camp, where teenage diarist Anne Frank was among thousands to die, was liberated by British soldiers in 1945, ending the suffering.

The last surviving British officer to liberate the camp, John “Jack” Chambers, has died at the age of 94, his family said.

Chambers was involved in the liberation of several other camps, including Bergen-Belsen in northern Germany, where more than 13,000 died in the months before the camp was liberated in April 1945, according to the BBC.

In the case of Bergen-Belsen, however, the Allies did not reach the camp until a few days after April 15, so the number of dead may have been significantly higher.

“He saw sights which nobody should have to see in this world,” Chambers’ daughter Judy said in a statement.

It is part of new measures to provide basic protection for some seven million domestic workers long excluded from Brazil's stringent labour laws.
Employment lawyer Marcelo de Oliveira said the 716,000 domestic workers who registered will now have the same rights to holiday and time off as the rest of Brazil's workforce.

"It's a great victory for the domestic workers' movement in Brazil," he told AFP.

In Brazil, household workers like maids and gardeners are still often treated as de facto slaves and are considered less important than agricultural or factory workers.

Many maids work long hours every day in hot and humid conditions, sometimes with no day off work at all.

The National Register of Domestic Workers, or Renad, is a national database intended to provide better coverage for the workers, currently estimated to number seven million.

The report also calls for the British-Irish language act, which protects the Irish language, to be strengthened.

text:
The very future of the African elephant, the largest land animal on Earth, could be at risk.
Last year saw the highest number of large seizures of illegal ivory for more than two decades.
From Kenya to Zambia, African law-enforcement and conservation authorities are facing a continuing battle with the poachers.
And it is in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where governance is at its weakest, that the elephant population is being hit hardest, with thousands of elephants killed each year.
Conservationists have recorded steep declines in population and fear fewer than 20,000 of the region's forest elephants remain in the Congo basin.
Panorama: Ivory Wars - Out Of Africa, is broadcast on BBC One, Thursday 12 April at 21:00 BST
Or catch up later via iPlayer

Trainer Best was last month found guilty of ordering conditional jockey Paul John to stop two horses from running on their merits.
But the BHA used solicitor Matthew Lohn on the disciplinary panel.
Lohn was being paid to advise on other matters, and the BHA will not oppose an appeal on "perceptions of fairness".

text:
In order to fulfil his dream of walking on the Moon, 47-year-old Shepard had to fend off criticism for his age, even from US Congress. AFP

Veteran US astronaut Alan Shepard, who in 1961 became the first American in space and then stunned the world with a Moon walk, has died at age 74, US media reported Friday.

Shepard was the astronaut who walked on the Moon — and even took his iron nine-iron out there to swing, according to legend — and made history during the tumultuous 1960s, as his country and the world hurtled toward the frontiers of space.

The veteran astronaut, who died in a hospital in Pebble Beach, near Monterey in California on June 28, was suffering from leukemia, the reports said.

Three men were hurt in the "targeted attack" in Cardowan, near Glasgow, when vehicles were set alight and a village street left resembling a "war zone".
Detectives now believe an incident an hour earlier, in which men in two other vehicles tried to block in a Ford Transit van, could be connected.
The van was later stolen and used in Sunday's Cardowan attack.
Det Insp David Reilly said: "What we know now is that around 12:30 on Sunday 5 June 2016, a 46-year-old man was driving his silver Transit van on Cumbernauld Road, Riddrie, when two cars, a blue BMW X6 4x4 and a white saloon car, each with three male occupants, tried to block him in.

Sir Ivan stepped down from his ambassador role on Tuesday, criticising "muddled thinking" within government about Brexit.
The government said he had quit early so a successor could be in place before negotiations start.

The woman's body was found in August 1974 on a heath at Cockley Cley near Swaffham in Norfolk.
Rope and a plastic found at the scene suggested connections with Dundee.
Twelve students in Dundee trawled through local newspaper archives, which police said resulted in "a couple" of new lines of inquiry.
The woman was found wearing a 1969 Marks & Spencer pink nightdress, while post-mortem examinations concluded she was aged 23-35, had given birth and was from central Europe.
The body was wrapped in a plastic cover bearing the National Cash Registers (NCR) logo which links it to Dundee, where the computer firm employed hundreds of people in the 1970s.
Jute rope, used to tie up the plastic, was also believed to have been manufactured in Dundee.

Ms Cooper gained 18,832 votes, increasing her majority from 3,244 to 6,373.

It is the third time Ms Cooper has been re-elected and secured her largest majority to date, with 55.8% of the vote.

In a tweet, Ms Cooper congratulated the other women who had won seats for the Liberal Democrats in Scotland, and all of those who were elected yesterday.

Ms Cooper told The Press and Journal in July last year: “I can’t wait for the election and I can’t wait to get back to work in parliament to champion the people of the North East.

“I have the best job in the world.

“I am the voice of the constituency of the North East of Scotland and that’s what I want to continue to be for many, many more years to come.”

GP Alisdair MacNair said he was aware of a number of medical groups using WhatsApp to discuss patients.
Use of internet-based messaging apps to send patient information is banned under current NHS guidelines.
NHS England told the BBC that it had no comment on the matter.
Dr MacNair said: "I have also seen chat on Facebook groups that sails pretty close to the wind in terms of discussing medical information.

The legislation will now be put to a vote in the Senate next week, where its prospects are unclear.
The 875-page bill would provide $740 billion over 10 years to address health insurance. The House's health overhaul, as of Wednesday, was 1,990 pages.

Democrats plan to use what they call a "deem and pass" strategy that will allow them to vote on a final, sweeping health care bill without ever having to vote on the House bill.

Now a US team has developed a hydrogel that attaches to ulcers and slowly releases a drug to help treat them.
The early findings are reported in the journal Science Translational Medicine.

It causes inflammation and ulceration of the inner lining of the rectum and colon.

Solicitor John Owen, 79, stole the money from John Williams after being made executor of his will.
He admitted 15 frauds at Caernarfon crown court in Wales, taking place between July 1996 and June 1998.

Judge Huw Edwards told him he was committing fraud even though Mr Williams was dead and had left him some money in his will.

But he added that when a family is grieving, the person looking after the estate “shouldn’t be taking them for a ride”.

The judge described the frauds as a “travesty” and “a deliberate, calculated and despicable betrayal” of a vulnerable 77-year-old.
