text:
The Volkswagen scandal underlined the inadequacy of standard lab tests which do not reflect the exhausts produced when driving in the real world. Here's what to look for when buying a new or used car

You may have heard the term Real Driving Emissions (RDE) and wondered what it meant. It’s just a name for a standard for measuring vehicle emissions which takes into account the air pollution and carbon dioxide created when driving in the real world, not just when performing tests in laboratories.

## What's wrong with current emissions tests?

The ‘laboratory’ tests are performed using the New European Driving Cycle (NEDC) standard. This involves the car being driven around a course and, in the case of diesels, having the DPF (diesel particulate filter) warmed to get it to perform at its most efficient. The result is low carbon dioxide

text:
The research was carried out for the Assembly's enterprise committee.
The committee asked Open University economist Leslie Budd to assess the potential impacts of a British exit from the European Union, so-called the 'Brexit'.
Dr Budd said economic output in Northern Ireland could be 3% lower as a result.
The most recent figures suggests the output of the Northern Ireland economy is £33bn a year.
A 3% fall would knock almost £1bn off that.
Dr Budd cautioned that estimating the economic consequences of 'Brexit' was complex and that making an assessment at a Northern Ireland level was even more challenging.
However, he said that transaction costs for cross border trade could "rise significantly" and "act as a disincentive" to economic co-operation.
He added that Northern Ireland would also become a less attractive location for emerging market companies which are looking for an entry route to EU markets.
Taken together, those two factors would undermine the logic of "harmonising corporation tax"

Dr Budd said that economic output in Northern Ireland could be 3% lower as a result.

The move by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) follows allegations that the company operates a 'pyramid scheme' - making money from recruiting new distributors, rather than sales.
Herbalife has denied these allegations and said it would "cooperate fully" with the FTC inquiry.
Its shares fell by as much as 16%.
But they recovered slightly and ended the day down by 7%.
"Herbalife welcomes the inquiry given the tremendous amount of misinformation in the marketplace," the company said in a statement.
"We are confident that Herbalife is in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations."
The investigation comes just a day after prominent hedge fund manager, William Ackman, renewed his attack on the firm.

SNP MSP Angus MacDonald tabled a motion calling for action to "reduce pesticides that harm pollinators".
The motion was agreed by the Scottish Parliament on Thursday and was supported by the Scottish Conservatives and Labour.

Mr MacDonald said: "There was a very positive response in the chamber and members agreed to the motion.

"My constituents were very much aware of the issue."

The motion also calls for "the continued provision of support" to help growers adopt greener approaches to cropping.

Mr MacDonald said: "This is the first time we've been able to pass an official, parliamentary motion on this matter and I hope to be able to put similar motions to the chamber in the future."

## 'Diversity of pollinators'

Musicians at a demonstration on Thursday said the proposals were too strict.

The rules, which state music should not be audible from more than 50m (164 ft) away, are not legally enforceable, the council said.
However, if the authority obtains an order under anti-social behaviour legislation introduced last year, fines of £100 could be issued to those deemed to be breaking the code.

Still in are Campbeltown, Glasgow Prestwick, and Stornoway in Scotland; Newquay in England and Llanbedr in Wales. RAF Leuchars is confirmed as a potential temporary facility.
Ministers are keen to see the spaceport established by 2018.
To make that happen, they will also have to put in place the necessary regulatory and licensing arrangements.

text:
The former Labour MP was chosen over Wigan Council leader Peter Smith by a panel representing the area's councils.
Mr Lloyd will lead a regional Labour group that aims to work with the area's six local authorities and the 21 MPs within it.
He has served on the Wigan council since 1991 and also chairs the North West Regional Development Agency.
Mr Lloyd said: "The Greater Manchester region is a key part of the national picture.
"I see this as a wonderful opportunity and am delighted to have been given the chance of playing my part in helping shape the future of this great region."
He will be taking over from Labour MP Gerald Kaufman, who has held the position since it was created in 1989.
Mr Smith paid tribute to his leadership: "I would like to thank Gerald for all that he has done to help our region and wish him well in his continuing

text:
Marie Farrell made the claims in a case where former journalist Ian Bailey is suing the Irish state for wrongful arrest.
Mr Bailey was detained in France for three weeks in 2012 over the murder of Sophie Toscan du Plantier in 1996.
A French court later found that he was being sought in Ireland to answer criminal charges.
But the court was unaware that the last warrant for Mr Bailey's arrest had expired in 2008.
In an affidavit Ms Farrell said: "There is a high level of professionalism and co-operation between both countries.
"However, if one member state makes an error, that error can have very serious and sometimes fatal consequences."
Mr Bailey also alleged that former Irish taoiseach Bertie Ahern, who is now deceased, "misrepresented" his case to former French president Nicol

text:
The photograph of Ajit Atwal, who used to represent the Liberal Democrats on Derby City Council, was taken on holiday in India last year.
In April, Mr Atwal apologised but was still suspended as a magistrate.
The Judicial Conduct Investigations Office said his behaviour "amounted to serious misconduct".
Labour colleagues in Derby made calls for Mr Atwal to resign as a councillor when the photo appeared in a national newspaper in March.
Later, he apologised if he had "caused anyone any alarm or distress" but refused to resign as a magistrate.
Mr Atwal lost his other role as a councillor in May's local elections.

text:
South Northamptonshire Council announced nine vacant posts, including a head of service, will not be filled and another four jobs will go.
The council said the aim to minimise cuts to frontline services and officers would focus on improving the efficiency of the local authority.
It said it hoped to avoid charge increases, but could not rule them out.
Ian McCord, portfolio holder for resources at the council, said: "Further cost reductions will be required.
"When reductions in central government grants and other external factors become clearer, we will announce what further steps need to be taken.
"We will continue to provide the services that our residents need in a cost effective way, and to look at other innovative ways to tackle this issue.
"The council has an estimated five-year deficit in its revenue budget of nearly £10m as a result of the recession.
"This is due to

text:
That is what a senior and respected medical scientist, a man who would be seen as a world authority on such matters, said to me.

The reason it is so important is not because there are 2600 people in Australia in this situation. The reality is the number of people is a very tiny percentage of the total population of Australia. The significance of the finding lies in that it tells us that the “lockdown”, enforced with brutal police enforcement, that was inflicted on millions of Australians at great social and economic cost has no basis in scientific reality.

If a very small number of people are not sick with COVID and are not likely to become sick the only reason to forcibly lockdown Australia for weeks, and months, is ideological. That was a decision made by Bill Shorten’s former staffer, who is in charge of COVID in Australia.

In short, it is yet another reason why Daniel Andrews must

text:
Mr Wells resigned on Monday saying he wanted to help his wife Grace "during her fight for life".
Police are investigating the incident, and a witness said: "They were both going through a red light. I think it was because the traffic was so slow, but he couldn't stop.
"They hit a big Audi and the impact just sent that car flying and flipped it around, like a rag doll. The car ended up on its roof in the middle of the intersection. I never saw a wreck like that, not even in a Hollywood movie. I couldn't believe it. It was a horrible scene."
Police said a man and a woman had been hospitalised, but did not provide any details, such as whether they were in the Audi or were the occupants of the bus.

The former Scottish first minster will star in Alex Salmond Unleashed during the annual arts festival in August.
Promoters for the Edinburgh Fringe said tickets were selling well for the comedic show, which they claim is "in the tradition of the late great Billy Connolly".
The show, which is described as a 'cautionary and satirical tale', has sold 50 per cent of the available seats in the first 24 hours of ticket sales.

> Mr Salmond will be donating part of the proceeds from the show to the Weldon Beaufort Trust, a small Edinburgh based cancer charity

"There was no major change in him the day after we lost 7-1 at Norwich to when we won 3-1 at Arsenal last week."

That was the message from Steve Clarke as he looked ahead to Reading's visit of the Potters tomorrow.

Clarke took over as manager at Stoke in September and won his first four games in charge to lift the mood around the club.

The run ended with defeat at home to Southampton, but Clarke's side were then undone by a freakish set of circumstances in the 7-1 mauling by Norwich City at Carrow Road at the end of October.

One person died and five were injured at the decommissioned power station on 23 February. Three are still missing.
Assistant Chief Constable Scott Chilton added that the victims' families had returned home after visiting the site.
A four-minute silence was held at demolition firm Coleman and Company's sites across the UK.
A spokesperson said it was "a sign of respect to our men, their families, friends and work colleagues".
Npower said it still did not know how the collapse happened and would not speculate.
Updates on this story and more from Oxfordshire
Thames Valley Police said the site remained "highly unstable" but that emergency services were continuing to work closely together to establish the best way to recover the bodies.

text:
Mrs McAreavey, 27, daughter of Tyrone Gaelic football boss Mickey Harte, was found murdered in her honeymoon hotel room on the island on Monday.
Three men have been charged in connection with her killing.
Avinash Treebhoowoon, 29, has confessed to the murder.
The confession followed the revelation that a lawyer for another man, Raj Theekoy, who is charged with conspiracy to murder, said his client had spoken to police and implicated the other two men.
Sandip Moneea, 41, and Mr Treebhoowoon appeared in court on Wednesday accused of her murder.

text:
They surrounded a house in South Yarmouth, Massachusetts, and ordered Shaun "Shizz" Miller out.
He walked outside in disguise and when they realised the "elderly man" was actually the 31-year-old they were looking for, they arrested him.
He had been on the run since being charged with heroin trafficking offences in April.
When officers searched the house in South Yarmouth, they found two loaded weapons hidden in a laundry basket, and nearly $30,000 (Â£23,000) in cash.

The Ibrox side lost 2-1 on aggregate to crash out in the first qualifier.
Their part-time opponents, who are playing in Europe for the first time since 1977, were made to rue a missed penalty when Ryan Bowman failed to find the net from the spot, though that proved academic as the League Two side struck twice in a minute to leave Gers boss Steven Gerrard fuming.
Gers were the dominant side throughout much of the game and took the lead when Connor Sammon tucked home.
However, a goal three minutes from time and an extra-time effort five minutes into the second period saw the hosts through in the first leg.
The visitors will still need to win the second-leg in Glasgow to progress to the Europa League second qualifying round.

Belgium-born Moussa, 26, joins the League One Saddlers after his short-term deal with the Shrimpers finished at the end of last season.
"I'm really pleased to have signed and I feel this is a club where I will fit in nicely," Moussa told the club's official website.
He becomes Walsall boss Jon Whitney's eighth signing of the summer.
Moussa started his career at Southend, scoring eight goals in 103 games, before moving to Leicester City in August 2010.

The firm, which recorded sales of Â£282m last year, said it was confident shareholders would benefit from strong growth.
"Our future as a public company can only extend our reputation," said Jimmy Choo chief executive Pierre Denis.
It said it would continue to open 10 to 15 shops a year, and planned to float at least a quarter of the shares in the company.

text:
Patricia Reid, 57, was found to have 76 micrograms of alcohol per 100 millilitres of breath following the crash at Rhuallt Hill, near St Asaph, on 25 May.
The legal limit is 35 micrograms.
Reid, a social worker from Cilcain, near Mold, Flintshire, pleaded guilty to driving with excess alcohol at Llandudno Magistrates' Court.
The court heard Reid was "distressed" because her mother had been taken to hospital and had drunk "several" glasses of wine.
She was also suffering from depression due to being out of work.
The court heard that after the crash, her car was found to have had a suspension fault which caused it to become unstable when she braked.
As well as being banned from driving, Reid was

text:
The company said that about 700 of its "partners" in the US had been affected by the mistake.
Exposed data included names, email addresses and, in some cases, home addresses and dates of birth, Apple said. The affected partners sell Apple's Homepod or work with Apple's Business Chat service. The personal information was left visible on Apple servers and some third-party services used by Apple.
Apple was alerted to the data exposure last month by an unnamed security researcher.

"Due to human error, these files were publicly accessible on the internet and they should not have been," said Tom Neumayr, an Apple spokesman.
"We are working to resolve the issue and notifying customers whose data was exposed."
The affected partners, who include telecoms operators and retail chains, should have already been notified by Apple. But a spokesman for the company declined to say which ones were
paraphrased_text: names, email addresses and, in some cases, dates of birth, Apple said. The data included names, email addresses and, in some cases, home addresses and dates of birth. the affected partners sell Apple's Homepod or work with Apple's Business Chat service.

text:
Victims were telephoned and told a fault had been detected on their machines and the problem could be fixed by giving the caller remote access.
The fraudsters charge £100 to "fix the fault" but remove up to £400 from people's bank accounts.
More than 120 people have fallen victim in the last two months, police said.
"The fraudsters claim to be from a variety of computer service companies and say they are from software tech support," said Det Insp Lee Morton from the Kent and Essex Serious Economic Crime Unit.
"If remote access is not granted, fraudsters may become aggressive.
"But once given access they will either load a fake virus on to the computer then give the impression that they have removed it, or they will gain access to bank accounts."
The force said legitimate computer companies would never make unsolicited phone calls to request personal information or to fix computers.
paraphrased_text: a fault had been detected on their machines and the problem could be fixed by giving the caller remote access. fraudsters charge £100 to "fix the fault" but remove up to £400 from people's bank accounts. more than 120 people have fallen victim in the last two months, police said.

text:
Carbisdale Castle, which overlooks the Kyle of Sutherland in the Highlands, was shut down about three years ago.
The Scottish Youth Hostels Association (SYHA) had to close it because of rising repair costs.
Last year, it was sold for an undisclosed sum and is to be turned into a private residence.
The swimming pool has been proposed as part of a new terraced area at the castle. A gym, jacuzzi and new bedrooms are also planned.
The proposals have been submitted with Highland Council for consideration.
The Dowager Duchess of Sutherland had Carbisdale Castle built between 1907 and 1917 following the death of her husband, George Granville William Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, the Third Duke of Sutherland.
Lady Mary was the duke's second wife and after he died she became embroiled in a legal dispute over his will with her stepson, the fourth Duke of Sutherland.
Following the
paraphrased_text: because of rising repair costs. The castle is to be turned into a private residence. The swimming pool has been proposed as part of a new terraced area at the castle. A gym, jacuzzi and new bedrooms are also planned. The proposals have been submitted with Highland Council for consideration.

text:
The left-wing demonstrators accuse the president of abandoning socialism with his austerity policies.
Recent opinion polls show Mr. Bachelet remains popular, with 67 percent of Chileans giving her good marks, although that is down from the 76 percent of the month before the protests began.
Chile, an exporter of the copper mined by many of the protesters, has become a model for conservative politicians in Latin America and beyond with its policies of free-market economics, political stability and low inflation.
In recent days, there has been some easing of tensions in Chile, with Ms. Bachelet announcing an additional $6.1 billion for social programs.
The government says it will begin distributing new tax benefits to low-income families in September. But protesters want even deeper changes.
paraphrased_text: 76 percent of the month before the protests began. 76 percent of the month before the protests began. the president has announced an additional $6.1 billion for social programs. the government says it will begin distributing new tax benefits to low-income families in September..

text:
Almost 8,000 people died from alcohol-related causes between 2005 and 2014, a third of the 23,500 alcohol-related deaths in that period.

The latest annual statistics released yesterday by National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre (NDARC), a research body at the University of New South Wales, show that overdoses in men under 35 is the leading cause of alcohol-related deaths, a third of which were from prescription medication.

Deaths from overdose have been steadily rising since 2005.

In 2012, the number of drug and alcohol-related fatalities almost doubled to 5,551 deaths, including 4,280 from alcohol.

Alcohol is also the greatest cause of harm in people aged 15 to 24 in Australia, with one third of deaths
paraphrased_text: almost 8,000 people died from alcohol-related causes between 2005 and 2014, a third of the 23,500 alcohol-related deaths in that period. text:
There is no question that the US car industry is back and booming. 2015 was a record year for car sales in the US, and 2016 is expected to be just as strong.
Carmakers are not taking any chances though, displaying the latest luxury, the coolest tech features, and of course, the fastest motors at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.
But unlike the futuristic vehicles on display at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last week, carmakers in Detroit are keen to emphasise cars can be driven now.
Take the 2017 Mercedes-Benz E-Class, unveiled at a chic event on Sunday night.

text:
His career spanned six decades; in that time he produced more than 700 records, wrote film scores and worked with music's greatest talents.
His technical knowledge and love of experimentation saw him produce incredible sounds from equipment that modern musicians would consider primitive.
His greatest success came with the Beatles; from the loveable mop-top recordings of the early 1960s to the acid-drenched psychedelia of Sergeant Pepper.
George Henry Martin was born on 3 January 1926 into a working-class family in north London. His parents, a carpenter and a cleaner, wanted "a safe civil servant's job" for their son.
He won a scholarship to St Ignatius' College in Stamford Hill, but when war broke out his parents moved out of London and he went to Bromley Grammar School.

text:
Up to 100,000 youngsters will be eligible for half-price day tickets using The Young Persons 16-25 Railcard. For the first time, there will be no annual subscription, which will reduce the cost of an adult day return by up to 40%.

And there’s also good news for everyone planning a day trip at the weekend or during the school holidays – off-peak fares will be available on 11 routes during peak times.

The new scheme was announced by Transport Secretary Patrick McLoughlin in a speech to the Rail Delivery Group’s (RDG) Future of Rail conference on Wednesday.

It comes as the RDG and the Government published a major set of reforms for the rail industry – the Rail Delivery Group’s (RDG) ‘A new deal for passengers and communities’.

The Rail Delivery Group (RDG) -

text:
The Working Group on Seanad Reform has also recommended a majority of Seanad seats be elected by popular vote.
The Seanad has existed for more than 90 years.
In 2013, voters in the Republic of Ireland rejected a government proposal to abolish it.
The Working Group on Seanad Reform's recommendations include:
The group said its principal objective was "the restructuring and reforming of Seanad Éireann to bring it into line with international best practice for second houses of parliament in the 21st century".
The report also included timelines and processes for the implementation of its recommendation.
The working group included a draft bill as part of its final report, which will be available within the next four weeks.
Taoiseach Enda Kenny has said the report will not sit on the shelf along with others on the same topic.

Health Secretary Vaughan Gething said the Specialist and Critical Care Centre near Cwmbran should open in 2022.
First proposed in 2004, the plans were put on hold in 2009 before being put back on the agenda a year later.
The new hospital, to be built at Llanfrechfa Grange, is part of a plan to modernise health services run by the Aneurin Bevan health board.
Mr Gething said the project had "strong support" locally and was a "positive step" in the drive to improve health care.

Morgan made his name on the US comedy show, where he was a cast member from 1999 to 2006 before moving to the UK and fronting comedy show ‘Morgan’s Life’ from 2008 to 2010.

However, in the wake of the controversy surrounding allegations of abuse from his former co-stars Rebecca Corry, Teresa Kearney and Loni Love, Morgan’s comedy show has been canceled.

It is not clear what caused the death of Abubakar Audu, who is from President Muhammadu Buhari's APC party.
The BBC's Chris Ewokor says the 68-year-old was believed to have received the most votes at the time of his death.
The result for the weekend's election has not been declared following reports of irregularities.
Mr Audu has been buried on Monday according to Islamic rites in his hometown Ogbonicha.
Our correspondent says that Mr Audu had been accused of stealing funds when he had previously served as Kogi state governor, something which he denied.

Helen Richardson-Walsh put the first goal on the board for Great Britain and the home team soon equalised.
Great Britain took the lead from a penalty corner but Canada came back with one of their own just before half time to go 2-2 at the break.

text:
The Foreign Affairs Committee demanded an explanation from the foreign secretary, amid reports the UK was preparing to send 1,000 personnel.

It also called on the government to make clear what is expected of the UK as a result of the decision to send the additional military assets.

Labour chairman Tom Tugendhat said the government needed to “do more”.

“We cannot allow ourselves to be bystanders to an appalling war,” he said.

“There is no good outcome to this conflict. In the face of brutality and suffering, it is vital that we support efforts to negotiate peace and do more to prevent further escalation of violence.”

text:
Leatherdale, 48, will leave New Road in March to end a 30-year association with the club as a player and administrator.
"It is a sad day for Worcestershire and a massive loss to the club," said chairman Stephen Taylor.
"It's one of those prestigious roles and I can fully understand David taking it."
An all-rounder, Leatherdale spent his entire playing career at New Road, making his debut in 1988 and helping the club win and retain the Championship title in his first two seasons.
In all, he won six major trophies, scored more than 15,000 runs and took more than 300 wickets in all forms of the game.
Leatherdale became commercial director after retiring in 2005 and replaced Mark Newton as CEO five years later.

text:
The mobile phone company, which employs about 4,500 people at the site, is undertaking a restructuring programme which will affect employees in a range of departments over the next few months.

The move is part of a wider plan for the company, which aims to make savings of £1.1 billion globally, as part of an international cost reduction programme.

An Orange spokeswoman said the changes meant some roles would no longer be necessary.

The changes will not affect the sales department, but the spokeswoman added: “Employees in a number of other departments will be consulted on the changes.”

At present, Orange employs about 7,000 people across the UK. The spokeswoman said there were no plans to close the UK offices or make any compulsory redundancies.

Officials said the suspects, who were armed with handguns, got away from the Tarzana property with an unknown amount of money and some personal items.
Brown or his representatives have yet to comment on the matter.
According to reports, the 26-year-old was at a nightclub at the time of the incident.

text:
Local officials in Vallauris have said they will restrict access to a stretch of beach to ensure the security of the king and his 400-strong entourage.
Public access to the sea will be prohibited intermittently for the duration of the king's stay.
Beach users have complained about the arrangements.
"Looking after their security is fine, but they should at least let us go for a swim," Mohamed, a disgruntled fishing enthusiast, told the AFP news agency.
Locals were also angry when a project to build a lift between La Mirandole beach and the villa involved pouring a huge slab of cement directly on to the sand.
The local authorities have allowed work on the lift to continue, but the Saudis have promised to dismantle it when they leave.

text:
PC Neil Doyle, 36, died after being struck by a "pile driver" punch in the early hours of 19 December 2014.
At Liverpool Crown Court, Andrew Taylor, 29, was jailed for seven years and six months and Timmy Donovan, 30, of Huyton, for six years and 10 months.
A third man, Christopher Spendlove, was cleared of manslaughter in July.
The trial judge, Mr Justice Turner, told the pair, who were convicted under joint enterprise law: "There is no such thing as a death-proof punch."
The judge rejected any suggestion the men acted in "excessive self-defence."
Andrew Taylor's barrister, Lord Carlile, said the family may never know who struck the fatal blow and had the punch landed slightly to the left or right "the consequences would have been entirely different."

The backlogs included people waiting a decade to hear if their partner had permission to live in the UK.
Immigration Minister Mark Harper denied the Border Agency was a "shambles", and said managers were "getting a grip".

text:
Where can you have a day out for less than £25?
The BBC's Price of Football study has analysed data from 223 clubs across Britain and Europe to find out how much is costs supporters to follow their team.
Overall, 36% of ticket prices in the division went up compared to last year's study - the biggest percentage increase across the men's leagues in the UK.
The average cost of the cheapest matchday ticket has gone up to £22.11 - a six-year high - while the most expensive matchday tickets average £36.13.
The average season ticket prices are at their lowest since 2013 - with the cheapest averaging £322.83 and the most expensive averaging £568.15.

text:
Fellow relegated side Hartlepool United start their campaign at home to Dover.
National League North champions AFC Fylde entertain Leyton Orient and Wrexham start at Maidenhead.
The Reds will make their debut in the National League on Saturday when they host Woking in a 3pm kick-off at the Panfield Stadium.

After a tough pre-season that saw three 4-0 losses for the Reds and just one win from a possible four matches, they have been boosted by the additions of goalkeeper Ryan Huddart and forward Jack King this week to get them prepared for the National League.
Boss Martin Allen insists he’s still got an eye on that promotion target and said he’s optimistic for the new season.
Meanwhile, former Red Dan Holman has joined the Reds’ National League opponents in a permanent deal from Woking.

Mugo wa Wairimu pleaded not guilty and has previously denied that he raped his patients after sedating them.
The charges stem from a Kenyan TV report which had footage showing an unidentified man allegedly assaulting an unconscious woman on a clinic bed.
Kenya's Medical Practitioners Board has said he is not a registered doctor.
Mr Wa Wairimu went on the run for a week after the report was aired on Kenya's private Citizen TV.
He was eventually arrested at a hotel outside the capital, Nairobi, after members of the public called the police.
The secretly recorded footage was filmed by a suspicious staff member.

In the women's C1, European champion Woods, 20, claimed silver with Australia's Jess Fox winning gold.

The charity has launched a new zero hours website which will host information for employers about the benefits of fairer contracts and for the self-employed.

The project will also see an interactive map developed to help people find the best self-employment opportunities in their area.

text:
Hundreds of drivers demanded more pay and protection from violent crime.
Many said they needed more money to maintain their buses and complained of being robbed and assaulted while on the job.
Bus drivers held a demonstration at the Metro Parking Deck on Monday.
It comes after Metro CEO Paul Wiedefeld said bus operators could go on strike if they don't receive a satisfactory pay and benefit proposal.
Union officials say Metro is proposing a 3 percent wage increase over four years.
They say the last time a 3 percent raise came with zero health insurance cost increases.
The current Metro contract expired in July, 2017.
The union's next session is on Tuesday.

text:
Karen Whitmore was made redundant from her post as assistant director of organisation and governance at Middlesbrough Council in June.

She has since been elected chairman of the north region and also became a member of the CIPFA Council executive.

Before joining local government, Whitmore had worked for both the private and public sector.

She is currently employed by York City Council as assistant director of the environment directorate.

In the past, Whitmore has played a key role in the implementation of both IPSAS and the UK GAAP for public sector bodies in England and Wales.

In her new role, Whitmore will work with public sector finance professionals across the north to provide a regional dimension to the CIPFA Council executive.

‘The CIPFA North Council is at an important stage, and I am determined to encourage a wide membership, so that we can be at the heart of the work that the North West
paraphrased_text: Karen Whitmore was made redundant from her post as assistant director of organisation and governance at Middlesbrough Council in June. Whitmore has since been elected chairman of the north region and also became a member of the CIPFA Council executive. ‘I am determined to encourage a wide membership, so that we can be at the heart of the work that the North West is doing,’ she said.

text:
O'Neill, 19, made five appearances for Burnley in all competitions last season after joining from Brisbane Athletic.
The Australian then played 15 times on loan at Oldham, helping the Latics avoid relegation from League One.
"He will add things to our team that we need, he is athletic and well skilled," Fleetwood manager Uwe Rosler told the club website.
O'Neill joins strikers Conor McAleny and Jordy Hiwula, defenders Lewie Coyle and Harvey Rodgers and midfielder Kyle Dempsey in joining Fleetwood this summer.
He is the third Burnley player to be sent out on loan for the upcoming season, following Chris Long's move to Northampton Town and Alex Whitmore's switch to Bury.
Find all the latest football transfers on our dedicated page.

text: The hunting of foxes with hounds was banned under the Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Act in 2002, and was replaced by the Hunting Act in 2004 which prohibited hunts from flushing foxes to dogs in England and Wales. However, the law is not being enforced in many areas. The RSPCA says ‘some hunts are getting round the law by claiming to be trailing, drag hunting or mink hunting’. This is a problem in many areas including Harewood, York, and West Yorkshire. Many ‘trail hunting’ packs are in fact hunting foxes. This was the case in 2011 at the Leeds Hunt. The footage of the hunt below (taken in 2006) shows a ‘trail’ marked by blue dye. Hounds are ‘sent’ the trail on two occasions, and do not seem

Wiltshire police and the ambulance service were called at about 7pm to reports of a man having a fit in the car park.

The coroner, Sarah Earnshaw, said he was taken to Salisbury Hospital, where it became clear he was suffering from sepsis.

text:
The firm, 2 Sisters, has been seeking more than four months to pay its bills, a document seen by the programme shows.

Some suppliers, owed tens of thousands of pounds, have been waiting since Christmas.

The supermarket has not yet paid many bills from the new year, the report says.

Some suppliers are owed six figure sums by the firm, according to the BBC.

The programme said one dairy company had been paid just £4,000 of the £400,000 it was owed by the food supplier.

However, it is understood that the supplier of the dairy products has now been paid the remaining amount.

The BBC programme also reported that staff working through the company had been waiting months for some money owed to them.

He called on MPs to "desist" from any formal leadership challenge to Mr Corbyn - who he said had been the victim of an "orchestrated campaign" by the parliamentary Labour Party.

The shadow Chancellor said that those in the party seeking to oust Mr Corbyn "are just plain wrong", and that he hoped the Labour leader would receive the full backing of the parliamentary Labour Party.

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's World at One, Mr McDonnell said that he was "not for a coup" or a leadership contest that would "tear the party apart" after the referendum result, adding that "this is not the time to divide the Labour Party".

The 24-year-old had spells on loan with Stevenage and Grimsby Town last season, but failed to find the net in 13 combined appearances for the two clubs.

The 34-year-old man from Lambeth was arrested on Thursday and is in custody at a south London police station.
Police say that he is wanted in connection with the death of a baby boy whose mother claims he was killed by spirits.
Tamworth-based Jameela Abdul Wahab, 23, told police that her one-year-old son died following a voodoo ritual.
She and her partner, who is the suspect, were arrested by Warwickshire Police, who referred them to the Metropolitan Police, which has taken on the investigation.
Abdul Wahab, 23, has denied murder charges and is expected to appear at Birmingham Magistrates Court later on Thursday.
She has told officers that her child was not killed by either her or her partner.

text:
Five million books a year flew out of DC Thomson's West Ward Works during the Dundee plant's 1960s and 70s heyday.

The building's current owner is aiming to turn the massive printing complex, which is being marketed as a potential film and TV studio, into a similarly successful production facility.

In a presentation last week to Dundee City Council, businessman Derek Smith, managing director of FD Real Estate, revealed he had secured a major UK animation studio as an anchor tenant for West Ward Works, which he bought for £5.6m in 2018.

Mr Smith told councillors West Ward Works is in line to become Scotland's first "Netflix Studio" and that the facility will see hundreds of jobs created over time.

text:
Carmarthenshire developer Enzo's Homes is in the process of buying the Penllergaer civic centre site.
Money from the sale will go to build new schools and modernise council buildings.
Council leader Rob Stewart said the scheme, if approved, would provide much-needed housing in the area.
Enzo Sauro, of Enzo's Homes, said the firm was working on the finer details of the planning application.
He added the company would also gift three pieces of land to the Penllergare Trust, which manages the adjoining Penllergare Valley Woods.
The three-storey Penllergaer civic centre building first opened in 1982 for the former Lliw Valley Borough Council.
Staff at the building have been relocated.

The 14-room house was bought in 1990 by John Harrison for £765,000.

A year earlier, his parents had purchased the 80 acres at Thornholme Grange, where, in 2004, they built and then sold a house for £1.95m.

text:
Tom Owen, 21, from Efail Isaf near Pontypridd in Rhondda Cynon Taff, was sentenced to six years in prison at Cardiff Crown Court today, Friday 18 September 2020, after being found guilty in August of a conspiracy to produce cocaine.

The sentence was handed down by Judge Thomas today.

Owen was arrested in April 2019 after he was stopped and searched by officers from the Serious Organised Crime Disruption Team in Cardiff Bay.

He and a group of others involved in the conspiracy were arrested.

An investigation was launched by the Metropolitan Police in London, and officers found £3,000 worth of cocaine in the car.

They also discovered details in Owen’s phone relating to the production and supply of cocaine and the movement of money.

Owen tried to distance himself from the activity

text:
The measles cases during 2012 have been associated with prolonged outbreaks in Merseyside, Surrey and Sussex.
There were also several smaller outbreaks in travelling communities.
The HPA said parents should ensure their children are fully protected against the disease with the MMR vaccine.
Dr Mary Ramsay, head of immunisation at the Health Protection Agency, said coverage of the MMR vaccine is now at historically high levels.
"But measles is highly infectious and can spread easily among communities that are poorly vaccinated, and can affect anyone who is susceptible, including toddlers in whom vaccination has been delayed."
The measles virus can spread through droplets in the air that come out of the nose and mouth when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
The initial symptoms include cold-like symptoms, red eyes which are sensitive to light, a fever and greyish white spots in the mouth and throat.
Measles
paraphrased_text: there were several smaller outbreaks in travelling communities. is highly infectious and can spread easily among communities that are poorly vaccinated, including toddlers in whom vaccination has been delayed." text:
These weals of misfortune are not a reaction to some new body art. Instead they are proof positive of the power of unintended consequences. A week or so ago I did a post on how I got my name into the Guinness Book of World Records. Today, because I had the name “The Wandering Whippet” engraved on the inside of my left wrist, I have entered a world of woe.

I have always thought, because I am a creature of habit, that the right hand always writes and the left always reads (I read for a living and can no longer remember when I last wrote). My son thought that I was nuts and was convinced that he could write equally well with either hand. I told him to prove it but he didn’t. Then, when he was about 16, he broke a bone in his wrist and I was right! He could write with his right hand but not with his left
paraphrased_text: they are proof positive of the power of unintended consequences. of misfortune are not a reaction to some new body art. They are proof positive of the power of unintended consequences...................................

text:
Iain Cameron writes about, photographs and measures snow.
His records of the white stuff are published by the Royal Meteorological Society.
The total of 73 is the most since 1994. They have lingered through to this winter because of the cool spring and frequent snow showers until June.
Patches were recorded on mountains such as Creag Meagaidh, Ben Macdui and Ben Nevis.
Mr Cameron said snow had survived this in areas where the phenomenon was unusual.
He said: "This includes, also for the first time since 1994, mountains in the north west Highlands, where 12 patches survived.
"The reason so many patches survived is undoubtedly to do with the very cool spring, which saw frequent and heavy snow showers right through May and even into June.
"In fact, there are good grounds to believe that the maximum depth
paraphrased_text: snow has survived 73 patches recorded since 1994. this is the most since 1994. the cool spring saw frequent and heavy snow showers.

text:
But Libor - or the London inter-bank offered rate - is crucial because, flawed as it is, it has affected most of our financial lives. It was treated by every bank for years as the best measure they had of the real cost of borrowing.
The interest rate that we journalists report on every month, unchanged now for 87 months, is the official Bank of England rate, which is currently 0.5%. But it is not this official rate that determines the cost of mortgages and other loans.
What really counts in determining the interest rates we pay is what it costs the banks and building societies to get hold of the funds to lend to us.
Libor was designed to track that cost. The trouble was - it could be fiddled.
Every working morning
paraphrased_text: the official Bank of England rate, which is 0.5%. But it is not this official rate that determines the cost of mortgages and other loans. What really counts is what it costs the banks and building societies to get hold of the funds to lend to us. And it was designed to track that cost. The trouble was - it could be fiddled.

Phelan, 53, took charge of the Tigers when Steve Bruce resigned in July after a breakdown in his relationship with vice-chairman Ehab Allam.

text:
A total of 138 candidates are standing in 18 constituencies across Northern Ireland.
The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) is contesting the most constituencies – 12 – closely followed by the Green Party and the UUP with 11 seats each.
The Alliance, SDLP and Sinn Fein are each standing in 10 constituencies.
Debate is due to begin on Monday 8 February, with the election on Thursday 18 February. The final results will be announced the following day.
Counting is expected to begin at 9:30GMT, with early results expected in Northern Ireland by 02:00GMT.
You can find your polling station on the NI Electoral Office website
The Northern Ireland Assembly is responsible for some devolved issues, including health, education and policing.
As Northern Ireland is part of the UK it also sends its MP

Twelve of the country's senior military figures said the UK was stronger in the EU at a time of "grave" challenges.
Downing Street later expressed regret that it had included a 13th signatory - Gen Sir Michael Rose - on the letter to the Daily Telegraph by mistake.
At least two defence ministers are backing the leave campaign.
A referendum on whether the UK should stay in the EU will be held on 23 June.
The intervention comes after leaders of some of Britain's biggest companies said leaving the EU would put the UK's economy at risk.
The letter, released by Downing Street and signed by officers from all three services, including former Chiefs of Defence Staff Lord Bramall and Lord Stirrup, said that while Nato was the most important alliance for UK security, the EU was an "increasingly important pillar of our security".

text:
The test version of the Orion capsule touched down safely in the Arizona desert after being dropped from a C-17 military aircraft at 500 mph, simulating its reentry into Earth's atmosphere.

The test capsule was released from a height of 25,000 feet, and parachutes opened at 18,000 feet to slow the capsule. After a freefall that lasted almost 10 minutes, the capsule reached terminal velocity of 500 mph and touched down safely.

"This is the very first time that we've landed this size and weight of capsule in the configuration it's going to fly on the test flights," said Phil McAlister, director of the commercial spaceflight development division at NASA headquarters.

The test capsule has undergone three high-speed drop tests over the past week at NASA's Yuma Landing

text:
As many as 80 scientists from eleven universities are tracking nearly 1,000 different types of gases and particles in the atmosphere.
Pollutants are being measured on the ground, at the top of BT Tower and from a research plane circling the capital.
The project is timed to provide reams of data during the Olympic Games.
It is also intended to help improve air quality forecasting in the years ahead.
One aim is to investigate how much pollution is generated by the capital itself - principally from vehicles - and how much blows in from the industrial centres of continental Europe.
London is frequently in breach of international air quality standards set by the EU and World Health Organisation.
In the two days before the Opening Ceremony of the Games, levels of ozone soared well above the WHO's recommended safe limit of 60 parts per billion over an eight-hour period.

text:
Recruitment is underway to find an independent chair to investigate why 17 schools were closed amid building safety fears.
Council leaders have written to the Local Government Association (LGA) to request they begin the process to recruit an independent chair for an external review into the decision making behind the closures.

The letter states: “Seven years on from Grenfell, residents of Brent continue to have concerns over their housing, following the tragic event that affected and devastated so many lives.

“The council’s closure of 17 tower blocks as part of the ‘Waking Watch Scheme’, which involved 17 tower blocks, has created a significant amount of anxiety to residents of the borough.

“It is essential to understand what went wrong and to learn the lessons to ensure this does not happen again.

“Brent Council is committed to transparency, accountability and being open to learning from past experiences
paraphrased_text: recruitment is underway to find an independent chair to investigate why 17 schools were closed amid building safety fears. council leaders have written to the local government association to request they begin the process to recruit an independent chair.

The 52-year-old said he was "humbled" to be given a British Empire Medal.

The charity was set up after the death of Georgia Murray in 2010.
Since then, four learning centres have been established to support the education and development of underprivileged children in Cambodia and Romania.
This year, the charity opened its fifth venue - known as a Georgia's House - in Salford.

Hazel Baines, who has dementia, fell on Harrowby Lane, Grantham, at about 17:00 BST on Tuesday.

She was rushed to Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham with head injuries but died on Saturday.

Tributes have been paid to the grandmother who was well known in the town and was president of the Grantham and Melton branch of the British Red Cross until her death.

The branch's chairman, Chris Barham, said Mrs Baines was very well loved by both her family and many friends.

"She was an inspiring lady who had the courage to step forward into the public arena to make a positive difference," he said.

"She leaves a great gap and the branch will miss her as we would a member of the family."

The Grade II-listed Lion Salt Works, near Northwich, produced salt since its opening in 1894 but closed in 1986.  Cheshire-based Pochin Construction was contracted to build a £6.5m museum in the old factory buildings.

The company carried out the structural, external and fit-out work, and says it also ‘carefully restored the existing buildings to their former glory’.

GVA has been appointed to market the 6,600m2 building in conjunction with the Vickery Holman Property Agency.

Nick Pochin, managing director of Pochin Construction, said: “This building is an outstanding example of a successful project, that has delivered on both quality and timeliness to a very happy client.”

The employee was working on Monday in a lab with pigs that had been infected with the deadly virus when a tear was noticed in a protective suit.
Officials with Canada's public health and food inspection agencies made the announcement on Tuesday.
They said there is currently no risk to the public.
The unnamed employee is in self-imposed isolation and will be monitored for the next 21 days, which is the incubation period for the virus.  The employee was also offered an Ebola vaccine that has been used in clinical trials in Africa.
The employee was working in a high-security "level four" laboratory with six pigs that had been experimentally infected with the virus. The lab worker noticed a split in the suit seam after leaving the containment lab during decontamination.

Performance for the grades A* to C has now been the same for the last three years with 66.6% of exam entries falling in that range.

The 99.9% pass rate at the sixth form is also the same as last year and is up marginally from the 99.8% pass rate achieved in 2014.

A* to C grades in all subjects have also remained steady at 82.6%.

Nearly three quarters of students at St Mary’s College have achieved a pass in English (74.7%) compared to 71.2% last year and 71.4% in 2014.

text:
One group in Cardigan, Ceredigion, has raised £12,000 as part of its application to the Home Office for funding of refugee support centres in the town.

The group of volunteers is now applying to have the Home Office recognise their town as being a potential refugee settlement.

The Welsh Government has not yet said how much financial support it will give to the project.

A spokesperson from the Home Office told WalesOnline that they were not aware of the application, but that they would be assessing it as soon as they become aware.

The team of volunteers in Cardigan is applying under the Community Sponsorship Programme to help refugees fleeing war and poverty.

They want to help people who have fled Afghanistan, Syria, and Iraq.

The event returns in July, headlined by opera singers Rebecca Evans and Dennis O'Neill, after concerns about its funding in recent years...

Picture: David Iliff

Cardiff Singer of the World 2019 will take place from 9–13 July, following a successful application to the Welsh Government.

The event returns after two years in the doldrums. Following the 2015 edition, funding from BBC Wales was reduced by two thirds and organisers were forced to cancel 2017's competition, which was due to take place in Wrexham.

In 2018, the competition, now known as Cardiff Singer of the World, was awarded £1.14 million by the Welsh Government, allowing the event to return this year.

Accounts for 1st Land Ltd, run by Howard Grossman, show the money was paid to Tottenham Hotspur.

The figure paid by Mr Grossman’s company in July last year is included in a set of accounts dated October 2018, published on Companies House on Wednesday.

The payments were declared to the authorities, the club said, as part of a “long-standing commercial arrangement with the business”.

Under Premier League rules, a club could be sanctioned for not paying “appropriate transfer fees” to another club for players signed before they joined the Premier League.

London mayor Ken Livingstone has led the chorus of congratulations to a group of the capital’s most prominent lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) citizens at an annual awards event.

The search giant will now highlight "authoritative sources" in search results, with a summary of claims that have been fact-checked.
Google says sites will be judged authoritative by an algorithm and the company will not be fact-checking news stories itself.
On Thursday, Facebook announced a campaign to help people spot fake news.
Google introduced its fact check feature on its News search site in October, but has now added it to its regular search results.
Publishers who have investigated a claim, for example a politician's statements, will be displayed more prominently.
A summary of the fact-checked statements and whether they are judged to be true or false will also appear.
However, the feature will not affect the order of search results and will not label sites known to spread false information as untrustworthy.

The unnamed saw mill firm had promised to build a new production line for cutting timber.
But the body said the company had not met the conditions of the agreement and had not paid 799.3bn dongs (US$36,000), representing nearly two-thirds of the compensation for labour during the period from November 2013 to May this year.
The body threatened to stop the construction work until the company paid the money.
The saw mill firm, in its proposal to the provincial government, said it did not want to build a new line as its investment could not make sufficient profits.
The body demanded the company continue the construction work with the remaining budget of 107bn dongs, while the rest would be returned to the firm.

text:
Developer Vattenfall welcomed the decision on its South Kyle scheme.
The £190m proposals went to a public inquiry in 2015 after an initial planning application two years earlier.
The company said the decision was good news for climate change targets but added there was a "long way to go" before the farm was operational.
The wind farm is located near Dalmellington, Patna, New Cumnock and Carsphairn.
"The Scottish government's consent decision for this scheme is reassuringly robust," said Guy Mortimer, Vattenfall's UK head of development for onshore wind.
"The wind farm proposal was scrutinised and carefully considered through a detailed public local inquiry in late 2015.
"As a result, this consent is a clear evidence-based decision that concludes South Kyle is an eminently acceptable proposal."

The county's police force said feedback from both farmers and those caught hare coursing said it was the greatest deterrent.
Traditionally offences start to rise in the autumn after crops have been harvested and continue until spring.
Last season, 176 men were arrested or reported for summons.
During the busiest months of November and December an average of 15 calls a day were received with the South Holland area the hardest hit, the force said.
Lincolnshire Police said it would also focus on working with neighbouring forces as part of its clampdown.
The National Farmer's Union's Lincolnshire advisor for the Holland region, Gordon Corner, welcomed the move.
He said many farmers had been threatened with violence and threats when facing gangs of hare coursers.
Source: Lincolnshire Police

text:
"The Only Way Is Ethics" will have as its climax, on 5-6 December, the first-ever Vegfest Scotland.
Ethics festival organiser Craig Tannock said: "It is not just a vegan event but about using all sorts of entertainment and media to celebrate ethical choices.
"From the Monday to Friday, there will be a city-wide programme involving anything that celebrates the theme."
Mr Tannock said this would include art, music, cinema, schools and workshop events, with everyone from businesses, campaigning groups, charities, the general public and political organisations being invited to take part.
Vegfest already holds annual events in Bristol, Brighton and London and its SECC venture becomes the second large-scale vegan festival to be announced north of the border in recent months.

Both

text:
Traces of beeswax found on ancient pottery from Europe, the Near East and North Africa suggest the first farmers kept bees. Bees would have brought in pollen that aided with crop diversification and helped to establish crops in areas where wild plants could not take hold, according to the study published today (April 20, 2016) in the journal Scientific Reports.

Archaeologists have known for decades that farmers and bees go back a long way — but the new work reveals that domesticated bees and beekeeping arrived well before the emergence of agriculture in Europe and the Middle East. “It’s another piece of evidence that agriculture in general started a lot earlier than we thought,” says study co-author Thomas B. Higham, of the University of Oxford in the United Kingdom.

For centuries, the idea that bees had a place in ancient civilizations remained a mystery. One

Higham, of the University of Oxford in the United Kingdom.

All eight Conservative MPs were re-elected with increased majorities.
It was down, in part, to the almost complete collapse of the Liberal Democrats in England.

In South Northamptonshire, the Lib Dems managed just 2.5% of the vote - down from 23.8% in 2015, and below their 5.3% share in 2010.

Labour's share in South Northamptonshire fell by half from 40.1% in 2015 to just 20% on Thursday, but this was still higher than the party's 16.2% vote share in the seat in 2010.

And the Brexit Party, which had a high profile in Northampton, failed to capitalise, coming fifth with 2.1%.

text:
Such terms will not be imposed for non-violent drug offenders with no gang or cartel ties, Attorney General Eric Holder said in a speech.
The US has one of the world's biggest prison populations, despite a 40-year-low in the country's crime rates.
Critics say that heavy drug sentences have hit minorities hardest.
"We need to ensure that incarceration is used to punish, deter and rehabilitate - not merely to convict, warehouse and forget," Mr Holder said in a speech to the American Bar Association in San Francisco on Monday.
Under the reforms, Mr Holder is directing US prosecutors who draft indictments for certain drug offences to omit any mention of the quantity of illegal substance involved, so as to avoid triggering a mandatory minimum sentence.
Only non-violent offenders with no previous charges or ties to gangs or cartels will be affected.
Source: Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Prisons
He advocated sending people convicted of low-level offences to drug treatment and community service

In Wales, councils are responsible for funding and overseeing schools.
But in England, Mr Osborne's plan will mean local authorities will cease to have a role in providing education.
Academies are directly funded by central government and head teachers have more freedom over admissions and to change the way the school works.
It is a significant development in the continued divergence of schools systems on either side of Offa's Dyke.
And although the Welsh Government will get extra cash to match the money for English schools to extend the school day, it can spend it on any devolved policy area.
Ministers have no plans to follow suit.
At the moment, governing bodies are responsible for setting school hours and they need ministerial permission to make significant changes.

It came a day after the embattled government inaugurated a new legislative body, the 545-member constituent assembly. It is the first of three major political bodies created under Nepal’s new political framework, paving the way for the drafting of a new constitution.

“I appeal to all parties and forces to work towards a united front, so that we can overcome political and economic problems in our country together,” said the former Maoist prime minister. “It is our collective responsibility to ensure a smooth and effective transition.”

Prachanda urged all political parties to work towards a “common minimum programme” to ensure political stability, economic prosperity and the full implementation of the peace process.

text:
The British Hospitality Association (BHA) said that thousands of businesses are facing having to drastically reduce their dependence on EU workers.
Staff from the EU make up nearly a quarter of all jobs in the sector.
Immigration is set to be one of the most controversial issues to be settled during the Brexit negotiations.
The hospitality industry represents 3 million workers and about a tenth of the UK's economic wealth.
In the first major business intervention since the triggering of Article 50, a report by KPMG for the BHA says that it will take 10 years to reduce the need for EU workers by training British staff, targeting older workers and encouraging younger people to take jobs in the sector.
But with the UK economy approaching full employment, the report says that there are no easy pools of labour to exploit and that EU nationals will still make up a large part of the workforce.

“It’s amazing, and I am excited,” said Rigondeaux ahead of Saturday’s defence of the belt he won from Nonito Donaire in November 2013.

“I know that the boxing public is very knowledgeable here in the UK, and are able to appreciate the technical ability.”

Rigondeaux’s WBA crown will not be on the line, despite him being advertised as champion.

text:
A meeting of the rule-making F1 Commission approved plans to adopt a structure to protect drivers from debris, sources at governing body the FIA have told Autosport.

The decision has been made in light of the accidents to Fernando Alonso and Nico Rosberg in the opening two races of the season.

The new rule, which is expected to be confirmed at the World Motor Sport Council meeting in Melbourne on Friday, will require cars to be built to a specification set by the FIA.

That rule will then be validated by a 1m-high barrier being tested at the test track, which each team will be expected to crash its car in.

This approach mirrors the regulations for the crash-test dummies used in F1 cars.

The rule will not be introduced before the start of the new engine rules, which are scheduled to start in 2014.

Tens of thousands of candidates will sit the exam on Thursday.
One of the two question papers was replaced last week amid concern about a possible leak.
A second paper was then released by the exam regulator on Tuesday, with the exams due to begin at 9.30 on Thursday morning in 165 countries.
The revised paper had been due to be published on June 18, but the UK’s exam watchdog Ofqual revealed details of the re-jigged exam on Tuesday.
The regulator said there was no sign of a leak on its website, and it blamed a technical error by Pearson Vue, the company that runs the test for the International Baccalaureate (IB) around the world.

The latest figures obtained by the New York Times show Milwaukee has seen the biggest rise, with a 76% increase.
It is followed by St Louis, Missouri, which has seen a 60% increase, and Baltimore, Maryland, with a 56% rise.
Some senior police officials say that heightened scrutiny of use of force by officers may have caused them to withdraw from everyday policing and emboldened criminals.
But others say an increase in gun ownership, a spike in gang-related killings and more young people settling disputes with guns may be contributing factors.

Salvors need it to be at five degrees before it can be towed back to port.

text:
Canada has revoked his citizenship three times since 1995 but each time it has been overturned on appeal, the latest this past March.

His latest request for a certificate of citizenship — which he received in 2011 — was turned down in October, with the government arguing in court that he “willfully concealed” his criminal past to obtain his Canadian citizenship in 1993. The Supreme Court heard from two attorneys general that this made him inadmissible to Canada.

“The government is making a political argument that Mr. Khadr shouldn’t be a Canadian, he is a Canadian,” his lawyer Nate Whitling said in the courthouse. “He is Canadian, full stop.”

Khadr’s case is currently on hold, but his next court appearance is June 24.

text:
Last week, about 120 diners, who had consumed about 2,000 euros of food and drink, left the restaurant without paying.

They left with their phones, cameras, watches and other personal belongings.

In the Netherlands, it is the most common form of fraud for restaurant owners: they leave without paying.

“They make it up on the way,” said the owner of the restaurant, who wanted to remain anonymous.

## How common is it?

Restaurants are regularly targeted by these kinds of fraud.

The police said that about 30,000 restaurants have been targeted this year.

The Netherlands is the most common target for this kind of fraud, the police said.

It is estimated that 17,000 of the restaurants that have been targeted are in the western part of the country.

The firm says it has operated beyond reproach for 40 years and has never been charged with criminal wrong-doing.
Shadow chancellor John McDonnell said "real action" on tax evasion was vital.

Typhoon Bopha made landfall on Mindanao, bringing heavy rain and wind gusts of 210 km/h (130mph) and forcing 40,000 people to be evacuated.
The storm has also caused power cuts, travel disruption and flooding in areas at risk of landslides.
The mining province of Compostela Valley was among the worst affected.
At least 43 people died and 25 were reported injured when torrents of water rushed down a mountain on to Andap village in the valley, local news sources reported.
The region's governor, Arturo Uy, said the victims included villagers sheltering in the village hall which was engulfed by the waters. An army truck carrying soldiers and civilians was also swept away.

The party’s leaders were among thousands of protesters who marched to the Turkish president’s palace on Wednesday to demand that he resign.

Riot police beat people with batons and fired tear gas to disperse a large crowd in the capital Ankara.

More than 1,000 HDP supporters marched in support of the call from President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s opponent.

The Urbaser Balfour Beatty waste-to-energy (WtE) plant, which has a capacity of 500,000 tonnes a year, will generate enough green energy to power the equivalent of 82,500 homes.

Caley Jags beat Falkirk 2-1 to win the trophy for the first time in the club's history.
Dozens of fans pitched up at the Caledonian Stadium to see the team board an open top bus.

Those who gathered at the stadium were given shelter inside the ground from lashing rain.

She insisted that the powers offered by the Smith Commission did not give Scotland "nearly enough" and said more was "needed now".

"The SNP has made clear for a long time now that in relation to the referendum, we will stick by the result, we will stick by the word of that referendum," said Sturgeon.

"But I would hope that would mean we would stick by the word of the people of Scotland, and there was a manifesto commitment there to transfer more powers to the Scottish Parliament.

The Kiwis were due to play Fiji in the final of the Oceania qualifiers after beating Vanuatu 2-0 in their semifinal last Saturday.

But after Fiji beat Papua New Guinea 3-2 in extra-time on Sunday, they faced the prospect of playing another game this coming weekend.

However, Fifa has confirmed that Fiji, who currently sit 146th in the world, have qualified.

New Zealand and Vanuatu will play in the Oceania qualifying final on 22 October.

The Kiwis, currently 107 in the world, and Vanuatu (207) will face each other in the final of the qualifying competition on 22 October with the winner advancing to face Peru in an Intercontinental playoff at a later date to determine who advances to next year's finals in France.

The Environment Agency brought the case to court after the company discharged muddy material into Whitsand Bay near Rame Head without approval.

The prosecution said that the company had previously been served with a compliance notice under the Environmental Permitting Regulations 2010 (EPR) stating that it must apply for a permit to deposit the materials. However, the court was told the company did not submit an application for a permit.

Mohamed Elshinawy, 30, is being held on a number of charges including trying to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organisation.
Mr Elshinawy pledged allegiance to IS online in February, the FBI said.
He told agents that he never intended to carry out an attack and just wanted IS agents to send him money.
The FBI said Mr Elshinawy used disposable mobile phones and multiple email and social media accounts to communicate with IS contacts.
He received the money through a PayPal account and a Western Union wire transfer, the FBI said.

The robotic craft takes supplies to the International Space station (ISS), but could be enhanced to return cargo to Earth and even carry a human crew, as well as dock at different locations in space.

Cosmic Girl, a converted Boeing 747 owned by the British aerospace firm, has taken off from the Mojave Desert on its first mission.

The carrier plane released a sub-orbital SpaceShipTwo which carried a test dummy, called “Mary”, and was used to see if the craft could release its payload of supplies into space.

The mission was successful and the craft returned to Earth safely.

Virgin Galactic is looking into using the craft for suborbital space tourism and could begin taking passengers as soon as 2018.

Russian state media reported that the USS Ross was acting "aggressively".
The US Department of Defense, however, said the ship was "well within international waters at all times, performing routine operations".

"Su-24 attack aircraft demonstrated to the American crew readiness to harshly prevent a violation of the frontier and to defend the interests of the country."

The most widely searched for question so far in 2016 is: What is 'Brexit'?
Other popular questions searched on the internet include 'What is Brexit?', 'When is it?' and 'How does it affect me?'

Brexit is the short name for Britain's EU membership referendum which will be held on June 23. On one side are those who would like the UK to leave the EU. Richard Hewitt drove from Cheshire to Newcastle after arranging to meet what he thought was a 13-year-old girl.

Instead he was confronted by vigilantes at a flat on Raby Street, near Central Station, which had been the scene of other stings.

In court today he pleaded guilty to attempting to meet a child following sexual grooming after he admitted posting sexual comments on an internet chatroom where users believed themselves to be talking to a 13-year-old.

North Tyneside magistrates heard Hewitt travelled from Cheshire to the Newcastle flat following online contact he had with the girl, in which he sent her a sexual picture of himself.

The US-backed coalition of mostly Arab states began air strikes a year ago in support of Yemen's internationally recognised government.

Five Arab states are now fighting against Shiite Houthi rebels in Yemen, in a conflict with echoes of the Iran-backed Shiite group Hezbollah's 1982 campaign against Israel. In recent days, the Saudis have increased the number of strikes against the Shiite rebels who have taken over the Yemeni capital, and some experts say it is an indication of what is to come.

The United States supports Saudi Arabia in the conflict, but is not involved in the actual fighting.

text:
Cyclone Winston brought winds of over 320 kph (200 mph), torrential rain and waves of up to nine metres to Fiji last week, killing 20 people, according to the latest reports.

The cyclone was the first of its size to hit Fiji in 20 years and was the strongest tropical cyclone ever recorded in the Southern hemisphere, meteorologists say.

Thousands of people have been left homeless and many are without food and drinking water.

The cyclone ripped roofs off houses, and sent trees and power poles crashing through property. Roads and bridges are blocked and damaged.

text:
Changes at the DVLA follow a campaign by Jackie McCord, whose daughter was killed in 2011 by an elderly motorist who police had told not to drive.
Police previously had to write or fax a request for licence removal. They can now telephone or email.
The death of Colchester 16-year-old Cassie McCord led to 45,000 petition signatures for the change.
Cassie, who wanted to become a lawyer, was hit by driver Colin Horsfall on a pavement as she was on her way to college.
Three days earlier, Mr Horsfall failed a police eye test when he drove into the exit of a petrol station.
He refused to surrender his licence and police were trying to get it revoked when Cassie was hit.
Mrs McCord had wanted a change in the law - known as "Cassie's Law" - to give police power to remove licences.

text:
The Chinese lantern festival was held in the UK for the first time in London in 2015 but has been taken to Yorkshire for its sixth year, where the giant lanterns have transformed the Fountains Abbey and Studley Royal grounds.

The festival showcased giant Chinese animal lanterns including elephants, dragons, and butterflies, in order to illustrate the harmony between the natural and human worlds in traditional Chinese culture.

The colourful lanterns had become a popular feature in Chinatown around the world, and the festival aims to help people “bring light to the darkness of winter” while celebrating Chinese lantern art traditions.

The Chinese lantern festival traditionally takes place on the 15th day of the first Chinese lunar month, or the full moon on the first lunar month.

Learned's husband, actor Edward Asner, was also a friend of Ralph's and called him "a real nice guy."

Mr Udaltsov is charged with organising "mass disorder" during a protest in Moscow in May 2012. He was arrested on 8 August.

Mr Udaltsov says the charges have been "trumped-up." The police said he planned to overthrow the government and was preparing to overthrow the regime at a time of crisis.

His lawyer said the arrest was linked to his plans to hold a protest against the Russian authorities.

Mr Udaltsov and the other defendants have denied any wrongdoing.

"The goal is to silence and isolate me. It is an absolutely political motivation," Mr Udaltsov said.

Russian TV channels aired video of the arrest live on air.

China has refused to take part in the arbitration and warned that the case will damage bilateral ties.
The latest move comes a day after a Philippine ship evaded Chinese vessels to bring supplies to troops stationed on a disputed shoal.
China claims a U-shaped swathe of the South China Sea - creating multiple overlaps with areas claimed by the Philippines, Vietnam, Brunei, Malaysia and Taiwan.
The Philippines says that China's claims are illegal under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

He is not contesting this election - Defence Minister Joao Lourenco is standing for the governing MPLA party.
His main challenger is expected to be Isias Samakuva, from the MPLA's rival in the 27-year civil war, Unita.

text:
The depressingly toxic nature of internet conversations is of increasing concern to many publishers.  But now Google thinks it may have an answer - using artificial intelligence to filter out the worst excesses of human misanthropy.

Google has developed a system that uses artificial intelligence and natural language processing technology to filter out harmful and abusive comments on blogs and websites, and replace them with more constructive, useful or even complimentary remarks from other readers.

It’s an approach that the search engine giant has developed over the past several years. They say it is now sophisticated enough to make comments that would ordinarily be deleted by moderators useful and relevant.

The AI system examines a comment before it is posted. If there are any keywords and language patterns deemed likely to be offensive, the system flags it for review. A user can then either reject or approve the comment in the normal way, or choose to let the system replace it with an alternative suggestion.
paraphrased_text: Google has developed a system that uses artificial intelligence and natural language processing technology to filter out harmful and abusive comments on blogs and websites. It replaces comments with more constructive, useful or even complimentary remarks from other readers.

text:
A study, reported in the journal Science, has now shown that eels can use their electric organs to remotely control the fish they hunt with. The team that conducted the study believes that this is a rare example of a vertebrate using an electrical system to communicate with another creature. This may also help researchers uncover how a lot of fish evolved their own methods of communication, which they use to hunt.

The study was conducted by a team led by scientists from the University of California in Santa Barbara, the University of Vienna and the University of British Columbia in Canada. They found that as long as the eels can see their electric field in the water, they can use it to control the behavior of a potential prey species, known as catfish.

text:
Will we get the final word on the Higgs boson? And what is Nasa's next mission to Mars likely to turn up?
The BBC News website science team signs the office crystal ball out of the equipment cupboard to tease out the stories likely to make headlines over the coming year.
One news story we can bank on for 2012 is a definitive answer to the question: "Does the Higgs boson exist?" First proposed in the 1960s by English theoretical physicist Peter Higgs and others, the particle is a vital missing piece in the most accepted theory of particle physics. It is an essential and fundamental building block of the Universe, which explains why everything around us has "mass". Yet the particle has so far evaded detection by experiments.
But it can't hide for much longer. The Large Hadron Collider

It follows claims that the draft Wales Bill was confusing, and would leave Welsh ministers with fewer powers.
The bill will be delayed until summer to allow time for changes, Mr Crabb said.
But First Minister Carwyn Jones called it an "avoidable delay to clear up an avoidable mess".
Mr Crabb said he would shorten the list of powers kept back by Westminster, cut red tape over new laws, and better reflect Wales in the legal system.
The new legislation is supposed to settle constitutional wrangling by making clear which powers were to be devolved and which not.
It includes areas such as energy, transport and elections.
But Welsh ministers have criticised the draft Wales Bill, saying some aspects of it would see them with fewer powers.
