text:
The All Blacks were exceptional in the first half in Sydney and, with the help of three tries in seven minutes, stormed to a 22-0 lead at half-time.

The Wallabies showed spirit after the break, but the Kiwis held on for a memorable win.

New Zealand’s defence – in particular in the scrums, mauls and on the deck – was as good as it gets, with Australia scoring just once with their last play of the game.

For the home side, Will Genia and David Pocock were stand-out performers, while Australia also had chances to cross the line twice early in the second half, but failed to convert them.

The spending watchdog said the resources of Scottish Enterprise and Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE) were possibly being spread too thinly.

It also raised concerns about whether HIE has been properly focusing on “high impact” projects to drive local economies.

The critical report comes at a sensitive time with the Scottish Government in the middle of overhauling the national strategy to boost economic growth, while the Scottish Government has recently announced a “radical” review of business support.

Officials say the falcons were brought from Qatar by a member of its royal family without proper documentation.
Members of Gulf royal families routinely take falconry, an ancient sport in the Middle East, to the United States as a hobby.

But one such trip from Qatar last weekend is now causing some consternation, as it violated federal wildlife laws, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said in a press release Wednesday.

“An individual traveling on a Qatari private aircraft landed at an airport in northern California and possessed seven live and one dead raptors without permits, violating the federal Endangered Species Act and the Lacey Act,” the press release said.

The data follows a stronger than expected services sector figure, and points to consumer spending helping to compensate for ongoing weakness in other areas of the economy.
Economists have warned the recovery was likely to be bumpy, with the UK’s growth prospects facing a number of significant risks. The company has held the onshore licence since 2008 to drill in what is known as the Rathlin Basin, a geological area that stretches from Ballycastle in County Antrim to Limavady in County Londonderry.
The borehole it had planned would have been the second one to be drilled in the area by Rathlin Energy.
During their initial explorations they found a small amount of crude oil.

text:
South Lanarkshire Council has said it is satisfied that Errington Cheese Ltd now has the relevant controls in place.
The firm's Dunsyre Blue variety was linked to an E.coli outbreak last July in which a three-year-old girl died.
The company - which is now producing cheese under a revised food safety management system - disputes that its products were responsible.
The Carnwath-based firm's new season Lanark Blue cheese has now been put on the market.
A total of 11 people received treatment in hospital during the E.coli outbreak in the summer of 2016.
In September, Scotland's Food Safety watchdog, Food Standards Scotland (FSS), imposed a ban on all cheese produced by Errington. People were advised not to eat the cheese and to return it to the seller.
In January, Errington won the latest round of a court battle against the sales ban.

About 170 women were part of the ATA, which flew aircraft from factories to the RAF.
Ms Rose died last month while on vacation in Scotland, aged 95. Her service was held in Bampton.
She was born in Cambridge in 1920 and learned to fly at 17 having left school and joined her family's motoring business based at an airfield.

text:
Eve Doherty, a Dublin-based sergeant, denied harassing Elizabeth Howlin between September 2011 and March 2012.

Ms Howlin alleged she was subjected to "vicious, aggressive and vile" harassment by Doherty and her colleagues.

She told the tribunal that she was left in terror of going to work. She had been a serving member of the Garda Síochána for more than 25 years.

Doherty was charged with four counts of harassment contrary to section 4 of the Non-Fatal Offences Against the Person Act, 1997.

The charges followed a Garda Ombudsman investigation. She was suspended from the force on full pay.

#### Trial

She faced the three-week trial in Dublin Circuit Criminal Court. She was unanimously acquitted in March.

text:
Marcus Nash alerted birders nationwide after seeing the citril finch in Burnham Overy on Sunday morning.
The bird normally lives in South America, and is not usually seen in the UK.
It was reported by many birders to be in good condition on the day, and was last spotted on Monday afternoon.
Marcus, who has more than 15 years experience in wildlife photography, said: “It’s great fun to go to places and photograph a bird that is unusual.”
A lot of people from all over the country have made their way out to see it. I think it was a first for me too.
” A photograph of the bird appeared on the website ‘Norfolk Bird Club’ where people were able to identify the bird as a Citril Finch, and from there, an exciting journey started.

text:
Dyke presented his proposals aimed at improving the future of the English game to club owners and executives.
But Football League chief executive Shaun Harvey has dismissed the plans.
“I am not aware of anything more being proposed by Mr Dyke but there is no reason for us to comment further,” he said.

BBC Sport understands that Dyke has already met with the FA chairman Greg Dyke but the FA has yet to comment on the proposals.

Football League clubs have also rejected Dyke’s plans but it is still to be revealed whether the Premier League are in favour of implementing change.

Dyke’s proposals would see:

- The Premier League and the Football League merged into one 24-team division.
- The top division would be split into two after 20 matches.
- At that point, the current top six, plus the next four best teams, would play each other twice and the bottom

Anna Dugdale had held the post at Norfolk and Norwich University Hospital for six years.
In a statement, she said she took the decision to leave following "increasing demands and challenges in recent months".

Sue Hogg, deputy chief nurse and chief allied health professions officer at NNUH, will become interim chief nurse.

The 25-year-old was volunteering for a children's charity in Uganda when staff received news that a woman had died - leaving behind seven children.
The youngest was a baby boy who didn't even have a name.
With no-one to take care of him, he was given over to staff at the charity.
Emilie, from Leigh Sinton, Worcestershire, became the baby's sole carer and had sleepless nights looking after the boy, who became known as Adam.
Now, she is fundraising to help cover the costs of formally adopting the youngster and bringing him back to live in the UK.
She has received more than £15,000 in donations, with the majority being raised since her story was shared online on Sunday.

text:
Clough was granted permission to speak to Forest, for whom he played more than 300 games and scored 131 goals, last week after the club agreed a compensation package.

Sky Bet Championship leaders Forest have been without a manager since they parted company with Dougie Freedman in March following a six-game winless run.

Clough, 43, the oldest son of World Cup winner Brian Clough, who also won the European Cup twice with Forest, has been in charge at Northampton since December 2011.

A club statement read: "The decision has not been taken lightly, but having spoken to John and having the opportunity to put across his vision, we feel that the club is at a stage that we now need a new direction under the guidance of a new manager."

Clough will hold talks with Northampton's owner Kelvin Thomas on Thursday to discuss his future.

Richard Maycock, who taught at Caludon Castle School, is accused of three counts of sexual activity with a child by a person in a position of trust.

The former school teacher is alleged to have engaged in a sexual relationship between 1980 and 1984 with a male pupil who was then 13 to 17 years old.

The alleged offence took place at a local swimming pool.

Coventry Crown Court heard the 77-year-old had denied the charge but had been told he must enter a plea on a single charge.

Karen Whitmore was made redundant from her post as assistant director of organisation and governance at Middlesbrough Council in June.
Teesside Magistrates Court heard claims she was targeted for raising concerns about the sale of buildings for under the market value.
Ms Whitmore claims unfair dismissal.
The hearing was told of Ms Whitmore concerns over the council's sale of Grade I listed Acklam Hall.
She said that when she asked by external auditors to investigate the sale she was told officers had agreed a price reduction of £1.2m for the building.
Ms Whitmore was also told to hide the way it was handled because the then-mayor, Ray Mallon, did not want to be embarrassed, she claimed.

But there other factors at play.
The first is cities and towns have to pay for the privilege to host the Tour.
Yorkshire in 2014 paid £10m mainly through local councils, with central government putting in another £10m.

The controversial point for London was this money came out of the cycling safety budget and that angered cycling campaigners.
Also the Tour was supported by the then transport commissioner Sir Peter Hendy, who has now left TfL to join Network Rail.

Police described how the car "went airborne" in the wet conditions.
The driver walked away with just cuts and bruises.
The car went 50 metres down a bank and ended up in a field, where it turned into a fireball and had to be extinguished by firefighters.

text:
While they are as well known as Caerphilly Castle and Cardiff's Principality Stadium, the M4 tunnels at Newport may be the most controversial structures in the Welsh capital city.

The tunnel has been a talking point for many since the early 1990s, when planning permission was originally granted, but it's a project that has been plagued by delays.

In 2012, work began on the £837 million M4 relief road. It has been under development ever since, and its estimated completion date is now set for 2023.

What's in store for road users in the future? What changes can we expect to see? And how did we arrive at the project we see today?

These are just some of the questions you can find the answers to.

text:
Robert Fidler, 66, built the four-bedroom home near Redhill in Surrey in 2000 without the planning permission necessary to convert the barn into a house.

He then began selling the homes on eBay, but they were taken down after complaints from people living in the local area, who feared he was taking advantage of them by making them buy a "shoddily" built house.

One buyer has claimed he is living in a house with "rats and leaks".

But Fidler insists that there is nothing wrong with the houses, which he says are all sold to order, "and can therefore not be the subject of complaint".

text:
Milk teeth have been discovered in the fossil jaw of a juvenile Wareolestes rex, a species of mammal from the Middle Jurassic.
Scientists suggest adult females secreted milk on to a bare patch of skin for their young to lap up.
Nipples and suckling as seen in modern mammals had still to evolve when Wareolestes rex lived.
The two centimetre-long jaw was found on Skye in 2015 and is one of the most complete fossils of the early mammal to be found outside of China.
Single teeth of Wareolestes rex have previously been found in England.
Palaeontologists from National Museums Scotland in Edinburgh and the University of Oxford have been examining the fossil from Skye.
Using micro-CT scanning technology, they have identified milk teeth and, inside the jaw, adult teeth that had not erupted through the gums.
The scientists said

Researchers have identified milk teeth and, inside the jaw, adult teeth that had not erupted through the gums.

text:
Michael Hall, 51, told pupils at Parkside Community School, Chesterfield they had "nice legs" and made sexual innuendoes to female staff, including making jokes about their breasts, a disciplinary hearing was told.

Another teacher reported how Mr Hall had told him: "I am going to get you back" after he refused to take part in a joke.

Mr Hall, who was the head of year at the 1,300-strong school, has been excluded from the school staff for eight days after a conduct committee found "serious misconduct".

But he was cleared on all serious allegations brought against him by parents. One parent, who complained that her daughter was "too frightened to go to lessons", had claimed Mr Hall said her daughter was too short, had "little t***" and that it was "nice to have your mum there".

text:
Home Retail Group said that it began discussions with Wesfarmers in September, with a firm offer resulting in November.
Wesfarmers will pay 150p per share, which values the business at £1.4bn, as Homebase is sold for £340m.

text:
They were among dozens who flocked into Syria to fight against Bashar al-Assad's regime.
Since the Syrian armed conflict broke out in March 2011, around 440 French citizens have gone to fight in its ranks, in varying capacities, as members of both anti-Assad and jihadist groups, according to the National Centre for the Fight against Radicalisation and Terrorism.
This figure does not include people believed to have crossed into Syria who have not been officially registered.
Of the 440 French fighters who have been identified in Syria, 175 are still thought to be there, according to the centre.
On Tuesday, French authorities said that eight French fighters had been killed in Syria, and that four had been killed in Iraq.
Here is the story of some of the French who went to Syria to fight.

text:
The company said that about 700 of its "partners" in the US had been affected by the mistake.
Exposed data included social security numbers, photos of driver licences, tax forms and other details, according to news site Motherboard, which first reported the issue.
The error was discovered by the drivers themselves.
"Whoah - went to upload new insurance docs and the documents page showed me thousands of people private info (social security numbers, home addresses, tax info). I screencapped it and sent to support," wrote one driver on the discussion site Reddit.
It is not clear if anyone unconnected to the company was able to access the information before the problem was addressed.
"We were notified about a bug impacting a fraction of our US drivers earlier this afternoon," Uber said in a statement.
"Within 30 minutes, our security team had fixed the issue.
"We'd like to thank

text:
Former eight-division world champion Pacquiao, 37, had announced his retirement after beating Timothy Bradley in April.
But his promoter Bob Arum said last month that the Filipino boxer would fight again this year.
"Retirement doesn't suit Manny right now," Pacquiao's manager Michael Koncz told the Los Angeles Times.
"Boxing is in his blood. When he trains, it's like a pressure-release valve. You can see a dramatic difference in his mood... he's happy.
"It's amazing what training and fighting does for him."
Pacquiao and his team will meet on 10 August in Manila to discuss whether the bout against 27-year-old Vargas should be staged in Los Angeles or Dubai.
"That's the essence of the meeting," Koncz added. "Not choosing the opponent. That's already been done."
Pacquiao's unanimous decision win over Bradley was his first fight in nearly a year, following his much-publicised defeat by Floyd

text:
Avana Bakeries has sold its food processing site in Rogerstone to Food Utopia, which it said would aim to keep the current operation at the site running.

The site produces sandwiches, baked goods and savouries for supermarkets and convenience stores under brands including Cakes4U, Wraps4U, Caterbake and Bakerbake.

Avana said it had sold the Rogerstone facility, where it employs around 100 staff, because it was under “significant financial pressure” as a result of a “consistent decrease in sales”. The site had been in the ownership of Avana since its foundation in 2007.

In a joint statement, Avana owners Gary Fellows, chief executive, and David Jones, technical director, said: “Despite recent significant improvement initiatives, trading in the food processing division has been disappointing. We therefore took the decision

The three day competition, organised by the Tennis Foundation, will run from 6 July and will feature the 13 best men and women's players.
Both singles and doubles matches will be played before the Wimbledon events begin on 13 July.
"We've not previously had the opportunity to play competitive matches on grass ahead of Wimbledon," world number six Alfie Hewett said.
"This tournament will form a crucial part of my preparations as I aim to transfer my recent form on to the grass."

The figure for the south-western Bay region is the first official death toll announced during the crisis. The full impact of the drought on the country is still unknown.
Humanitarian groups fear a full-blown famine will follow.
Currently, almost three million people in Somalia face food insecurity.
Local news outlet Alldhacdo reported dozens of deaths due to cholera in the town of Awdinle, also in the Bay region. The disease is often spread due to lack of clean drinking water.
Somalia's President, Mohamed Abdullahi Farmajo, declared the drought a national disaster on Tuesday.
The drought in Somalia has been partly caused by the El Nino weather phenomenon which has affected east and southern Africa.
As well as the lack of food caused by the drought, there are many cases of dehydration.
Domestic animals are also dying in large numbers, and carcasses litter the landscape.

The trading update comes ahead of the final sale of the government's 15% stake in the 500-year old company.
Royal Mail said UK letter volumes declined by 5% in the quarter with revenue down 4%. But that was in line with forecasts.
UK parcel volumes were 3% higher and rose by 9% in Europe, with revenue up 2% and 8% respectively.
The company said its outlook for letter and parcel volumes remained unchanged from guidance issued with its annual results in May.
Royal Mail said it remained focused on cutting costs at its UK business this year.
It added that, as in all previous years, its performance would be weighted to the second half of the year given the dependence on its traditionally busy Christmas parcels delivery period.

17 May 2017 Last updated at 11:55 BST
Rio de Janeiro celebrates its 450th anniversary

Rio de Janeiro is celebrating the 450th anniversary of its founding, known as "Rio 450".

Ceremonies have included the planting of trees along with musical and cultural events.

The celebrations will continue into 2018, which marks the 150th anniversary of Brazil's abolition of slavery.

In 1565, Portuguese explorer Duarte da Costa discovered a sheltered inlet on the coast of Guanabara Bay.

He named it Rio de Janeiro, meaning "river of January", after it was discovered during his trip from Bahia in Brazil.

8 January 2015 Last updated at 08:44 GMT
Special crews experienced in working at heights will repair damaged roofing on more than a hundred properties in Scotland where the snow has been so severe.

Householders in Edinburgh and the Borders, as well as Orkney and Aberdeen, are among those affected.

Many of the properties are listed buildings and they cannot be repaired until the snow melts.

text:
The Welsh Government backed Kancoat despite being advised it was a "high risk" venture with a "weak and inconsistent business plan".

The Kancoat scheme was proposed as a way of stimulating the Welsh economy during the 2008 global financial crash and aimed to create 100 jobs through the production of waterproof coverings for cars, caravans and other large vehicles.

However, the Welsh Government's audit office has revealed that when it went to the Welsh Government’s enterprise agency to find out whether it could underwrite the loan they were told that Kancoat’s business plan was “weak and inconsistent”.

The audit office said that the Welsh Government's finance department did not follow procedures when it went ahead with the loan and that its decision to back Kancoat was "based almost entirely on the confidence that [Kancoat] would not default on its loans".

Ex-Liberty director Shami Chakrabarti is shadow attorney general and Keir Starmer, who left the team in June amid a wave of resignations, returns as shadow Brexit secretary.
But Dame Rosie Winterton, who had tried to negotiate between Mr Corbyn and many of his MPs, is out as chief whip.
Mr Corbyn's critics have suggested the reshuffle will fail to unify the party.
One senior figure said the reshuffle so far looked "vengeful and cack-handed", and Middlesbrough South MP Tom Blenkinsop accused Mr Corbyn of "seeking submission not unity".
Another MP, Neil Coyle, told BBC Radio 5 live that Dame Rosie's work during a difficult period for Labour had been "underestimated".

So far this year a powerful spy chief, the Nanjing party secretary and a top diplomat have been placed under investigation.
This suggests that Beijing wants to clean house of officials who may not be completely loyal to President Xi Jinping and his anti-corruption drive, experts told the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post.
A source from China’s security ministry told the Post that the head of one of the country’s largest secret intelligence outfits may have been targeted in an anti-corruption drive.
The head of the Second Division under China’s State Security Bureau, who oversees China’s counterintelligence and foreign espionage, is being investigated on suspicion of “severe discipline violations”, according to the report.

text:
Arthur Simpson-Kent, 49, stabbed Ms Blake to death along with their sons Zachary, eight, and Amon, four, at the family’s home in North Finchley, north London, on January 21.

A jury unanimously found him guilty of murder and two counts of murder.

Simpson-Kent had insisted in court that he did not kill Ms Blake and her children, and instead claimed they were killed by a “sinister and unknown force” that had taken over his mind and body.

“I don’t know how this happened, the police got the right man,” he said as he was led away from the Old Bailey.

He will be sentenced at a later date and faces life in prison.

Ms Blake was stabbed more than 50 times, while her sons suffered 60 blows and 113 separate injuries.

Prices briefly advertised online for holidays at the Hard Rock Hotel in the Canary Islands were too low, with the company later cancelling the promotions.

There was “no legal justification” for the “faulty” prices and Hard Rock will pay the affected customers for any expenses caused by the promotions that ended up being incorrect, the European Commission said in a statement.

It said that Hard Rock sold 658 holiday packages for stays at its hotel in the Canary Islands during the discount period, which was initially between 25-27 November last year.

The promotions were for “free” stays, meaning hotel rooms were offered for free and the cost was made up for by a higher priced flight option.

The Nigerian government is sending parents to Cameroon to attempt to identify the girl.
She told investigators in Cameroon she was one of 270 kidnapped in Chibok by jihadist group Boko Haram.
The abductions sparked international outrage and the #bringbackourgirls social media campaign.
While about 50 of the girls managed to escape, 219 of these girls remain missing. They were taken by the militants from the Chibok community in northeastern Nigeria.
Reuters news agency reported that one of two girls arrested in northern Cameroon on Friday carrying explosives claimed to be one of the missing Chibok girls.
The girls were arrested after being stopped by local self-defence forces in Limani near the border with Nigeria, the target of frequent suicide bombings in recent months.

They are being urged to tell the government what administrative tasks should be cut or scrapped altogether.
Launching the workload challenge for teachers, which includes a survey, the minister for schools Michael Gove said teachers were wasting an enormous amount of time on bureaucracy that was often created by politicians.
The survey is for teachers, unions, parents and others and asks for specific examples of administrative tasks teachers have to perform that could be cut or stopped altogether. The department also wants to know what information teachers actually need from school managers.
The survey is just one element of the challenge which will include talks with the profession, the creation of a new administrative centre at the department and new computer systems.
The challenge’s goal is to halve the amount of time primary teachers spend on administration and cut it by 30 per cent for secondary schools.

"Everybody is disappointed. We had 21 shots on goal, scored four and could have scored many more, and still lost," said Neilson. "There are no excuses, the ball is round and it went in their net. You have to put it away.

Hundreds of passengers flying with Ryanair, Easyjet and British Airways will continue to face flight cancellations until Tuesday.
Ryanair said a further 42 flights would be cancelled on Monday, and 195 will also be cut on Tuesday.
EasyJet cancelled up to 15 flights on Sunday, with another 15 grounded on Monday and Tuesday.
Flights to and from Paris have also been badly affected, after air traffic controllers at the city’s airports called a three-day strike.
Paris Charles de Gaulle airport advised passengers to check the website of their airline for up-to-date flight information.

text:
The fossil animal, which retains impressions of feathers, is dated to be about 160 million years old.
Scientists discovered the world’s oldest bird fossil, according to a new study. It is a feathered bird about the size of an American robin that lived 160 million years ago. The fossil is a feathered wing bone called the humerus. A group of researchers announced the discovery Tuesday in the journal Nature.
The fossil of the bird is estimated to be 30 million years older than the next oldest bird fossil, which was a humerus unearthed in China in 2017.
“If you could only find one bird fossil, you would want this to be it,” said Mike Benton of the University of Bristol, who wrote an accompanying commentary in Nature about the finding.
“This is the fossil I have been waiting for

"No job is big or small. Some may think what they do is insignificant, but I have found my destiny. It is to make wigs," says Mr Kumar.
"It's my very small contribution towards giving people, who are facing a grave illness, some hope and dignity," he adds.
Born in a farming family, Mr Kumar ran away from home at a young age to work with a film crew which assisted studios making Kannada-language films.
Working long hours as an apprentice, he learnt the craft of making natural hair wigs - a painstaking job where every strand is hand woven.

Doctors said the 82-year-old was bitten by a venomous spider, but non-poisonous bites can get infected, experts said.
"I would love them to take it off, it's so damn painful," said Mr Phillips.
He is due to have surgery at Kidderminster Hospital on Monday.

The Bees stay three points clear of the relegation zone, while the Owls remain two points adrift at the foot of the table.

text:
Geoffrey Mark Ball has a history of sexual assaults on women and is due to be released from prison.
The 44-year-old, who has lived in Middlesbrough and Wales, defrauded his victims and lied about his identity.
Cleveland Police applied for the sexual harm prevention order "due to the risk he poses to vulnerable females", they said.
Ball was convicted of indecently assaulting a woman in 1989 and jailed for six months.
He was sent to prison for four years in 2006 for grievous bodily harm.
Following a prison sentence in 2010 for sexual assault he was was put on the sex offenders register until 2017.
In 2013 a police manhunt was launched for Ball after he breached the requirements of the Sexual Offences Act.
He is due to be released from Holme House Prison in County Durham.

“When I’m at home I watch things on TV, the news, and it’s one of the first things I’ve seen," Commons said ahead of the match against Sweden.

"It just shows you what a great icon he was. You only have to look at the reaction from the fans in the stadium.

"I think it’s something that should never be shown to young children and shouldn’t have been shown before kick-off.”

The NW200 received Â£124,000 from Sport NI to carry out improvements.
More than Â£124,000 worth of improvements have been made to the North West 200 circuit.
The Department of Culture, Arts and Leisure has announced that the money was provided by Sport NI and was used to complete 11 safety initiatives at the 8.9 mile circuit.
The improvements included the upgrade of existing road surfaces, the installation of new crash barriers, the replacement of the existing electronic timing system and the development of spectator viewing areas.

The pair spoke to veterans and their families beside the annual display of more than 100,000 small wooden crosses, each one representing a Canadian soldier who gave his or her life in conflict over the years.

Snow fell lightly as they stood under a tent that had been set up, sheltering the crosses from the elements.

The Remembrance Day ceremony included a two-minute silence and the singing of the national anthems. A military aircraft did a fly-by overhead before the sound of a cannon boomed. The crowd then headed over to City Hall for an afternoon ceremony.

The snow had started falling before the ceremonies began.

text:
In tests on 1,100 patients affected by a rare cancer called sarcoma, more than half were born with gene mutations known to increase cancer risk.
The study, published in The Lancet Oncology, said the inherited mutations could become targets for treatments.
And families affected by cancer could be offered screening and advice.
Inherited mutations in genes linked to breast, ovarian and bowel cancer, among others, were found to be common in sarcoma patients.
The researchers, from The Institute of Cancer Research, The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust and University College London Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, said the results were revealing and gave a more detailed picture of how cancer risk is inherited.
Prof Ian Judson, who led the study at The Institute of Cancer Research in London, said: "We are going to need to think differently about inheritance.

text:
Of the 53 seats up for election, the Tories have won 23 and the Liberal Democrats have won 14.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats have each held 16 seats in Cornwall for the last four years.

However, the election was fought on a different ward system, which included a number of new and revised wards.

In the St Austell area, the Lib Dems will replace Labour as leader of St Austell town council, after taking seats in Truro, Bodmin and St Austell North.

They also took the seat in Tregony and Mevagissey from the Conservatives and replaced them with a new candidate for the first time in six years in the Parish of St Austell.

The Tories retained the St Austell East and Mevagissey North wards, and took the Bodmin East seat from the Lib Dems.

text:
Sarah McCann found the photo of Arthur Brown a couple of years ago as she worked in the Belfast city centre shop.
She told BBC Radio Ulster's Sunday News programme that the photo gave her chills, and that she simply had to find out more about the Belfast soldier.
"The first thing I saw was his face, he was so young. I was hooked," she said.
The back of the photograph had some clues to help her, as it revealed his name and his length of service.
Arthur Brown had sent the photograph to a woman named Ellie Dugan, who had written on it: "Arthur Brown aged 18, died of wounds.
"He had 13 months of service, gone but not forgotten by his good friend, Ellie Dugan."
"You could tell they really had a connection, he meant quite a lot to this woman", Sarah said.
"We've all really cared for someone in our life and to see this photo just sitting

Wenger, 67, was charged with verbally abusing and pushing fourth official Anthony Taylor after being sent off in the closing stages of Arsenal's 3-1 loss at Burnley.

The Frenchman is now facing a touchline ban for the next game, but has hit back at suggestions the charge was unwarranted.

text:
Jewish Human Rights Watch, an organisation set up to address a claimed rise in anti-Semitism in the UK, has won the right to be included on the register of ‘charities’ maintained by the Charity Commission. The Commission had previously rejected the application of the organisation to be recognised as a ‘charity’ as “there was nothing of a charitable nature about their purpose”. The Charity Tribunal ruled that, even if it has not so far been apparent in reality, the JHRW has the potential to do good work and so should be recognised for the moment on a ‘watching brief’.

This case is a warning to everyone in the voluntary sector, and especially the many organisations set up in 2009 in response to particular perceived needs. It is easy to underestimate the time and resources needed to formulate a constitution that meets the requirements of charity law and to draw up the necessary administrative and financial systems that satisfy the Commission’
paraphrased_text: Jewish Human Rights Watch has won the right to be included on the register of ‘charities’ maintained by the Charity Commission. In a speech at Def Con in Las Vegas he said the rise of artificially intelligent machines would not be a huge threat to humanity.

He also said it was “the responsibility of governments to develop the weapons first” and added that the world needed a “disarmament agreement” between nations to put off the arms race.

This warning comes just weeks after Google decided to stop developing artificial intelligence for military use because it does not want to help create “weapons or other technologies that cause or are likely to cause overall harm”.

Professor Hawking told an audience of hackers that the development of full artificial intelligence (AI), which could be “either the best or worst thing ever to happen to humanity”, was in the hands of a few people and institutions.

Kieron Flux went missing after a night out in the Val d'Isère resort. A search helicopter found his body in the Géante valley on Friday

French police say the body of a British skier has been found after he was reported missing last week in the Alps.

The Savoie mountain rescue service says it found the body of a 32-year-old man, identified as Kieron Flux, on Friday.

Flux had left his hotel to ski off-piste in the popular Val d’Isere resort, but was reported missing by a friend after he didn’t return.

The body was found in the Géante valley, about 620m (2,000ft) from Val d’Isere.

The cause of death was not immediately known.

Future Library was created by Scottish artist Katie Paterson and the writings will be kept in trust in Oslo, Norway.
One thousand trees have been planted outside the city for the paper on which the works will eventually be printed.

The US Senate passed the measures, part of a general aviation bill, on Tuesday in response to rising concerns about drone safety.
It proposes $100,000 civil fines and up to $250,000 in criminal charges for those who interfere with manned aircraft. Interference could include using drones to attack a plane.
The bill proposes an exemption for hobbyists flying drones weighing under 4.4 pounds or less, but the drone must be less than 400 feet away from the operator. The maximum fine for hobbyists would be $1000.
It would also allow for the use of remote sensing technology as an alternative to a visual sighting if an operator can use a “line of sight” camera. Previously, visual sighting was mandatory.
The Senate’s passage sets the stage for the House of Representatives to pass the

text:
Some 2.63 million new vehicles were registered in 2015, up about 6% on 2014 and the fourth consecutive year of growth, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said.
Stronger consumer confidence, special deals and cheap finance drove sales.
Registrations in December are thought to have been the best December figures on record.
It is thought that some 180,000 new cars were registered last month,
The previous record for sales in Britain was set in 2003 when 2.58 million new cars were sold.
Car registrations in the UK, Europe's second-biggest auto market after Germany, fell sharply after the 2007-8 financial crisis but have gradually recovered, returning in 2014 to pre-crisis levels at 2.48 million.

By training two space telescopes on a supermassive black hole with the mass of a billion Suns, they measured the strength of its ferocious winds.
The team also confirmed that these winds blow outwards in every direction, an idea that had been tricky to prove.
The work shows how such black holes can affect the evolution of their galaxies.
It was conducted by an international team of astronomers using the telescopes XMM-Newton and Nustar, run by the European Space Agency (Esa) and Nasa respectively.
"We know that black holes in the centre of galaxies can feed on matter, and this process can produce winds. This is thought to regulate the growth of galaxies," said Prof Fiona Harrison of the California Institute of Technology, Nustar's principal investigator.

Some 500,000 women in their late 50s were affected by the decision of the coalition government.
It added up to 18 months onto the start date of their state pension.

"I intended to stay in employment, but that came to an end at 61. I claimed Jobseeker's Allowance (JSA) and so far have applied for almost 4,000 jobs," she said.

A deal with the National Aeronautical Centre (NAC) in Wales will see aircraft tested for military or civilian use.
The NAC, based in St Athan, has secured a deal to become the UK’s testing centre, using a £20m (US$25.6m) government fund to help British companies produce new aircraft.
The NAC plans to provide aircraft, equipment and services, ranging from a simple simulator to airborne intelligence and surveillance.

“Testing is a vital part of the design process,” said NAC chief executive David Rowlands. “The need for a UK airfield to test aircraft designs and products is growing. We have an enormous amount to offer British industry.”
The airfield is owned by Cardiff City Council and operated by the Wales Aviation Academy. The NAC said that it is the first privately funded, independent test base in the UK.

The grounded yacht was safely re-floated at the same time by the local Harbour Master and RNLI lifeboat.

text:
A spokesman revealed that guidance was issued on 4 August.
He said the exact terms of the policy were classified.
The move comes days after the US Army ordered its own troops to stop using drones made by Chinese manufacturer DJI because of alleged "cyber-vulnerabilities".
It became illegal to fly personal drones within 400ft (122m) of the US's 133 military facilities in April.
The Federal Aviation Administration announced at the time that those who disobeyed the order would face financial penalties and possible criminal charges.
The watchdog has forecast that US-based hobbyists will own more than 3.5 million drones by 2021, and that there could be a further 1.6 million commercial models in operation.
The technology's growing popularity has raised privacy and safety concerns.
There have already been incidents in which members of the public have shot down drones flying over their own properties.
And

text:
Her fans may have noticed a sci-fi inspired theme in her recent performances and music, but now she wants to go a step further.

She's now trying to raise £400,000 to launch her own music-themed amusement park.

Jem was left a legacy by her late father, which included a 7.5 acre field, near to her home in Sussex.

She has already used it to stage a live concert and to record a music video but now she wants to use it as a permanent facility for fans.

Speaking to Sky News, she revealed the park would include a "musical rollercoaster" and have live music, as well as workshops for children.

If Jem manages to secure the funding, her new project will be called Jemfest.

- Watch Sky News live with the free Sky News app and smart TV apps

text:
David Brickwood, 74, died in hospital after being assaulted in Lindsay Avenue, Abington in the early hours of 2 January 2019.

Mr Brickwood was attacked just yards from his home following a dispute with two men.

He was discovered with serious injuries at about 2.30am by a passer-by who called the emergency services, but paramedics were unable to save him.

Two men were arrested later on suspicion of attempted murder, then later charged with Mr Brickwood's murder.

Mohammed Saeed, 33 and from St Helens, Merseyside, was sentenced to life in prison after he admitted murder at a hearing at Liverpool Crown Court in September.

text:
Foley, 42, died suddenly in Paris on Saturday before the Irish province's scheduled game against Racing Metro.
A statement on the province's website said: "It is with profound sadness that Leinster Rugby has learned of the death of former Leinster back-rower Tony Foley.

"Having left the Province in 2007 to take up a role as a coach with the Ireland national team, Foley was named Ireland's manager last year and also coached the Munster team to the Heineken Cup title in May.

"A fierce competitor on the rugby field, Foley was a member of the Leinster squad that won the European Cup in 2009 and played in five Heineken Cup finals.

"He was capped for Ireland on 62 occasions and played in two World Cups.

"Tony

After the eight week-old baby went missing, they were charged with her disappearance. Her mother was convicted of her murder.
She was released when evidence matched the dingo story but doubts lingered.

''Obviously we are relieved and delighted to come to the end of this saga,'' Ms Chamberlain-Creighton told reporters outside the courthouse.
''No longer will Australia be able to say that dingoes are not dangerous,'' she added. ''We live in a beautiful country but it is dangerous.''

text:
The sizes and weights of the creatures are recorded by zookeepers so they can monitor the creatures' health and well-being.
Baby koala weights are closely monitored by Australian zookeepers.
Baby koala weights are closely monitored by Australian zookeepers.

A BABY koala that weighed just 18 grams was born at Australia Zoo on Wednesday, a spokesman for the zoo said.

Zoo spokesman Matt Wright told 97.3 FM radio: “We’ve actually got to look at it three times a day to make sure that it’s not losing weight – not drinking as much milk – which is really the biggest problem with them when they’re so small.

“Koala joeys are a lot bigger and heavier than they were ten years ago.

“A lot of their weight comes down to the milk mum feed

Another finding of the study for Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE) was that women earned less than men.
This gender pay gap was wider than the average for Scotland.
The research by ekosgen into occupational segregation examined the situation in Argyll, Moray, Highlands, Shetland, Orkney and the Western Isles.
HIE published the study to mark this week's International Women's Day.
But the report has also flagged up issues for men. They were found to be attaining less higher level qualifications than women and were less likely to enter higher education.

text:
The 24-year-old, whose real name was Chris Hardman, was found in Lowestoft, Suffolk, on August 17, 2015.

An inquest into his death heard a post mortem said he had multiple injuries - including broken ribs, a collapsed lung, a fractured spine and head injuries.

He had been drinking on the day and had been taking steroids, and was in a "combative and delusional state" when he was found outside a hotel.

The court heard that police arrived when the hotel's receptionist called for assistance and found Hardman in a "violent struggle".

He was taken to the James Paget Hospital in Gorleston, where he died four days later.

text:
Azelle Rodney, 24, was travelling in a car that was stopped by police, who were looking for a group they believed were on their way to an armed robbery.
An inquiry last year chaired by Sir Christopher Holland ruled there was "no lawful justification" for the shooting.
The CPS has now made a decision to charge the man, identified only as E7.
The former police marksman will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court for a preliminary hearing on 10 September.
Mr Rodney was shot six times - in the arm, back and head - in Edgware in April 2005.
He was travelling with two other men when officers stopped the car and opened fire.
His mother Susan Alexander said: "I am very pleased at the CPS's decision to prosecute the officer who killed my son.
"I have waited a long time to see this

text:
The home side took charge early on thanks to James Alabi's penalty after Michael Ihiekwe brought down Evan Horwood - although the Owls' man was harshly judged to have deliberately handled it.

Horwood equalised from the spot before half-time after Ihiekwe had upended George Williams.

And in the 76th minute, the youngster scored what proved to be the winner with a crisp finish from close range.

Rovers had other chances, the best falling to Williams who saw a powerful drive parried by Owls keeper Lewis Price.

At the other end, Chris O'Grady headed over when well placed.

The win leaves Rovers in the play-off places with 24 points from 16 games.

Source: Team_Talk
paraphrased_text: Owls beat Rovers 1-0 at the etihad stadium on saturday. defender James Alabi opened the scoring from the penalty spot.

text:
A California court ordered German firm Bossland to pay $8.6m (Â£6.8m) to Blizzard for 42,818 counts of copyright infringement.
Blizzard had argued that Bossland had reverse-engineered and otherwise altered its games without permission.
It follows related court rulings in the UK and Germany.
Bossland had attempted to have the US case dismissed, but did not defend itself in court, according to the news site Torrentfreak.
It also faces having to cover about $177,000 of legal costs.
"The Bossland hacks destroy the integrity of the Blizzard games, thereby alienating and frustrating legitimate players and diverting revenue from Blizzard to defendants," the US games developer had argued.
The tools included the ability to see other players' positions, health scores and other information from a distance
paraphrased_text: A US court ordered German firm Bossland to pay $8.6m (£6.8m) to Blizzard for 42,818 counts of copyright infringement. Blizzard had argued that Bossland had reverse-engineered and otherwise altered its games without permission.

The record for the furthest-thrown "standard raw" sausage stands at 150ft and 6in (45.9m) and is held by Nick Alway, who also won this year's event.

text:
The writer and activist will run in the Southend West constituency in her first campaign to become an MP.
Last month, Ms Monkman was one of the speakers at the Extinction Rebellion protest in London, where protesters held up a 100ft inflatable sculpture of the Earth and brought Westminster to a standstill in protest at the lack of action on the climate crisis.
Earlier this year, she announced plans for a live music event at Glastonbury, which she had been due to take part in.
In a blog post explaining her decision to run for Parliament, she said: “When I announced that I would be cancelling my Glastonbury show earlier this year, I promised you that the Earth was still the top of my list, and that, in whatever way I could, I would continue to make your voice heard.

text:
Probably the most interesting stat for me was that regular pay - excluding bonuses - saw a 2.2% increase in February and a 1.8% rise in the three months to Feb. And for the first time since serious records began, that headline rise is the real rise - because CPI inflation is 0%.
It is striking that fears of employers significantly shrinking pay rises with the disappearance of inflation have not materialised: there is no sign in the UK of so-called bad deflation (which of course means the Bank of England remains on course to push up interest rates, rather than cut them).
Here is the thing: regular pay has been growing at a faster rate than inflation since last October, after years of lagging inflation. And what is more, pay rises in the private sector, which provides more than four-fifths of all employment, are even greater, at 2.6% in one month and
paraphrased_text: regular pay - excluding bonuses - saw a 2.2% increase in February and a 1.8% rise in the three months to Feb. And for the first time since serious records began, that headline rise is the real rise - because CPI inflation is 0%. and what is more, pay rises in the private sector are even greater, at 2.6% in one month and 1.8% in the three months to Feb.

The company said it would run the normal half-hourly service, which was replaced with buses, from Monday.
It comes the day after its parent company Govia Thameslink Railway (GTR) launched a consultation on a massive shake-up of timetables.
The direct services between Brighton and Seaford could be reduced from 2018.

Some services were later restored, including five in Transport Secretary Chris Grayling's Epsom constituency.

text:
"Stressed" Maggie May had to be sedated after getting wedged between the stairlift and a rail at her home in Helsby .

The 50-year-old poodle, who was rescued by the RSPCA, had to be removed from the house by firefighters when she became stuck on Wednesday afternoon.

She was taken to Chester Fire Station to be assessed before going on a trip to the vet's to be sedated.

Fire crews from Helsby and Kingsway were called to the property at 2.40pm.

Maggie, who weighs 10kg (22lb) and has "extremely long limbs", apparently got stuck in an upstairs bathroom where the stairlift was being temporarily used by her owner.

text:
North Wales Police are using DNA tests in a bid to solve 17 separate cold cases of unidentified human remains found in their area from 1968 to 2011.
It is known as Operation Orchid.
Tests have suggested a body found at Cable Bay, Anglesey, in 1994 could be that of Pauline Finlay who went missing on the Wexford coast earlier that year.
The Wexford woman disappeared while walking her dogs near the coastal village of Kilmuckridge in March 1994.
Formal identification has not yet taken place but North Wales Police have contacted her family about the results of their tests.
The force has submitted a file to the local coroner and an inquest will be held at a later date.
In a statement, North Wales Police described the recent development as a "significant breakthrough" in the 22-year-old case.
Most of the 17 cold cases under re-examination involve bodies found around the coast.
The separate cases are not being treated as crimes, but detectives want to identify the remains to

text:
The fee is already in place in some US cities, but will be rolled out across the country from August.
In other countries, including the UK and Australia, it is already mandatory for people to pay to throw their rubbish in the bins.
But US residents have been able to dump their rubbish for free – or sometimes for a small fee – for many years.

In July, the US will join countries such as Australia, where a pay-as-you-throw system has been in place for years, and the UK, which has adopted the system more recently.

It means American rubbish bags and wheelie bins must have a label to show how much has been thrown away, and the money collected must be used to pay for a permit.

It will also be mandatory for recycling to be collected, rather than thrown away, under the new legislation.

What’s the deal with paying?
People

text:
The Premier League leaders extended their winning run to 13 matches, but Liverpool and Arsenal remain in pursuit, with Manchester City out of the title hunt after their loss to Everton.

### 1. Liverpool’s winning streak ends in defeat by West Ham

Liverpool failed to win in the Premier League for the first time since April, and that run of 37 games was halted by West Ham, who took the lead early in the second half through Jarrod Bowen.

Mohamed Salah pulled one back for the reigning champions, but Liverpool were unable to find a winning goal and instead had a penalty appeal turned down before their 15-game unbeaten run was ended at Anfield.

### 2. Manchester City lose again in Everton win

Manchester City fell to their second league defeat of the season as Everton won 2-0 on their way back to the top of the

text:
Officers have been instructed not to exercise discretion, but issue tickets for speeding and seatbelt offences and for using a mobile phone, even though their use does not appear to have affected the safety of the road user.

“If you were to tell us that something isn’t a safety issue we might ask what is the problem with what we are doing,” the officer said. “We have been instructed by our political masters to do this. And if we are told that is the case and we continue to have the debate, you are wasting our time.”

The officer added: “We are taking a fairly robust approach to speeding, even if someone is in a car on their own. If that person does not want a ticket then that person should not be driving at the speed limit.”

Officers are being trained to “use their eyes” in a new police campaign against dangerous driving that has seen 1,8
paraphrased_text: officers have been instructed not to exercise discretion but issue tickets for speeding and seatbelt offences and for using a mobile phone. 'if that person does not want a ticket then that person should not be driving at the speed limit then that person should not be driving at the speed limit'.

text:
The RSPCA wants the Dangerous Dogs Act to be changed so dogs are banned on the basis of behaviour not breed.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) is calling for the Dangerous Dogs Act to be repealed and replaced with a Dog Control Act that prohibits behaviour not breed.

Currently, dogs can be killed or confiscated under the Dangerous Dogs Act for being inappropriately described as a banned breed - a Pit Bull Terrier, Japanese Tosa or Fila Brasiliero. But the RSPCA is now calling for the law to include a ban on all aggression in dogs and for police officers to be given powers of enforcement against aggressive dogs, rather than being used to enforce a breed law.

Dr Andrew Knight, Director of Animal Welfare Science, Ethics and Law at the University of Winchester, has been working with RSPCA
paraphrased_text: the Dangerous Dogs Act to be changed so dogs are banned on the basis of behaviour not breed. Currently, dogs can be killed or confiscated under the Dangerous Dogs Act for being inappropriately described as a banned breed - a Pit Bull Terrier, Japanese Tosa or Fila Brasiliero. but the RSPCA is calling for the law to include a ban on aggression in dogs and for police officers to be given powers of enforcement against aggressive dogs.

But until a dramatic stunt on 26 June involving a gun and a hardcover book that left Pedro dead, there was little indication in their videos how far they were prepared to go in order to attain online celebrity.
The couple from the US state of Minnesota had been uploading videos for less than two months documenting their everyday lives.
Though they had filmed some minor pranks - Monalisa dusting a donut with baby powder before feeding it to Pedro, for example - they seemed relatively harmless.
In one video filmed in a hospital, they learn their new baby is going to be a boy.
"Imagine when we have 300,000 subscribers," Monalisa pondered in a video uploaded at a fun fair on the day Pedro was killed. "People will be like 'oh my god, hi!'"

text:
Premises in Linlithgow, Cowdenbeath, Burntisland and Kincardine were targeted on Monday.
It is believed that two men entered The Bearded Baker on Linlithgow High Street at 9.45pm on Monday before threatening staff with a bladed weapon and assaulting the shop manager.

The two men fled empty-handed towards the back of the shop.

They are described as two white men aged in their late teens or early twenties, approximately 5’ 10” in height, slim to medium build. One was wearing a bright blue hooded top and the other was wearing a black jumper with a large white and red horizontal stripe, a black flat cap and a dark coloured hooded top.

Detective Chief Inspector Kevin Harkins of Livingston CID said:

“Officers are currently carrying out enquiries and we are keen to
paraphrased_text: two men entered the bearded baker on Linlithgow high street on monday. they allegedly threatened staff with a bladed weapon and assaulted manager. one was wearing a bright blue hooded top and the other was wearing a black jumper with a large white and red horizontal stripe, a black flat cap and a black flat cap.

text:
A remote demolition brought down the decommissioned site at about 06:00 BST in a unique operation using remote-controlled robots.
Ken Cresswell, 57, and John Shaw, 61, and Chris Huxtable, 34, were trapped under rubble on 23 February.
The body of Michael Collings, 53, of Teesside, was recovered.
The building - which was due for demolition when it partially collapsed - had been too unstable to be approached afterwards.
RWE Npower, which owns the site, said the demolition had "gone as planned" and all of the structure was brought down.
A spokesman said: "Now the building has been brought down, an inspection has confirmed the area and debris pile are safe and our contractors have resumed the recovery operation.
"We will continue working seven
paraphrased_text: remote demolition brought down the decommissioned site at about 06:00 BST. the body of Michael Collings, 53, of Teesside, was recovered. the building - due for demolition when it partially collapsed - had been too unstable to be approached afterwards.

text:
The first-time observation was made on 24 Themis, a huge rock that orbits almost 480 million km out from the Sun.
The researchers say that ice is not stable in such circumstances and has to be replenished by some means - perhaps from inside the object.
They tell Nature magazine the finding plays into the theory that much of the water in Earth's oceans was delivered from space.
"It's interesting that we have detected ice on an asteroid because there have been suggestions that water on Earth came from impacts with many asteroids in Earth's early history," said Professor Humberto Campins, from the University of Central Florida, Orlando, US.
"This detection of water-ice on the surface of an asteroid supports that idea," he told BBC News.
24 Themis is about 200km in diameter, making it one
paraphrased_text: 24 Themis orbits almost 480 million km out from the Sun. It is 200km in diameter, making it one of the largest rocks in the solar system. researchers say that ice is not stable in such circumstances and has to be replenished by some means - perhaps from inside the object. they say the finding plays into the theory that much of the water in Earth's oceans was delivered from space.

Deborah Stokes rang up to complain about criticism of her son's showing in England's World Twenty20 final defeat.
The two Radio Hauraki hosts had been discussing the last over of the final, when Stokes was hit for four sixes.
After being told she was off air she said she was "totally brassed off" about the hosts' "personal attack".
England all-rounder Stokes was hit for consecutive sixes by Carlos Braithwaite from the first four balls of the final over as West Indies became the first team to be crowned World T20 champions twice.
Stokes' mother Deborah, who lives in New Zealand where Ben was born and lived until he was 12, was put straight through to presenters Jeremy Wells and Matt Heath after calling in.

text:
Darren Manley stocked products with names such as King B, Cherry Bomb, Blow and Charly Sheen at his shop Red Eye on Oxford's Cowley Road.
They were described as research chemicals and herbal incenses.
He has now been handed a six-month suspended jail sentence by a judge at Oxford Crown Court, who also ordered £120,000 in fines and costs to be paid.
Oxfordshire County Council's trading standards team said the way the products were sold without health risk warnings was illegal.
The council started investigating the business in 2014 after doctors raised concerns about the products' effects upon people using them as drugs.
Jody Kerman, a trading standards manager, said the way the supposedly legal highs were sold meant they were not legal.
He said: "The products were labelled incorrectly and contained dangerous substances with no appropriate warnings
paraphrased_text: Darren manley stocked products with names such as King B, Cherry Bomb, Blow and Charly Sheen at his shop on Oxford's cowley road. he has now been handed a six-month suspended jail sentence by a judge at Oxford crown court. trading standards team said the way the supposedly legal highs were sold without health risk warnings was illegal.

text:
Salford won 19-18 in golden-point extra time to relegate Rovers at the Lightstream Stadium and secure their place in next year's Super League.

Tyrone McCarthy scored his second try five minutes from the end of normal time to give Rovers a 16-12 lead and put them within touching distance of safety before Josh Griffin touched down in the last minute to force the game into golden point.

Craig Hall had earlier cancelled out Jack Sowerby's try for Salford but McCarthy had crossed for the first time to make it 6-4 early in the game.

Ken Sio replied for Salford before the break before Sowerby's try put Salford in front on 47 minutes.

McCarthy's try looked as though it would be the one to keep Hull KR up but Griff

text:
Members of the RMT union in Penzance walked out at about 04:00 GMT and are also set to take 24-hour action on 6 November, in the latest in a long-running dispute.

RMT officials said the action was in response to Network Rail's "wilful breach" of agreements to make workers redundant.

RMT said "the situation continues to deteriorate".

It said the company had "actively sought to provoke a strike" and its conduct had "brought the whole process into disrepute".

Stations in Newquay, Truro, Par and St Austell will also be closed as part of the strike action.

##
paraphrased_text: members of the RMT union in Penzance walked out at about 04:00 GMT and are also set to take 24-hour action on 6 November. RMT officials said the action was in response to Network Rail's "wilful breach" of agreements to make workers redundant.

"We believe that we can keep our run and reach the play-offs, but it is up to us. It is in our hands now. We are three points off the play-offs, which is nothing," he told the club's official website.
"I have seen a big difference between League One and League Two. In League One, everything was a lot quicker. There was more quality, more speed, a better tempo of the game.
"However, I really enjoy playing for this football club and hopefully we can take three points off Port Vale and make the play-offs. We have a good chance."

The shrine is being built by Manoj Tiwary, a local film star, and will be opened to the public early next year.
Tendulkar retired from international cricket following India's victory over the West Indies in a Test in Mumbai last week.
Shortly afterwards he was awarded the country's highest civilian honour, the Bharat Ratna.
Many of his fans in India describe Tendulkar as the god of cricket.
On Tuesday, Mr Tiwary inaugurated the 5ft 6in (167cm) deity of Tendulkar amid prayers at the site of the proposed temple in Atraulia village in Bhabhua district in Bihar.
The idol of the star, sporting a blue jersey with the World Cup in his hand, is made of

text:
Imran Khan, 34, of Pendle Street in Accrington, Lancashire, admitted taking the girl from Nairne Street in Burnley on 26 March.
He also admitted intending to commit a sexual offence and breaching a sexual offences' prevention order.
Following the hearing at Preston Crown Court, Khan was remanded in custody and is due to be sentenced on 23 October.
Police said the girl was bundled into the boot of Khan's car before being driven to Scarth Lane in Hapton where he exposed himself and tried to force her to commit a sexual act.
Khan then dumped her in a wheelie bin before she later freed herself and was found wandering alone in distress by other children, the court heard.
Det Insp Jim Elston of Lancashire Police said it was a "horrendous" and "terrifying offence".
Khan was

text:
The visitors took the lead through Ryan Strachan's strike from outside the area.
Declan McDaid's first Cowdenbeath goal levelled things, but Peterhead were ahead again just two minutes later, Leighton McIntosh tucking in from close range following James Redman's pass.
Jack Beaumont's free-kick made it 2-2, but Nicky Riley teed up Jamie Redman to lash home from inside the area.
paraphrased_text: Cowdenbeath equalised just two minutes later. a corner from Leighton McIntosh made it 2-2.

text:
Lindsey Kushner QC said women were entitled to "drink themselves into the ground" but their "disinhibited behaviour" could put them in danger.
Judge Kushner made the courtroom plea as she jailed a man for six years who raped a girl he met in a Burger King in Manchester city centre last year.
But, Rape Crisis slammed her comments as "outrageous" and "misguided".
Yvonne Traynor, chief executive of Rape Crisis South East, said: "As a judge and a woman she should know better.
"The only person who is responsible for rape, is the rapist.
"Women are yet again being blamed for rape."
The judge spoke out as she retired from the criminal bench.
Judge Kushner, 64, said "as a woman judge" it would "be remiss" if she did not beg women to protect themselves from predatory men who ''gravitate''
paraphrased_text: judge Lindsey Kushner QC jailed a man for six years for raping a girl he met in a burger king. judge said women were entitled to "drink themselves into the ground" but their "disinhibited behaviour" could put them in danger. judge said it would "be remiss" if she did not beg women to protect themselves from predatory men.

text:
The Chamber was shot almost entirely in Wales and receives its premiere in Cardiff on Thursday night.
It is described as a "claustrophobic thriller" that has been directed by Ben Parker, whose previous short films include the BAFTA Cymru winner, The Tunnel (2011) and the 2013 Cannes Film Festival Official Selection, Shifted (2013).

The film is about a businessman (Phil Daniels), who is trapped and terrorized in a room by a stranger (Charlie Creed-Miles).

Speaking about the film at the premier event, Dan Clucas, producer said: “The Chamber is a chilling portrayal of a very human story set in our modern day world and is a reminder that everyone, however seemingly safe, can find themselves in a position of fear. We’re looking forward to showcasing the film
paraphrased_text: the film is about a businessman (Phil Daniels) who is trapped and terrorized in a room by a stranger (Charlie Creed-Miles) the film is described as a "claustrophobic thriller" that has been directed by Ben Parker.

text:
Sounds out of this world, right?
A black hole is a dying star that has collapsed inward from its own weight.
The pull of gravity from its centre becomes so strong that even light can't escape, which is why it looks black.
Our local supermassive black hole is called Sagittarius A* and lies more than 26,000 light years away.
Well, there was a LOT of teamwork involved.
Eight observatories from all over the world were linked together electronically to form one giant virtual telescope called the Event Horizon Telescope (or EHT for short).
Michael Bremer, an astronomer and project manager for the EHT, said the telescope is powerful enough to spot a golf ball on the Moon!
For the best chance of zooming in and focusing on the black hole, the astronomers waited for good weather.
Then they spent five nights recording data.
All of the data is being collected and flown to the
paraphrased_text: a black hole. a supermassive black hole. the Event Horizon Telescope (or EHT). The EHT is a virtual telescope. a golf ball on the Moon! EHT. EHT. EHT.

text:
Judges overturned a theft conviction against Roman Ostriakov after he stole cheese and sausages worth €4.07 (£3.54) from a Lithuanian supermarket.

Ostriakov, 32, was sentenced to 12 months in a local prison in 2018 after a panel of three judges found him guilty.

A report from the Office of the Prosecutor-General of Lithuania said that the judges’ decision was based on unproven facts.

On Tuesday, the Court of Appeals overturned that verdict, ruling that Ostriakov, a Russian citizen who was granted refugee status in Lithuania, had been wrongfully accused.

Ostriakov reportedly has no previous criminal history.

Lithuanian law forbids prosecutors from appealing convictions or acquittals. This is why they issued the report
paraphrased_text: Roman Ostriakov, 32, was found guilty of theft in 2018. he was sentenced to 12 months in a local prison in 2018. a panel of three judges found him guilty of stealing cheese and sausages worth €4.07 (£3.54) from a Lithuanian supermarket. on Tuesday, the Court of Appeals overturned that verdict, ruling that Ostriakov had been wrongfully accused.

text:
Richard Sharvin, who was believed to be in his 70s, died after the accident that involved a tractor took place close to Strangford village on Friday.
Police attended the scene along with officials from the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) who will lead the investigation.
South Down MP Margaret Ritchie said people in the area were in "deep shock" after the death of the father of two.
"I want to offer my deepest sympathies and condolences to Richard's widow and to his daughters," the MP said.
"The local community will stand shoulder to shoulder with them in their tragic loss."
Ms Ritchie added: "Richard was a very upstanding member of the community - loved his farm, loved farming enterprise and he was very
paraphrased_text: south Down MP says people in the area are in 'deep shock' after the death of the father of two. police attended the scene along with officials from the health and safety executive (HSE) who will lead the investigation.

Tahir Alam from Park View School told BBC Radio 4's Today programme there was no segregation of boys and girls or assemblies supporting Al-Qaeda.
"We're shocked by so many false allegations," said Mr Alam.
But local MP Khalid Mahmood said schools had changed their practices because of so much scrutiny.
"They realise they are being focused on and significantly changed their attitudes, changing the way they hold assemblies," said Mr Mahmood.
The MP for Perry Barr said that the conflict had arisen because there had been efforts to turn a non-faith school into a "religious school".
Mr Mahmood told BBC WM he had received complaints that in some schools, where there had been allegations of extremism, children were learning radical views that conflicted with their parents.
"The real issue here is how you start to groom these young people away from the philosophy of their parents and towards the philosophy that some teachers

Rebecca Burger's death was announced on Facebook in what her family called a "domestic accident".
A warning against the faulty dispensers was also posted to her Instagram account, saying it "exploded and struck Rebecca's chest, causing her death".
French media reported she died of cardiac arrest after the incident, despite medical attention.
The popular fitness and travel figure was well-known in France, with some 55,000 Facebook fans and 154,000 followers on Instagram.
One of Ms Burger's family members took to Instagram, warning readers not to use the dispenser, saying that tens of thousands of "defective devices" remain in circulation.

text:
Fell, 22, who had surgery in October for testicular cancer and missed the start of this season after chemotherapy, scored an own-goal in the final minute as the Baggies lost their unbeaten home record.

Villa have now taken seven points from the last nine and boss Di Matteo said: “The goal we conceded was unbelievable.

“We had control of the game and could have gone 3-0 up, but we made a big mistake. Fell’s a great lad and one of the nicest people I’ve met in football. We had to move him back to get his game time up and he’s done well, but that’s an error that can’t be tolerated.

“A player doesn’t know when he is going to make a mistake. I told him I was disappointed, but he shouldn’t take it personally.”
paraphrased_text: villa lost 3-0 to the victors at the emirates on saturday afternoon. defender Fell scored an own-goal in the final minute of the game. the 22-year-old had surgery in October for testicular cancer. he missed the start of this season after chemotherapy.

text:
The ship was greeted with fireworks and cheers from a crowd that had gathered at the Cocoli locks to celebrate.
The Panamanian President, Juan Carlos Varela, described the waterway as a route that would unite the world.
The president thanked the nearly 30,000 people who had worked on the canal's expansion.
Construction on the new lane for the canal, which runs for 77km (48 miles), began in 2007 and was due to finish in 2014.
But strikes and disputes over costs delayed the $5.2bn (£3.8bn) project.
Panama Canal expansion prompts safety concerns
The original Panama Canal was first used in August 1914. It was built by the US and handed over to local control in 1999.
The expansion allows a new, much-larger generation of container ships to pass through the isthmus.
Some 35 to 40 vessels transit the waterway everyday.
Panama hopes the expansion

text:
Philippe Lamberts said MEPs could move from the French city to their other building in Brussels, Belgium.
His suggestion came as MEPs are deciding on where their new parliamentary session will take place. The building has been closed since March due to the Covid-19 pandemic.
Lamberts told the BBC’s Europe Editor Katya Adler that MEPs were already meeting virtually because “there is no physical meeting taking place at the moment.”

The 17-member European Parliament group Lamberts leads called for talks with EU leaders.

French politicians have warned that Strasbourg’s position is not guaranteed, citing the health risks associated with it.

The European Parliament building in Strasbourg was one of several places affected by the riots.

text:
Eligible food bank users in Cardiff who have pre-payment meters will be given vouchers for gas or electricity.
It will enable them to have lights and heating on for around two weeks.
The fuel bank will be located at Cardiff Foodbank and run by npower and anti-poverty charities The Trussell Trust and National Energy Action.
Rebecca, a mother-of-four who had to give up her job as a qualified beauty therapist to support her eldest child, was the first recipient of the fuel bank voucher in Wales.
"Without the help of the food bank and fuel bank, I would not have had electric for a week and would have struggled to feed my children," she said.
"I often have to borrow from my father to help me pay the bills - he has mental health problems and I worry about the extra stress this

text:
Another Israeli was wounded in the attack in Halamish. The Israeli army says the attacker was shot and caught.
The attack came near the end of the day’s prayers and on the heels of last week’s truck attack on a popular tourist spot in Jerusalem that killed four Israelis and left 17 injured, and a pair of attacks in May in the West Bank that together left seven Israelis dead.

Rabbi Ahiad Ettinger was fatally stabbed in his home in the settlement, and is believed to be the head of the settlement. A tenth suspect, Salman Abedi, who was the suicide bomber, died in the attack itself. Seven have been arrested, two of whom have been released without charge and four are still held under police bail.

In the immediate aftermath of the attack, the Metropolitan Police Service urged anyone with any information about Salman Abedi to call the anti-terror hotline. However, two days after the bombing, the police stopped taking calls and have instead asked the public to go to their nearest police station with any information.

Videos have autoplayed on Facebook’s News Feed for some time, leading to a curious rise of “silent movies” as publishers adapted to knowing that the majority of viewers would be watching, but not listening, to their work.
But between now and the end of the year Facebook’s News Feed will be enabling sound on your News Feed by default, a move the company has been testing out on a limited number of users for a short while.
The firm said it had received “positive feedback” so far.

In a statement carried by KCNA news agency, the country's top military body said the "high-level nuclear test" and more intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) tests were possible in response to an unprecedented series of large-scale war games by the United States and the South.

North Korea, in a statement through its state media, accused the United States of "reckless provocative acts" aimed at staging a "surprise preemptive nuclear strike" on the North.

The US military drills with South Korea that kicked off in late March and ended Thursday involved about 300,000 U.S. and South Korean troops. The exercise involved an unarmed B-52 flight by the U.S. military. The North saw the move as a sign that it was in the US nuclear strike crosshairs.

The council calculated the GFO has a 100% return on investment and that the city gets £2.86 back for every pound invested in the film office.

Party leaders took to the streets from Dumfries to Inverness, while the SNP became the latest party to launch their election manifesto.

On what may end up being the last of the hustings, the SNP pledged to invest £23m in high street regeneration in the event of a majority at Holyrood.

They also promised £450m in support for the oil and gas industry.

With days to go until election day, party leaders were doing the rounds of rallies and events, while some took to the streets.

Nicola Sturgeon visited a café in Dunfermline, while Alex Salmond walked down George Street in Edinburgh with a marching band.

text:
The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) said the H5N8 strain of avian flu has been found at Grange Farm in Redgrave.
Public Health England said the risk to public health from the virus is very low.
Gressingham Foods confirmed the birds will be culled, even though none of them currently has avian flu.
The strain was detected in the environment, rather than the birds.
The discovery follows investigations after avian flu was discovered on a separate poultry farm near Redgrave last month.
The premises will be cleansed and disinfected to reduce the risk of further spread, Defra said.
A 3km protection zone and 10km surveillance zone are already in place following the previous case.
The Food Standards Agency said bird flu does not pose a food safety risk for UK consumers.

Nisbet the eland was born at Blair Drummond Safari Park near Stirling to parents Limba and Bud on 6 August.
It is the first time in 25 years that an eland, the largest species of antelope, has been born at the safari park.
She has been named after Scottish international high jumper Jayne Nisbet on account of the eland's jumping skills.
Park manager Gary Gilmour said: "She is very lively, especially in the mornings.
