text:
Frank Le Villio was 19 when he was arrested by the Germans in Jersey in 1944 after taking a "joyride" on a German soldier's motorbike.
Historian Stanley Keiller began researching his story for a talk about his own occupation experience.
He tracked him down to a pauper's grave in Nottingham.
Mr Keiller said: "All the motor vehicles were confiscated; you can imagine a keen youngster couldn't resist the temptation to give a German bike a spin, they had no humour in them at all".
After the war Mr Le Villio made his way to Nottingham to live with his father, but died one year later of tuberculosis aged just 21, according to Mr Keiller.
The historian, who now lives in Devon, was looking into the story of Harold Osmond Le Druillenec, who survived Bergen-Belsen.
Mr Le Duillenec mentions Frank Le Villio in an account
paraphrased_text: historian Stanley Keiller began researching his story for a talk about his own occupation experience. he tracked him down to a pauper's grave in Nottingham.

text:
Exxon Mobil ended down 1.6%, adding to losses struck last week after it reported second quarter earnings halved. Chevron shares lost 3.3%, also extending last week's losses by 2.2%.
The Dow Jones fell 0.5% to 17,598 points.
The S&P 500 was down 0.3% to 2,098 points, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq also shed 0.3% to 5,115.
Oil fell to the lowest level since March as traders worried about signs of weak demand and increasing supplies.
Brent slid 4.7% to $49.74 a barrel and US crude fell 3.8% to $45.34 a barrel.
"The slowdown in China feeding into a slowdown in Asia, and the question becomes how much of that is feeding into the US?" said Quincy Krosby of Prudential Financial in Newark, New Jersey.

The Museums Association’s guidance on capital project management was produced by the association’s project management committee to help museums manage capital projects, from the point of inception through the planning process to completion. It includes a template for a business case for capital projects, a glossary of project management terminology and a checklist of legal requirements for capital projects.

"There is a small minority of people who set out to exploit the high demand for popular events," a government spokesman told Newsbeat.
But the official line is that while buyers must be protected, people should have a way of selling unwanted tickets.
The campaign Put Fans First is trying to get the government to change how sites like viagogo and StubHub work.
Tickets to sold-out gigs and sporting events are usually still available to buy on similar sites but often at a much higher price.
The campaign group doesn't want to ban them but says it wants to make the process more transparent.
For example, they want resellers to have a say about who they've bought the ticket from and what its face value is.

When I questioned him during the only live television debate on Sunday Politics (Sunday 12 February, still available on the iplayer) I reminded him that UKIP's 'unique selling point' was no longer unique. The Conservatives were a Brexit party too these days, and they were in a position to deliver it.
"Stoke Central is Brexit Central and it wants a true Brexiteer", he told me. "That's me".
So how does that square with his declaration, at the moment of his defeat in the early hours of Friday morning, that Stoke Central was only seventy-second on his party's 'hit list' of target seats?

The book about her dramatic escape in 1995 became a best-seller in India and was made into a Bollywood film in 2003.
Ms Banerjee had recently moved back to Afghanistan to live with her husband.

Staff across all departments in Treforest, Newport and Cardiff are affected by the proposed redundancies.
The cuts represent a 20 per cent reduction in the workforce.

The university said that the redundancies were due to a series of “financial challenges” it faces, including falling numbers of Welsh students. It has also suffered from reduced cash in the public purse.

The university said that the proposal “is necessary to ensure the ongoing financial stability of the institution, particularly as it moves towards becoming an independent university next year.”

If the 45 redundancies are approved, they will follow recent job cuts in the department of law, social science and languages.

Davies-Okundaye trained in Adire, a traditional indigo-dyed cloth worn by women in south-western Nigeria, and Aso-Oke, a traditional weaving style common in the Yoruba region. In 1977, she established an art center in Oshogbo, Osun state, to preserve and propagate African culture through art and craft, especially the techniques and styles that were fast disappearing. She is one of the first African women to open a gallery.

Okundaye’s pieces draw heavily from the rich visual symbolism found in the Nigerian environment. They often feature geometric patterns derived from Adire cloth designs and traditional Yoruba weaving patterns. Her work depicts images of the market, the village woman with her cooking pot and traditional utensils on her head, men at work in the field, religious images and dancers at festivals. Prof Mike Richards has contacted health watchdog Monitor over his concerns.
A Care Quality Commission (CQC) inspection between 30 June and 4 July 2010 highlighted many problems at the Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust in the management of the end of life care of cancer patients.
In a letter to Monitor, Sir Mike outlined his grave concerns about the way in which Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust has handled patients, their care and their relatives.
He said there has been a lack of candour with patients and their families over the prognosis for patients and a failure of staff to communicate with patients in a clear and appropriate way.
There were also problems with how and when drugs were administered to patients and how their symptoms were managed.

Perfect Strangers was made as a test run during preparations for making a feature-length romantic comedy, Journey Bound.
The 26-minute short will be given its first Scottish screening at Glasgow's Southside Film Festival next month.
Perfect Strangers was shot at locations on Rannoch Moor.
The comedy was made by Bafta-nominated director Ryan Hendrick and David Newman.
With actors Kenny Boyle and Clare Sheerin in the lead roles, the short features music from Scottish-based singer-songwriter Jack Henderson's debut album.
Hendrick said: "We are thrilled that our little film is finally returning home for its first Scottish screening after a successful few months on the festival circuit.

Just when you thought this election could not get any stranger comes the news that George W Bush could be voting for a Democrat. And not just any Democrat.
The revelation came from Texas land commissioner and Trump supporter George P Bush who suggested at a small Republican gathering that his grandfather George HW and uncle George W could both be casting ballots for Hillary Clinton.
Rumours that Bush Senior was a secret supporter of the wife of the man who beat him in 1992 have been circulating for a few weeks, after he reportedly spilled the beans to a member of the Kennedy clan. The 92-year-old was apparently not impressed by Trump's mockery of his son Jeb in the primaries.

Mohammed Awad, 56, and his wife Hasma Awad, 47, died in the early hours of Friday at a house in Manchester.
Three girls and one boy, aged between 10 and 17, and a man are all stable in hospital after the fire in Parsonage Road, Withington.

He also praised people who helped save the children's lives.

text:
But what does Germany owe Greece, if anything, and why?
The Nazi occupation of Greece from 1940-44 was brutal, murderous, and destructive. The German army killed Greek civilians in mass, public executions. It imprisoned Greek men in forced-labour camps. It used Greek children as human shields. And it destroyed a once flourishing economy and education system, among other things, through war, looting, and repression.
Today, Greece still bears the scars of German occupation. An estimated 25,000 people were killed, many more tortured, and Greece was devastated and its society wrecked.
To put it plainly, the German army killed and tortured innocent Greeks. If Germany owed a debt to Greece it was not just money; it was justice and an apology.

text:
Newcastle City Council refused planning permission to the development near Kenton School in September 2014.
McDonald's had launched an appeal but has now withdrawn it after the council changed its planning policy.
Hundreds opposed the restaurant saying it would encourage children from the school to eat unhealthily.
A McDonald's spokeswoman said the firm was made aware the authority had amended its policy to take into consideration the proximity of certain businesses to schools, meaning the plans no longer adhered to planning guidelines.
"We have withdrawn our appeal as a direct consequence. We are genuinely disappointed and frustrated by this development at such a late stage," she said.
The company claimed the new restaurant would have created about 70 jobs and made a "positive contribution" to the area.

Lord Harris said he was "frustrated" by the lack of action after his review of self-inflicted deaths among 18-24-year-olds, submitted over six months ago.
The report said rehabilitation was failing and recommended more help for young inmates, including from family.
The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) said the report was being considered.
A spokesman said the MoJ would "respond in the autumn".
A "self-inflicted death" is defined by the MoJ as a suicide or "accidental deaths as a result of the person's own actions".
Lord Harris's report - Changing Prisons, Saving Lives - was submitted to the Ministry of Justice in April then published in July.

text:
Five other sailors were injured in the crash involving the guided missile destroyer USS John S McCain.
Officials are also conducting a "comprehensive review" of the Pacific fleet following Monday's incident.
It was the fourth crash involving a US Navy ship in a year, and the second in the past two months.
Navy Adm John Richardson, the chief of naval operations, said in a statement: "This trend demands more forceful action.
"As such, I have directed an operational pause be taken in all of our fleets around the world."
The pause, which will be staggered across the fleets, will last one to two days and could begin within a week, he later told reporters.

Researchers examined the aftermath of same-sex sporting events and found that men spent longer talking, touching or embracing their opponents than women.

They suggested that their findings indicate gay people may be perceived as less masculine, and could help explain why gay athletes often have difficulties with the heterosexual community.

Researchers examined the aftermath of same-sex sporting events and found that men spent longer talking, touching or embracing their opponents than women

The study, reported in the journal Evolution and Human Behavior, involved showing videos of sportsmen shaking hands, exchanging a pat on the back or hugging to heterosexual participants.

A gecko is about the largest animal that can climb using this method.
They hope the study could help in the development of new adhesive substances.

It's a mix - part economic fundamentals, part market emotion as herding investors follow each other down a negative spiral, fearful of being left beached as the tide goes out, and part brute market forces, the major trading houses looking to make a profitable turn on share prices which they bet are not going up any time soon.

text:
Alexander McDonald, 27, admits carrying out the fatal attack but denies murdering Catherine McDonald, 57, in their home, in the St Mungo's area of Glasgow in April 2011.

Advocate depute Robert Weir QC told the court that police were called to the home after they received a 999 call from Mr McDonald who said he had killed his mother.

The prosecution claim Alexander McDonald hit his mother on the back of the head with a table lamp before going into the kitchen and pulling out a chef's knife which he used to stab her.

He then took his mother's body to their back garden and set the house on fire in an attempt to destroy the evidence.

Mr Weir told jurors the killer later went to a local police station and handed himself in after saying: "My name is Alexander McDonald. I've killed my mum."

Aviation data analysed by BBC News uncovered the routes and airports where customers faced the worst punctuality.
On average, passengers missed connecting flights on international journeys because flights were not on time.

## Most Delayed Flights In Australia

- Brisbane is the most delayed airport in Australia, with only 69% of Qantas flights departing on time during 2018.
- Melbourne Airport is ranked second most delayed with 71.6% of Jetstar domestic flights departing on time.
- Sydney Airport was ranked third with only 72% of domestic flights departing on time.
- Adelaide has the best record for on time departure in 2018 with 79% of all flights taking off on time.

Some 1.3m housing association tenants in England are to get the right-to-buy their properties (the right to buy is being phased out in Scotland).
Mr Clark said the bill, in Wednesday's Queen's Speech, would allow people to fulfil their home-owning aspirations.
But critics say it will make the housing crisis worse.
Council tenants have had the right to buy the homes they live in at a discount since the early 1980s.
The scheme was given a boost in 2012, with bigger discounts and the then housing minister Grant Shapps promising that for "the first time, every extra home sold will be replaced on a one-for-one basis".

Sixty staff were made redundant on Thursday due to cashflow problems.
The company from near Dumfries had about 140 employees when it went into administration last month.
Mark Ranson of administrators Armstrong Watson said a delay in the receipt of funds from customers meant the staff could not be kept on.
"The administrators have been seeking recovery of those funds from customers, and will continue to do so," he said.
"All staff affected will be kept informed and payments will be made as soon as funds become available.

About 50 bikers caused chaos on 31 October when they brought a major route into Leeds to a standstill and rode dangerously through the city centre.
Two men, aged 27, and one, aged 23, have been arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to cause public nuisance.
Nine men and a woman who were previously arrested remain on police bail.
Meanwhile, Leeds City Council has been granted a five-year extension to its county court injunction banning similar events.
More on this story and others from Leeds and West Yorkshire
The injunction allowed officers to stop ride outs planned to take place before Christmas and on New Year's Eve, police said.

More than 300 people were forced to flee a blaze that broke out in the Angeles National Forest on Friday.
A separate fire that swept over a major highway, forcing people to abandon their cars, calmed down overnight.
Light rain brought wetter air later on Saturday and helped the teams fighting the fires.

Two people were injured from the effects of smoke inhalation from the fire that broke out on Interstate-15, the main road linking Los Angeles and Las Vegas.

text:
The internet giant said it would open the 310,000-sq-ft Dunstable site in the autumn.
Central Bedfordshire councillor Nigel Young said it was an "important milestone" in the area's regeneration.
The centre, at Prologis Park in Boscombe Road, will be the company's ninth in the UK, and the second in the East of England.
Councillor Young said the new centre would benefit from local transport improvements which form part of the Conservative-led authority's wider regeneration efforts.
Amazon's UK operations director John Tagawa said the firm looked forward to the new site playing an "integral role" in the business.
"Over the last two years, we have added well in excess of 2,000 new employees to our UK workforce and we are delighted to be able to create a further 500 permanent jobs at our new Dunstable centre."

A sharp increase in air fares, due to the earlier timing of Easter, was the main reason behind the rise from February's rate of 1.4% to 4.1% in March, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics.

The data for March, released on Wednesday, comes after a period of stability in the measure of inflation. The consumer prices index, a closely watched measure of inflation used to assess the rate of change in the cost of living, hit a four-and-a-half year high of 5.2% last September before falling to 3.6% in February.

Just a year after it opened for business, the popular restaurant in Moscow's Gorky Park has been forced into a radical image change.
Gourmet shellfish are just one of many things that have vanished in Russia since President Vladimir Putin banned fresh food imports from those countries that blame him for the crisis in Ukraine.
"We had to explain to our guests that there'd be Russian meat and fish now, instead of oysters," shrugs Ilya Sokhin, revealing his restaurant's more prosaic new menu.
Beefburgers, beetroot soup and blini have replaced the snails and seafood once rushed straight from Paris to Mr Sokhin's smart Moscow table-tops.

Buses and coaches have transported thousands of migrants from the Hungarian capital Budapest  to the Austrian border, with others travelling by train. Hungary said on Saturday that its bus service to the border had been a one-off measure, however.
When they reached the border, migrants waited to board buses to a train station in the Austrian village of Nickelsdorf.  Hungary has said it is pressing ahead with plans to tighten border controls despite temporarily relaxing the restrictions.
Austrian police officers helped people board trains in Nickelsdorf, with some picking up young children. From there, many headed to Vienna.

text:
Under Secretary of State for Transport Claire Perry was answering East Anglian MPs' questions on service performance.
Network Rail said suicides were a sensitive issue but had made progress in reducing the number of such incidents in East Anglia in the first nine months of the 2018/19 financial year.
A spokesman said: "In the last few years, Network Rail and others have made significant progress in reducing suicide rates.
There were 22 suicides in the region in the first nine months of the year, down from 26 last year and 29 in 2016/17.

A spokesman for the rail company said: "Suicides are a tragic and sensitive issue.
"We work closely with the Office of Road and Rail and the Samaritans as part of the rail industry's commitment to reducing suicides.
"We're continuing to implement our strategy

Thomson started his third spell at Easter Road last week having negotiated his release with Dundee's Paul Hartley.
"I'm delighted to have got him back," said Hibs boss Neil Lennon after signing him on a six month deal.

"Steven has played 270-odd games for us already and has a lot of experience of playing in Europe in the last couple of seasons.

"His return gives us a few more options in midfield, particularly if we are in Europe as well as the Scottish Cup."

Thomson, who has been ever present this season for Dundee, said that he was looking forward to getting started at Easter Road.

The Villans head to Burnley on Saturday looking to record a fifth straight win in all competitions.

A previously secret file from the 1980s briefed Margaret Thatcher on Sir Peter Hayman's "sexual perversions" - just three months before he was unmasked as a paedophile.

The Prime Minister was told that Hayman, deputy chief of MI6 at the time, had been investigated for possessing material including obscene drawings of children.

Hayman, then in his fifties, "did admit his homosexuality" to his superiors after the MI5 began spying on him in 1981.

But MI5 told the Prime Minister that the former High Commissioner to Australia "repeatedly denied" that he was a paedophile.

He had told the security service that he was attracted to boys "only over puberty and after" but this had "not been proved".

The hashtag #ShakeItOffJalene took off after 4-year-old Jalene Salinas's family shared a Facebook video of the little girl rocking out to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off" to celebrate her first day of kindergarten. It turns out that Jalene and Taylor have a lot in common, though, even if they're nearly 20 years apart — both singers love cats.

While Jalene may be more of a dog person (she even brought her cat along on her journey to school), Swift's favorite pastime is playing with her own cat, Meredith, who she's brought with her on tour. GP Alisdair MacNair said he was aware of a number of medical groups using WhatsApp to discuss patients.
Use of the app for medical purposes had “increased significantly” since the General Medical Council issued a statement on the subject, said the BMA.
He said the use of social media by doctors could be a “grey area”, as the GMC guidelines only applied to private accounts – not group chats.
The GMC statement said: “It is always important to be mindful of patient confidentiality and the potential risks of confidential information falling into the wrong hands.”
BMA Scotland vice chairman Alastair MacLennan said: “Doctors are increasingly using apps such as WhatsApp to share information quickly and easily, for example to organise rota swaps, arrange patient transport and discuss patient care.

Tiny broaches pinned to the chests of 3,000 supporters flashed red-white-and-blue in the midday sun at the funeral of a man who was a symbol of hope to millions of Venezuelans for their country's future.

President Nicolas Maduro joined hundreds of thousands to say goodbye to Leopoldo Lopez, once one of Venezuela's most powerful men as mayor of Caracas.

"You are the nation's son, Leopoldo," Maduro told the cheering crowd. "Leopoldo is a symbol of Venezuelan patriotism, a symbol of freedom and democracy."

The Mark IV tank, on which the replica is modelled, was first used in warfare in the Battle of the Somme on 15 September 1916.
With 57,000 casualties on the first day it is regarded as the bloodiest day in British military history.
The tank will be in position in the square until 11:00 BST.
David Willey, from Dorset's Tank Museum, which has provided the machine, said: "The British Army sent its new 'secret weapon' into action - and it did so in order to prevent the sort of casualties experienced on that first day of the battle."
Designed to travel at walking pace (3mph) to support the infantry, the plan was for 32 tanks to be involved in the first attack, but only 18 saw action because of mechanical failure or difficulties with the terrain.

LetScotland - the Association of Professional Letting Agents in Scotland - said it would provide "a voice for honest, ethical, professional letting agencies in Scotland".

The organisation's stated aim is to provide tenants in Scotland with a safer renting experience.

Membership fees will apply; the fee structure has yet to be announced, but an AGM is scheduled for early November.

LetScotland also says it will work to increase the number of Letting Protection Schemes operating in Scotland, and to give landlords more choice when it comes to insurance and redress schemes; it also aims to provide landlords with a forum to discuss current issues.

Officials from the Irish Rugby Football Union will join representatives from the Northern Ireland Executive and Irish Government to outline their plans to jointly host the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

The meeting will take place ahead of a visit by World Rugby chairman Bill Beaumont to Dublin and Belfast later this week to get an insight into the respective proposals put forward by England, France, Ireland and South Africa in their bid to host the tournament.

The joint Irish proposal is the first time the competition has been hosted by joint administrations of the sport.

"We are confident our joint Ireland bid can win the trust of the global rugby family," said IRFU CEO Philip Browne.

The Chinese firm's latest model is a crop-spraying drone, which it claims is "40 times more efficient" than manual spraying, despite having just 12 minutes of flight time.
It will be released in China and Korea where hand-spraying is more common.
DJI made $500m (Â£332m) in drone sales in 2014 and some analysts predict the firm will hit $1bn in sales this year.

The foldable device is also dustproof, water-resistant and made of anti-corrosive materials, the firm says on its website (in Chinese).

Now, she has welcomed a daughter, Harper, who was born by surrogate in the USA.

Samantha is the UK's oldest lesbian to have a baby.

She used a clinic in San Diego - but it was far from plain sailing.

Experts have linked the text on both the front and back to themes in the author's novel Mansfield Park.
The fragment was stuck to a letter discovered in a first edition of her memoirs, written by her nephew, James Edward Austen-Leigh.
The revealed text is part of a sermon apparently composed by her brother, the Reverend James Austen in 1814.
The book and letter, written by Jane Austen's nephew in 1870, had been held in a private collection but was recently bought for an undisclosed sum by the Jane Austen museum in Chawton, Hampshire.
Very few examples of Jane Austen's handwriting survive - there are no manuscripts of her famous books and many of her letters were destroyed after her death.
A team at West Dean College near Chichester, West Sussex, succeeded in unsticking the fragment, allowing the previously unseen writing on the back to be deciphered.

Ironically, I doubt that anything is going to stop the new elections taking place, the fact that they are unlikely is not a reason not to hold them.

In the UK, the Queen is elected but that election is fixed, so it is very unlikely that she will be elected more than once.
He stressed that the new rule is likely to remain in place for the next two years and it is therefore very unlikely that there will be another general election before the term expires.
It was unlikely that I would go back to my office this afternoon, and I had told my wife.

In the UK, the Queen is elected but that election is fixed, so it is very unlikely that she will be elected more than once. Ironically, I doubt that anything is going to stop the new elections taking place, the fact that they are unlikely is not a reason not to hold them.

In a TV interview on Sunday, Mahfouz Saber said judges were "lofty and have status" and had to come from "a respectable milieu".
The son a rubbish collector "would get depressed and would not continue" if he was appointed a judge, Mr Saber warned.
Thousands of people took to social media to express anger at his comments.
In those few words, Mr Saber encapsulated the system of patronage and privilege that brought so many Egyptians onto the streets back in 2011 to bring down Hosni Mubarak and the status quo, says the BBC's World Service Middle East analyst Sebastian Usher.
His dismissal is a small victory for Egyptian liberals but also a bitter reminder for them of how little the system has changed, he adds.

text:
A First Nations group filed a complaint about it with the Canadian Human Rights Commission in 2007.
Child welfare systems on reserves receive more funding from the federal government than their provincial equivalents.

For the past decade, the Cree Nation has been lobbying Ottawa to stop discriminating against its children by withholding services.

"Federal laws and the federal bureaucracy have to change," said Ethel Blondin-Andrew, who chairs the provincial child welfare agency. "It's just that simple."

Blondin-Andrew's comment in a recent Toronto Star article about a case in which the Cree Nation's child welfare agency is trying to bring four aboriginal kids home to Waskaganish from Alberta, where they're living in foster care, is a sentiment that's been echoed many times by child welfare advocates and First Nations leaders.

Parliament had helped enable a "terrorist state" to emerge by voting against military intervention against the Assad regime in 2013, he said.
Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said Assad had been left "to do his worst".

Jeffrey Blue told the court Newcastle United's owner reneged on a promise to pay him a multimillion-pound sum.

Mr Blue, 47, who was Newcastle United's director of football before being dismissed in December 2009, claimed Mr Ashley, 46, told him: "I'll pay you what I've got to pay you. You're a smart f*****g businessman, go and do the deal."

The pair had discussed a transfer for West Bromwich Albion midfielder Kevin Nolan and Mr Blue said it was on the back of that conversation that he went ahead and completed the deal, worth around £8 million.

Some groups walked more than 100 miles (170km) to reach the island off the Northumberland coast.
Each group had been raising funds for different charities, the BBC reported.
Six groups of hikers set off from 20 UK cities on Monday, walking along well-trodden coastal paths to reach Holy Island.
Holy Island – known as Lindisfarne to locals – is accessible by a causeway which becomes covered by the sea at high tide.
The last group made it onto the island on Tuesday at about 6pm.
Those taking part had hoped to be reunited on the same day.
Holy Island’s priory was founded in 635AD.

text:
Researchers in New Hampshire suggest the 180km-wide Chicxulub crater in Mexico was carved out by a smaller comet than previously thought.

The Chicxulub impact is thought to have caused mass extinctions of marine organisms 66 million years ago and possibly the destruction of dinosaurs.

But the exact size of the impactor has been debated.

The new analysis, published in Nature Geoscience, finds the comet was 7-8km across.

Until now, scientists have argued that the Chicxulub impactor was around 15km in diameter.

The reason for this large spread of estimates has to do with the way in which researchers have tried to reconstruct the crater – based on the pattern of ejecta or rocks blasted out of the impact event.

She later became a successful businesswoman, working for Rolls-Royce for over 40 years, eventually as a director. Andrew Bedford, 27, from Huntingdon in Cambridgeshire, was last seen at 18:20 BST on Saturday in London Road, Witchford, near Ely.

Police divers were seen searching the Great Ouse in Witchford on Sunday and Monday, while police helicopters also carried out searches.

Mr Bedford’s family described him as “lively, charming and generous”.

Det Con Paul Fawcett, from the Cambridgeshire Specialist Operations team, said: “Our searches were carried out alongside other enquiries including reviewing Andrew’s mobile phone records.

text:
The very future of the African elephant, the largest land animal on Earth, could be at risk.
Last year saw the highest number of elephant poaching since records began, according to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).
In 2011, 34,000 elephants were killed for their ivory, compared with 17,000 the year before.
The figures are in CITES's latest report, which highlights the increasing threat to the world's wildlife as demand for ivory grows in some Asian nations.
"We are deeply concerned. We are worried by the trend ... there is clearly a huge increase in the number of seized ivory," the CITES secretary-general John Scanlon told the BBC.

text:
Wales has 735 of the councils handling over Â£43m of public money but only an estimated 30% received qualified audit opinions on their last accounts.
The warning comes as community councils are being asked to take on more services by cash-strapped county councils.
The auditor has had to warn some councils for "serious weaknesses."
"The accountability and scrutiny that comes with the use of public money is growing ever tighter," said Huw Vaughan Thomas, the Auditor General for Wales.
"Community councils are responsible for over Â£43m worth of funds and are likely to be devolved more responsibilities."
Community councils represent the first tier of local government in Wales, and are equivalent to parish councils in England.
They can hold the purse strings for local community buildings, parks, cemeteries, allotments and toilets.

text:
The army has been deployed to rescue thousands of stranded people after two days of heavy rain.
At least 188 people are now known to have died in floods in Tamil Nadu state since last month.
A depression in the Bay of Bengal has triggered rains in coastal areas.
Last month, non-stop rain for nearly a week brought the city to a standstill.
Two days of fresh rains have again led to massive flooding, so much so that flights from the city's airport have been indefinitely suspended after flood waters entered the runway and tarmac areas on Tuesday evening.
Reports say some 400 passengers are stranded at the airport, and all flights have been cancelled.
More than a dozen trains have also been cancelled after flood waters inundated the tracks.
The army and the National Disaster Response Force have been deployed in the city's worst-affected southern

text:
Selahattin Demirtas and Figen Yuksekdag are accused of spreading propaganda for militants fighting the Turkish state.
They were among eleven detained by the anti-terror authorities on Friday after an investigation against the party's senior leadership.
They both deny the accusations.
The two were detained on terrorism-related charges on Friday as part of a crackdown on alleged supporters of the Kurdish rebel group the PKK, which is a terrorist organisation for the EU and US.
Turkey has been increasingly under fire from rights groups and EU leaders in recent months, and the arrests further heighten fears over freedom of speech, as well as the rule of law, in the country.
Earlier this week, Mr Erdogan announced he was ending the EU-backed refugee deal in response to Germany's call for the arrests.

text:
After defeating Dundee 5-0 on Friday evening, Celtic knew any points dropped by the Dons would ensure a fourth straight championship.
Ronny Deila has secured the league title and the League Cup in his first season in charge of the club.
"We have achieved a big thing," Deila told his club's official website.
"Hopefully there will be more and more.
"Defensively we have been unbelievable the whole season and we have hardly conceded a goal. Offensively we have been getting better and we scored five beautiful goals against Dundee on Friday night.
"We have worked so hard for this and finally we are there and can start thinking of next season. There is always high pressure here and I put high demands on myself as well.

text:
Substitute Vincent Aboubakar swept in the winner two minutes from time, flicking the ball over defender Ali Gabr and thumping it home.
Nicolas Nkoulou had earlier equalised for Cameroon, rising highest to power in a header on the hour mark.
The equaliser cancelled out Mohamed Elneny's opener on 22 minutes with a beautifully taken near-post strike.
The wild celebrations for Aboubakar's winner announced Cameroon's return to the continental summit, after a 15-year wait.
It also makes them the second most successful nation in the competition's history - behind Egypt - and marks the first time they have beaten the Pharaohs in the final in three attempts.
Besiktas striker Aboubakar ran towards the triumphant Cameroon fans in the Stade de l'Amitie stands in Libreville to celebrate, pursued by delirious team-mates

text:
The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said output slumped in the run up to the European Union (EU) referendum.

The fall was caused by a sharp downturn in manufacturing output as Britain's factories and metal production came to a halt in the run up to the Brexit vote.

Output in the manufacturing sector plunged 1.4% in May - worse than most economists predicted. Economists had predicted a fall of 0.4%.

The figures come the same day David Cameron resigned from Number 10.

The ONS said construction output plummeted 3.7%, following a downwardly revised 1.3% contraction in April.

Matthew Fell of the Confederation of British Industry said: "These figures reinforce the mixed picture of the UK economy, with the Brexit vote taking a toll on manufacturing and construction activity."

"

Two people who were travelling on the microlight are feared to have died.
The Ikarus C42  disappeared after leaving City Airport in central London, and is thought to have plunged into the North Sea.

A rescue helicopter, the London Air Ambulance, four lifeboats, and police and lifeboat teams are at the scene.

The pilot, a 49-year-old man, and his passenger, a 46-year-old woman, were travelling to Dundee.

A spokesman for the Maritime and Coastguard Agency said they were notified at 1.49pm that the aircraft had crashed at 1.35pm.

He said the emergency services were searching for them.

Brayden Dillon was asleep in his family's Sydney home in April when a masked gunman allegedly broke in and shot him in the head.
Conrad Craig, 26, was arrested earlier this week and charged with murder.
A 30-year-old woman was charged with murder on Wednesday, the same day Brayden's family held a vigil for what would have been his 16th birthday.
Police have described the shooting as "execution style" and said it happened after the gunman had entered the home and threatened Brayden's mother.
The teenager's stepfather and young step-siblings were also in the house at the time.
The woman will appear in a Sydney court on Thursday.

Eight of the so-called "K6" boxes will replace modern ones following a Â£25m revamp of Hull city centre

The K6 boxes were designed by Sir Giles Gilbert Scott, who was also responsible for Battersea and Waterloo power stations, and the red telephone box is recognised as one of the UK’s most iconic designs, said British Telecom (BT).

The first of eight red telephones boxes were installed yesterday (26 July) to coincide with the opening of the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee.

It comes after a revamp of the city centre as part of the Â£25m Hull Townscape Heritage Initiative, which is backed by the Heritage Lottery Fund.

The installation was carried out by BT in partnership with Heritage Englands, the Hull City Council and Hull Culture and Leisure Ltd.

The recipient was Ross Martin from Alaska who ordered the headset when pre-orders opened in January.
Mr Luckey said he wanted the "satisfaction" of delivering the first Rift headset.
On 28 March, the consumer-ready Rift headsets should start to reach people who were among the first to order it in January.
Before now the only versions of the headset available were made so developers could familiarise themselves with the software and hardware in the device. The consumer-ready Rift has improved lenses and electronics to make VR as immersive as possible.
Mr Luckey said it was important to him to hand over the headset given that he had been involved in its development since 2009.
"I'll be damned if some random delivery guy is going to get the satisfaction of delivering the first Rift," he told game news site Polygon. "That's mine."

text:
Ethiopia's Tedros Adhanom said the two nations have chosen to swim rather than sink together, AFP news agency reports.

"There is an unbreakable unity among us," he said. "Let me say with great pride that we have chosen to swim rather than sink together," he said.

Dr Tedros Adhanom was elected as the head of the World Health Organisation in May.

At least 300 people were killed when the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) collapsed at its construction site on Monday, leaving about 350 people injured.

Ethiopia's Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn also visited the site of the tragedy.

"The people who died in this incident will not be forgotten. Their names will never be forgotten. The sacrifice of their lives will forever remain in our hearts as a great honour for our country."
paraphrased_text: Ethiopia's Tedros Adhanom said the two nations have chosen to swim rather than sink together. "There is an unbreakable unity among us," he said.

Several videos of women driving have been posted online despite official warnings that women who took part risked sanctions.
Some women received warning phone calls from men purporting to be from the interior ministry.
But one woman who took part said she had faced no reprisals.
"I went to the grocery shop near the house... there was a reporter with me," Mai al-Sawyan told the BBC from Riyadh.
"Personally I know three other women" who also drove, she said.
"No-one approached me," she said, adding she was hopeful that the ban would be lifted soon.
But one leading activist - the university lecturer Aziza al-Yousef - said she had decided not to take part in the protest drive after being called by the authorities.

The eurozone is expected to grow by 1.6% this year and 1.4% in 2017.

The European Commission's autumn economic forecasts painted a mixed picture for the single currency bloc.

The eurozone is forecast to grow 1.6% this year and 1.4% in 2017, the lowest among a group of major economies.

It says they often fall through the cracks as they are not at crisis point.
Ministers say their social care reforms will improve support.
Based on Freedom of Information requests from 141 local authorities in England, the report says: "These children have needs that are too great for schools, health or other universal services to meet on their own, but they are not eligible for support from statutory social care services.
"Our research suggests many are living in challenging family situations, affected by issues like domestic violence or substance misuse.

Prime Minister David Cameron said Khan had been plotting "specific and barbaric attacks".
He added the "act of self-defence" was lawful.
Mr Muthana said: "I think they are on a hit list. They're targeting everyone now.
"I ask the prime minister not to target them but if they have evidence I don't mind, they deserve it...but I don't think they are involved in attacks on the UK."
He added: "I think the prime minister is hiding something. He's making excuses.
"They just want to intervene in Syria.

The park encourages the public to catch and send in spiders so it can use them to produce anti-venom.

"There might be one at a museum, but this is the biggest one we've had in our venom programme," Mr Collett said.
A "good Samaritan" had handed the spider in at a local hospital, which acts as a collection point for the Australian Reptile Park's venom milking programme, he added.

"He is denying the case," his lawyer Betina Hald Engmark told reporters following the court session, adding that it was "surreal to see him in the cage".

"He did not show the physical stress that he had been in fear for his life. He was in such a calm state," she said.

Australia's electoral office organised polling booths at each of the country's three Antarctic stations.
Opinion polls suggest Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull will beat Opposition Leader Bill Shorten when the official poll is held on Saturday.

Worcestershire Acute Hospitals NHS Trust said it had a backlog of 22,000 letters, from 10% of its 220,000 patients who had been discharged since the start of the year.

The trust has been overwhelmed by a huge backlog of paper correspondence - the majority of which are the dreaded letters telling patients they have cancer.

Health chiefs say the problems began following the closure of the letter delivery department earlier this year, but they have now hired new staff who have been trained to deal with sensitive correspondence.

However, as the scale of the problem was only identified by the end of March, it will be months before the backlog is cleared, says Worcester Acute Hospitals NHS Trust.

text:
The Scottish government acted after an inquiry into a serious Clostridium difficile (C. diff) outbreak.
Regulations have required all Scottish hospitals to make sure that they have systems in place to prevent the spread of C. diff and other healthcare-associated infections (HAIs).
These requirements are set out in Part II of the Healthcare Associated Infections (Scotland) regulations 2016 and a guidance document – Preventing the spread of Clostridium difficile in healthcare facilities: guidance for healthcare settings.

The regulation requires all providers to have systems in place, appropriate to the particular circumstances of the service, to prevent the transmission of healthcare associated infections (HAIs) including C. diff.
This requires:
- A system of screening for colonisation of patients with C. diff and, where available, an antibody test to detect immunity in healthcare workers;
- Appropriate cleaning

County Durham's Bowes Museum secured money from the Art Fund, Heritage Lottery fund and private donors.
The museum will work in partnership with galleries in York and Bristol.
The government had placed an export bar on the "distinctive painting" last November while a buyer was sought.
York Art Gallery and Bristol Museum and Art Gallery will work with the Bowes Museum to deliver "a diverse and exciting activity programme surrounding the painting".
Adrian Jenkins, director of The Bowes Museum, said: "During the 15th century, Netherlandish paintings were admired all over Europe for their visual sophistication, imagination and invention, and those by Bouts and his workshop were no exception."
Netherlandish artworks were usually painted in oil, often depicting religious scenes or small portraits with richly detailed backgrounds.

The museum will work with the Centre for Archaeology at Durham University to uncover the remains beneath the building.
The museum's grand staircase was destroyed in a fire 70 years ago and the centre's chief executive Simon Thurley has now called for public help to restore the museum.

text:
The provision is for an expected penalty over the sale of financial products linked to risky mortgages before the 2008 financial crisis.

The group is expected to pay more than £5 million in a settlement with the FCA.

It comes after HSBC admitted it had also manipulated foreign exchange rates (FX) and attempted to rig benchmark rates around the world, between January 2006 and January 2013.

"We deeply regret past actions.

We have worked hard to put in place systems, processes and people that help us to serve our customers well while meeting our regulatory obligations," the company said.

A spokesman for the Bank confirmed it would not comment on whether Lloyds Banking Group had been fined but said the bank was "fully committed to putting our customers at the heart of everything we do".

It’s the biggest stadium of the tournament with 51,000 seats and is home to the Japan’s biggest domestic club, the Yokohama F Marinos. In fact the stadium was specially built for the F Marinos.

The capacity is only a third of that of the national stadium in Tokyo that will host the tournament finale on July 12 but this game is no lesser.

With both teams looking to get their tournament campaigns off to a winning start, this has the makings of a very intriguing clash.

text:
The 11 September 2001 attacks killed almost 3,000 people in New York, the Washington DC area and Pennsylvania. It also killed something else—the reputation of the US intelligence agencies. Despite the 9/11 report saying there were 22 ‘missed opportunities’ to stop the attacks, the US government insisted on an ‘intelligence failure’ being behind the attacks.

The truth was much darker than that.

The ‘failures’ were not due to any intelligence agency’s failure to pick up information, or failure to share information. They were due to deliberate, criminal non-reporting of critical intelligence information.

In 1999 a man named Abdul Bary had been identified as a possible suspect who may have links to terrorism. He lived in a small town near Hamburg, and worked as a chemist for a company which supplied pharmaceutical raw materials. The man

The Croft Blend Fine Old Scotch was taken to France by Cpl William Mill in 1914 but was never opened and has remained unopened and un-decanted ever since.

The whisky bottle was a gift from Mill's brother. William Mill's nephew David, has decided the whisky is safe to be opened, decanted and tasted at the National War Memorial in Edinburgh Castle where he will be present with members of the Mill family.

The unopened bottle was stored in an oak box which contained a leather-bound family Bible - it has been estimated it could be worth thousands of pounds because of its history.

David Mill said: "The family is very excited about sharing a wee dram of whisky with the country's servicemen and women. It was a surprise that it had been left undrunk and the family's pride in that has never left us."

His

Reuters news agency says the firm built special software last year to comply with a classified request.
"Yahoo is a law abiding company, and complies with the laws of the United States," the tech firm said in a statement provided to the BBC.

text:
The partially dismembered body of David Miller, 56, was found at his flat in Northampton last June.
Michael Hedges, 42, from nearby Northampton, had gone to the flat to steal money to support his heroin addiction.

On Friday he was convicted of murder following a two-week trial at Northampton Crown Court.

He is expected to be jailed on Monday.

The court heard Miller had asked Mr Hedges to look after his gold Rolex watch, but after he was murdered his watch went missing.

Prosecutor, Mark Heywood, said Mr Hedges had stabbed the father-of-two once, causing a fatal wound to the chest.

Mr Miller suffered severe loss of blood before being stabbed five more times, causing 10 separate stab wounds.

Michael Hedges was then discovered in the victim's car two days later

Thomson started his third spell at Easter Road last week having negotiated his release with Dundee's Paul Hartley.
"I had a chat with the manager at Dundee and felt that the travelling was really hard on the body," the midfielder told BBC Scotland.
"I'm only 31. I feel as though I can contribute."
Thomson was Dundee captain but had made only 12 appearances for the Premiership side this season because of a number of niggling injuries, before the chance came to return to a club sitting second in the Championship.

text:
Voeckler announced plans to retire after the Tour de France in July this year, and the Tour de Yorkshire is set to be his final race in Britain.
"This race feels like home for me," said the 37-year-old Frenchman.
"The crowd are always shouting my name, holding up banners, or writing it on the road. I have never seen anything like it."
The 2017 Tour de Yorkshire will begin in Bridlington, with a 173km stage to Scarborough on Friday, 28 April.
Find out how to get into cycling with our special guide.
In stage two on 29 April, riders start in Tadcaster and travel 122.5km to Harrogate, before the three-day race ends with a 194.5km stage from Bradford to Fox Valley, Sheffield on Sunday, 30 April.

Paul Michael Sadler, 35, from Broughton was taken to hospital following the accident on the A5104 in Broughton at about 21:30 GMT on Saturday.
He died during the early hours of Monday.
The van driver, a 26-year-old local man, was arrested after failing the roadside drug swipe test.
He has since been released on police bail pending the result of further tests.
Mr Sadler's family were said to be "completely heartbroken", according to a statement issued by North Wales Police.

text:
Launching its manifesto, the party again ruled out taking part in any future coalition.
However, it said it would be prepared to work with the government as a "critical friend".
The party's manifesto for the 6 May general election sets out a series of policies on housing, jobs, health and the economy.
It has proposed the creation of a "British Investment Bank" to boost private-sector lending and says it would aim to get a budget surplus "as soon as practicable" after 2015, while not ruling out a rise in capital gains tax.
It also says it would build new nuclear power stations with private-sector companies as well as developing new renewable energy sources like offshore wind farms and tidal lagoons.

That year Clegg's star was on the up - he was at number 10 in a poll of who would make the best next prime minister behind then deputy prime minister Nick Clegg and Labour leader Ed Miliband, ahead of then Conservative leader David Cameron and Ukip leader Nigel Farage.

He has also asked whether the chancellor or his advisers were involved in the arrangement.
Senior Tory MP David Davis said the amount of back tax Google has agreed to pay was a "very small number".

text:
Madagascar's government chartered a plane to evacuate her and 85 other women.
The youngest of her four children has just turned two.
As the death toll rose and reports spread about how little food and water people had, the UN began planning their evacuation. But then the country went into a full-scale lockdown.
When the charter flight was finally allowed to land, they had an unexpected arrival waiting for them, and an unexpected mission to fulfill.
In Madagascar and several other African countries, women and girls in need of protection are often taken in by shelters and safe houses set up by non-profit organisations. These women and children are usually there because they're fleeing abuse or domestic violence, or they've been trafficked or abducted.
But as Covid-19 cases soared in those countries, governments ordered many NGOs and private organisations to close their doors.

Kevin Nolan told the jury he had passed the details of a hamper salesman named "Mark Kingston" to club officials.
Stephen Ackerman is accused of selling hampers to players that never arrived under the alias Mark Kingston.
The 48-year-old, of Loughton, Essex, denies 19 fraud charges with the proceeds totalling more than £60,000.
Mr Nolan told Snaresbrook Crown Court he was the given the details of "a fella called Mark" by nightclub manager Scott Cummings.
The 34-year-old said he passed the details to player liaison officer Tim De'Ath telling him: "Mark sold luxury hampers and he would like to come into the training ground."

text:
The Tavistock and Portman Clinic in London, a national centre helping under-18s from across the UK, says 441 young people came to them for assessment in 2013/14.
That's compared to 91 in 2009/2010.
It's thought better awareness of LGBT issues could be behind the rise.
Christina Richards, a senior specialist and psychotherapist at the Nottingham Gender Identity Clinic says: "I think the increase in referrals is largely due to wider acceptance and wider understanding.
"Some of the silly ideas about what 'trans' means have disappeared now.
"We realise it is something that affects all people from all walks of life and that people go on and do rather well if they get the help they need.

The party's only remaining AM was named education secretary on Thursday, subject to Saturday's approval at a special conference near Newtown, Powys.

However, he will be forced to resign his AM-ship to take the job, creating an additional vacancy at the assembly.

Lord Elis-Thomas has already been replaced as the party's AM for Dwyfor by Simon Thomas, who was first elected as an AM for Mid and West Wales in May.

Now he will become an AM for Mid and West, and is expected to retain his seat, despite the by-election that must be held to fill his old seat.

It said investing in the sector made no sense given that smoking killed some six million people a year.
The move by Axa is an attempt to stop its insurance business being associated with the tobacco industry, which has come under huge pressure to change because of its role in causing disease.
France’s second biggest insurer said it would sell or remove tobacco-related investments from funds it sold to clients, with around €750m ($877m; £608m) expected to be affected.
It is also removing tobacco shares from the €10bn of assets it manages itself.
Axa said it expected to reduce its tobacco-related investments, which it puts at €1.6bn, to “minimal” levels by the end of next year.

A judge said Mr Hawkes' evidence concerning VAT was "wholly incredible".

text:
The Sex and the City star was due to play the lead role in a new play called Linda, by Penelope Skinner.
In the play, the main character is an academic who is sacked from her university post because a colleague reports a sexual assault he did not witness.
Now Skinner says she has “cut back” on the play while she rethinks what she wants to say about the topic.
Skinner said: “I decided last week that I needed to take a pause and make a decision about how to proceed and how, in the current climate, to make the play we were hoping to make.
“It’s a very important, very exciting play about women in work, and I’ve always thought of it as an ambitious project.”

Swansea are four points above the relegation zone, while Leicester are five points clear at the top.

Similar stories have appeared in the Sun, the Independent, the Telegraph and in other online publications.

Seamer James Anderson will miss the match with a side strain suffered in England's win at Edgbaston, which put them 2-0 up in the four-Test series.

Anderson has struggled with a number of injury issues in the summer, including the recurring problem in his right ankle which flared up in Bangladesh this winter.

However, that is not expected to be an issue in terms of any selection dilemmas for the Lord's Test, which starts on Thursday.

Meanwhile, all-rounder Ben Stokes is fit to play his first match since suffering a right knee injury in training just before the start of the first Test and will battle with Chris Woakes for the final pace bowler's place.

Woakes, 26, is fit after suffering a dead leg which saw him leave the field midway through the Edgbaston clash.

text:
A Healthcare Improvement Scotland inspection of BMI Healthcare's Albyn Hospital identified a "significant number of areas" which needed improvement, the watchdog has said.

However, it did say that there were no immediate risks to patient safety at the privately-run facility.

The inspection report was carried out on October 28 2015, following Healthcare Improvement Scotland's routine monitoring of the hospital.

It said that while there was a "good knowledge of patients' rights and support for complaints and suggestions", "patients told us that communication was not always done well".

The report stated: "We were also told that the private nature of the hospital had contributed to staff feeling less accountable and motivated to work to the highest of standards. We found a significant number of areas where improvements were required."

A further inspection carried out on January 14 revealed that management were taking a range of action
paraphrased_text: inspection of Albyn hospital identified a "significant number of areas" which needed improvement. report carried out on October 28 2015, following Healthcare Improvement Scotland's routine monitoring of the hospital. further inspection carried out on January 14 revealed that management were taking a range of action.

Queen recently celebrated the 40th anniversary of one of their biggest hits, Bohemian Rhapsody, and will headline 2016's Isle of Wight Festival.
Other winners included Iron Maiden, AC/DC, Foo Fighters, Led Zeppelin, Alice Cooper and Noddy Holder.
Queen, who originally consisted of May, Freddie Mercury, Roger Taylor and John Deacon, still perform live despite the death of singer Mercury in 1991.
Previous recipients of the living legend award include Jeff Beck, Jimmy Page, Motorhead's Lemmy, Ozzy Osbourne, Iggy Pop and ZZ Top.

The Spring 2015 forecast has been published by the Ulster University Economic Policy Centre.
It says the NI economy had a relatively strong 2014, with increasing employment levels supporting high levels of consumer and business confidence.
Lower oil prices had a positive impact for consumers and businesses.
The report says that as a result, 2015 should also deliver relatively strong economic growth.
However, it adds: "Given the surprising Conservative Party majority (albeit slender) in the general election, the key trajectory of government spending over the period of this new Westminster parliament remains on a downward trend.

A reporter and later news editor, he was in charge of BBC Radio Wales' news coverage in the 1970s and 1980s, later becoming a radio features producer for BBC Radio 4.

He is remembered for his warm voice and the distinctive way he read the Welsh news headlines, introducing them on Radio Wales as "The News" – a feature he adopted from his time at BBC Radio Manchester when he was news editor.

He became known in Wales by many other names, including 'the velvet voice' and 'the news man from the land of my fathers'.

When he first took over the presenting of the news, he faced criticism from a Welsh language nationalist who complained that his accent was unsuitable for the Welsh news. But in fact his roots were very much Welsh.

Police blocked access to a main road in the capital and used pepper spray to try to control the crowd.
Protesters threw punches and kicks and tried to break through police lines in the latest demonstration in weeks over the arrest last month of prominent opposition member and radio commentator Sam Rainsy. The protests are the largest in more than two years, and have been prompted by accusations of corruption and rising food and fuel prices that have sparked public anger.
Hundreds of police officers gathered around the barricades to try to keep protesters away from the National Assembly building and the nearby Australian Embassy, the scene of a violent protest two weeks ago in which several people were injured.

Anna Dugdale had held the post at Norfolk and Norwich University Hospital for six years.
In a statement, she said she took full responsibility for serious criticisms raised by the CQC and has tendered her resignation.
Its report raised particular concerns about the hospital's leadership.
It said there was a disconnection between staff and the leadership team and "serious concerns" were raised over board effectiveness and a bullying culture within the management.

One blast took place near the former military academy for women, while the other struck close to the interior ministry.
Emergency crews rushed to the scenes of the blasts, which were cordoned off.
It is the first deadly bomb attack since the toppling of Muammar Gaddafi last year.
The bombs struck at dawn close to the interior ministry's administrative offices and near the military academy on Omar al-Mokhtar Avenue.
The city's head of security, Col Mahmoud Sherif, said the blast outside the military academy left two people dead and four or five injured.
No casualties were reported from the other explosion, he said.

One of the few purveyors is Bremont, which has a boutique in the upmarket central London area of Mayfair.
Its mechanical watches sell for between £2,695 and £30,950, and are all designed and painstakingly assembled by hand in England.
It employs around 30 watchmakers at a workshop in the Oxfordshire town of Henley-on-Thames, and makes many of its own parts at a factory in Silverstone, Northamptonshire.
"The goal is to produce watches that you could put on in 20 to 30 years' time and that will still look great," says Nick English, Bremont's co-founder.

He also runs Edinburgh-based charity Fresh Start, which he set up more than 15 years ago.

Dr Barr is also the convener of the Presbytery of Edinburgh's superintendence committee and a member of the business committee.

Andrew Neil will be interviewing the politicians, with Jeremy Vine on swingometer duties - there will be four of them this time to reflect the different permutations. Huw Edwards takes over from David Dimbleby at 07:00 BST on Friday and will continue anchoring the main programme until 18:00 BST. Ian Blackford's proposal comes in the wake of plans for a single board to oversee Scotland's enterprise agencies.
HIE supports economic growth in the Northern Isles, Western Isles, Highlands, Moray and Argyll.
A Scottish government spokesman said the body would continue to provide its locally-based support.
Concerns were raised about the future of HIE when a phase one review of the country's enterprise and skills support recommended an over-arching statutory body to co-ordinate the work of Scottish Enterprise and HIE.
MSPs, including Conservative Donald Cameron, Labour's Rhoda Grant and Liberal Democrat leader Tavish Scott expressed fears of centralisation by government ministers.
Mr Blackford said that while he "fully endorsed" the establishment of one board, he also wanted HIE to have a "management or advisory board" which would "reflect the priorities" of the Highlands and islands area.

The Republic of Ireland's passport office tweeted the milestone: "Wow, we have just broken a new record, over 700,000 Passports have been issued so far this year! #RecordBreaker".
Last year, nearly 670,000 Irish passports were issued.
There has been a surge in applications from Great Britain and Ireland since the UK voted to leave the EU in June.
An Irish passport would allow its holder to continue to move and work freely within other EU member states once the UK withdraws.
The latest 2016 figures available are up until the end of October, and they show that there were 635,635 passport applications, compared to 566,142 in 2015.

text:
It is thought someone tried to throw the items over the wall of HMP Bristol but they rebounded and fell into the playground at St George Primary Academy, police said.

Officers believe an adult may have thrown the items before making a quick getaway, but did not explain how the suspect entered or left the prison.

Superintendent Andy Bennett, from Avon and Somerset Police, said: “There was a firework and a possible small knife found.

“There are concerns that this was the result of a deliberate act and it could have been a mistake or somebody trying to take the firework to a party.

“The police are investigating to see who it was and why it was taken.”

The playground reopened shortly after 11.30am, with the children now going home later than usual at 2.15pm, head teacher Paula Tillbrook said
paraphrased_text: firework and knife found in playground at St George primary academy. thought someone tried to throw items over wall of prison but they rebounded. police believe an adult may have thrown items before making quick getaway.

Christopher Keeling, 58, attacked Ann Robinson in December 2000.
Miss Robinson died in 2014 and a post-mortem examination found her death was directly linked to the assault.
Keeling, of Selby Road, Thorne, Doncaster, who was originally convicted of attempted murder in 2001, admitted murder at Sheffield Crown Court.
He was sentenced to life, and ordered to serve a minimum of 18 years in jail, less the time he had previously served.

text:
Bottas' win moved him to within 10 points of team-mate Lewis Hamilton in the championship, and 23 behind Ferrari's Vettel with four races to go.

Bottas jumped ahead of Hamilton in the opening corners, with a bold move on the outside of Red Bull's Max Verstappen, to lead at the end of a dramatic first lap.

But with Hamilton right behind, there was no opportunity for Bottas to ease away, and the Finn had to defend on numerous occasions.

Bottas said: "Lewis was really quick, I needed some tyre degradation to get away but it wasn't enough, I had to keep him really close. He had a bit of an advantage on the straight but we had a bit more on the corners so it was good."

text:
The VidyaGyan Leadership Academy, a boarding school in India's Uttar Pradesh state, is offering an elite education for pupils drawn from the rural poor.
There are about 200 places on offer each year - but such is the appetite for families to get a better life for their children, there are 250,000 applications.
The school, set up by the Shiv Nadar Foundation, is completely free, and offers the type of education usually available only to the very wealthy.
Roshni Nadar Malhotra, a businesswoman and trustee of the foundation, says the school has been modelled on India's private schools, which put students on the pathway to top universities and high-flying careers.

text:
Officers have been instructed not to exercise discretion, but issue tickets for speeding and seatbelt offences and for using a mobile phone while driving.
The move was announced at a meeting of the Policing Board on Thursday.
It comes after 54 people died on Northern Ireland's roads since the start of the year.
At the same point in 2012, 26 people had been killed. In the first eight months of 2013, 40 people had died on the roads.
A father whose son suffered catastrophic injuries in a speed-related traffic accident spoke about the impact it had had on his son and the family on the day the police crackdown began.
He said his son suffered horrendous injuries in the accident and although he had survived, his son was not the "same boy as he was".
"He has made a good recovery, but he is certainly not the same boy as he was. His life is totally ruined," he said.
Police Service of

text:
With the onset of what is still a feeble winter, the air quality in India's capital has again become appalling. Particulate pollution has shot up to the dangerously unhealthy zone, which is a threat to even those people with asthma. With the onset of a cold wave, the air quality has been affected in most parts of northern India, with smog and haze reducing visibility in Delhi and several parts of Uttar Pradesh and Haryana.

In fact, an All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) study in 2016 had revealed that a person living for even a few years in Delhi has lungs equivalent to a 60-year-old smoker! Air Pollution, which in 2015 was declared an epidemic by the WHO (World Health Organization), is the fifth leading cause of deaths in the world, and the leading environmental cause of death, ahead

Each of them has promised, in varying ways, to settle constitutional arguments for, if not a generation, then a long time. The current Wales Bill is unlikely to be the last word and it looks like it would be unwise to assume that the issue will have gone away, even if all the Welsh nationalist parties agree on the terms.

The reason for this is simply that we do not really know what the English want. It is clear that some of them are rather uncomfortable about the prospect of continuing to fund the Welsh Assembly and the Welsh NHS. For most people, however, England’s interest has never been an issue in the debate. The English are too polite to talk about it.

Tunnelling is set to start for a line from Turin to Lyon, which is expected to cut the travel time by nearly half.

Construction work is set to start on a high-speed rail tunnel between France and Italy after the countries agreed on the project on Friday.

When the €7.5-billion ($9-billion) railway line is completed, the travel time between Turin and Lyon should be nearly halved to just over two hours.

“After long years of negotiations and intense consultations, it's with great satisfaction that we finally sign this agreement,” French transport minister Élisabeth Borne said in a joint press conference with her Italian counterpart Graziano Delrio and the director-general of the European Commission’s Directorate-General for Energy, Klaus-Dieter Borchardt.

He said eurozone reforms would allow the UK to negotiate changes to its relationship with Brussels.

Newcastle's draw at Sale earlier on Saturday means Irish slip to the bottom of the Premiership table.

The country boasts spectacular scenery, including Lake Titicaca, the world's highest navigable lake. A growing number of visitors are being drawn to its variety of attractions.
The country has been experiencing an economic boom. Foreign investors, attracted by the government and encouraged by favourable conditions, have been keen to get involved in exploiting the country's mineral wealth, sometimes in the face of local resistance.
Peru has become the world's leading producer of cocaine.
The country is still trying to come to terms with the trauma of a two-decade conflict - roughly from 1980 to 2000 - between the state and leftist guerrilla groups, the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement and the Shining Path, which still has a following.

text:
Social welfare secretary Corazon Soliman said that nearly 500 people were taken from the streets of Manila to an upscale resort in the Philippines.

The move followed an order last month from the city’s mayor, Alfredo Lim, to give the “street dwellers” three months to look for new accommodation.

A total of 448 men and women were rounded up and sent for a month’s rehabilitation at Club Balai Isabel in Batangas province, about 60 miles south of Manila.

Soliman said that the programme cost approximately £1,300,000 but would save the government the cost of cleaning and caring for people who had no means to support themselves.

During their stay at Club Balai Isabel, the “street dwellers” received counseling and medical treatment, as well as nutritious food and clothing.

Research by charities Crisis and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation suggested "informal" methods used by councils to tackle the problem had masked a 9% rise in cases in 2013-14 - to 280,000 cases.
Official statistics put the number of "accepted homeless" cases at about 52,000 last year, down 3% from 2012-13.
The government said the charities' figures were "misleading".
The annual independent study - which drew on a survey of England's 326 councils in 2014 - said the rise in the number of people facing homelessness was in part the result of benefit cuts and sanctions.
It also blamed a "woeful lack of affordable housing" which meant growing numbers of people were having to live away from their area.

text:
The CMA report recommended that price comparison websites should no longer be obliged to show deals on which they do not earn a commission.
Consumers need to know what they are buying before they commit to a purchase.
As such, the CMA's remedies seek to help consumers understand what products and services they are being shown on comparison sites, and help them make better informed choices.
By removing financial disincentives for comparison sites to display products and services, this will help people shop around and find a better deal.
"We are pleased with the progress that has been made on the implementation of the recommendations from our original report.
"We now want to ensure that consumers can find the best price for the product or service they need and want, and are given clear information on how a comparison site generates its profits and on any financial incentives offered to help consumers make an informed choice."

The charity, Blyth Tall Ship, is using Â£777,200 of Heritage Lottery funding to restore the cutter, Blyth.

The 74ft, gaff-rigged Blyth will undergo a full restoration, including a new mast and sails, to be completed by April 2016, after which it will be used to give youngsters the experience of sailing as its crew.

The charity was set up in 2012 as part of the Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee celebrations.

Blyth was launched at the South Shields Cochin Yard in 1892, and is now at Newcastle’s Discovery Museum, where some of the restoration work will take place.

It will then be moved to the new Blyth Tall Ship Project workshop on Blyth Quayside to complete the work

Francis Paul, the secretary-general of the National Olympics Committee of Kenya (Nock), Pius Ochieng, Nock's vice-president and chairman of the Kenya Swimming Federation (KSF), Peter Nyoro, head of the swimming department, and swimmer Mary Nakhumicha are also facing misconduct charges.

The Kenya Sports Appeals Tribunal (KSAT) handed them the ban after hearing a complaint from Nock following the selection of a Kenyan 17-member swim team for the African Games in Brazzaville from November 2-16.

The ban means they could miss the Commonwealth Games in Birmingham next year and the World Aquatics Championships in Budapest next year.

Michael Smithyman was given two life sentences for the violent murders carried out in Kent in January 1990.
He said he used the opportunity to study.
He did a law degree and a masters before a judge let him have an MBA.
“That’s where I got the management skills,” he said.

Smithyman, who now runs his own business, has written a book, “The Business of Crime: A criminal entrepreneur’s guide to making money in prison”.
“When I was in prison it felt like there was money to be made. If you could just find some way to get ahold of it,” he said.

text:
Leanne Wood said Plaid faced a "big mountain" but it was not impossible to become Wales' biggest party.
It goes in to next year's Assembly elections as the third biggest party, behind Labour and the Tories.
Ms Wood will deliver a speech on Saturday at the SNP conference in Aberdeen, the biggest in the party's history.
"There are many things that we can learn from the SNP experience, not least the way in which they replaced the Labour government back in 2007 and have turned a lot of the problems around that were in Scotland back then," she said.
"We can learn lessons from Scotland there - where there is a strong party, a national party of government, then there can be real success and we can do the same for Wales."

Changing habits such as starting earlier and smoking more cigarettes have been blamed for the dramatically increased risks of lung cancer.
The trends, reported in the New England Journal of Medicine, show death rates in women have caught up with men.
The study looked at data from more than two million women in the US.
The first generation of women smokers started during the 1950s and 60s. In those early years, women who smoked were nearly three times more likely to die from lung cancer as people who had never smoked.
Looking at medical records from women between 2000-2010 showed they were 25 times more likely to die from lung cancer than their non-smoking friends.
It follows a similar pattern in men, who reached a similar

Kieran Kiely, 24, had absconded from Castle Huntly prison four days earlier when he attacked Christopher Smith, 29, in the street in Dundee.

The victim, a heroin addict, was known to Kiely as he had also been in Castel Huntly jail.

But his friends and family are concerned he is being treated in a “cage” at the hospital and are calling on him to be released and put into a proper recovery unit instead.

Smith’s sister, Kelly, has now launched a campaign to get him out.

She said: “My brother has been locked in a 22-bed room in the secure ward. The room is made to look like a prison. The beds are bolted to the floor and the rooms are bolted to the door.

text:
Their high fitness levels also appear to increase their chances of surviving cancer if they are diagnosed later on.
University of Vermont researchers said even moderate exercise is enough for most people to reduce their risk, but the most significant benefits are seen in those who work out at a high intensity.

“I think we all intuitively know that exercise is good for us,” said exercise physiologist Gregory O’Brien, a professor at the University of Vermont.

“But what’s unique about this study is that we have quantified exercise and exercise volume and shown that there is a relationship between this and cancer risk that is surprisingly strong,” O’Brien told CBS News’ Dr. Emily Senay.

His team of researchers published their work in the British Journal of Sports Medicine.

For their analysis they combined findings from more than 110,000 people and 28 separate studies into their review of how exercise affects cancer

Mr Hart, 46, joined United five years ago from Sara Lee and was previously was a law firm partner and a lawyer for the US Treasury.
