text:
UK Coal plans to close the pits at Kellingley, North Yorkshire, and Thoresby, Nottinghamshire.
Business secretary Vince Cable said that it had made all reasonable efforts to save the mines.
He said that the Government had been working to explore what other options are possible to save the mine, and the communities they serve, from such devastating economic loss.
But it is with great sadness that I have to accept the position we are in, he said.

Mr Cable added that the Government was determined to secure jobs for as many of the 1,500 miners in Yorkshire and Nottinghamshire whose jobs are threatened by the closures as possible.

The Governments review of the UKs coal reserves and the future of the coal industry in the UK, which was due to be published in the spring, has been delayed.

text:
Sushmita Banerjee, who was married to an Afghan businessman, was killed outside her home in Paktika province. She and another woman were killed by an assailant with a pistol.

Banerjee, from Kolkata, had married Afghan businessman Mohammad Ijaz Haqqani 17 years ago. According to Banerjee’s brother Abhay, she married the businessman who was much older to her.

Haqqani, who is 19 years older than his wife, was not at home when the gunman shot Banerjee. However, the assailant did not harm Haqqani’s children as they did not witness the incident.

The police have arrested suspect Abdul Wali over the incident, and has launched an investigation into the killing. The investigators believe the suspect killed the women due to financial issues.

Indian officials

text:
Thomas Stokes, 47, and son Martin, 23, posed as potential buyers for three of the dogs before punching the owner and his dog in a car park.

A pair of dog thieves targeted unsuspecting owners after tricking them into thinking they were serious buyers.

Thomas Stokes, 47, and his son Martin, 23, posed as potential buyers for three of the dogs before punching the owner and his dog in a car park.

They then stole a Staffordshire bull terrier, a French bulldog and a Labrador as their unsuspecting owners looked on.

The pair of criminals then sold the three dogs for £2,500 and shared the proceeds, a court heard.

But the thieves failed to spot the CCTV cameras at the car park and were caught on tape committing the crime.

text:
The #WordsAtWork campaign by the country's Diversity Council asks people to avoid expressions they say exclude minority groups.
Using "girls" for women, and "walk the talk" to people in wheelchairs, are among terms they say are offensive.
Mr Morrison was awarded the role of Australian of the Year partly for his equality campaigning.
The former military man - once chief of the Australian Army - admitted he had used some of the terms himself.
But of "guys" Mr Morrison said "I have now removed that from my lexicon as best I can. I think it's important."
Insisting the campaign was not intended to create a "language police", he said: "People use language to denigrate others and to take away their self-respect. Sometimes it happens unconsciously, but the effect is the same."

text:
Paul Nicholl, 50, of Carnkenny Road, Newtownstewart, drank beer and took diazepam before he drove his car into a wall.

The defendant admitted a charge of being in charge of a vehicle whilst over the prescribed limit for diazepam.

A police officer witnessed the defendant’s vehicle collide with a wall on April 30, last year.

The officer noticed the defendant staggered out of the vehicle.

The officer smelled alcohol on the defendant’s breath and observed he had bloodshot eyes, slurred speech and poor co-ordination.

The defendant told police he had been driving.

The defendant had a reading of 192 micrograms of diazepam per litre of blood, above the prescribed legal limit of 188 micrograms per litre of blood.

Residents slept in a gym overnight as a police cordon was put in place.

text:
Carmarthen Park, which opened in 1900, will be turned into a training and competition venue for cyclists.
Carmarthenshire council agreed on Monday to give £286,000 to the project, after Sport Wales pledged £296,000.
The local authority hopes it will increase interest in cycling and bring high class racing to the area.
With an original grandstand, bandstand and lodge, it has been used for a wide range of sports, eisteddfodau, circuses and concerts.
The investment will see the track upgraded and improved safety fencing put in.
The council's executive board member Meryl Gravell told Monday's meeting that "cycling was on the up" in the county and across Wales and the project was "worthy of support".
paraphrased_text: Carmarthen Park, which opened in 1900, will be turned into a training and competition venue for cyclists. Sport Wales pledged £296,000 to the project on Monday. the track will be upgraded and improved safety fencing put in.

text:
The crash happened in LeFlore County, about 100 miles (160km) north of Jackson, the state capital.

A total of seven people died, including four students, a faculty member and the bus driver.

The collision occurred when the SUV crossed into the wrong lane and slammed into the school bus.

One of the students and the SUV's driver have been listed in a critical condition at a nearby hospital, while two students have been flown to Children's Hospital in Little Rock for treatment, Governor Asa Hutchinson said.

"I think we all are aware that this is a devastating event for this community and this school," he added.

Hutchinson said that he has "declared a state of emergency for LeFlore County, which will open the door for federal assistance, if needed, in the recovery process for the school and the community."

Investigators

text:
Jordan Watson's body was found in the graveyard in Carlisle early on Tuesday morning; Cumbria Police initially said a man had been killed.
A post-mortem examination revealed he died from multiple wounds to the head and neck caused by a sharp implement.
Detectives said they were shocked by the murder and said for a child to die in such circumstances was "appalling".
The body was found in Upperby Cemetery, next to St John The Baptist Church in Manor Road, at about 07:45 BST on Tuesday.
Police patrols have been increased across the Carlisle area while the investigation continues into the death of Jordan, who lived in Ridley Road in the city.

The Rs remain in 11th despite their west London derby win, while the Bees stay 17th.

text:
BBC Wales understands one proposal was for two parties to withdraw candidates in seats where the third party had a chance of victory in the poll on 5 May.
The Greens said the "electoral math was there" but not the "political will".
Plaid confirmed "exploratory talks" had ended. The Liberal Democrats said they "decided it wasn't the right approach".
Wales Green Party leader Alice Hooker-Stroud said: "Talks took place but no final proposal to take to our members for final agreement was reached."
A spokeswoman for Plaid Cymru said Wales needed "a new direction and fresh thinking".
She added: "Informal, exploratory talks were held with the Liberal Democrats and Green Party in order to establish whether any cooperation was feasible between the parties.
"These discussions have since come to an end.

After an online appeal he has reached the £7,000 needed for surgery which could help him resume his career.

text:
Mr Obama said the memory of 6 August 1945 must never fade, but did not apologise for the US attack - the only wartime atomic bombing in history.

Thousands of people are believed to have died shortly after two US planes dropped the bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, killing about 150,000 people.

"Seventy-five years ago today the United States of America dropped the first atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima," Mr Obama said.

"This tragedy brought the Second World War to a close and ushered in a new era of cooperation and global security."

He paid tribute to those killed, and survivors of the attacks, and those who had helped rebuild Japan after the war.

"On days such as this, we must resolve to share the truth of that history with every generation.

text:
In 2008 archaeologists first explored the site in Wiltshire examining the cremated remains of some 200 adults.
Researchers said their findings showed a "surprising degree of gender equality" despite artists portraying prehistoric man as in charge of the site "with barely a woman in sight".
The findings are reported in the magazine British Archaeology.
The study showed the findings are important because burial at Stonehenge was likely to have been reserved for selected people of higher status.
It also contrasts with the evidence from older Neolithic tombs in southern Britain, with their higher ratios of adult males to females.
Christie Willis, a PhD student at University College London and an expert on human remains, sorted through some 45kg (99lbs) of bone fragments.

text:
They say the unusual approach is an attempt to provide "revolutionary protection" against mosquito-borne diseases such as Zika and chikungunya.

But experts are concerned the design may be just too quirky for everyday use.

Dubbed the OM mosquito helmet, its design was dreamt up by Chinese architecture student Yong Huang.

It features two transparent domes covered with a material called polyurethane, which is used to make sporting equipment.

The material is said to be strong enough to stop the pests and their bites getting through.

And the helmet’s domes are reportedly designed with a negative pressure valve to ensure the air inside doesn’t get too hot for wearers.

But the design is certainly not to everyone’s liking.

When posted online, it was likened to a bumblebee, a hornet nest

It appears the rocket was fired from a base in the country's west near the border with China.

text:
The anti-homosexuality bill also makes it a crime punishable by a prison sentence not to report gay people.
The prime minister, Yoweri Museveni, has said he will not sign the bill into law after a long period of silence and speculation over its fate.

He told parliamentarians in his party that he wanted to read the bill, before announcing his position.

Uganda’s government had previously said it was opposed to the bill, passed by parliament late last year.

It includes the death penalty for gay people found guilty of repeated “aggravated homosexuality”. The bill also makes it a crime punishable by a prison sentence not to report gay people.

Many donors, including the US, had warned that they would cut aid if the law came into effect.

It was passed amid fears of a rise in homophobia across Africa, as some governments become more authoritarian.

text:
Privately-run HMP Doncaster suffered from a "lack of staff" and "ineffective initiatives" aimed at reducing violence, a report said.
The National Offender Management Service said many issues identified in 2014 remained unaddressed.
Serco said it was addressing the problems with a new management team.

Police today issued an urgent appeal to trace the man, who is a white male of medium build, and who is understood to have been travelling on foot with a large hold-all bag.

The father of three had been staying in a hotel in Gunwharf, Gosport, near Portsmouth, on the south coast of England.

The plan is backed by grant funding of £420m and follows agreement between the Scottish government and the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla).

SYHA Hostelling Scotland said three additional summer youth hostels will open in Edinburgh, Glasgow and Perth between June and August.
The new accommodations are expected to offer up to 470 beds across all three sites. SYHA said the accommodation options will be aimed at "young people and local communities, as well as domestic travellers looking for a safe and affordable place to stay".
The youth hostels will have a dedicated space for outdoor gear and equipment, while the hostels will also provide information about local cycle routes and walks.
Bevis Watts, chief executive of SYHA, said: "We are extremely proud to be opening these three new hostels as we approach what should have been our 90th birthday year.
"This will be a much-needed injection of accommodation into the local economies of three key areas of Scotland.

Abdullahi Sheikh Abas, 31, was picked by an electoral college to be a federal MP.
He was not, however, picked by a college that is actually elected, or one whose members are elected on the basis of votes. He was elected by a college that has only 5,000 members.
These members are not even drawn from the constituency that the MP is supposed to represent – they are not even Somalis.
This is not an isolated incident. The whole process is designed to ensure that Somalis never have to go to the polls.

text:
A study, reported in the journal Science, has now shown that eels can use their electric organs to remotely control the fish they hunt.
A researcher from Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee, found that the electric discharges from eels made the muscles of their prey twitch.
This makes the fish easier to capture either by immobilising it or making it "jump" to show where it's hiding.
Kenneth Catania, who led the study, set up small aquatic arenas to test the eels' hunting abilities - putting an eel and an unfortunate fish into the same tank.
When they spotted their prey, the eels released pulses of electricity that appeared to immobilise the fish.
Further study revealed that the eels' electric pulses directly activated the nerves that controlled their prey's muscles.
"When the eel's pulses slow down - when the eel gets tired at the end of its attack - you see individual fish twitches, with one twitch from every pulse," said Dr Catania.
"That tells us that the eel is reaching in to the prey's nervous
paraphrased_text: eels released pulses of electricity that appeared to immobilise their prey. This made the muscles of their prey twitch. This makes the fish easier to capture either by immobilising it or making it "jump" to show where it's hiding.

text:
The optical illusion is not in fact a rainbow according to BBC weather presenter Keeley Donovan,
"It is known as a sundog (parhelion)," Keeley Tweeted to her followers. "Parhelion comes from Greek and means ‘beside the sun’. A sundog forms when refracted sunlight is scattered into your line of sight. This effect occurs in winter due to the sun’s low angle above the horizon."

The parhelia is actually caused by the refraction of sunlight by ice crystals in cirrus clouds. In this case, it's the result of the crystals being aligned horizontally, so that the sun's light is refracted back towards Earth, as opposed to vertical, when the light is refracted away from Earth.

Ice crystals are more common at the Earth's altitude.

Parhelia have been known to exist

The body of Roy Blackman, 73, was found inside the property on Headcorn Road, Biddenden, just before 11pm on Saturday (August 19) with a serious head injury.

A post mortem examination on Sunday (August 20) failed to establish a cause of death.

Further enquiries into Mr Blackman's death are continuing today and the cause is being treated as unexplained.

Detective Chief Inspector Neil Kimber, of Kent Police, said: "It is crucial that anyone who saw anything suspicious in the Headcorn Road or High Street areas between 8.30am and 11pm on Saturday, including vehicles or people acting suspiciously, contacts police as soon as possible.

"Mr Blackman’s family have been informed of this development and our thoughts are with them at this difficult time.”

text:
With the onset of what is still a feeble winter, the air quality in India's capital has again become appalling. Particulate matter - particles so small they can be ingested deep into the lungs - and a toxic cocktail of nitrogen oxide, ozone, benzene, carbon monoxide and sulphur dioxide hangs heavy over the world's most polluted city. People cough, wheeze and whinge and your correspondent is no exception.
With the worsening air quality, public outrage against it has spiked. Expats are worried again - there are reports of Norway considering classifying the city as a "hardship" posting on account of increasing air pollution - and an international school suspends outdoor activities. A court wonders whether Delhi has become a "gas chamber".
Truth be told, the world's fifth largest megacity has turned a "gas chamber" in winter for a long time now. We

Three fire crews remained in attendance at the property on Sunday morning.

text:
Current operator Govia, which owns London Midland, and West Midlands Trains Ltd, have been formally asked to tender for the network.

The franchise could be awarded as soon as the end of next year and start in late 2017 - a much shorter period than the five-year process which saw Govia granted the London Midland network in 2007.

It means services would continue to run for longer during evenings, although the frequency of night time services would depend on whether there is greater funding available.

Transport Minister Claire Perry said: “We are making a significant new investment in Midland Main Line services – and will be looking at extending evening and weekend services, with more seats for passengers and faster journeys too.

“I urge anyone who is interested in running the franchise to get in touch. We will give more details about the bidding process in a few months.”

Mr Hichilema's convoy allegedly refused to make way for President Edgar Lungu's convoy on Sunday, resulting in an argument between the two.

President Lungu's spokesperson Amos Chanda said this on Tuesday in an interview.

Mr Chanda said President Lungu's convoy was driving on a one-way road when Mr Hichilema decided to "chase and confront" him, resulting in a heated argument.

He said this was unbecoming, irresponsible and disrespectful, adding that the two were former classmates and the altercation was childish.

Mr Hichilema, in a statement, said President Lungu was driving dangerously, adding that Mr Chanda's version of events was wrong and malicious.

He said he was at a meeting when he heard there was an accident involving his convoy.

Roald Dahl's books have been the bedrock of countless childhoods.
More than 200 million copies have been sold worldwide and translated into 59 languages.
The author's infamous characters, Willy Wonka, Miss Trunchbull and the Twits amongst them, will be affectionately remembered by children and adults alike across Wales.
Schools across the country are marking Roald Dahl Day by dressing up as their favourite villains and heroes, with an Enormous Crocodile bench to be unveiled in Cardiff Bay.
Though well known for his Norwegian and English connections, 2016 has seen a concerted effort to highlight the influence of Wales on the writer's colourful imagination.

text:
Alex Jones struck his fourth goal of the season from the penalty spot to haul the Valiants level at the ABAX Stadium after Posh had defender Andrew Hughes dismissed for deliberate handball by referee Graham Horwood.
Jones had earlier opened the scoring in the sixth minute, firing home on the half-volley after Remie Streete nodded Ben Purkiss' right-wing delivery into his path.
Posh's response was impressive and almost immediate as Marcus Maddison picked out George Moncur to fire his first Posh goal just eight minutes into his full debut after arriving on loan from Championship side Barnsley.
The hosts squandered a stack of glorious chances in the second half before Moncur looked like being the matchwinner as he slotted them ahead with six minutes to go after a cross from the left from substitute Paul Taylor broke into his path.
But Posh were denied victory amid the late drama as Hughes saw red

The girl, who cannot be named, is accused of murdering Elizabeth Edwards, 49, and Katie Edwards, 13. They died in a fire at the family home near Kirkby Lonsdale, Lancashire, on 10 March.

Mrs Edwards died of smoke inhalation. She and her daughter had been subjected to a violent assault before the blaze.

Prosecutors claim the girl inflicted serious head wounds on her mother and sister with a large kitchen knife after becoming upset about a letter which was sent from prison to her family.

The teenager denies murder. A jury at Preston Crown Court has been told the girl suffered from mental health problems.

The trial continues.

Friends and family gathered for his funeral at St John the Baptist Church in Guilden Sutton on Wednesday.

Many of these issues particularly affect young women, the survey by the Young Women's Trust found. The BBC spoke to four young women to find out more about their experiences.

Having to make sacrifices for their children is a major reason that young women find it difficult to balance work and childcare.

For single parents this is even harder when they may have to juggle their work schedules as well.

Many struggle to get to work and have to resort to using public transport and car shares.

They also find it difficult to find childcare as costs are high and are particularly struggling with a lack of affordable and reliable childcare.

text:
The exploding star was first observed back in June last year but is still radiating vast amounts of energy.
At its peak, the event, known as PS16dlv, was around 10 billion times brighter than our sun. This makes it one of the brightest transient events of the last 40 years, according to astronomers.

Now, a study published in Nature Astronomy shows that an explosion at a black hole could explain the powerful event.

The findings come after astronomers first observed the phenomenon using the Palomar Observatory near San Diego, California.

Astronomers at Durham University in the UK say these observations showed the “extraordinary brightness and high velocities of the material around PS16dlv”.

These high speeds may suggest an unusual origin for the blast, which “exceeds the capabilities of conventional stellar-mass black holes,” they explained.

This event
paraphrased_text: is 10 billion times brighter than our sun. This makes it one of the brightest transient events of the last 40 years. Now, a study published in Nature Astronomy shows that an explosion at a black hole could explain the powerful event.

Sam Allardyce has resigned as England manager following a newspaper investigation alleging he offered advice on how to "get around" football's transfer rules.
The Sunday Times said he also suggested representatives of a fictional Far Eastern company could act as "middlemen" and negotiate deals on behalf of owners.
The Football Association (FA) "commissioned an investigation" on Saturday after being shown transcripts of the sting.
The FA has "reluctantly accepted" Allardyce's resignation with "immediate effect".

Joanne Lee was was working for Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board when she took more than 800 patient files.

A Welsh health board boss caught with thousands of patient records on her home computer had hoped to take them overseas to help ailing children, a court heard.

Joanne Lee said she was unaware that she was breaking the law when she transferred the medical notes to her personal drive, the trial at Caernarfon Crown Court was told.

Prosecutors accused the 55-year-old of putting patients at risk of identity theft.

Lee, who worked as an information assistant for Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, pleaded guilty to an offence under data protection legislation.

On Friday morning the court heard how the patient records had been removed from the secure health board system and put on Lee’s home computer.

The Quebec group said turbans were dangerous because players could get their heads caught in another player’s neck.

text:
The S92 incident happened on the West Franklin Platform last month.
An Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) bulletin has revealed when panels were removed it was immediately clear a tail rotor piston was damaged.
The helicopter came to rest having rotated more than 180 degrees.
No-one was injured.
Sikorsky S92s began undergoing specific tail rotor safety checks worldwide on Tuesday due to the incident.
The bulletin said a bearing was in a "severely distressed condition", and initial findings were the failure had been "rapid".
Further disassembly founds "signs of severe overheating with extreme wear".
The report said there was a "consequential total loss of control of the tail rotor".
Initial investigations show the S92 helicopter spun 187 degrees when landing on the West Franklin platform.
The AAIB said the incident took place on 28 December and it was made aware of it on 5 January.
Its investigation is continuing.
A phased return to service of the fleet after the checks

The army is the most powerful institution in the country and its chief is the most influential figure in the country.
Ultimately the appointments of the service chiefs are approved by the President and Commander-in-Chief.
The Chief of Army Staff (COAS) is the commander of the Nigerian Army and the most senior military officer of the Army.
The Chief of Army Staff is appointed by the President upon the recommendation of the Minister of Defence and the Chairman of the Armed Forces Council.
The Chief of Army Staff is accountable to the Federal Government through the Minister of Defence and the Armed Forces Council.

It will be a time travel back in the 19^{th} century when it was in the height of use and then right through to today. There will be a lot of focus on the many wonderful people who used the hospital, patients, staff, nurses and doctors.

The Project

text:
The National Union of Teachers annual conference heard claims sexism is being “rebranded” as something fashionable and mainstream.
Delegates debating policy said the NUT must play its part in the movement for “greater gender justice”.

Julia Smedley, a member from Sheffield who proposed a motion on gender equality, said: “There is no reason why men shouldn’t do their fair share in the home and at work. There is no reason why women should be the default child-carers and there is no reason why workplaces should be so structured that women bear the brunt of the burden.

“Yet despite the progress towards equality we have witnessed in recent decades, gender inequality remains stubbornly entrenched.

“Sexism is being rebranded as something fashionable and mainstream, with women being routinely dismissed, harassed and abused simply because they are women.”
paraphrased_text: claims sexism is being “rebranded” as something fashionable and mainstream. delegates debating policy said the NUT must play its part in the movement for “greater gender justice”.

With Labour, the SNP and the Tories all offering their support to the legislation at some point during the passage of the bill, it passed without much opposition and was duly accepted by the country's footballing authorities.

Sales rose by 0.5% last month, after surging by 1.3% in April, according to the US Commerce Department.
April's figure was the strongest gain since March 2015, and a slowdown in May had been expected by economists.
Car sales rose by 0.5% with spending on fuel at service stations up by 2.1%, reflecting the increase in oil prices.
Sales at clothing stores increased by 0.8%, the largest gain since November.
Online retail sales climbed 1.3%, with receipts at sporting goods and hobby stores also up 1.3%.
When sales of cars, petrol, building materials and food services were stripped out, so-called "core retail sales" rose 0.4%.
The retail sales data is a key gauge of consumer spending in the US.

text:
Surgery was suspended for two weeks at Leeds General Infirmary's paediatric heart unit after data suggested a higher death rate than average.
A year-long NHS England review has concluded the unit "does not have an excessive mortality".
But it also found that some families of very sick children received poor care.
Operations at the hospital's unit were suspended on 28 March 2013 after NHS England raised concerns about data on mortality rates at the centre.
The suspension came just a day after a decision to stop children's heart surgery at the hospital - as part of an England-wide reorganisation of services - was quashed in the High Court.
Operations were allowed to resume at the unit on 10 April last year after an investigation revealed the mortality data was flawed.
A two-pronged review was launched by NHS England, one part examining the unit's mortality rates and the other

text:
Karen James took on at the role at Tameside General Hospital last July after former chief executive Christine Green quit.
The hospital was one of four which were in special measures following the Mid Staffordshire Hospital scandal.
Ms James was appointed after a four month search to find a successor to Ms Green.
Ms James said: "This role really is the pinnacle of my career and I'm determined to make a difference for the patients, carers and staff of Tameside and the wider community.
"I will continue the hard work and progress made by the Board, senior management and staff over recent months in ensuring that our Trust is safe, provides high quality care and is financially sound.
"I also hope to continue the relationship with the community and our partners to ensure that the healthcare needs of our population are met in the most effective and efficient manner possible."
Ms James has worked as an executive in the NHS for almost a decade.

text:
Separate factions within the shareholder group are understood to be unable to agree whether to accept an improved offer to settle claims they were misled, following a sharp downturn in shares between the bid and the settlement last month.

Shares in the bank, whose chief executive Mike Geoghegan resigned in October in the wake of a global share price tumble, have since climbed, although they remain well below the 90p per share settlement.

However, one shareholder told The Times: “The group has been divided over this. There are a lot of people who think the shares will now go even higher and they don’t want to give up the right to make further claims against the board.”

text:
The collection includes 43 diaries and approximately 2,000 letters spanning the actor's career, from the age of 18 until his death in 1988.
It was gifted to the library by his friend and neighbour Paul Richardson.
The 1950 edition of the diary, as well as a letter from the archive, will be on display in the Library's permanent exhibition space later this month.
It is believed that roughly 85% of the archive is unpublished material never before seen by researchers, offering unique insights into the life of a gay man before the decriminalisation of homosexuality in 1968.

What puts off so many of us from going swimming?

Moves including banning the sale of new diesel and petrol cars from 2040 and Â£255m for councils to tackle air pollution locally have been welcomed.
Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said the government was determined to deliver a "green revolution".
But environmental groups criticised the decision not to include a scrappage scheme or immediate clean air zones.
The plan to stop all sales of petrol and diesel cars by 2040 is part of the government's intention for almost every car and van on UK roads to be zero emission by 2050.
The government report includes the promise of Â£40m immediately to start local schemes rolling, which could include changing road layouts, retrofitting public transport or schemes to encourage people to leave their cars at home.

Unite said BA had refused to accept its final offer on the issue of the "sanctioning" of striking cabin crew.
The union claims that crew who previously walked out have not had their bonuses or benefits, including free and discounted travel, restored.
BA said that the proposed action was "extreme and completely unnecessary".

Figures published on Sunday shows around three out of four people who develop bowel cancer are over the age of 65, with the median age at diagnosis being 70 years old. Bowel cancer is the fourth most common cancer in the UK and the second leading cause of cancer death.

text:
Hoardings have been put up around Marland House - a rundown block of shops and offices which greets visitors at Cardiff Central railway station.
Work has started to flatten the building, along with the adjoining Wood Street NCP multi-storey car park.
The Central Transport Interchange will then be built in Central Square - the base for the city's new bus station.
It has been designed around an enclosed public concourse, with a large waiting area.
There will also be walkways to the adjacent railway station, a bicycle hub, shops and restaurants.
Cardiff council said the site perimeter would start going up around "eyesore" Marland House on Tuesday, followed by preparatory works for the demolition, which is scheduled to be completed later this year.

text:
Liam was murdered by his mother Rachael and her partner Nyomi Fee in Fife.
A pilot version of the named person scheme has been scrapped, after a judge ruled it would put children in danger.

The scheme has been controversial since it was first mooted five years ago.  It was planned to have every child in Scotland allocated a  named person (NP) – usually, although not necessarily, the head teacher – who would be responsible for collecting information and making decisions about that child’s  development.  The information would include details about their health, school life, family background and social life.

Campaign groups including the Christian Institute raised concerns that the scheme would infringe parental rights and give too much power to the State.

In March 2015, the Christian Institute and others successfully challenged the law, arguing that the scheme would breach the right to private and family life of both children and their parents

The average family would be left with just £44 a month after covering bills and household expenses, based on the charity’s research.

Oldham had not won in the league since 18 October under Robinson, 42, and the Latics are three points from safety.

The former Scotland international told the club's website: "We're in a relegation scrap and we have to get out of it. I've had to take over when the team was rock bottom, and it will be extremely difficult, but one of my biggest strengths is staying positive and keeping the team positive.

text:
On the outskirts of the Mexican state of San Luis Potosi, the skeletal remains of the partially constructed Ford plant loom over a barren landscape dotted with the empty shells of houses and unfinished shopping malls.

The story of the doomed US$2.3 billion plant, which has been sitting idle since Ford abandoned plans to build there in 2009, is familiar by now: as Mexico’s car and electronics industries were being gobbled up by Asian multinationals, the country’s leaders believed luring US manufacturing would create jobs and help them climb out of recession.

text:
The Pride & Prejudice author is thought to have made the handwritten entries in the record book while a teenager in Hampshire in the late 18th century. The journal contains a rare surviving account of the life of young Jane Austen, detailing her education, her sister and brothers, their family life and her love of reading.

She also details the people in her local area and her relationships with them.

The book was given to Jane Austen by her father Reverend George Austen in February 1790.

It records that she was born at Steventon Rectory on December 16 1775.

The shrinkage was largely in response to a government sales tax, which held back consumer spending.
Japan's sales tax rose from 5% to 8% in April.
On a quarterly basis, the economy contracted 1.7% in the second quarter after a 1.5% rise in the first three months.
Private consumption, which makes up 60% of economic activity, was 5% down on the previous quarter.
The economy grew at an annualised rate of 6.1% in the first quarter of this year.

text:
Jefferson Parish Sheriff Newell Normand said that Ronald Gasser, 54, was facing a count of manslaughter for killing Joe McKnight in Terrytown on Thursday.

Gasser is a former member of the Jefferson Parish Sheriff's Office.

Authorities said McKnight, 28, a standout at Curtis High School in Thibodaux and University of Southern California before an eight-year stint in the National Football League, was involved in the argument before Gasser shot him dead.

Sheriff Normand said he did not know what started the argument between Gasser and McKnight. He said there was a report that the shooting started over "road rage".

McKnight was not charged with any crime and died en route to the hospital, Normand said.

Norman said Gasser fired one shot at McKnight, who he added had no weapon in his hand.

text:
Colston Hall bosses had previously maintained that the Bristol attraction was named after the street it is on, rather than Edward Colston.
Much of the Bristol-born MP and merchant's wealth came from the slave trade.
The change, which will not come into effect until 2020, follows a campaign to urge Colston Hall to alter its name.
Louise Mitchell, chief executive of the Bristol Music Trust charity that runs Colston Hall, said it was the "right thing to do" for artists, the public and the "diverse workforce" at the venue, which recently announced plans for a refurbishment costing nearly Â£50m.

text:
Findings have also been announced in relation to a Newsnight report that led to Lord McAlpine being wrongly implicated in child sexual abuse at a home run by the late Lord Janner.

The Home Secretary, in consultation with Lord McAlpine, requested that the report be published with his commentary removed.

The original review was conducted by BBC deputy director-general, Mark Byford, and examined the BBC’s editorial decisions and process that led to the report that aired on 2 October 2012.

The original report concluded that the Newsnight editor had not made a sufficient effort to properly verify the claims made.

The findings of the review have now been published online, including a summary of the points Mr Byford did make and a copy of his correspondence with Lord McAlpine.

It reported passenger growth of 8.7% on the same period in 2014, after 1,073,483 passengers used its routes to, from and through Aberdeen, Scotland’s oil capital. Domestic passengers numbered 497,716, showing an increase of 8.9% compared with the previous year.

The 70-year-old pilot was seriously injured.
The pilot "noticed a change in the sound of the engine" just as he was about to contact air traffic control at Luton Airport, the Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) report said.

But there has so far been no agreement from the militant Hamas movement, which controls Gaza, as indirect talks continue in Cairo.
Deputy PM Nick Clegg says he wants licences stopped if violence returns.

Announcement imminent?

text:
The young birds were saved after their mother was killed by a dog in Station Park, Moffat.
They were pulled to safety by a family on pedalos in the park's pond.
The ducks are now being cared for at the South of Scotland Wildlife Hospital in Dumfries and they will be released back into the wild once they are old enough to fend for themselves.

"This is an important example of why dogs should be kept on a lead and under control whenever there are wild animals nearby.

Ban Bloodsports on Yorkshire Dales, the group who petitioned for the end of grouse shooting, has been calling on the Council to cancel the license.

The National Park Authority (NPA) , who had the authority to revoke the license, has now said it will not grant the license on the open moor. The NPA has now announced that it will be consulting with local landowners over the future of grouse shooting within the open moor of the Yorkshire Dales National Park. This has been a major U-turn in the authority’s stance after voting against the cancellation of the license in July 2019. A British teenager is fighting for his life after a horror crash at a motorsports race at Donington Park, Leicestershire on Sunday.

Seventeen-year-old Billy Monger, from Wokingham, suffered extensive injuries to both his legs in the smash, which left him trapped in his car for more than an hour.

He has lost both legs below the knee and has undergone three operations since the crash, according to The Sun.

US space agency-led scientists flew small, instrumented, chase planes directly in the exhaust plume of a big jet to measure the sorts of pollutants they emit that can harm human health and harm the environment.

The research flights, part of a US National Science Foundation-funded project known as AMP, studied the complex chemistry that occurs inside the plume to determine how much of the toxic air pollutants, including benzene and acetaldehyde, are emitted from the plume.

The results provide insight into which airborne compounds pose the greatest environmental and health hazards.

“This is the first time scientists have had a clear view of what is in the plume as emissions come out the exhaust pipe, and we were surprised by what we found,” said Paul Shepson, of Syracuse University, a co-principal investigator of the project.

text:
The annual rate of house price growth was 4.7% in May, down from 4.9% in April and 5.7% in March.
In May alone, house prices rose by 0.2%, the same as the previous month.
The Nationwide said one factor was that many people had rushed to buy houses in March because of stamp duty changes that took effect on 1 April.
Further evidence of the drop off in activity following the peak in March came in UK mortgage figures from the Bank of England.

text:
Bob Renning, 52, pulled up on a freeway in Minnesota to help another vehicle that was filling with smoke.
He told WFTV that the vehicle pulled up behind him and said the woman had been trying to find a phone and had to stop.
“I stopped. I looked in her rear view and I was going to give her a warning card, and then I’m going to call the police,” Renning said.
At first, Renning assumed the man was a good Samaritan but quickly learned his motives were not pure.
“He’s sitting in this car by himself with a little child in the back seat, and he comes up behind me and just says ‘do you have any money,’ and my heart just sunk,” Renning said. “I didn’t want to give him anything.”
He quickly called authorities on the man, who was later arrested for attempted robbery.
Law enforcement says

text:
Jack Sampson opened the scoring for the Silkmen on 25 minutes when he steered home from Danny Rowe's cross.
Grimsby gained momentum after half-time and equalised on 58 minutes through Jon Nolan's close-range finish.
Gibraltar international Reece Styche won the game for Macclesfield when he ran onto Chris Holyroyd's long ball to net his fourth goal in three games.
The Mariners remained third in the table despite the result, while Macclesfield moved up to ninth, nine points adrift of the play-off places.

text:
South Central Ambulance Service said paramedics were sent to the Mountbatten Leisure Centre at 18:30 GMT.

It is understood there were about 200 people in the centre at the time of the blaze.

Six fire engines were sent to tackle the blaze with firefighters using breathing apparatus, hoses and a ladder.

There have been no reports of any injuries and the cause of the fire is unknown.

Police said there were about 200 people in the centre when the fire started, but it was evacuated before any damage was done.

The fire service tweeted that they had “made good progress”.

Police are still working with the fire service at the scene and say it is too early to confirm what caused the fire, which happened in the foyer of the centre.

text:
Tristan Voorspuy was killed by pastoral herders on Sunday in Laikipia while inspecting some of his lodges, a local police official told Associated Press.
It follows a pattern of traditional herdsmen invading ranches in the area to seize pasture amid an ongoing drought.
Mr Voorspuy was the founder of luxury safari company Offbeat Safaris.
Martin Evans, chairman of the Laikipia Farmers Association, said Mr Voorspuy was attacked while inspecting a lodge that had been set alight by so-called "land invaders".
When he did not return by Sunday afternoon, an aerial search spotted Mr Voorspuy's injured horse but did not catch sight of the rancher, Mr Evans said.
His body was left at the scene for more than 24 hours owing to the volatile security situation, but it has since been retrieved.

Dennehy, 33, from Peterborough, is serving life for murdering three men whose bodies were found in ditches in Cambridgeshire in 2013.
She also attempted to murder two men in Hereford.
In a High Court challenge, barrister Hugh Southey QC said continued isolation left her "tearful and upset".
Dennehy is challenging justice secretary Michael Gove over HMP Bronzefield's decision to continue to keep her separated from other prisoners, which entails long periods of isolation.
She is "arguably the most dangerous female prisoner in custody", Jenni Richards QC, for the prison, said.
More on this and other stories from Cambridgeshire.
Read more about 'the woman who murdered for fun'

Mr Barroso told BBC Breakfast yesterday that the euro was the "only" solution to Britain's problems, adding: "The only solution is to be part of the single currency."

text:
Ethiopia has not commented on the reported fighting in the Tsorona area, about half-way along the frontier.
Residents on the Ethiopian side of the border reported hearing gunfire and seeing a large movement of troops and artillery towards the border.
A peace deal in 2000 ended the countries' two-year war but it has not been fully implemented.
Ever since, the countries have been in a state of "neither war nor peace", says the BBC's Ethiopia correspondent Emmanuel Igunza.
Eritrea says the tense relations with Ethiopia are why it has national conscription, which can last for decades.
It's not clear why the fighting has erupted now as neither country has issued any reasons.
But in recent months both sides have upped the rhetoric with the latest verbal salvo coming from Eritrea's President Isaias Afwerki

text:
The UN Budget Committee recognised gay spouses, regardless of whether or not gay marriage is legal in their country of origin.
Previously, the UN followed national legislation on the issue.
The vote went 80 to 43 against Russia's resolution, which had backing from China, India and Muslim countries.
EU member states and the US lobbied hard against the resolution and for UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon's plan to include gay couples in the staff benefits scheme.
Speaking after the vote, US Ambassador Samantha Power said: "We must speak plainly about what Russia tried to do today: diminish the authority of the UN secretary general and export to the UN its domestic hostility to LGBT rights" - referring to the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community.

The details are contained in report produced by researchers at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, on behalf of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
It shows that the typical household income in Northern Ireland fell by 8% during the recession, compared to a 2% fall in the West Midlands.
The research is based on official data.
It also shows that the percentage of households living in poverty - defined as living on 60% of a typical income - rose by more than 2%.
The report states that Northern Ireland started from "a relatively low base" in the pre-recession period, with typical household incomes already 6.5% below the UK as a whole.
It adds that the recent falls have "exacerbated this disparity", leaving Northern Ireland 10.2% below the UK as a whole.
The report examines household incomes using both a "before housing costs" measure and an "after housing costs" measure.
Housing costs are mortgage and rental payments.

text:
County passed up a host of chances before Liam Boyce finally put them in front, heading home for his eighth goal of the season.

They were also indebted to goalkeeper Michael McGovern for a number of crucial saves to keep Accies at bay.

The visitors came close to grabbing a late equaliser when substitute Josh Edwards was denied by McGovern and then David Templeton hit a post.

County had a chance to wrap up the win in injury time when Jordan Thompson raced clear but his effort came off the post and Accies survived.

The point for Accies was scant consolation for boss Brian Rice and he said: “We started the game superbly, got into really good positions and didn’t take our opportunities.

“As the game went on, we didn’t control the middle of the park any more and that caused us problems and the goal before half-time changed the game.

text:
Kerry Smith was selected to fight the parliamentary seat for UKIP in December but pulled out after he made offensive remarks against gay people and other UKIP members.
Ian Luder has been selected as his replacement.
Mr Luder is a former labour councillor and Lord Mayor of London.
Former Tory MP Neil Hamilton pulled out of the selection process after a letter from UKIP's finance committee was leaked to Channel 4 News querying his expenses claims for the party.
Mr Smith has announced he will contest the seat as an independent.

Fifteen-year-old Nihal Bitla was the face of India's awareness campaign against progeria.
Bitla made headlines while trying to locate 60 other Indian progeria sufferers to participate in a clinical trial in Boston with him.
He ran an active social media campaign to raise awareness about the disease.
Most recently he fronted an awareness campaign called #HatsOnForProgeria, where he appeared with a group of supporters at Mumbai's iconic Chhatrapati Shivaji railway station.
He had also appeared at a #RunForProgeria event in the southern city of Bangalore.
Bitla shot into the limelight after he met Bollywood actor Aamir Khan in December after the Facebook page "Humans of Bombay" highlighted his story and the fact that he was a "super fan" of the star.

text:
Twelve of the country's senior military figures said the UK was stronger in the EU at a time of "grave" challenges.

The former heads of the Army, Royal Navy, RAF and security agencies told MPs that their concerns had become even more acute now Britain has voted to leave the EU.

The letter to Defence Select Committee Chairman Julian Lewis also pointed out that only 16% of the UK's defence industry was actually British-owned and that membership of EU institutions meant that access to the continent's huge procurement market was guaranteed.

Without it the UK would have to rely on export to the rest of the world in order to justify investment in developing new products, they said.

Colin Farmer, 61, was stunned by police following reports of a man walking through Chorley with a samurai sword.

Police were called to a house in Chorley, Lancs on December 31, 2016 following reports of an "extremely drunk" man seen walking through the streets with a samurai sword and an axe.

As he was walking through the town centre, the drunken Farmer was spotted by a member of staff working at a local newsagents.

text:
Carwyn Jones said he supported the UK keeping its access to the market, but said individual deals for any of the home nations were unworkable

Wales would consider staying in the single market if the UK exits the European Union, its first minister said, in a major shift in policy that breaks with the government’s hardline Brexit stance.

CARwyn Jones said he supported the UK keeping its access to the market, but said individual deals for any of the home nations were unworkable.

As he spoke, business and economic organisations lined up behind a call for the UK to remain part of the single market or risk economic damage.

The first minister said: “It is not as if it was impossible to leave one part of the EU and stay in the single market.

The report for the Russell Group of universities says investment in buildings and facilities will generate thousands of new jobs.
The study analysed 69 projects undertaken by 34 Russell Group universities over the last three years. The projects involved spending £2 billion, and generated £2.6 billion of total economic impact.

The projects supported 5,087 jobs, including 2,006 construction posts, 209 apprenticeships, 345 posts in professional services, and 2,427 full-time equivalent posts during the operation of the new facilities.

The findings of the analysis by PwC are published by the Russell Group ahead of a major international conference organised by the group to explore the relationship between investment and growth in universities and cities.

He was addressing a huge Russian audience in a live televised phone-in.
He also insisted "there are no Russian troops in Ukraine". Moscow denies Western charges that it is directly arming and reinforcing the rebels.
Later he said those who had ordered the murder of Boris Nemtsov - one of his leading critics - might never be found.
Mr Nemtsov, a prominent opposition politician, was shot dead on 27 February near the Kremlin.
Five suspects, all of them Chechens, are in custody. Mr Putin condemned the murder as "disgraceful".
It was Mr Putin's 13th marathon annual phone-in with the Russian public, and lasted nearly four hours.
Mr Putin denied reports that Ukraine's President Petro Poroshenko had offered to let Russia have the rebel-held areas in the Donbas region.
The rebels reject Kiev's rule and are getting humanitarian aid from Russia, which annexed Ukraine's Crimea region last
paraphrased_text: he was addressing a huge Russian audience in a live televised phone-in with the Russian public. it was Mr Putin's 13th marathon annual phone-in with the Russian public, and lasted nearly four hours. he insisted "there are no Russian troops in Ukraine".

text:
Italy and Juventus goalkeeper Buffon, Argentina and Barcelona striker Messi and Portugal and Real Madrid forward Ronaldo were chosen by a jury of 80 coaches and 55 journalists.
Messi and Ronaldo have won the award twice - Ronaldo winning last season.
The award will be presented at the 2017/18 Champions League group stage draw in Monaco on Thursday 24 August.
Pernille Harder (Denmark, Linkoping and Wolfsburg), Dzsenifer Marozsán (Germany, Lyon) and Lieke Martens (Netherlands, Rosengard and Barcelona) are the three nominees for the women's award.
The players who make up the rest of the top 10 are:
4: Luka Modric (Croatia, Real Madrid)
5: Toni Kroos (Germany, Real Madrid)
6: Paulo Dybala (Argentina, Juventus)
7: Sergio Ramos (Spain, Real Madrid)
8: Kylian Mbappe (France, Monaco)
9: Robert Lewandowski (Poland, Bayern Munich)
10: Zlatan Ibrahimovic (Sweden, Manchester United)
paraphrased_text: Buffon, Messi and Ronaldo were chosen by a jury of 80 coaches and 55 journalists. Messi and Ronaldo have won the award twice - Ronaldo winning last season. The award will be presented at the 2017/18 Champions League group stage draw in Monaco on Thursday 24 August.

text:
Paul Maguire, of Westbourne Terrace, London, died on the A5 near Marlborough Way, in the Tamworth area, on the Staffordshire/Warwickshire border.
The 58-year-old suffered multiple injuries in the accident at about 16:40 BST on Tuesday, West Midlands Ambulance Service said.
The man driving the Ford Transit van was uninjured.

text:
Wales, competing in round two of the World League for the first time, finished second in their pool behind Italy with two wins from three.
Natalie Blyth, Beth Bingham and Eloise Laity scored against a Thailand.
It was also the second consecutive clean sheet for goalkeeper Rose Thomas after their 7-0 win over Singapore.
Wales' tournament opened with a 3-0 defeat by Italy and the convincing win against Singapore followed in Kuala Lumpur.
It is the first time Wales' women's hockey side have played at this level of competition.
In the Pool A clash with Singapore, Natasha Marke-Jones opened the scoring.
There were two goals each for Lisa Daley and Phoebe Richards, whilst Abi Welsford also found the net and Sarah Jones completed the rout.
Find out how to get into hockey with our special guide.
paraphrased_text: Wales finished second in their pool behind Italy with two wins from three. It was the second consecutive clean sheet for goalkeeper Rose Thomas after their 7-0 win over Singapore. It is the first time Wales' women's hockey side have played at this level of competition.

Van de Sanden, 23, has scored three goals in 17 games for her country and featured at the World Cup last year.
"Shanice is a hard-working striker who will add goals to the team," boss Scott Rogers told the club website.
The 2016 WSL campaign gets under way on Wednesday, 23 March.

The 54-year-old from Stoke-on-Trent went 5-0 up but was pegged back to 7-6 in the deciding frame by Ronnie in the evening session.

Bingham looked on his way back to the table to secure the win when he attempted to play a safety shot after potting a black with the cue ball behind the green.

But he completely misjudged the power with the cue and the ball ricocheted off the green and rolled towards the top cushion before coming to rest in the bottom pocket.

"I was a little nervous but I've seen plenty of them like that," said a smiling O'Sullivan.

text:
Prices briefly advertised online for holidays at the Hard Rock Hotel in the Canary Islands were too low, with the company later cancelling bookings made.
Customers were given the option to pay the remainder of the actual price, but this was often nearly double the original advertised fee.
Jet2 apologised to customers affected and said all had received full refunds.
Sarah Crosby, a BBC employee from Bramley in Leeds, originally paid £1,800 for her holiday and was then asked for an extra £1,400.
She said: "It was meant to be a big celebration for my 50th birthday, I've booked time off work for it and now I don't feel like I want to get anywhere else, I had my heart set on that.
"I just think, it's your mistake, you've advertised the holiday at that price, you should honour it for people who pay the money."
Several people told
paraphrased_text: prices advertised for holidays at the Hard Rock Hotel in the Canary Islands were too low, with the company later cancelling bookings made. customers were given the option to pay the remainder of the actual price, but this was often nearly double the original advertised fee. Jet2 apologised to customers affected and said all had received full refunds.

text:
Emmanuel Macron will take on Marine Le Pen in a run-off election on 7 May.
The candidates stand starkly divided on key issues: the EU, immigration and taxes, reports the Financial Times.
France’s pro-EU Emmanuel Macron and anti-EU National Front leader Marine Le Pen will vie to become the next president in a run-off vote on 7 May, after securing the highest votes in a first-round ballot for the French presidency, preliminary results showed.
Macron won 23.7 percent of the vote, slightly more than conservative rival Francois Fillon with 20.0 percent. But he is guaranteed to win in the second round run-off next month, as far-right challenger Le Pen has won 21.5 percent to top her National Front party.
Le Pen is now set to be the first far-right candidate to make it to the
paraphrased_text: Emmanuel Macron will take on Marine Le Pen in a run-off vote on 7 May. Macron won 23.7 percent of the vote in a first-round ballot for the french presidency. Marine Le Pen has won 21.5 percent to top her National Front party. the candidates stand starkly divided on key issues: the EU, immigration and taxes.

20 September 2016 Last updated at 15:44 BST
The CCTV film, taken from the train near Downhill Strand, shows a beach lifeguard waving to the train to warn the driver about the two pedestrians.
The footage shows the pair running from the train. They were not hit and only received some scratches in the incident.
Translink, which operates buses and trains in Northern Ireland, released the July 2015 footage as part of a campaign to raise awareness over the risk of trespassing onto rail tracks.
It said there were other near misses in September, including one involving a young person near Jordanstown, County Antrim.
The company said there were 304 incidents of trespassing on tracks between April and the end of August this year.
Hotspots included areas near Whiteabbey, Antrim and Finaghy.

text:
Applause rang out at the hearing when the decision was made to keep 76-year-old Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr in jail.
Blanton was sentenced to life imprisonment in 2001.
He was part of a group that blew up a Baptist church in Birmingham, killing an 11 year old and three 14 year-olds.
His former prosecutor said he had never expressed remorse.
Eyewitnesses talk about the Birmingham church bombing
Two other men convicted of the bombing have since died in prison.
The group bombed the 16th Avenue Baptist church, which was being used as a meeting place by black civil rights leaders, in an attempt to maintain racial separation in the southern states of the US.
Public schools in the city were facing an order to desegregate - to educate black and white children together - at the time.
The deaths

text:
Stephen Gilbert's solicitor pleaded guilty on his behalf to speeding in his Kia car at 40mph in a 30mph zone in Bath city centre.

It was only one of a number of speeding offences the Conservative MP was found to have committed.

Earlier this month it was revealed that the St Austell and Newquay MP was caught driving at an average of 89mph in a 40mph zone on the A30 between Bodmin and the A303 at Temple.

The Cornwall MP also admitted speeding on the A303 from Temple to Sturminster Newton at an average of 75mph and in his Kia at 40mph through the one-way system in Bath.

Mr Gilbert also admitted driving a Kia without insurance at 44mph in a 30mph zone at
paraphrased_text: Stephen Gilbert's solicitor pleaded guilty on his behalf to speeding in his Kia at 40mph in a 30mph zone in Bath city centre. it was only one of a number of speeding offences the Conservative MP was found to have committed.

text:
The tweets were made after a picture of the forward's child, Sofia, was posted on his Twitter page.
Vardy wrote: "The thing is you just don't know what's happening at home. You'd rather a player say 'My child has got a bad chest so I'm going to miss this game' than 'I have a bad hangover'.
"I've said to my agent if my kid's poorly, I'm not playing. If my partner's just given birth, I'm not playing. I want to be there.
"I would never play if I wasn't fit. But you'd rather a player say 'I can't be here today because my wife's giving birth' than 'I didn't sleep very well and the food in the hotel wasn't very nice. I'm a bit hungover'."
On his way to scoring

text:
Owen Paterson has denied ministers were slow to react to the outbreak.
The Chalara fraxinea fungus, which causes ash dieback, can lead to the death of large numbers of ash trees.
It was first spotted by Forestry Commission scientists in 1964 and has spread throughout mainland Europe.
In 2010, the disease was found at a nursery in Essex, and last October the Chalara was confirmed to be in ash trees in the wild.
The Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) issued advice on the disease the following day.

25 April 2013 Last updated at 17:30 ET
By Tom Edwards

Environment secretary defends government action

The government has “acted quickly” over the discovery of a potentially devastating tree fungus in the UK, environment secretary Owen Paterson has said.
paraphrased_text: last October it was confirmed to be in ash trees in the wild. The Chalara fraxinea fungus causes ash dieback and can lead to the death of large numbers of ash trees. Environment secretary Owen Paterson has denied ministers were slow to react to the outbreak.

text:
But imagine you were also not able to speak to your neighbours, watch television or do basic things like buy groceries from the supermarket.
Living in this kind of isolation is the fate of a generation of retired Chinese people, many of whom moved to Wales to work in restaurants and takeaways, but never learnt English.
The issue is being tackled at Swan Gardens, a residential complex in the heart of Swansea, which has all its signs in Chinese and satellite television from the residents' homeland.
Other features include a restaurant-standard kitchen, ping pong table and a "lucky" fishpond.
But there are no room numbers four or 14, as four sounds like "death" in Chinese and is considered bad luck.
Even for the 28 people, aged 57 to 89, who live in the St Helen's Road accommodation, there are still communication challenges to overcome.
Many of the residents cannot read or write in their own language,

text:
Lebanon defender Ramez Dayoub and forward Mahmoud El Ali have been banned for life pending an appeal after being found guilty of the offence by their national association.
The charges relate to incidents in a 2014 World Cup qualification game and a tournament in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia where the opposition were gifted a goal and an attempt was made to coerce a team-mate.
For German head coach Theo Bucker, who played for both Borussia Dortmund and Schalke in a 19-year playing career, the news has cast doubt on his own future.
"I'm really mixed up in my way of thinking these days," he told the BBC's World Football programme. "I don't know what the next step is."

text:
The ruling conservative Liberal Party has promised to hold a plebiscite on the issue if it returns to power at this weekend's election.
But questions remain over whether the party would abide by a result in favour of same-sex marriage.
Meanwhile a video has emerged of Opposition Leader Bill Shorten praising the idea of a plebiscite.
Mr Shorten last week slammed the government's plan as a "platform for homophobia" and advocated a parliamentary vote to decide the issue.
But he told a Christian lobby forum in 2013 that he would rather let the public vote on same-sex marriage than leave the issue to MPs.
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is tipped to hold power at the election on Saturday and is aiming to hold a public vote on same-sex marriage by the end of the year.

text:
The Office for Budget Responsibility's (OBR) says the UK faces the challenge of an ageing population and the high cost of an ageing population in the latest update of its economic forecasts.

In its July 2021 Economic and Fiscal Outlook (EFO), the OBR says the Government needs to raise taxes "relentlessly" in the long-run or risk public services being put in jeopardy.

This is the OBR's first EFO since the UK emerged from lockdown, the Budget in March and the Chancellor's spending plans.

The UK economy is forecast to grow 7.3 per cent this year, the most since 1941, with growth slowing to 1.7 per cent next year, before hitting 1.8 per cent in 2023.

However, the OBR warned the economy will

The attack happened in the north of the country, in the Kidal region.
The deaths of the soldiers, who were all from Chad, brings the number of UN peacekeepers in Mali killed so far this month to ten.
Mali descended into conflict after a coup in 2012, and has faced an insurgency led by Islamist militants.
French troops intervened to halt a subsequent advance by Islamist rebels but separatist violence has flared in recent months, despite the deployment of UN forces.
"We lost five comrades today in the north towards Aguelhok. Their vehicle hit an explosive device. It's terrible," a Chadian officer told AFP news agency.

text:
The draft directive would require 75% of the packet to be covered - front and back - with the warnings. But company branding could cover up to 20% of the packet, including the logo.

A minimum of the text would also be required on the front of the pack.

A consultation process on the proposals, which could lead to the directive being introduced by 2015, will begin this month after the European Commission published a report on the draft last Friday (23 January).

“The current level of health warnings on cigarette packs in the EU is outdated, and we need more and stronger health warnings, especially as the latest scientific evidence clearly demonstrates the devastating effect of smoking for consumers and the huge economic burden the industry places on society,” said EU Health Commissioner Tonio Borg.

“This measure will improve the health information to consumers about the risks of smoking and smoking-related products.

text:
Opposition MPs say an amendment to voting laws manipulates the ballot in favour of pro-government candidates.
Carrying banners reading "absolute power corrupts", demonstrators called for an election boycott and for the amendment to be repealed.
Kuwait has experienced months of unrest over the rule of Sheikh Sabah al-Sabah.
The crisis was sparked in June, when the Constitutional Court annulled parliamentary elections held in February, in which the Islamist-led opposition made significant gains. The court also reinstated the previous assembly, allied to the ruling family.
After months of protests and confrontations between the opposition and the government, Kuwait's emir ordered the dissolution of that parliament and announced new elections.
Last month, he issued a decree cutting the number of candidates a voter can elect from four to one, saying

text:
Dog walker Gavin Thomas found the scorched cub hidden in hedges close to the bodies of other cubs.
RSPCA Insp Gemma Cooper said it was "very lucky" and was receiving treatment.
South Wales Fire and Rescue Service said the fire, between Mountain Ash and Ynysybwl, had been started deliberately.
It is hoped the cub, which was initially mistaken for a puppy, will be released back into the wild later this year.

text:
Priority has been given to seven housing estates across the borough deemed in urgent need of repair - and potentially - demolition.
Today (March 19) the Leader of Newry, Mourne and Down District Council, Cllr Charlie Casey, unveiled his new housing plan to improve the standard of public housing provision in the district.
Cllr Casey said: “This is the first phase in our five year plan to improve and refurbish stock across the district. We are committed to making sure that the 4000 or so people who live in these areas have warm, dry, modern houses.
“Within this phase we have identified seven schemes where the stock is in particularly poor condition. Once the condition survey work has been completed we will be taking urgent action to begin refurbishing them as soon as is possible.”
The housing plan aims to improve over 470 dwellings in the areas
paraphrased_text: priority has been given to seven housing estates in urgent need of repair - and potentially demolition. the housing plan aims to improve over 470 dwellings in the areas in particularly poor condition. the leader of newry, Mourne and down district council, Cllr Charlie Casey, unveiled his new housing plan today.

Germany top Group C having won all six games and are five points ahead of second-placed Northern Ireland.
Bayern Munich's Robert Lewandowski netted a hat-trick for Poland in their 3-1 victory over Romania in Group E.

text:
Flintshire council is building 92 homes in Flint and work is under way on a £10m extra care housing scheme with 70 apartments for people aged over 60.
A new £5m health centre also forms part of the major redevelopment.
Flintshire council's chief officer Clare Budden said the projects would "breathe new life into the heart of the town".

text:
Thorsten Herdan told BBC News that the world can’t stabilise CO2 emissions without making polluters pay.
Mr Herdan’s idea is being backed by the German government and, if widely adopted, could see a price tag of about 110 euros ($150; £93) put on each tonne of CO2 polluted into the atmosphere in return for a carbon credit that would help a user balance its carbon footprint.

The credits would give individuals, organisations and businesses an easy way to work out their own emissions footprint.
It’s thought that if the average UK family could cut their carbon footprint by about a quarter, then they could pay the extra they wanted to by selling on the carbon credit that they had produced and not used.
Thorsten Herdan said that this “market based” idea would have the dual advantage of reducing greenhouse gases, and helping developing countries, such as

text:

But I guess I am reading this book as a Stephen King fan and I can only hope I am not an obsessed one.
But what can I do, the first chapter started off pretty well but soon I was bored out of my mind.
I thought I would read a few more pages. I would read this till the end as the book was just delivered yesterday.
But I don’t know what I was thinking because I kept on falling asleep and it kept getting worse.
What’s wrong with me?
What happened?
What did I do to not want to read this book?
I just checked the rating on Goodreads and I can relate to the 2 star rating.
I am sorry Mr. King for not liking your book.
Maybe I should just read a couple of pages every day

text:
Hailed by outgoing US President Barack Obama as probably "my closest international partner", the chancellor has cultivated the image of a statesman with a global outlook to match.

But Mrs Merkel may be about to find herself in the uncomfortable position of having to challenge some of his cherished ideas, particularly on the future of Nato, the western defence alliance that has guarded Europe against Soviet aggression since the end of World War II.

US President-elect Donald Trump has made clear that he intends to question the alliance, which he has described as "obsolete" in the absence of a direct threat, and to demand greater financial commitment from other members.

A spokesman for the new president said it was "ridiculous" for the US to pay for security in other countries.

But in a sign of just how important Nato is to Germany, the country's Foreign Secretary Sigmar Gabriel on Friday offered a

text:
The three animals were each mauled around the neck area by at least one dog in their field in the eastern part of the forest on Thursday.
They were treated by vets and underwent surgery for their wounds. They are all now in a stable condition.
Hampshire police confirmed officers had been called to the scene following the attack and were investigating.
An alpaca in the same field had also been the victim of a dog attack earlier in the year.
The owner, Susan Sears, has farmed the animals for six years and has a herd of about 80 animals which are bred for their wool.
"It's devastating.  We've bred these animals and get to know them individually - they've all got their own characters," she said.
She has set up a crowdfunding appeal to help raise money for the animals' treatment.

text:
The west London schoolgirl beat nine-year-old Saffy by spelling the word "eleemosynary", meaning charitable.
Rhea got through to the head-to-head after her mother contested an incorrect answer during her earlier specialist round about Florence Nightingale.
Independent adjudicator Olivia van der Werff later ruled it was acceptable.
The dispute centred on the question: "To which medical officer did Florence Nightingale report in the Crimea?"
Rhea's answer Duncan Menzies was initially deemed incorrect. But her mother Sonal, who gave up her job as an obstetrician to help educate Rhea, successfully argued that Nightingale effectively reported to every medical officer.
The programme was watched on Channel 4 on Tuesday by an average of 1.3 million viewers, not including +1, according to overnight ratings.

text:
Sean Donaghy will take up a new post with the Health and Social Care Board.
Health Minister Edwin Poots said that the former BBC Head of News NI Sean Donaghy has been appointed Director of Corporate Affairs at the Health and Social Care Board.
He said: “I am pleased to welcome Sean Donaghy into the role of Director of Corporate Affairs at the Health and Social Care Board.
“He has a vast experience in the media, and the board will benefit hugely from this skill set as they work towards the implementation of the new arrangements for health and social care. I wish him well in his new role.”

text:
Northamptonshire Police has applied for a Civil Destruction Order for Muppet - seized from Ingleborough Way, Duston, near Northampton, on 23 February.
The force announced the move on its Facebook page and has had 129 comments to date, most attacking the decision.
Police said letting the dog live was not a "safe option".
The dog's owner has refused to sign a destruction order, so a hearing will take place at Wellingborough Magistrates' Court on 15 October.
In total, four people were bitten and needed medical treatment.
Sgt Liam O'Neil said: "Letting the dog back was not an option. There were too many victims for this to be considered a safe option."

text:
Scientists plan to send the long-range autonomous vehicle under the sea-ice of the Arctic - from one side of the ocean basin to the other. The trip, expected to take less than a month, would set a new world record for the longest voyage across ice-covered seas by any vehicle.

"IceBreaker-ONE [the autonomous vehicle] is built to handle the harsh conditions of a polar environment," Dr. Eric Leuthold, from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, said in a statement.

"It's designed to travel long distances across the top of an ice sheet, measuring how that ice sheet behaves mechanically and changes chemically as it moves from land into the ocean," Dr. Leuthold added.

During the voyage, the IceBreaker-ONE will map an area that spans 1,000 miles by 1,000 miles over a period
paraphrased_text: a new world record for the longest voyage across ice-covered seas by any vehicle. The IceBreaker-ONE will travel 1,000 miles by 1,000 miles over a period of less than a month. the vehicle will map an area that spans 1,000 miles by 1,000 miles over a period of less than a month.

The Markit/CIPS UK manufacturing PMI fell to 51.9 in December, down from 52.5 in November. The rate of growth was broadly in line with market expectations. Output, new orders, exports, stocks, prices and input costs all fell in December.

- December PMI was unchanged from November’s 52.5. Manufacturing is expanding at its weakest pace since October 2012, but output and new orders remain positive.
- 34% of manufacturers cited a stronger export orderbook in December, although some panellists reported that overseas demand was falling due to geopolitical uncertainty.
- The slowdown was largely driven by an uptick in cost pressures.
- The rate of growth in input costs rose to the second highest since 2011.

text:
Wang Fengying had called herself "Princess Changping" and claimed to be a descendent of the Aisin Gioro family, which once ruled China, for more than a decade. She held court with visitors in the lavishly decorated living room of her 1500 square metre compound, offering guests wine from her own vineyard and cigars from her private reserve. She also drove a Mercedes Benz and enjoyed the trappings of a life of immense wealth and influence, all topped off by the knowledge that her descendants were some of the most famous people in China's history.

But last week, all of that came crashing down. Wang Fengying, who had been known as the richest woman in China, was sentenced to five years in jail for fraud. The Beijing Intermediate Court found her guilty of misrepresentation, and of defrauding her followers by selling them fake calligraph
paraphrased_text: a private estate. a Mercedes Benz. Wang Fengying had been known as the richest woman in China for more than a decade.
