The Tooting MP promised to "name and shame" landlords who had been convicted of housing-related offences.
He claimed that some council-owned properties had been turned into "hell holes".
He said: "We are going to name and shame people who are not doing their job properly."
Asked what the council had in place to tackle the issue, Mr Allan said: "We will be coming up with a series of measures to tackle the problem - we want to work with them, we want to persuade them - but we will have the legal measures too."

Mr Allan made the comments during a debate at Wandsworth Town Hall about "rogue landlords".

He claimed that a number of private landlords were not carrying out proper repairs on their properties.

"We have some landlords who do not care and we will name and shame them so that people will not rent from them

could make Barnes and Noble's Nook e-book reader available to millions of new customers, integrating it with the Microsoft's new Windows 8 operating system.
The as-yet unnamed new company will be 82.4% owned by Barnes and Noble, with Microsoft getting a 17.6% stake.
It will house the bookseller's digital and college education book businesses.
But some industry commentators believe publishers will be "terrified" at the implications of the deal.
"This deal with Microsoft could be the saviour of its digital division but won't help the bricks and mortar business," Tim Coates, managing director of Bilbary, an e-book content provider, told the BBC. "In fact it could accelerate its decline.

RAF Mildenhall is due to take delivery of 10 CV-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft and 12 MC-130J Commando II fixed-wing planes.
The USAF said up to 900 extra personnel and family members would be expected to arrive as part of its plans.
The first aircraft will be delivered this month and all 22 are expected to be based at RAF Mildenhall by 2018.
The Osprey can take-off and land vertically like a helicopter, and then its rotors tilt round to allow it to fly like a aeroplane.

text:
David Cameron has boasted that the deal he secured in Brussels with the 27 other European leaders is legally binding, and cannot be renegotiated.

In a piece of political theatre, the prime minister announced after the conclusion of a three-day summit that the 19 member states of the euro had signed up to Britain’s demands on “welfare” for migrants and an “emergency brake”.

Speaking to reporters at a press conference alongside the president of the European council, Donald Tusk, Cameron said the summit agreement, which is not even a communique but merely a set of five pages of annexes to the conclusions to the summit, is “not a verbal arrangement … it is legally binding”.

In a bid to give his agreement more gravitas, Cameron repeated 16 times in four paragraphs of the text that the deal would be legally binding.

A third man, Birrell Stewart, 30, was pronounced dead after being picked up from the water on 10 August.

The Australian Council of Graduate Research (ACGR) congratulates Dr Maria Hinfelaar on her appointment as Limerick’s institute of technology’s next president.

He is due to see a specialist this week.
"Harry's hip problem was aggravated in the game against Reading," the defender's agent, Jeremy Saul, told the Manchester Evening News."This required an injection, with a view to playing at Arsenal.

The House of Commons backed the move "as a contribution to securing a negotiated two-state solution" - although less than half of MPs took part in the vote.
The result, 274 to 12, is symbolic but could have international implications.
Ministers abstained on the vote, on a motion put forward by Labour MP Grahame Morris and amended by former Foreign Secretary Jack Straw.
Middle East Minister Tobias Ellwood said the UK reserved the right to recognise Palestine when it was "appropriate for the peace process".
In 2012 the UN General Assembly voted to upgrade the Palestinians' status to that of "non-member observer state". Some 41 nations - including the UK - abstained.

text:
Cancer Research UK said the increase in malignant melanoma rates could reflect tanning behaviour in the 1970s era of 'suntans in a tin', as most skin cancers are related to sun exposure.

The charity said it is concerned over the rise in cases, which it attributed in part to a change in tanning behaviour in the 1970s, when tanning became more fashionable.

Its report said in the past, tans came from the natural sun or the sun bed, now they are achieved by the bottle.

Suzanne McEvoy, Cancer Research UK's melanoma expert, said: "While there are many causes of the increase in skin cancer cases, it could be due to a rise in indoor tanning.

"The 1970s was a time when women were embracing a tanned look and in the past, tans were achieved

The voluntary rate of £7.85 an hour set by university researchers is 21% higher than the legal minimum wage of £6.19 for anyone over the age of 21.

Students are not obliged to accept the rates set, and can attempt to negotiate with employers for a higher rate.

However, it is expected that students will accept the £7.85 per hour, as there is no guarantee of future employment for those who are more expensive.

Employers are also only obliged to take on a minimum number of students, and may choose to hire their own staff instead.

The minimum hourly rate varies around the country, with students on average earning just £4.82 an hour in London, but earning over £6 an hour in the North West and Scotland.

text:
Alderley Edge is the kind of place where you might have thought the Conservatives could win local council seats without really trying.
The average price of a home in this leafy, Cheshire town is an impressive £900,000. The Tories’ share of the vote in the 2019 General Election was a whopping 70 per cent.
But in last month’s local council election, the Conservatives got just one seat, losing five.
One Tory, James Collis, admitted that the local party’s social media strategy may have backfired.
He was responding to a story in a rival publication that the campaign leaflets being distributed in the constituency included the slogan ‘Brexit Done’.
The same story added that the leaflets were also delivered in a box displaying the Union Jack. Mr Collis admitted to the Chester Chronicle that the party had used the

text:
In an unprecedented move Commissioner Eddie Lynch has decided to use his legal powers to look into care standards at the Dunmurry Manor home.
It follows an investigation by the South Eastern Trust in December, after concerns were raised by family members and former employees.
New admissions to the 76-bed home have since been suspended.
The commissioner will investigate not just the activities at the home, but also the response of the relevant authorities, including the health trusts involved and the Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).
Speaking about the investigation, Mr Lynch said:  "Family members have made complaints to me about the care that their relatives received in Dunmurry Manor.
"I have also heard, from former employees, that the care and protection of older people in the home was below acceptable standards and in some cases, caused harm to frail older people."
Since opening
paraphrased_text: commissioner Eddie Lynch will use his legal powers to look into care standards at the home. it follows an investigation by the south eastern trust in December. concerns were raised by family members and former employees.

text:
The Community Security Trust (CST), which monitors anti-Semitism, recorded 1,309 incidents in 2017, a 30 per cent rise from 992 incidents in 2016. However, the number was still far lower than the 1,652 in 2014.

Much of the rise was linked to social media and abuse directed at Jews supporting Israel or criticizing the Palestinian movement, the CST said in its annual report.

There was a sharp increase in anti-Semitic attacks on the right-wing Jewish blogger Stephen Pollard, who receives hundreds of anti-Semitic tweets every day.

Abuse of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn for refusing to remove prominent anti-Semites from the party's benches also helped the total.

An investigation into how Mr Corbyn's office handled anti-
paraphrased_text: the number was still far lower than the 1,652 in 2014. compared to 992 incidents in 2016. Much of the rise was linked to social media and abuse directed at Jews supporting Israel or criticizing the Palestinian movement, the CST said in its annual report.

Social workers asked a judge to look into the case after allegations were made by a number of children.
Some of the abuse, which was videoed on occasion, allegedly took place at a Birmingham hotel.
Judge Hilary Watson concluded it was "highly probable" the children had been forced to perform sex acts on animals.
"Such suggestions might seem fantastical but become a grim reality when seen in the context of my findings that the children have been made to perform sexual activities with each other," she wrote in her judgement.
She made a series of findings of facts after analysing evidence at a family court hearing in Coventry.
More on this and other stories in Coventry and Warwickshire

text:
But in an age when so much of our lives are online, little thought has been given to how we handle a person's digital world when someone dies.

As a result, social-networking sites have been inundated with the remains of dead relatives, friends or acquaintances, with users often unable to make sense of the deceased's profiles, and unable to delete them without the account owner's username and password.

In fact, Facebook is so concerned that it is even asking the British government to set up a new national register of death in order to remove these accounts faster and with greater ease.

The company has even drawn up a plan to work with a government department on such a system, which could be used by a person's friends or family to automatically notify Facebook when they die.

text:
Brij Dhande was left puzzled as to why his recycling was sometimes being collected and other times labelled as contaminated with other waste.
After installing CCTV outside his West Bromwich home, he caught the man transferring rubbish from one bin into his recycling.
Contractor Serco apologised for the "completely unacceptable behaviour".
"I'm struggling to explain it," Mr Dhande said.
"I've never met the man and have no idea what's behind it and without talking to him we're going to be at a loss."
The IT businessman said the mystery began about seven months ago and followed no regular pattern as to when his rubbish would and would not be collected.
"I've had to go through the bin sometimes to sort out the rubbish, which isn't very nice - it's not very nice for anyone to do," he said.
"Also, as taxpayers, we're paying

Brij Dhande was left puzzled as to why his recycling was sometimes being collected and sometimes labelled as contaminated. Mr Dhande said the mystery began about seven months ago and followed no regular pattern as to when his rubbish would and would not be collected.

text:
The trio were among 25 players given therapeutic use exemptions (TUEs) during the tournament in South Africa.

The use of therapeutic exemptions is allowed in international sport for athletes with medical conditions.

According to the New York Post, which reported the claims, the "large majority" of the TUEs were approved for minor ailments such as sore throats.

A total of 25 players at the tournament in Johannesburg and Cape Town received TUEs, including nine from the winning United States, according to the Post, which cited a source.

It also claimed the International Tennis Federation (ITF), the sport's world governing body, did not have the authority to decide who is eligible to receive a TUE at a major event.

ITF spokesperson Simon Spurway confirmed to insidethegames that WTA players had used TUEs in South Africa

The Duma declared that the Soviet dictator and other Soviet officials had ordered the "Katyn crime" in 1940. It said the Soviets knew the killings took place but "in their desire to justify themselves" have lied to Russia and the world.

The Duma resolution described the mass killings in the forests near Katyn and other towns in western Ukraine as a "genocide of the Polish people" and called on Putin to recognize the killings and to "punish" those responsible.

The Katyn forest massacre is one of the most enduring controversies of World War II. Soviet officials denied until 1990 that the killings had ever taken place. The Duma resolution says that the Soviets knew about the murders from the time they were carried out. Hamilton, who trails Vettel by one point in the world championship, complained consistently of tyre problems in his Mercedes and had a messy pit stop which left him having to pass three cars to take second place on the podium at Monza.

Vettel's Ferrari team-mate Kimi Raikkonen had a better pit stop but also suffered with his tyres and had to settle for third, a point behind Hamilton.

"The car was ok but the tyres were very difficult, I don't really know why," Hamilton said. "We are in the championship battle and obviously it is not always going to be a walk in the park."

"We will keep pushing. It was not an easy race but it is still good to get on the podium with third. I still don't really understand why the tyres were not working. I am not sure what the others had."

text:
The Department of Commerce said it will impose tariffs of between 14.78% to 15.97% on Chinese firms.
This compares with an earlier level of between 2.9% and 4.73% it announced in March.
China has criticised the move saying it will hurt trade relations and will provoke trade friction.
"The US is provoking trade friction in the new energy sector, and sending a negative signal to the world that stirs global trade protectionism and obstructs the sector's development," Shen Danyang, spokesman for China's Commerce Ministry was quoted as saying by the Reuters news agency.
The export of solar cells and solar panels has been a contentious issue between the US and China.
The US-based manufacturers of these products have alleged that government subsidies provided to Chinese firms have helped them cut

text:
Brailsford was unhappy with a report by a cycling website reporter and excluded him from listening to Chris Froome's media conference on Monday.
But the 53-year-old says he regrets his comments and has apologised.
"I can be a bit stubborn at times," he told BBC Radio 5 live. "We're in battle mode, but I let myself down."
Brailsford added: "It wasn't very clever and I wouldn't want my daughter doing that.
"I went and apologised to the person involved."
Team Sky rider Froome is set to win his fourth Tour de France title on Sunday after finishing third on the penultimate stage on Saturday.
The 32-year-old took time out of all his major yellow jersey rivals on a 22.5km individual time trial in Marseille.
He will not have his lead attacked on Sunday's processional final stage into Paris and will win the race for the third successive year.

text:
The malicious program demanded a payment to unlock files it scrambled on infected machines.
However, a growing number of researchers now believe the program was launched just to destroy data.
Experts point to "aggressive" features of the malware that make it impossible to retrieve key files.
Matt Suiche, from security firm Comae, described the variant as a "wiper" rather than straight-forward ransomware.
"The goal of a wiper is to destroy and damage," he wrote, adding that the ransomware aspect of the program was a lure to generate media interest.
Although the Petya variant that struck this week has superficial similarities to the original virus, it differs in that it deliberately overwrites important computer files rather than just encrypting them, he said.
Mr Suiche wrote: "2016 Petya modifies the disk in a way where it can actually revert its changes, whereas,

text:
Snap Map lets people search for places such as schools and see videos and pictures posted by children inside.
It also lets people locate their "friends" on a map that is accurate enough to determine where people live.
Snap, the company behind Snapchat, stressed to the BBC that location sharing was an opt-in feature.
Snap Map was launched on Wednesday and was promoted as a "new way to explore the world".
Video clips and photos that members have posted publicly can be discovered on the map, while members who have chosen to share their location can also be seen on the map by those they have added as "friends".

text:
Simon Buckden, 44, got more than £7,500 in money and services after pretending to have rectal cancer and convincing the NHS to pay for experimental surgery to remove a supposed tumour.

But when the operation was done, Buckden was revealed as a fraudster who had only invented his condition.

The married scammer, of Hastings, East Sussex, will now face a retrial for 20 charges including conspiracy to obtain pecuniary advantage by deception and fraud.

A jury at Canterbury Crown Court in Kent was unable to reach a decision over Buckden's guilt, despite having deliberated for a week.

He had earlier admitted to conspiracy to pervert the course of justice by having the surgery to remove a 'supposed tumour' in June 2007.

text:
Questions are being asked about the security of Pakistan's vital military installations after a well-organised group of gunmen held off Pakistan's best special forces for a full day and night before being eventually overpowered on Sunday.

The gunmen who attacked the headquarters of the elite paramilitary force had managed to get hold of at least a dozen sophisticated weapons and several rocket-propelled grenades before launching their assault.

The attackers were also able to infiltrate deep inside a fortified army base in Karachi to attack the headquarters of the elite Sindh Rangers, with the rangers facing what appeared to be better trained and equipped gunmen than they usually confront.

The attackers' sophisticated armoury raises questions about the infiltration of high-tech and military grade weapons to groups intent on attacking Pakistan's institutions and infrastructure.

text:
Under current law, emissions must be cut by 80% by 2050 - but ministers have said this does not go far enough.

The Committee on Climate Change - which advises the Government on emissions targets - said this would be "challenging but feasible".

It found that under the current target, the UK economy would have to cut emissions by 6% per year on average to 2050 - more than double the average rate so far.

This would require carbon prices - such as through carbon taxes or trading schemes such as the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) - to be raised to around £150 per tonne of carbon dioxide.

The committee said the target needs to go further if the UK wants to retain its credibility as a world leader in combating climate change.

Wales' Jones won four bouts in Hamburg to reach the final only for Canadian opponent Ivett Gonda to withdraw.
The London 2012 gold medalist missed March's Dutch Open and April's Presidents Cup with her injury.
The 22-year-old used the German event to improve her fitness ahead of the European Taekwondo Championships in Switzerland later this month.
Jones beat Jennifer Richter of Germany 21-3 in her first match of the day, and Genesis Anduja of the Dominican Republic 14-2 in the second round.
The European Games champion progressed with a 14-2 quarter-final victory over Germany's Rhonda Nat, then beat Belgian's Raheleh Asemani by the same score.

Stunned residents described a "massive whirling noise" as windows were blown in and debris smashed into cars.

It found that the number of workers filing such cases had fallen from 16,000 a month to 7,000 since the fees were introduced in 2013.

The British Medical Association renewed calls for boxing to be banned after middleweight Nick Blackwell was placed in an induced coma following his defeat by Chris Eubank Jr.

Blackwell was placed in a medically induced coma while doctors monitored his brain activity in order to minimize any further damage to his brain, according to his promoters.

Dun Deardail was constructed on a prominent knoll on Sgorr Chalum, a hill overlooking the River Nevis in Glen Nevis.
AOC Archaeology, which will lead volunteers in the dig, has described the site as "enigmatic".
Little is known about the origins of the fort, who built it or when it was constructed.
The first phase in a three-year project will examine the defences.
They were vitrified, meaning stone and wood in the defensive walls were burned at a high temperature for a long time to fuse the stone together.
Examples of vitrified forts can be found across Scotland, including in Aberdeenshire.
The Lochaber site has never before been excavated or dated with any accuracy.
Forestry Commission Scotland, which is supporting the project, said it may have been constructed in the first millennium BC or first millennium AD.

text:
More than once he tried to escape out of a first-floor window, convinced his teacher was criticising him.
He is not alone - and teachers have long known that pupils with autism are prone to bolting. But now researchers have identified what goes on inside the young person's mind in these moments, giving fresh hope of tackling the behaviour and perhaps preventing the bolting altogether.
The study, carried out at the University of California, has shown that children with autism who are about to run away experience a heightened sense of threat and distress from others, making them more sensitive to the fear they believe they are causing. They also found the threat of criticism from others makes them feel they are being unfairly singled out.
The researchers were surprised to find that children with autism were so distressed because their perceptions of how others might see their behaviour is so distorted.
One of the lead researchers, Christy Llerena, said
paraphrased_text: he tried to escape from a first-floor window, convinced his teacher was criticising him. But now researchers have identified what goes on inside the young person's mind in these moments, giving fresh hope of tackling the behaviour.

At the time I described the changes as some of the most radical in the history of the Tube.
Almost exactly two years on and we are on the brink of another strike over the same issue.
Back then, further strikes were called off when the late Bob Crow received assurances that: "London Underground had agreed a station-by-station review of the ticket office closures, which could mean that some will stay open."
That didn't happen and nearly all ticket offices were shut by last December.
And what followed was a huge reorganisation.
Staff have been moved from behind ticket offices onto gate lines - driven by the use of Oyster cards and bankcards - and around 838 staff have been cut, to save about Â£40m a year.
This is called the Fit for the Future (FFTF) programme and it has fundamentally changed the way staff work on the Underground.

But crossing the desert can be as dangerous as crossing the Mediterranean - and a group of young men in a backstreet compound sit nervously and in silence.
In one corner of the walled yard is a pile of five-litre jerry cans, each with a sackcloth cover and strap.

South Yorkshire Police has charged one person for every 16 child sexual exploitation complaints over two years.
It also brought among the fewest prosecutions of child abusers in the past three years, according to the CPS.
Lib Dem Lord Scriven said victims had been "let down", while the force stressed CSE investigations involved "highly complex evidence".

South Yorkshire was among 10 constabularies to which the BBC sent Freedom of Information requests.

The vessel is believed to be a pinnace - a small boat which would have acted as a supply boat for larger ships.
It is likely to have gone down with its parent ship when the German High Seas Fleet was scuttled in 1919, following the end of World War One.
A team from Orkney diving boat MV Valkyrie came across the wreck after an unexpected object was picked up on sonar equipment.
Diver Simon Brown expected to find a lump of anti-torpedo boom net.
Instead he discovered a German vessel which has lain undiscovered for almost 100 years.
Skipper Hazel Weaver told BBC Radio Scotland: "There's lots of piles of steel boom netting dumped after the First World War and the Second World War in Scapa Flow and we assumed it was a pile of that."

He said adherents of an extremist interpretation of Sunni Islam posed the greatest terror threat to Australia.
But he stressed "99.9% of Australian Muslims" were of no interest to ASIO.
Mr Lewis said in 2013, 45% of suspected Sunni Islamic extremists were aged between 25 and 34. Two years later, 40% were aged between 15 and 24.
"It basically dropped by a decade in the space of a couple of years," he told a senate estimates hearing on Tuesday night.
"We are still looking at a very young cohort that are impacted and influenced by this... extremist, violent message."

A residents' levy to fund the site, managed by Port Marine Management Ltd (PMML), was scrapped in 2015 after complaints about cost.

Darpa, the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, has awarded computing giant IBM a $3.5m (Â£2.1m) contract to work on its Vanishing Programmable Resources (VAPR) project.
It is looking to develop a class of "transient" electronics that can be destroyed by remote control.
The kit could be used in combat zones.
IBM's proposal involves the use of a radio frequency trigger that could shatter a glass coating on a silicon chip and turn it into powder.
"A trigger, such as a fuse or a reactive metal layer will be used to initiate shattering, in at least one location, on the glass substrate," the US government said in its grant award notice.
Darpa wants to develop large distributed networks of sensors that can collect and transmit data for a limited period and then be destroyed instantly to prevent them falling into enemy hands.

Stoke Gifford Parish Council voted on Tuesday to charge Parkrun a fee to use Little Stoke Park, near Bristol.

Parkrun is a free, 5km run which is held every Saturday at 9am in more than 40 locations across the UK.

A geophysical survey has now confirmed the outline of a late-medieval building in the outer ward, where the king could have been born.
Neil Ludlow, consultant archaeologist, said it shone new light on the castle.
Much of the interior of the castle, which dates from the 11th Century, was destroyed after the Middle Ages.
The survey also revealed up to three previously unknown buildings in the inner ward, as well as several buildings and a possible well in the outer ward. All are invisible to the naked eye.

text:
The pictures show the Oxfordshire stately home before it opened to the public for the first time.
Staff at the World Heritage Site, which opened in the summer, are delighted to be welcoming visitors again after a £6.3million restoration project.

The beautiful landscape park, with its historic avenues of towering limes, had been shut to visitors to allow for repairs to a number of historic structures, including the Grade II-listed icehouse, walled kitchen garden and fernery.

Work to restore the grounds was carried out by The Landscape Partnership – a joint venture led by The National Trust, which acquired Blenheim Palace in 1984 and handed it back to the 12th Duke in 2003.

Highways England's regional director Rob Gittins said: "Our team are out clearing drains and treating major routes but drivers are advised that the worst of the weather has not yet arrived and so they should consider delaying their journeys on Wednesday where possible."

The Met Office has issued a yellow warning of wind for the majority of the region.

text:
The "Fighting Bradfords", from County Durham, between them won two Victoria Crosses, two Military Crosses and a Distinguished Conduct Medal

THE two "Fighting Bradfords" of World War One, brothers who won a total of two Victoria Crosses, two Military Crosses and a Distinguished Conduct Medal between them, were born and bred within yards of each other in a tiny North-East hamlet.

But although they fought side-by-side, brothers Sergeant Walter and Lance-Corporal Harry Bradford were killed on opposite sides of the battlefield 102 years ago, on the same day.

The Bradfords' families were close, and Harry and Walter lived in neighbouring cottages in Langley Park, County Durham, about a mile from Beamish Museum.

Tristan Voorspuy was killed by pastoral herders on Sunday in Laikipia while inspecting some of his lodges, the company he owns, Voorspoor Management Ltd. (VM), confirmed on Monday.

The death of the 48-year old British citizen has brought the country’s security situation under scrutiny once again with the latest statistics showing that 140 security officers have been killed since 2005. Voorspoor was a decorated officer in the British military.

“He was tragically shot while travelling in a small team along some of the tracks around his lodges to assess the damage from the recent floods,” the company said.

“He was killed by pastoralist herders as a result of their conflict with landowners,” according to VM.

"Somebody somewhere killed Yusuf and the person is walking round - that is not fair."
A 21-year-old man and 17-year-old boy arrested on suspicion of murder are on bail pending further inquiries.
Mrs Sonko begged people to contact police if they could help in any way.
She said: "Anybody please, please from the family, from everybody, from all over the world, anybody knows who killed Yusuf please tell the police. What happened is not right."
And she added: "Yusuf was only 18-years-old. He hadn't started life."
Mrs Sonko described her son as a "humble, kind and respectful" boy who hoped to study business at university later this year.

James Boysen, who is 55 and from Texas, was missing the whole of the crown of his head after treatment for a rare type of cancer.
He was also given a new kidney and pancreas during the procedure.
The software developer said he was "amazed" at how he feels after the surgery at Houston Methodist Hospital and the Anderson Cancer Center.
Mr Boysen was diagnosed with leiomyosarcoma in 2006.
The cancer of the muscle on the scalp was treated with a combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, but it permanently damaged the surrounding tissue.
The scalp and skull were destroyed by the treatment, leaving his brain vulnerable.

text:
About 6,000 rocks are known in Britain to have ancient cup and ring carvings. More than 2,000 of them, the vast majority, are found in the Lake District, and almost all of these are in the central and southern parts of the National Park.

Most Lake District carved stones are in a few valleys – Eskdale, Duddon, Seathwaite, Wasdale and Dunnerdale – and more recently in the Rannerdale area. A few outliers include rocks on Black Combe, Grasmere Common, and in the Lingdale and Swindale valleys. The rocks vary in size from a few centimetres to the massive Cumbrian Stone at Great Stony Cairn, which measures 4m by 1.7m.

It is launching a new pilot scheme for its Dorset kerbside collection scheme in a bid to reduce the number of black bags left outside properties and improve the service offered.

It is working in partnership with local councils to roll out the scheme in Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, East Dorset and North Dorset. The other local authorities will be added over the coming weeks.

From 16 September, it will issue free reusable authorised blue bags. Residents will be able to obtain more bags, if needed, from the relevant Dorset Council locality.

The annual inflation rate as measured by the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) rose to 0.6% in July from 0.5% in June, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

This is the first time that the rate of inflation has hit 0.6% since October 2014, when it stood at 0.7%, while the annual inflation rate has increased in eight of the past 12 months.

Inflation has been below the Bank of England’s 2% target since August 2014, and has averaged 0.2% since September 2012.

The rise in the annual inflation rate is in large part due to the increase in petrol and diesel prices, which the ONS attributed to the weakness of sterling against the US dollar since the UK voted to leave the European Union (EU).

What's different about this paint is that some particles are on a nanotech scale, at just one thousandth the width of a human hair. When nanoparticles, like those in this paint, are added to standard white paint, they give it the ability to reflect sunlight and thus deflect away heat.

text:
James Macmillan attacked father-of-five Mahmoud Hussein in Birmingham before running away, leaving him for dead.
Walsall Crown Court heard the Muslim community worker, who lived alone in a supported accommodation block, had asked for cigarettes and been given some by Mr Macmillan.
But in a “racially motivated” attack the following day he kicked Hussein, aged 31, about his head and abdomen and left him for dead.
The 27-year-old admitted manslaughter and was jailed for six years on Wednesday.

Judge Melbourne Inman, QC, said there had been a dispute between two men, Mr Macmillan and a man called Ali Hassan.

The US company's DNA testing service has included a right to grant Ancestry a "perpetual" licence to use customers' genetic material.
A New York data protection lawyer spotted the clause and published a blog warning about privacy implications.

A group of teenagers made the find behind a row of shops in the town of Humpty Doo on Sunday.
The heads belonged to crocodiles ranging from between three and four-feet to eight and nine-feet long, said Crocodylus Park manager Steve Salisbury.

Crocodile skulls in Northern Australia’s Top End are a common sight, said Salisbury, who has worked with crocodiles for more than three decades.

But it’s unusual for a group of young people to uncover so many skulls in a relatively short amount of time, he said.

“It’s a big find,” Salisbury said. “They could have just found one and kept looking, but they’ve actually found a whole lot.”

Attacks continue to be relatively infrequent, but they are frightening enough to lead politicians to take measures to try to avoid them. And it is that a bite from a great white shark can easily be fatal to a person, as in the case of the attack last year on a diver near Cape Town in South Africa.

Taha Hussain, 21, from Slough is on trial accused of nine counts of disseminating terror documents via smart phone apps including WhatsApp.
The Old Bailey heard he became increasingly extreme in the two years before his arrest in August last year.
The defendant denies all the charges against him.

The measures will place significant emphasis on wind and solar power and other renewable energy sources.

Thirty-four people were killed when police opened fire on striking platinum miners on Thursday.
At least 78 people were injured in the confrontation.
Mr Zuma, who cut short a visit to Mozambique to visit the scene, said he was "saddened and dismayed" at the "shocking" events.
"I am convinced that the Commission of Inquiry will uncover the truth and facts will emerge," he said in a statement after meeting police and injured workers.
Visibly distraught, he said it was not a time for finger-pointing but he would try to make sure such a loss of life never happened again.
By Martin PlautBBC World Service Africa editor

Claimants will have to show they have suffered serious harm before suing for defamation, under the Defamation Bill.
It will be a new defence if the claimant was not identifiable from the defamatory statement or that they did not suffer any harm.
This change, which was originally recommended by the Leveson Report, has been opposed by free speech campaigners.
It means less protection for the public in general in this area of law.
The Leveson Inquiry into phone-hacking and the culture, practices and ethics of the UK press was set up after revelations in the summer of 2011 by The Guardian newspaper that News International, owner of the News of the World and the now-defunct Sun on Sunday newspapers, had engaged in illegal interception of telephone voice mails.

His forces have been steadily recapturing rebel-held towns near the Lebanese border for several months.

Drug errors, lack of staff and falls were highlighted by the Care Quality Commission in its review.
Safety was also a major issue in other services for the elderly and disabled, including care homes and home help.
The CQC said the failings were "completely unacceptable", as it unveiled the full findings of its new inspection regime for the care sector.
The new "tougher" system was launched in 2014, amid concerns problems were going undetected.
The CQC has now completed inspections for all 24,000 services in the sector, which provide care to one million vulnerable people.
More than 200,000 of them live in nursing homes, which had the most serious problems.

The Centre for Carbon Measurement will be based at the National Physical Laboratory in south-west London.
It will raise accuracy of equipment used to measure carbon dioxide levels

A new laboratory to improve the accuracy of measuring devices used to test levels of CO2 in the atmosphere has been announced.

The Centre for Carbon Measurement (CCM) will bring together scientists and researchers to improve measurements of carbon dioxide.

The centre will be based at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL) in Teddington, south-west London.

It will include £11.4 million investment from the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills.

Streams came out of a team challenge where staff were tasked with creating a wearable device that could help improve outcomes for those living with type 1 diabetes. This product aims to help people with the disease to manage their condition with improved real-time data and early warnings, enabling better choices and improving overall quality of life. Streams provides a way for those with the condition and their loved ones to see how they’re doing, by using wearable sensors that allow real-time monitoring of physiological data and early warning of potentially dangerous situations.

text:
With their sides battling for a first Heineken Cup final appearance and both players' eyes on the British and Irish Lions squad announced two weeks tomorrow, the two captains were never going to be short of motivation.

England back rower Nick Easter and Welsh forward Dan Lydiate - the only players to have started every Heineken Cup game this season - were evenly matched for much of the second half as Harlequins and Toulon both fought for a spot in Saturday's final against Munster at Twickenham Stadium.

But as the clock ticked into the final quarter, the two flankers began a prolonged personal duel that seemed likely to decide which side would progress. Both showed their skill in defence and attack but, as he has done all season for the champions of France, Lydiate was able to impose himself on the game.

Quins could not match the French side's power

Striker Mandy Islacker angled just wide with Germany's best effort after half-time in a game of few chances.

In a scrappy opening period England had the better of the game and should have taken the lead on nine minutes when defender Laura Bassett found herself unmarked in the area but headed straight at Nadine Angerer.

Fara Williams headed narrowly wide at the far post and Fran Kirby was denied by a last-ditch tackle as England kept the World Cup holders penned in for long periods.

The second half fizzled out with both teams guilty of some poor passing and the only real chances of note came late on as substitute Islacker forced a save from Karen Bardsley.

England host Finland in the group stages of their first Women's World Cup next week.

text:
The Royal Bank of Scotland has identified barriers which starter farmers are struggling with, including the physical size of modern farms.
Bigger farms are often unaffordable when they come on the market and are being bought up by neighbours.
RBS wants more joined-up action to help unlock the potential it says young farmers can bring.
New farmer John Matheson has a hundred suckler cows in a twisting, steep sided glen on the River Deveron in Aberdeenshire.
He has been there for just eighteen months, despite wanting his own farm since the age of eight. He is now in his 50s.
John previously had livestock on rented grass but the locations were spread far and wide meaning a drive of almost 30 miles each day to tend them.
He said: "I can now get up in the morning at seven o'clock and I'm finished feeding and have seen everything by nine in the morning.

# Panda bears might hibernate this winter to escape extreme Chinese cold

The Chinese government announced the unusual move this week to help combat a national energy crisis.

Hibernation, the sleepy-time state in which an animal lies dormant in a dark, warm place, is a familiar scenario. But the idea has been proposed by the Chinese government for one animal that we're not used to seeing snooze: the giant panda.

This isn't to imply that pandas regularly spend their days out and about and just need a few extra z's. Like most bears, they typically retreat into a state of torpor between November and April, when food is scarce. But a growing energy

The announcement came at the first US-Africa Leaders' Summit, attended by over 40 African heads of state.
The partnership between the world's two largest coffee producers is a historic opportunity.
The agreement will help Ethiopia export coffee from ports in neighboring Djibouti as well as in Somaliland and Berbera.
The agreement also aims to increase export capacity, strengthen logistics, and improve processing facilities.
The first container ship from Berbera to Djibouti left in late 2018 and marked the start of a trade corridor that could connect both countries with Ethiopia.
As of now, Ethiopian Coffee is imported from Djibouti to the port of Berbera where it is stored until it is shipped back to Ethiopia.

text:
Like bats who emit sounds in order to navigate, researchers can now plug sounds into a computer algorithm to map a room.
The team were able to determine how close a robot was to a wall by measuring the time it took to reach the wall, as well as the time it took for the sound to bounce back from the wall.
This is the first time computer scientists have created such a system without using a camera.

### How the Algorithm Works

With this system, the researchers are able to determine the location of walls and the distance to the wall from the robot’s position.
“If you think of a robot in a room with one big wall,” said computer science Ph.D. student Yuanzhong Xie, one of the lead researchers on the project. “It can go up to that wall and then bounce off the wall. It can also go behind the wall. If the robot knows where the first wall is, it
paraphrased_text: researchers were able to determine how close a robot was to a wall by measuring the time it took for the sound to bounce back from the wall. ### How the Algorithm Works With this system, researchers are able to determine the location of walls and the distance to the wall from the robot’s position.

Nick Hardwick, chief inspector of prisons, said Thameside jail in south-east London was effectively in lock down for much of the day. He said: "What we have is a jail in chaos, and that is not exaggeration."

A report published today by the prison inspectors found that conditions in Thameside had deteriorated "dramatically" since a previous inspection.

"Violent assaults on staff and each other are commonplace," Mr Hardwick said. "In many ways, Thameside is in lockdown for the majority of the day, which is very bad for prisoners.

"Violence is the biggest cause of death and injury in our prisons. It causes terrible pain and suffering, and it costs the taxpayer millions in damages. We cannot afford these scandals, not now. There is a national emergency in our prisons. This has got to change."

His comments come as his select committee publishes its report on the next science budget.

Asked how he would balance the priorities, he said: "There's no simple way of doing that but it should be thought about in much more depth by ministers and civil servants."

He headed a review last year into funding for science, engineering and technology.
The report is due to be presented to the prime minister and his cabinet today.

Her legal team asked to speak for 10 minutes to the judges, saying Savchenko needed more time as she had never had a chance to study Russian law, and needed to study it before making the most important decision of her life.

text:
Nobody can be totally sure when 'the business end of the season' actually starts or, indeed, what the phrase really means.
But if there was any doubt, a week of matches like last week certainly provides some clarification.
As well as one-sided encounters in the Premier League on Saturday and Sunday there was the Manchester derby, Arsenal v Chelsea, Tottenham's last-gasp win at Crystal Palace and Everton's home defeat by Swansea.
Throw in some exciting matches in midweek between West Ham and Sunderland, Burnley and Swansea, Liverpool and United, Southampton and Everton and you're beginning to see how the games at this stage are not only about who wins what.
If you're going well, a couple of defeats can suddenly send you into 'what's happening? territory' while a loss might just provide the impetus for a revival.

text:
The civil conflict erupted in December 2013 after Mr Kiir accused Mr Machar of plotting a coup.
Since then tens of thousands of people have died and almost 2 million people have fled their homes.
The United Nations says the conflict in the country could lead to a genocide.

## ‘Deeper levels of mistrust’

But after weeks of talks in the capital, Juba, the two leaders signed a deal that includes the formation of a transitional government of national unity to lead South Sudan.
“Today our journey to a lasting peace begins,” Mr Kiir told supporters in Juba, where the ceremony took place.
Mr Machar said they had “overcome difficulties and made the final push to peace”.
But he added that both men had to “move beyond our own ego”, with South Sudan’s people to “take us forward”.

Speaking in French at a Paris press conference with his French counterpart Jean-Marc Ayrault he said the two would work together "to improve our relations with Iran and to promote a positive development" after the Islamic regime agreed to freeze its nuclear program for six months.

The deal, which emerged on Sunday after days of tense talks in Geneva with western powers, the EU and Iran, will see the Islamic Republic keep its nuclear facilities but prevent it from increasing its capacity and enrichment of uranium.

Austrian Chancellor Werner Faymann (SPÖ) meanwhile was cautious about the nuclear deal reached with Iran, but described it as “an important first step”. The new engines are due to only be introduced in the next-generation MG 350/2.5 TDI.

Diesel engines are becoming popular in the new generation of small-capacity cars.

But the MG 350/2.5 TDI is the first small car to come with a diesel engine that is a twin-turbocharger, turbochargers, and high-compression diesel engines.

The new engine also offers better performance than the diesel engines in the MG2 and MG3.

text:
Disability hate crime is "overlooked" and "under-reported", a joint inspectorate review into police, probation and social services has found.

A report into how local authorities, police forces and the probation service responded to reports of disability hate crime in England found that most did not have policies to make clear how they would investigate such crimes.

The report - Disability Hate Crime: How the Criminal Justice System and Local Authorities Respond, by inspectors from HM Inspectorate of Constabulary and HM Inspectorate of Probation (HMIP) - found evidence of good practice and improvements in response to disability hate crime since the 2008 review but also found problems, including a lack of awareness about disability hate crime and poor quality investigations.

The inspectors called for clear leadership of responses to disability hate crime across all relevant organisations and a commitment to improve services for victims. They also
paraphrased_text: "under-reported", a joint inspectorate review has found. disability hate crime is "overlooked" and "under-reported", a report has found. a joint inspectorate review into police, probation and social services has found. disability hate crime is "overlooked" and "under-reported", a report has found.

Speaking from his hospital bed in Belfast, Matthew Bryce said he was grateful to be receiving treatment following his ordeal.
The 22-year-old from Glasgow was picked up by a coastguard helicopter 13 miles off the Argyll coast on Monday night after going surfing on Sunday morning.
He is now receiving treatment for the effects of hypothermia.
In a statement, issued through Ulster Hospital, Mr Bryce said: "I am so grateful that I am now receiving treatment in hospital.
"I can't thank those enough who rescued and cared for me - they are all heroes.
"For now, I am not facilitating any interviews as I am exhausted. Please respect the privacy of myself and my family at this time as I recover."

Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH), which is part of a project to restore large areas of the peatland, said the model could form part of its strategy on the climate impact of agriculture.

The model was created by James Currie, who is studying for a PhD at the University of Edinburgh, and is being presented at the British Ecological Society meeting in Belfast today. The research is being funded by the Scottish Government.

SNH estimates that about 1.6 million hectares of peatland in Scotland were drained over the past three centuries by landowners looking to reclaim land that could be used for farming. Much of the damage was done in the 19th and early 20th century.

The euro fell against both the pound and the dollar as markets assessed potential interest rate moves over the next few months.
The European Central Bank is expected to maintain its loose monetary policy for some time to come.
However, markets are now waiting for rate rises in the UK and US.
On Tuesday, Bank of England governor Mark Carney said that the point at which UK interest rates may begin to rise was "moving closer".
And on Wednesday, US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen reiterated her view that US interest rates are likely to rise before the end of the year.

text:
Dr Brian Harris, 77, denies 13 counts of rape, sexual assault and indecent assault against five men between 1991 and 2011.
The jury at Merthyr Crown Court was told on Friday he will not give evidence in his own defence.
Dr Harris had worked for the NHS and in private practice in Cardiff for 40 years.
His legal team told the court he had been assessed by a clinical psychologist last July and August who concluded Dr Harris was likely to have experienced significant cognitive decline, more than would be expected as part of normal ageing.
There was strong evidence, the court was told, of a significant decline in his intellectual ability and his ability to recall.
The trial began three weeks ago.

The Campaign for Accountability identified 329 research papers published between 2005 and 2017 on public policies that were indirectly or directly funded by the search giant.
Google hit back saying the group refused to name its own corporate funders.
It added that it valued researchers' "independence and integrity".
The Campaign for Accountability runs a series of projects, including one named The Google Transparency Project, which aims to expose the practices of the search giant.
CfA executive director Daniel Stevens said: "Google uses its immense wealth and power to attempt to influence policy makers at every level. At a minimum, regulators should be aware that the allegedly independent legal and academic work on which they rely has been brought to them by Google."

text:
A deal with the National Aeronautical Centre (NAC) in Wales will see aircraft tested for military or civilian use.
The NAC, which has authority to fly drones, said it was attracted to Newquay because its 3,000m runway is bigger than in Wales.
Testing will take place in a 3,000 sq mile segregated area for unmanned aircraft over the sea.
Ray Mann, from the National Aeronautical Centre, said: "We fly about three or four missions a day in west Wales.
"We have a 1,200m runway, but Newquay has one of the longest runways in the UK which is a huge advantage."
The NAC's agreement could see a number of its clients, which include the Ministry of Defence and Thales, operate their aircraft from Newquay.
Mr Mann said the firm was attracted by the prospect of office, hangar and security

Seamer James Anderson will miss the match with a side strain suffered in England's win at Edgbaston, which put them 2-1 up in the five-Test series.
Yorkshire's Plunkett, 30, played the last of 13 Tests in June 2014, while Derbyshire's Footitt, 29, is uncapped.
Under-pressure opener Adam Lyth, also of Yorkshire, has been retained.
As well as Anderson's certain absence, doubt remains over the fitness of Mark Wood after the 25-year-old Durham seamer missed the third Test with an ankle injury, though England are hopeful he will recover in time.
"We felt bringing in two extra bowlers in Liam Plunkett and Mark Footitt was necessary," said national selector James Whitaker.

Mzee Mohammed, 18, was detained by security staff at Liverpool One shopping centre where he was seen "behaving erratically" with a knife.
He suffered "a medical episode" while in the custody of police, and later died in hospital.
Further tests will be carried out to establish what caused his death.
The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) is investigating his death.
IPCC Commissioner Carl Gumsley said investigators had met with Mr Mohammed's family as part of its evidence gathering.
He said it was too early to "comment on or verify any accounts from any source as to what occurred at this time".

Mr Li is on an official visit to France where a UN-led climate summit will be held later this year.
After meeting officials in Brussels, he said the details would be announced by the end of the month, which is Tuesday.
Last November, China - the world's top greenhouse gas emitter - committed for the first time to limit its output.
Chinese President Xi Jinping said the country would target 2030 for its emissions to peak.
At a press conference in Brussels on Monday after meetings with EU leaders Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker, Mr Li said China would submit its Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) report to the UN secretariat on climate change "by the end of this month".
All countries are supposed to submit their INDC, as the pledges are called by the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, before the Paris summit in November.

text:
In the jittery days that have followed the violent clashes between Lebanon's army and fighters loyal to the radical Sunni preacher, Sheik Ahmed al-Assir, some Lebanese have tried to place this latest crisis in Lebanon's long history of sectarian conflict. Alas, the more it is understood, the more it baffles.

Some of those who have weighed in say this clash marks the beginning of the end for the Shiite-led regime of Hezbollah. Some, such as retired Maj. Gen. Michel Aoun, a former Lebanese Army commander, say this latest conflict is a direct consequence of the U.S. decision to intervene in the Syrian civil war in favor of the rebels. It marks the first time prescription drug spending for diabetes has exceeded the figure for asthma (Â£863m) in a single year.

Three other people were injured, one seriously, in the incident which happened between Arbroath an Montrose, near the Maryton junction.

One fire engine from Arbroath, an ambulance, police and coastguard helicopter were called to the scene at 10.30pm on Saturday.

A fire service spokesman said: “We sent one engine from Arbroath and this arrived within minutes to find a car on its roof in the central reservation.

Two women and a man, who all suffered minor injuries, were also taken to hospital.

text:
The road bridge over the River Wharfe at Tadcaster partially collapsed in December, with a temporary footbridge currently connecting the two sides.
Plans to widen the bridge were agreed at a council meeting, but in a letter the Samuel Smith's Brewery said the proposal contradicted planning policy.
The brewery did not wish to comment.
Repairs to the bridge are set to conclude in December, with paths widened to improve safety for pedestrians.
The seven-page letter said the proposal was "contrary to the provisions of the adopted Development Plan and national planning policy".
It said the move could impact "important nature conservation interests" and did not consider the effect it would have "on the behaviour of flood waters".
Chris Metcalfe, county councillor for Tadcaster at North Yorkshire County Council, said the brewery could apply for a judicial review on the move.

While he found his new home was a "nurturing and healing environment", Mr McKinniss was disappointed that the sexual revolution had not spread to everyone.

"It was a real shame that the revolution didn't include the sexuality of women," he said. "In those communes, women were still considered to be the nurturers. Women weren't considered to be the equals of men. They were still expected to bear children and to clean and cook.

Jets were scrambled 943 times in fiscal year 2014, a 16% increase on 2013.
This is just one shy of the record 944 scrambles in 1984, during the Cold War when aircraft from the former Soviet Union were very active around Japan.
But no aircraft violated Japan's airspace, the ministry said.
Japan's national broadcaster NHK said fighter scrambles dropped to around 150 annually after the Cold War ended.

Priority has been given to seven housing estates across the borough deemed in urgent need of repair - and potentially - demolition.
Town planners said 20,000 people will be affected - and 8,500 homes. The work will last 15 years.

text:
The next series of The Apprentice is going to look somewhat different.
The 42-year-old comedian has confirmed he’s going to appear in next year’s series as an adviser. He’s joining Lord Alan Sugar and Karren Brady, who have served as the show’s advisers since it first hit our screens in 2005.

The entrepreneur turned actor recently spoke to The Sun about his involvement, in which he confirmed that, despite his role, he’s “not going to be an extra in it”.
“I’m not going to be an extra in it,” he told the publication. “I won’t be an adviser, but I’ll be playing myself, I’ll be myself and I’ll be saying, ‘Come on guys, get a clue!’”
We’re so here for it.
The actor added: “So I’ll just
paraphrased_text: comedian will join Lord Alan Sugar and Karren Brady as advisers. he says he’s not going to be an extra in the show.

text:
Three beavers have been filmed together on the River Otter in Devon.
Landowner David Lawrence is mystified about where the animals have come from.
A spokesman for the Department for Food, Environment and Rural Affairs said it was unlawful to release beavers in England and they were looking into what action to take.
A lone beaver was spotted on Mr Lawrence's farm in January and last July a woman claimed she saw a beaver on the River Otter.
But this is the first time anyone has reported a group of the animals on the river.
Environmentalist Tom Buckley filmed the beavers gnawing trees, grooming themselves and playing on the riverbank.
Steve Hussey from the Devon Wildlife Trust, said there was evidence that otters and beavers were sharing a waterway, for the first time in two or three hundred years.
"But this

text:
The Fitzwilliam Museum needed £85,000 to secure the sculpture of the Mater Dolorosa by Pedro de Mena, which would otherwise have been auctioned.
Museum director Tim Knox said the fundraising was "right to the wire".
A "last-minute rush in donations" helped them meet the deadline, he said.
The Cambridge University museum's bid to purchase the Virgin of Sorrows sculpture was supported by £30,000 from the Art Fund and £10,000 from The Henry Moore Foundation.
However, a further £85,000 was needed by the end of September to prevent the private owner from selling it publicly.
Last-minute donations and "extremely generous donors who promised to make up the shortfall" had secured the sculpture for the museum, Mr Knox added.
"This has been right to the wire, and every single penny

The aim is to develop an algorithm that can automatically differentiate between healthy and cancerous tissues.
This "segmentation" is necessary in patients with head and neck cancers.
And it is hoped the time it takes to design targeted radiotherapy treatments could be cut from four hours to one.
"Clinicians will remain responsible for deciding radiotherapy treatment plans," UCLH said.
"From my perspective, one of the challenges that we have in the treatment of all tumours, but particularly brain and neck [tumours], is their complexity," said Dr Kieran Breen, of Brain Tumour Research, who is not involved in the work.
"One way we can really improve this is by using the knowledge we already have," he told the BBC.
"This is essentially what this project is doing."

text:
The Bank of Scotland found the amount of new business fell "at a marginal pace", while backlogs of work also declined.
New export orders contracted at a slower pace but the amount of new orders fell more quickly.

"It is not clear whether this can be attributed to a fall in demand or supply chain delays," the survey report said.

The business optimism index rose to the highest level since March.

The report also found that staffing levels grew at a slower rate but were stronger than expected.

Jobs grew more slowly than in April but at the fastest pace since May 2016.

The sector confidence index increased to 19.1 from 17.4 in April, while

text:
It said such policies offer "poor value for money".
"Firms must start putting consumers first, and stop seeing them as pound signs," said Christopher Woolard, director of policy at the FCA.
The insurance industry rejected the accusations, calling some of them unhelpful.
Add-on insurance is where a policy is sold alongside another product.
For example, customers buying a mobile phone, or a holiday, are often offered insurance at the same time.
Nearly 3,000 consumers have complained about such policies in the past nine months.
The FCA found that a quarter of customers buying them were unaware that they could get similar products elsewhere.
And more than half of such customers did not compare the different policies available.
The FCA judged add-on policies by their "claims ratio".
This measures the proportion of the initial cost of a product that is eventually paid out under the policy.

The man, who was a passenger in the car, was shot in the head in West Bromwich shortly after 14:30 BST.

A woman in the same car was shot in the stomach after the pair were confronted by a group of three men.

The woman's injuries are not believed to be life-threatening. Both are in hospital receiving treatment.

West Midlands Police said the circumstances were unclear but it was thought the incident was drug-related.

The area was sealed off by armed officers and the Birmingham Crime Scene Investigation team and police cars were stationed on roads approaching West Bromwich.

text:
It is among a package of measures being unveiled this week by Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg at a London summit.
New guidance about the right to a free interpreter and translator in court proceedings is being drawn up.
There are an estimated 70,000 Polish immigrants and other recent arrivals in the UK who do not have adequate English.
There will also be a review of the impact of the European Arrest Warrant on vulnerable suspects and victims.
A Home Office spokesman said:

"We understand that people whose first language is not English will have greater difficulty understanding procedures and may have more limited access to support."

text:
They flew from Buckingham Palace to the Norfolk estate by helicopter to start their Christmas break.
The royal couple had been due to take two commercial flights, one each way, to save the environment as part of their joint initiative “Travel Together” but Prince William had to cancel his trip for work commitments.

Meanwhile, Kate was accompanied to London Heathrow Airport by her private secretary Catherine Quinn.

Kate looked stylish in a pair of dark jeans, a black jumper and a camel coat with her hair tied in a ponytail.

Prince George and Princess Charlotte will spend Christmas at their grandparents’ mansion. (Image: Getty)

A spokesman for the Met Office said: “We’re just trying to confirm at the moment if it was a waterspout.

“The pictures we have seen are consistent with a waterspout, but we are in the process of trying to get some clarity.”

text:
We asked you to pick your best XI from Euro 2016 and over 100,000 of you responded.
An old-fashioned 4-4-2 was the preferred formation - 55% of you went that way - and the team was dominated by players from France and semi-finalists Wales.
Who made the cut and who missed out?
France captain Hugo Lloris was picked by 32% of readers - 32,720 - to start in goal for this team.
Lloris, 29, conceded just five goals in his seven appearances at Euro 2016; keeping three clean sheets in the process.
Italy legend Gianluigi Buffon was the second-most picked goalkeeper, with Germany keeper Manuel Neuer selected by just 480 fewer people.

text:
Fairer Finance (FF) says airlines like Flybe, Monarch and Ryanair may be in breach of rules which say the charges people pay when they change or cancel a flight should be “proportionate”

The watchdog says these and other budget airlines may be “making a killing” by charging passengers up to £200 a head.

It claims customers should only pay the cost of the flight, plus a small administrative fee. It says a maximum charge of £50 for booking tickets should apply.

FF has written to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to warn that it may take legal action if no progress is made in resolving what it claims is a “market failure”.

It wants to take the issue further by raising it in the European Parliament.

“The UK’s airlines seem to be the worst offenders in Europe when it comes to penalising passengers who have to change

text:
Cook, 29, said he will have to "wait and see" if he will keep the captaincy after England were beaten 5-1 in their Ashes series.

Cook will play in the last Test, starting at the WACA in Perth on Thursday. He has been struggling for form on this tour but has said he will not quit Test cricket unless captain Cook loses the captaincy.

"I've said all along that if I stop playing international cricket it'll be for an England team, rather than me as an individual," he said in a press conference ahead of the fifth and final Test. "I love the Test match game. It means more to me than anything else."

The Ashes are won by the team with the most Test match victories, and the Australian team, led by Steve Smith, were already 4-0 up in the series by the time the pair began the interview.

text:
Under government reforms, the UK's biggest firms will have to reveal how much more their chief executives are paid compared with the average worker.

The rules aim to increase transparency in executive pay and provide a more complete picture of pay ratios in companies.

Ministers will now move to implement the proposals and the legislation will be put before Parliament later this year.

They will also consult on a statutory duty to report on pay and how that can improve corporate transparency and accountability.

The measures are being consulted on now with the aim of coming into force by the start of 2019.

The move comes after former Business Secretary Sajid Javid called last July for greater transparency around executive pay and how to "restore trust in the system".

Under the plans, companies with 250 or more employees will be required to:

- Report on the ratio between CEO pay and

This year, the day was also a time to honour the memory of the 323 British servicemen and women who have lost their lives serving on operations or in accidents since 2011.

North Korea, meanwhile, has threatened to fire off missiles towards the US island territory of Guam - home to 163,000 people and a military hub in the western Pacific.

Mr Trump told North Korean leader Kim Jong-un to "get his act together" or "he will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen".

Guam's Homeland Security adviser George Charfauros told the Pacific Daily News that the governor had not received a call from US President Donald Trump in relation to the heightened military tensions.

Soon after, the state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) published an article calling for "physical action" against Guam.

The US military has said that the planned exercise - which includes computer simulations, live fire drills and flights by long-range aircraft - will involve 2,500 USA personnel and is routine

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) said the threat is due to a combination of high tides and a strong wind.
Eight flood alerts were in place on Thursday evening but no warnings.
Scott Squires, from NRW, warned "some large waves could splash over sea defences".
Meanwhile, heavy and persistent rain is expected to affect Wales over the weekend, particularly in the north.

Root was adjudged caught behind on review after playing a sweep shot against spinner Ravindra Jadeja.
He was seen talking to himself as he departed and aimed a kick at the boundary rope on his way off the field.
"There was frustration there," said Root. "If I get punished then I'm sure it's deserved."
The original decision of not-out was overturned when third umpire Bruce Oxenford decided that a sound picked up by the on-field microphone as the ball passed the bat was an edge to wicketkeeper Parthiv Patel.

text:
North Lincolnshire and Goole, University Hospitals of North Midlands and St George's University Hospitals trusts have a predicted deficit of £115m in 2015-16.

Hospital trusts with a predicted deficit of more than £5m in 2015-16 will be required to work with their commissioners to develop plans on how they will deliver their budget and will have to report to the Trust Special Administrator team regularly, the Department of Health has told HSJ.

The move is aimed at ensuring that the trusts do not require special measures to be introduced to prevent them from going bust, and has been made following the financial wobbles of Basildon University Hospitals and Medway Foundation Trusts, both of which nearly entered into special measures.

text:
New government figures, released just over a year since the e-petition website was launched, show 12 people every minute are signing up.
In its first year, a total of 36,000 petitions were submitted, attracting 6.4 million signatures.
If a petition secures more than 100,000 signatures it can be considered by MPs for a debate in Parliament.
The website was set up by the coalition as a way to "build bridges between people and Parliament" and increase public engagement following the expenses scandal.
At its launch in August 2011, Leader of the House of Commons Sir George Young said it could provide a "megaphone" through which the public could make their views heard.
One year on, and the site has been visited 17 million times, with an average of 46,500 visits a day.
A large number of petitions have been submitted, although nearly half - 47% - were rejected for failing to meet the government's criteria.
So far, 10 petitions have reached the 100,000 signature

The unemployment rate dropped to 6.1%, its lowest level since September 2008.
That figure beat analysts' expectations and is an encouraging sign after disappointing growth in the first quarter of 2014.
The strong report sent the Dow Jones Industrial Average above 17,000 for the first time as investors cheered the news.
Economists blamed harsh winter weather for a 2.9% annualised decline in US economic output from January to March.
Jobs growth in professional and business services was particularly strong, with 67,000 jobs being created, followed by gains in the retail sector, which added 40,000 jobs.

text:
Legend has it that it was  consecrated some 12 centuries ago on the nearby Sanjan beach, landing point of a boatload of refugees who had fled the Arab conquest of Persia to save their 3,000-year-old Zoroastrian faith, and that it has remained unquenched ever since.
The first-ever Udvada Utsav (festival) held over the Christmas weekend drew 4,000 believers.
Yet, what became the "burning issue" was not the ancient fire but the solution proffered to tackle the existential crisis once again faced by this distinctive - and distinguished - community.
Their numbers are down to a critical 61,000, and diminishing by the day; another 40,000 are scattered across the world with an even greater struggle to hang on to their distinctive identity.
In his speech, eminent lawyer Darius Khambata said Zoroastrianism, being a universal religion, should be opened to anyone seeking to join.

The firm, whose brands include Scalextric, Airfix and Corgi, said it would reduce the number of individual product lines by 28% and slash overheads by around 13% as it seeks to return to profitability by 2010.

Hornby, which was placed into administration last month, has now reported a £2.1m pre-tax loss, on sales of £95.1m, for the 26 weeks to September 27, compared to a £1.7m profit for the same period last year.

Chairman Steve Cooke said: "In these difficult trading conditions, particularly within the UK and US, we have to ensure our company is as cost effective as possible and that we are offering the right range of products to customers."

text:
Local officials in Vallauris have said they will restrict access to a stretch of beach to ensure the security of the king and his 40-person entourage, including 12 bodyguards, which will accompany him to the resort.

Local councillor Philippe Barre said the security perimeter would take up one-quarter of the beach, where the king and other members of his family will stay.

There will be no access for 200 metres on either side of the royal villa from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. from Saturday.

Local shops and restaurants will be allowed to remain open, but the beach is set to be transformed into a royal playground with trampolines, slides, swings and boats for the king and his children to play in.

text:
Russians celebrate Prince Vladimir the Great as the man who converted their country to Christianity, but for some Ukrainians this represents an attempt to steal their past.

At the heart of this lies an argument over the so-called Baptism of Rus’, which according to historical records happened in 988.

Today, July 28, is a national holiday in Russia, Orthodox Christians celebrate the Baptism of Rus’ – a symbolic date when the Christian faith was brought to Kievan Rus’, the forerunner of both Russia and Ukraine.

## History lesson

The events associated with the “Baptism of Rus’” are described in the Primary Chronicle, which is considered the fundamental historical source for events that took place in Kievan Rus from 850 to 1110. The document was written during the 12th century by a person known only as the Tale Teller, and

text:
Marcus Nash alerted birders nationwide after seeing the citril finch in Burnham Overy on Sunday morning.
The bird normally lives in mountainous areas of Europe including the Alps and the Pyrenees.
Mr Nash said: "I've seen them before in the Alps, so immediately knew what it was."
The male bird remained at the dunes during the day and was spotted again on Monday.
Paul Stancliffe, from the British Trust for Ornithology, said the only other recorded sighting of the bird in the country was on the Shetland Isles, in 2008.
"It's just an incredible record," Mr Stancliffe said. "It doesn't normally move very far. It must have got caught up in a weather front."
David North, from Norfolk Wildlife Trust, said the area was a "mecca" for wild birds and continued to amaze.
"There are always surprises but not many birders would have guessed they would see a citril finch," he said.

Former Walt Disney chief executive Michael Eisner is in exclusive negotiations over a potential takeover.

Operation Dynamo, which rescued more than 338,000 Allied soldiers, was run from Dover naval HQ at the Admiralty House in the town’s Docks.

The building has undergone a huge transformation with the original period design retained with the addition of modern technology, creating a space for businesses to rent.

It is a Grade 2 listed Georgian building over three floors with original features including fireplaces, sash windows, cornicing and flooring.

The office space is available to let on a full and part-time basis, with the owners offering to build bespoke office space to suit the needs of tenants.

"Everybody in that dressing room must look in the mirror," Paatelainen told BBC Scotland after his second match in charge.
"It doesn't matter about tactics or shape, if you don't get the basic fundamentals right."
United fell behind to a Leigh Griffiths strike after 15 minutes, with Dedryk Boyata adding a header before a Kris Commons brace and Scott Brown's late strike.
The visitors were repeatedly torn apart by the league leaders and posed little threat in attack.
"It doesn't matter what you do on the training ground, if it doesn't happen out there on the pitch," added Paatelainen, who was brought in to replace Jackie McNamara.

A document - the Columba Declaration - will be debated by the ruling bodies of both churches next year.
It commits the churches to "grow together in communion and to strengthen their partnership in mission".
Founded in two different branches of Protestantism, England's church is Anglican and Scotland's Presbyterian.
The declaration has been authored by Kirk minister the Reverend John McPake, and the Church of England's Bishop of Chester, Peter Forster.
They say the agreement will allow clergy and lay people from each church to be welcomed into the other when they move across the border.
The pact also recognises that the two churches have constitutional responsibilities in separate parts of the UK.

text:
The choir has been put together as part of the Edinburgh Art Festival.
About 30 Edinburgh residents, chosen after an open call to audition, will join the group of about 30 children, who will be accompanied by a professional piano teacher.

“The project aims to explore ideas of the community and how that may have altered or be altered in an era where traditional communities are under threat,” said project manager Mark Cunningham.

He said they were looking for local singers who are able to sing at a professional level but may not have the time to commit to joining a choir for a year, as well as those who have been part of a choir but are no longer able to commit due to work and family.

“It is very different and we are excited about it. It’s an experiment.”
