Mr Litvinenko died from radiation poisoning in a London hospital in November 2006, nearly three weeks after drinking tea laced with the substance.
Two Russians, Andrei Lugovoi and Dmitry Kovtun, have denied any involvement.
The 43-year-old may also have been poisoned in October that year, counsel to the inquiry Robin Tam QC said.
Mr Litvinenko had fled to the UK where he became a vocal critic of the Kremlin and worked for the UK intelligence service MI6.
He had recalled feeling unwell around the time of a meeting at a security company in mid-October and "vomiting on one occasion about two or three weeks before being hospitalised," Mr Tam said.

text:
The Valhalla exhibition claims to reveal more about the life of Vikings in Britain and the Isle of Man using the latest forensic science techniques.

The exhibition, developed with the University of Huddersfield, the University of Nottingham and the Isle of Man, features the latest 3D technology and scientific research to reveal more about the lifestyles, customs and diet of these historical figures.

It includes a full scale Viking longhouse, artefacts and a number of new interactive experiences, such as a table-top computer game.

Valhalla: Viking life revealed, opens on Wednesday, October 19, at the JORVIK Viking Centre, Castle Yard, York, and runs until 2017.

For more details about the exhibition and the JORVIK Viking Centre, visit: www.jorvik-viking-centre.co.uk/

A 35-year-old Swedish man, with alleged ties to the Islamic State, has been arrested in London in connection with the recent disappearance of Libyan migrants from the Italian coast.

Mered Medhanie, who is the subject of a Swedish arrest warrant, was arrested on Friday by London’s Metropolitan Police on charges of facilitating and organizing illegal human trafficking.

British authorities said that Swedish police had informed them that they were looking for Medhanie. The Swedish warrant accuses Medhanie of arranging the trafficking of migrants in southern Sweden between 2012-2013.

text:
The idea of "biodiversity offsetting" is controversial, with some campaigners dubbing it a "licence to trash".

But the practice has grown around the world with the number of schemes estimated at 1,500.

Now, a new report is recommending that such schemes are only used in the last resort.

The Government-commissioned report, carried out by a former civil servant and a top lawyer, says that biodiversity offsetting - where a company is allowed to destroy habitats in one place so long as it restores habitats elsewhere - needs to be tightly regulated.

Under rules that are currently being developed in England, developers will soon be able to carry out destructive activities provided that they offset their loss of habitat.

But there are concerns that the proposals could allow development to take place in the places where they are most likely to have a significant environmental impact, such as in places
paraphrased_text: there are now 1,500. text:
The hospital is at risk of losing its A&E and maternity services in a planned shake-up of Dorset's health services.
Dorset Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) wants one hospital to specialise in emergency care for the county and its preferred site is at Bournemouth.
Borough of Poole councillors voted in favour of supporting Poole to become the county's main A&E department.
A clinical services review is proposing major changes at Dorset's three main hospitals, as well as across community care.
Read more on this and other stories from across the south of England

text:
The MP for Corby is moving to New York with her three children to be with her husband of a year, Peter Mensch, who is managing director at Q Prime talent agency.

She said she was "sad to be leaving the House of Commons" and would remain an MP until the next election in 2015.

Ms Corbyn said she planned to remain involved in politics and that she would continue to serve her constituency, as well as her Labour Party colleagues.

“This is not an easy decision for me to make. But with my husband now living in New York, it is impossible to continue to balance my family and my political life,” she said.

“This is not a decision I have taken lightly. When I was elected in 2010, I was very clear that I would serve my constituents for the full five years of the parliament.

text:
The details are revealed in Transport for London (TfL) board papers.
They set out for the first time the impact of spending cuts on London’s transport network.
This year there are £451m of cuts.
Next year £431m more are scheduled, plus an extra £216m.

By the end of the government spending review period, in 2015, total savings will amount to £997m.
TfL’s budget relies heavily on fares revenue, but passenger numbers are falling.

Therefore the impact will hit services and be felt by all of the 1.3bn people who use the network each year.
TfL expects to make a small loss this year and in the years ahead.

TfL has announced that it will be making a “very modest” deficit this year, and expects to make a further modest deficit

text:
Moelfre RNLI lifeboat station raised the alarm at 13:20 BST on Friday after a crew saw the incident involving a 20ft fishing vessel.

Two local Coastguard teams from Holyhead and Amlwch were also called to the scene to rescue those aboard.

Three of the four fishermen on board were taken to Ysbyty Glan Clwyd in Bodelwyddan with serious injuries.

A spokesman said the fourth fisherman was not seriously hurt and is now recovering at home.

Carl Williams, lifeboat operations manager for the station, said: “Due to a number of factors, such as the height of the seas and the location of the vessel, there was absolutely no chance of recovering the vessel on scene and a decision was made to tow the boat back to the harbour as soon as we possibly could, whilst the casualties were being treated.
paraphrased_text: three of the four fishermen on board were taken to Ysbyty Glan Clwyd in Bodelwyddan with serious injuries. a fourth fisherman was not seriously hurt and is now recovering at home.

A man, aged 52, and woman, 50, were held on suspicion of human trafficking for labour exploitation following a dawn raid by Kent Police in Maidstone.
It is claimed the men were threatened with violence and forced to live in squalid conditions while working as chicken catchers for the food industry.
Police say a total of 32 workers could be at risk from exploitation.
Friday morning's raid on the offices of a licensed gangmaster followed a multi-agency investigation.
Liam Vernon, from the UK Human Trafficking Centre (UKHTC) at the Serious Organised Crime Agency (Soca), said: "We suspect the people arrested today were involved in the trafficking of Lithuanian men into the United Kingdom for exploitation within the food industry.

text:
First Milk, one of the UK's largest dairy farmer co-operatives, announced in June many farmers would be paid 1.5ppl below cost in their May invoice because of plummeting prices for dairy produce. As a result of this crisis it said around 60 farmers would immediately leave the co-operative to supply the market directly, in a move which will leave 86 farmers, in total, who will receive the lower price.

"We are aware of concerns regarding our May milk price invoice and are doing everything we can to provide reassurance to our farmer members," said Rob Newson, First Milk's chief financial officer.

The real annual salaries of emergency workers, many of whom will be working over Christmas, have dropped by thousands of pounds, it said.

Emergency services’ annual salaries were found to have dropped by £2,199 on average in real terms, according to a survey by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) and the charity Citizens Advice.

The Government’s pay cap will mean that the public sector pay bill will be £3.5 billion lower than if the policy had not been introduced.

A total of 285 pay settlements were surveyed this year, with the average increase found to be 1.7 per cent, a decrease on the previous average of 1.8 per cent.

The research also reveals that the pay gap between public and private sector workers has widened to 13.8 per cent.

The study also found that

The index, the UK's leading measure of share prices, has been rising steadily since the middle December.
It marks the eighth successive record high. The latest boost came from a 1% drop for the pound against the dollar.
A weaker pound boosts the profits of the many multinational companies listed on the FTSE 100 when their foreign earnings are converted into pounds.
The pound's sharp fall was provoked by comments on Brexit made on Sunday by the Prime Minister, Theresa May.
She rejected the idea that the UK could "keep bits of membership" of the EU, raising the prospect of a so-called "hard Brexit".

text:
Demonstrations began in the northern Kasserine region after a man was electrocuted while protesting at being rejected for a government job.

The demonstrations were in protest of unemployment among the youth in the area and the alleged corruption of the authorities.

The protests were sparked by the death of 26-year-old Moez Abid, who was electrocuted when the police dispersed a crowd of protesters. According to Reuters, Moez tried to reach a cabinet minister's car and was stopped by the police.

“This anger is just about to explode everywhere,” said protester Samia Rguibi.

Around 100,000 Tunisians participated in the protests in the north and northwest of the country, reports Reuters. This is the same region in which the first anti-government protests began in 2010.

A murder probe has been launched. Two men, aged 30 and 52, have been arrested and remain in custody.

text:
The well-preserved ancient remains from the "Pit of Bones" site in Spain have been known for more than three decades.

The bones were dated to 130,000 years ago using radiocarbon dating, a method that could only detect the youngest sample in a group of fossils. The new study used uranium-thorium (U-Th) dating to get a more accurate age estimate.

The U-Th method is used on calcite, a chemical deposit that forms on bones, shells and teeth. Researchers can measure the ratio of uranium and thorium in the deposit, and determine how long it took the deposit to form. This method can work on fossils up to a million years old.

"We know how long it took to form the deposits, but the problem is it is still unknown how exactly the deposits formed," said study co-author Manuel Will
paraphrased_text: dated to 130,000 years ago using radiocarbon dating. Radiocarbon dating could only detect the youngest sample in a group of fossils. text:
The Brazilian president is ideologically driven, intelligent and committed to her mandate.
But, compared to the tact and political nous of her predecessor, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, the current incumbent of the presidential palace in Brasilia casts a lonely figure, reluctant to immerse herself in the deal-making, opportunistic world of Brazilian politics.
Even some of her allies agree that, although re-elected as president two years ago, Ms Rousseff has not been a particularly great or successful leader.
Brazil's first female president is going through one of the most difficult periods of her political life.
This week she walked out slowly, barely managing a smile, before the foreign media in Brasilia.
The make-up could not conceal the tired lines on the face of a woman who feels she is being wronged and betrayed by a misogynistic, treacherous Congress.
She looks down,

text:
British number four Evans, 26, dropped to 58th in Monday's latest standings, two places below Slovenia-born Bedene.
Bedene, 27, moved to the UK in 2008 and switched nationality in March 2015.
"I don't think he really believes he's British either," said Evans after losing in the Madrid Open first round to Robin Haase on Monday.
"It's nothing against Aljaz. I like him, he's not confrontational in any way - but to me it doesn't sit well if you play for another country.

He was taken to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh where he passed away on Thursday 2 February.
His family said he would be "sadly missed".

text:
There have been arguments about whether it exists, the cause, the best treatments and even the name itself.
These disagreements have reached the level of abuse and death threats.
The disease itself, however, remains poorly understood - or as one doctor put it: "The whole thing is surrounded by uncertainty".
For a long time, the existence of CFS/ME was widely dismissed and labelled as "yuppie flu". That opinion has largely been reversed in the past decade.
Should the illness be called CFS, ME or CFS/ME?
Doctors prefer the term CFS as the main symptom is fatigue, while ME has a specific meaning related to inflammation of the brain and spinal cord.
However, this is not popular with some patients' groups or charities, which talk about ME as a specific disease, saying "fatigue" is too broad a term.
Prof Michael Sharpe, of the University of Oxford, said: "The concepts of CFS and ME have been conflated as CFS/ME. That may
paraphrased_text: disagreements have reached the level of abuse and death threats. doctors prefer the term CFS as the main symptom is fatigue. while ME has a specific meaning related to inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. some patients' groups or charities talk about ME as a specific disease.

“Suspect Phillip Harkins will be charged with the offence of Murder, Police said.

“Police would like to thank the community for their ongoing assistance in this matter.”

Mr Harkins will appear in Brisbane Magistrates Court Monday.

A police search is now underway for 36-year-old Steven Bollard, who is believed to have been in the vehicle during the incident.

text:
The Culture, Media and Sport Committee said it would investigate concerns about the public being swayed by propaganda and untruths.
The inquiry will examine the sources of fake news, how it is spread and its impact on democracy.
Claims that voters in the US election were influenced by fake news spurred the inquiry, the committee said.
Damian Collins, the committee chairman, said the rise of propaganda and fabrications is "a threat to democracy and undermines confidence in the media in general".
"Just as major tech companies have accepted they have a social responsibility to combat piracy online and the illegal sharing of content, they also need to help address the spreading of fake news on social media platforms," he said.
"Consumers should also be given new tools to help them assess the origin and likely veracity of news stories they read online.
"The committee will be investigating these issues as well as looking into
paraphrased_text: the rise of propaganda and fabrications is "a threat to democracy and undermines confidence in the media in general", committee chairman said. the inquiry will examine the sources of fake news, how it is spread and its impact on democracy.

text:
Gail Purcell is charged with causing death by careless driving following a collision with Michael Mason, 70, on Regents Street, London, in 2014.
The 58-year-old from St Albans, Herts, pleaded not guilty at the Old Bailey.
The Cyclists' Defence Fund raised Â£60,000 from 1,500 donations to pursue the action.
Mr Mason died 19 days after the collision having never regained consciousness from his injuries.
Police had declined to refer the case to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS).
Private prosecutions can be brought by any individual or organisation and proceed in exactly the same way as those brought by the CPS.
Before proceeding with a prosecution, the CPS will consider if the case is in the public interest and if there is sufficient evidence to secure a conviction.
Ms Purcell will face a six-day trial on 3 April and was granted unconditional bail.

The Spring 2015 forecast has been published by the Ulster University Economic Policy Centre.
It says the NI economy had a modest expansion in 2014, with growth likely to continue in 2015 – but more slowly.

Key points:

- 2015 growth will be 1.8 per cent, up from 1.4 per cent in 2014.
- Growth will be supported by a rising population and strengthening demand.
- The housing market will support growth, but the construction sector is still constrained.
- Growth in Northern Ireland will be faster than the UK average and we should see another year of positive job creation.

An army spokesman said the building was searched and weapons were recovered.
Indian-administered Kashmir has seen a wave of deadly unrest since a popular separatist leader was killed by the security forces in July.
On Monday, militants had entered an empty government building near Pampore town on the outskirts of the main city of Srinagar.
Troops, paramilitary soldiers and police surrounded the building while firing rockets, flame throwers and grenades, reports said. The militants fired back with automatic weapons and hurled grenades.

Take Merthyr Tydfil, where the Labour majority is currently just over 4,000. In 1997 it stood at 27,000.

Steven Poole often incorrectly fitted flue connections and failed to supply and fit carbon monoxide detectors.
Before his death, he admitted regularly breaching legal requirements.
Pembrokeshire council said more than 160 people had taken up the offer of a free carbon monoxide alarm out of more than 500 households it wrote to.
"We are still very concerned that there could be many incorrectly fitted stoves in the county, which are potentially dangerous," said Huw George, cabinet member for environmental and regulatory services.

Seven people were killed and 48 injured in Saturday's incident.
The attackers were shot dead by police after driving into pedestrians on a busy shopping street.

The suspects were wearing fake suicide vests which were detonated by police after the suspects were shot.

Police spokesman Brigadier Adam Lilley told a press conference that three suspects had been shot dead and four hand grenades and seven improvised explosive devices had been recovered.

“It is very evident that we have to remain vigilant,” he said.

British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said Britain “stands shoulder to shoulder” with France.

Robert Sumwalt of the National Transportation Safety Board said they would be gathering evidence, including any mobile phone footage of the crash.
The balloon caught fire and plummeted to the ground in a field near Lockhart, about 30 miles (50km) south of Austin.
Witnesses have suggested it may have hit power lines.
The local sheriff's office said identification of those killed would be "a long process".
Neither the victims nor the operator of the balloon have been officially identified but friends and relatives named the pilot as Skip Nichols who ran Heart of Texas Hot Air Balloon Rides.
Wendy Bartch, a former girlfriend, said he had been involved with hot air balloons for about two decades.
"He was a good pilot and loved people," she told the Austin American-Statesman newspaper.
The Facebook page of the balloon ride company was filled with messages of condolence and pictures of Mr Nichols.

text:
First Minister Alex Salmond announced details of his 2012/13 plans in the Holyrood chamber.
The government will now be funded by an additional £370 million, £200 million of which is new money and £170 million will come from savings elsewhere in government.
Salmond revealed the government will reduce the taxpayer’s contribution to free personal care for the elderly by £21 million.
The funding gap will be plugged by a reduction in the free prescriptions for all in Scotland – a policy introduced last year.
The changes will bring in a £130 million contribution to the government’s finances.
Salmond also announced he would raise the basic income tax rate to 20p.
The top rate of 40 per cent will also be introduced, with a rate of 50 per cent for those with an income above £150,000.

text:
Lord Justice Weir said that while there were some genuine and appropriate cases for anonymity, many of the applications were a "lot of dross".

"I do not think it is right that the judiciary should be required to give time and space in our busy courtrooms to such applications when they have other business to deal with. This is not an efficient use of judicial time," said Lord Weir, whose name was withheld at the request of a local newspaper.

The ruling, which came after a man sued for defamation by the Sunday Sport newspaper and an ITV television show asked for anonymity so his partner would not be embarrassed, may limit the use of privacy injunctions.

Privacy injunctions were popularised by Max Mosley, the former head of Formula One, who was awarded one after a story appeared about him with a prostitute at a Nazi-themed orgy.

text:
Silent Majority, painted during the 1998 Glastonbury Festival, shows soldier-like figures landing on a beach with a speaker in an inflatable raft.
Its Norfolk owners say it "depicts the ...rave and hip hop scene of the time".
The work is unusual for a Banksy piece, as it is largely freehand with little use of stencils.
Auction house Digard said it was thought to be one of the artist's oldest works.
The metal piece, painted over three days outside the festival's Dance Tent, measures 2.4m (7.8ft) by 9.9m (32ft).
Its message reads: "It's better not to rely too much on silent majorities ... for silence is a fragile thing... one loud noise and it's gone."
The elusive graffiti artist's team has provided a certificate of authenticity as part of the auction lot. It was painted in collaboration with fellow Bristol artist Inkie.

Optometry student Vithiya Alphons was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia after returning for her final year in 2015 and needed a stem cell transplant.
Despite a global appeal, no suitable donor was found and doctors were forced to use her mother's cells.
Miss Alphons took a year out to recover and has now finished her course.
"I was not going to allow cancer to get in the way of getting my degree and my dream of becoming an optician," she said.
Thousands of people signed up to the stem cell donor register following the appeal by Miss Alphons and the Anthony Nolan charity.
She is now helping to highlight the need for more ethnic minorities to sign up as donors.

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull on Wednesday promoted Mr Wyatt to an aged care and indigenous health portfolio, following a government reshuffle announced this week, the Australian Associated Press (AAP) reports.

The position will see Mr Wyatt oversee the government's policy on indigenous health and aged care, as well as the National Disability Insurance Scheme and mental health.

Wyatt, who has Aboriginal, Irish and English descent, was born in the West Australian Aboriginal town of Roebourne and was first elected to federal parliament in 2010.

text:
How many British people have bought a bar of chocolate on holiday somewhere outside Europe and been surprised at how different it tastes?
EU rules demand chocolate contains 30% cocoa - compared with only 10% in the US - and that is what makes British chocolate so delicious, says emeritus Professor Mike Gordon.
"A high cocoa content is important to give it a good flavour," said the retired food and nutritional sciences lecturer at the University of Reading.
"I remember having a Hershey bar in the 1960s which was pretty poor quality, but I've not tried US chocolate for many years," he said.
The quintessentially British Cadbury's chocolate has been made at the  Bournville factory in Birmingham since 1905.
The regal-looking purple-wrapped bars contain up to 5% vegetable fats under EU law but it is not added to the recipe across the pond.
So

The Super Puma crashed on its approach to Sumburgh Airport last August.
Sarah Darnley, of Elgin, Moray, Duncan Munro, of Bishop Auckland, County Durham, Gary McCrossan, of Inverness, and George Allison, of Winchester, Hampshire, all died when the Eurocopter EC225 left the BP-operated oil platform.

A helicopter crash report revealed how the Super Puma was operating 30 minutes longer than it should have been.

It found that the chopper’s pilots had made four errors that may have caused the crash.

text:
Rates have now remained on hold for more than six years and the Bank is not expected to raise them until next year.
Analysts say the Bank is under no pressure to raise rates yet with inflation near record lows.
Inflation, as measured by Consumer Prices Index, was all but flat at 0.1% in May. That was up from -0.1% in April but well below the Bank's 2% target.
However, in the Bank of England's inflation report in May, governor Mark Carney warned that inflation was expected to pick up notably towards the end of the year.
The half-dozen years of ultra-low interest rates have cut returns on savings, but mortgage borrowers have benefited from lower repayments.
The Bank also left its money-printing stimulus programme, known as Quantitative Easing (QE), unchanged at Â£375bn.
The Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) will reveal why it decided to leave policy as it is when it publishes

text:
Australian researchers are investigating whether the scent of a natural predator can help repel millions of crown-of-thorns starfish (CoTS) plaguing the Great Barrier Reef.

The team has been testing a lure called COTS-X, which emits the odour of predator eagle rays and attracts other rays to eat the starfish.

The researchers have so far successfully deployed the product along the western side of the Ribbon Reefs on the northern most region of the Great Barrier Reef at a site called Moore Reef, about 70 kilometres off the coast of Cairns, as part of a five-year trial.

The hope is COTS-X will be approved for deployment as a tool to help manage the infestation by the end of next year.

Professor David Suggett from the Australian Institute of Marine Sciences
paraphrased_text: COTS-X, which emits the odour of predator eagle rays and attracts other rays to eat the starfish. Researchers from the University of Guelph tested 100 raw meat sausage samples labelled as being solely beef, pork, chicken, turkey, or lamb for the presence of other meats.

The study, published on the US National Library of Medicine website, was designed to see how prevalent mislabelling of meat is in commercial products.

The scientists found that more than 20% of samples tested contained ingredients not listed on the labels, with the vast majority including pork and beef in products labelled as having just one meat source. Other examples included chicken in turkey products, and beef in chicken products.

Sex education should be compulsory in all state secondary schools, the Local Government Association (LGA) believes.
It says pupils are at “extreme risk” of abuse and sexually transmitted infections because of a lack of classes, which are sometimes “patronising or irrelevant”.

Consumer spending is the driver of the UK's economic growth, accounting for about 60% of all our economic activity.
The quickest route to a downturn in that growth figure is consumers who rein in spending.
Today's sharp rise in prices (inflation is now at its highest rate for four years) increases the pressure on the just-about-managing classes.
And savers, once again, are feeling the strain in an era of ultra-low interest rates.

The SNP, meanwhile, accused the Conservatives of trying to "smear" Scotland.

Norman Martin, 93, and Islwyn Morgan, 89, joined Treorchy Male Voice Choir in 1957 and 1959 respectively, and they have been inseparable since.

The pair, who live in Mountain Ash, first met as teenagers in Treorchy’s Cymmer Boys’ Institute and the rest, as they say, is history.

They have never missed a rehearsal in more than 65 years – apart from Islwyn missing one rehearsal in March this year as he was recovering from surgery.

Members of the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) are campaigning against plans to cut about 180 firefighters and control room staff from the fire service as a result of £5m worth of cuts in Lancashire.

The firefighters protested outside the Fylde coast fire headquarters in Penwortham earlier this month, and say the cuts will endanger lives.

FBU general secretary Matt Wrack said: “Firefighters are extremely worried that if the plans are put into action, the fire service will be unable to respond properly to fires and other emergencies, and this will put at risk both firefighters and members of the public.

The Severn Valley Railway Society, which was set up at Kidderminster in 1965, is marking its golden jubilee with an exhibition.
The Severn Valley Railway was built between 1858 and 1862 and originally linked Hartlebury, near Droitwich in Worcestershire with Shrewsbury in Shropshire.
During the late 19th and early 20th Centuries, the line was important for transporting freight as well as passengers.
The line closed as a commercial service from 1963 to 1970.
During July 1965, the group had to send an urgent telegram to British Railways to stop engineers dismantling the line north of Bridgnorth.

A new report from the University of Colorado at Boulder shows that law enforcement entities all across the United States are requesting data on Apple users at a rate of 2,100 requests a week.

In 2015, Apple released data on users to law enforcement at least 216 times for investigations and at least 59 times to respond to legal requests.

A related boost to consumer spending could also help create a rosier Budget picture for Chancellor George Osborne.
The Office for Budget Responsibility is expected to produce a stronger forecast for UK economic growth at Budget time.
BBC economics editor Robert Peston said a fall in inflation expectations generates an annual windfall for the Treasury of around £6bn.
In January UK inflation hit a record low of 0.3%, helped by oil prices.
The reduction in the squeeze on public finances is "more or less automatic", he said.
Low inflation means lower payments by the government on index-linked debt. It also means lower increases on certain benefits, he said.
Reduced spending on welfare means there could be more cash available for expenditure on schools, hospitals, and the police, he added.
Other experts said Mr Osborne could use the spare cash to give more wiggle room in meeting deficit-reduction plans.

A council spokeswoman said the centre, which was used as a training venue for the London 2012 Olympics and adjoins Sunderland Football Club's Stadium of Light, would close in 2018 to allow "substantial repairs" to be carried out.
A statement added: "These works are required to remedy problems with condensation and leaks.
"To allow for the necessary arrangements to be put in place, the works will be carried out next year and it is estimated they will take six-nine months to complete.
"During the period of the works it is anticipated some dry-side facilities will remain in use such as the gym and changing

text:
Nisbet the eland was born at Blair Drummond Safari Park near Stirling to parents Limba and Bud on 6th July 2012. Her mother Limba was the first to arrive and then Nisbet arrived a few hours later followed by sister Nora. As the sisters are now in their teens, we think it's time to rehouse them closer to their birthplace.

Nisbet will be the latest addition to our herd at the Highland Wildlife Park near Kingussie.

The baby will be on view for the first time at the safari park this weekend, 12th and 13th May and visitors will see her on the 'Safari Drive' as she is still a little small to walk around the park.

Julia Gillard was visiting the assembly in Cardiff Bay as part of a campaign to get more women into public life.
Currently 22% of the Welsh Assembly is made up of women.
Liz Saville Roberts, the first Plaid Cymru AM to be elected said "It's a huge privilege to be able to stand in front of people with the words 'Assembly Member for Dwyfor Meirionnydd'.
"The fact that Plaid Cymru has achieved a major breakthrough is something of which we should all be proud."

The company's troubles came to light earlier this week when it discovered suspected fraud by senior employees in a Singapore-based subsidiary.
OW Bunker is Denmark's third-largest company and supplies 7% of the world's bunker fuel, used in shipping.
Shipping lines were trying to find alternative suppliers in the wake of the news late on Friday.
The company owes 13 banks $750m (Â£472m) and says it cannot survive without new credit.
OW Bunker's chairman, Niels Henrik Jensen, said in a statement: "It is now clear that such facilities will not be made available. Nor is a sale as a going concern a realistic option."
The bankruptcy filing was lodged in the probate court in Aalborg in northern Denmark.
The company said on Thursday it had discovered fraud by senior employees in its Singapore-based subsidiary, Dynamic Oil Trading.

text:
Passport and credit card details were also stolen from the Grozio Chirurgija clinic, Lithuanian police said.
After the release of hundreds of photos from the clinic in March, the rest of the database was published on Tuesday.
Patients in Denmark, Germany, Norway and the UK have received demands for ransoms of up to 2,000 euros (Â£1,737).
Lithuanian police say it is unclear how many of the clinic's clients have been affected but dozens have reported receiving such demands.
Officers said a hacking group called Tsar Team was behind the theft and publication of the data.

text:
The decision follows pressure from campaigners, who accused the company of dragging its heels over providing financial aid.
Benetton was one of several fashion brands linked to the Rana Plaza complex.
It has not said how much it will pay.
More than one million people signed a petition on the campaigning website Avaaz urging the Italian company to pay into the Rana Plaza Trust Fund, or face embarrassing protests during next week's Milan fashion week.
The nine-storey factory collapsed in Dhaka on 23 April 2013, after warnings from workers and local journalists that it was unsafe.
Benetton said it was working with a "globally-recognised third party" to establish how much it should pay out to survivors and families of the dead.
Walmart, Primark and Matalan were among the other well-known brands who made clothes there.
The fund is being organised by the UN's International Labour Organisation. It has

text:
Avon lady Louise Houghton and neighbour Lisa Quinton were both bitten on the legs during two separate incidents at the house in Isfryn Road, Meliden.
Donna Whitelam, 41, had pleaded guilty to having a dog dangerously out of control and causing injury.
Llandudno magistrates banned her from keeping dogs for two years.
Whitelam had also admitted two lesser charges of owning dogs dangerously out of control.
Magistrate John Rooney said the dogs had "acted in a pack temperament".
He sentenced Whitelam to a 12-month community order, and ordered to pay the victims Â£500 each in compensation.

text:
The black and tan male collie cross was picked up at the summit of Scafell Pike in the Lake District on Saturday by a couple of Scottish holidaymakers.
Concerned about its wellbeing, they took it home and handed it to the Scottish SPCA rescue centre in Glasgow.
The charity now wants to locate the owner of the dog, nicknamed Scafell.
The dog, which had not been microchipped, is believed to be aged between five and eight years old.
Described as "petrified and nervous" when found, it took the couple, from Maybole, South Ayrshire, about half an hour to coax it over to them.
Anna O'Donnell, from the Glasgow centre, said: "At this stage it's all a bit of a mystery but we believe Scafell may have been taken up the mountain by his owner and become lost.
"There is also a chance he was abandoned and made his own way up to the top.
"It would be fantastic if we are

text:
Tomkins has not played for nine months after suffering a knee injury playing for New Zealand Warriors.
The 27-year-old played just 32 games for the Blackpool based club before joining the Warriors midway through their Super League season in 2008.
Hull confirmed the signing of Tomkins in a statement which read: ‘Hull FC are delighted to confirm the signing of a new player for the next four years.

Hull are currently preparing for Sunday’s Challenge Cup semi-final against Castleford Tigers.

text:
Under current law, emissions must be cut by 80% by 2050 - but ministers have said this does not go far enough.
Following the climate deal in Paris, it is clear the UK must not increase CO2 at all because the warming threat is so severe, they added.
No details of the law change have been given - and critics said the UK was failing to meet even current targets.
The global climate agreement, which was finalised at a summit in Paris in December, commits to keeping global temperatures "well below" 2C (3.6F) above pre-industrial times and limit the amount of greenhouse gases emitted by human activity.
Speaking in the Commons, energy minister Andrea Leadsom said government believed it was necessary "to take the step of enshrining the Paris commitment to net zero emissions in UK law".

Did the Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood over-play its hand?

I think that they have a case for that claim.
Their candidate for president, Mohamed Morsi was narrowly beaten in the first round of voting – coming 2nd.
But it wasn’t just that they came second – it was the way the campaign ran.

Morsi’s popularity among Egyptians is still extremely high, and his main opponent, Ahmad Shafik, had much lower popularity and a murky past.

text:
Simon Hayes, 45, from Barnet, north London, was half-way through loading the dishwasher when he got distracted and went into another room.
He returned to the kitchen to find the not-so cunning cub seemingly stuck in the machine among the dirty dishes.
Dr Hayes, a vet, eventually ushered the "bold little thing" out using a broom after it failed to flee from the bottom trolley.
He said: "It was quite a warm evening so I had the back door open. I got distracted and went to do something else - when I came back he was there.
"He was quite a bold little thing but he looked surprised to see me coming.
"He was pretty still and he couldn't work out how to get out."
Dr Hayes moved the bottom rack to let the fox find his own way out,

text:
Malcolm Roberts won a Queensland Senate seat as member of the anti-immigration One Nation party in recent elections.
He says the United Nations is using climate change to lay the foundations for an unelected global government.
His previous writing indicates that he believes a shadowy cabal of bankers is controlling world affairs.
One Nation is led by Pauline Hanson, who during the 1990s was a controversial figure in Australian politics for her views on immigration and Indigenous Australians.
The party won four seats in Australia's Senate during the election, making it the fourth-largest voting bloc in the upper house.

Ten Wirral Cricket Club batsmen were out for ducks, only the number 11 troubled the scorers, with the other runs coming from two leg byes.
It left Wirral some way short of the 109 they needed to beat Haslington in a Cheshire League Division Three fixture.
While an embarrassing loss, it was not a world record lowest score - Somerset club Langport were dismissed for zero against Glastonbury in a 1913 match.
The lowest score in a first-class match is six, made by "The B's" against England at the old Lord's ground in 1810. And the lowest total in a Test match is 26, posted by New Zealand against England in 1955.

The firm, whose brands include Scalextric, Airfix and Corgi, said it would reduce the number of individual product lines by 40%, but said it would keep its most well-known toys.
It plans to raise £8m via a share placing to fund the restructuring.
The plans come after the firm reported a £13.5m loss in what it said was a "difficult and disappointing year".
The model trainmaker reported a £200,000 pre-tax loss for the 2015 financial year.
Chairman Roger Canham blamed the poor performance on the implementation of a new software system and supply chain issues due to the reorganisation of its European business.

text:
During the campaign, Mr Trump called for greater protection for US jobs and said he would tear up the Trans-Pacific Partnership - the biggest multinational trade deal in years.
But after a two-day summit in Peru, leaders defended the benefits of open markets.
China also claimed growing support for a wider 21-nation trade deal it backs.
In a communiquÃ© at the end of the summit the Apec leaders said: "We reaffirm our commitment to keep our markets open and to fight against all forms of protectionism."
It also referred to the "rising scepticism over trade", after the uneven recovery since the financial crisis had caused more people to question whether globalisation worked for enough people.

text:
Gail Purcell is charged with causing death by careless driving following a collision with Michael Mason, 70, on Regents Street, Cambridge, in August.

Purcell is accused of taking a dangerous driving and failing to stop at the scene, and was charged with causing death by dangerous driving following an investigation into the incident.

But, Mr Mason's family have questioned why Mrs Purcell was not charged over Mr Mason's death.

Mr Mason, of Long Road, Cambridge, died as a result of the collision on Tuesday, August 8 and an inquest into his death was opened and adjourned at the city’s coroner’s court on Thursday.

text:
Accounts for Bad Wolf revealed large remuneration packages worth a total of £1.8m over 18-months.

Wales' most famous film producer and director Rupert Wyatt has quit as a director of Bad Wolf's parent company, Bad Wolf Limited.

New accounts, filed by Bad Wolf in October, also reveal an eye-watering remuneration package paid to staff and the firm's founders at Bad Wolf over 18 months.

The accounts show more than £1.7m in payments in the 18 months to January 31 2020, before Covid-19 hit.

These sums include Bad Wolf Limited's remuneration package for co-founder Jane Tranter and other staff.

text:
The Bank has significantly revised its position on the direction of travel for the British economy since its last gloomy assessment in August.
Forecasting that the country will grow faster than the rest of Europe, the Bank predicted that Britain will be the sixth strongest economy in the developed world in two years time, overtaking Canada and France.
It raised its forecasts for growth this year and in 2010. It said the UK economy could shrink by only 4.75pc this year, slightly better than the 5pc decline it predicted in August, which at the time was seen as relatively bullish.
The figures showed that economic activity is recovering strongly, although it warned that the UK is unlikely to return to pre-crisis levels until late 2011, and the outlook remained highly uncertain.
Mervyn King said the revisions were driven by a faster-than-expected rebound in business investment

text:
An Israeli missile hit the car of Ismael al-Ismar, a leader of al-Quds Brigades in the city of Khan Younis. He died on the spot.

Meanwhile, Israeli troops killed one of two suspects that attacked an army post in the northern West Bank. The other one was arrested. Both are members of the al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades militant group.

At least 13 other Palestinians were wounded in the fighting. Earlier this week a similar incident on the Gaza border prompted Israel to impose a total closure on the Palestinian enclave.

Palestinians accuse Israeli troops of causing a humanitarian crisis, as medical supplies are running out and thousands of patients are unable to travel abroad for treatment. Israel has promised humanitarian supplies will be delivered on Monday.
paraphrased_text: killed. 13 other Palestinians were wounded in the fighting. Earlier this week a similar incident on the Gaza border prompted Israel to impose a total closure on the Palestinian enclave.

He was arrested at 04:15 BST within a security perimeter. He did not gain access to the palace.
The Met said the suspected intruder had been drinking and that the incident was not thought to be terrorism related.

text:
Scientists scanned the brains of 15 people recalling four similar scenes, in a study published in PNAS.
They spotted a region that lit up when subjects were asked to mentally wander through places they had visited.

Crucially, the more a region of the right superior frontal gyrus (SFG) was activated, the better the people were able to reimagine the locations.
Researchers say it is an important discovery.

They hope that the research will improve the accuracy of memory recall, helping law enforcement agencies in court and improving the treatment of people with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and dementia.

It could even help people who have lost the ability to recognise faces after suffering damage to the hippocampus as a result of stroke or other factors.

Annuities provide an income for the rest of your life, however long you live. After your death some annuities pay a smaller sum to your spouse or partner. These are often called "joint life" annuities.
The new proposal is that you will be able to cash in your annuity for either a single lump sum or a series of payments. This has obvious advantages. Pensioners can invest it in a different way in the hope of receiving a higher income, perhaps via a buy-to-let property. Or you could pay off your mortgage, reduce other debts, help children with university fees, or even go on holiday.

text:
The attack happened near the Water of Leith Walkway at Anderson Place shortly after midnight on Saturday.
Police said the man, who was white and aged between 18 and 24, subjected the woman to a "terrifying ordeal".
He was about 5ft 8in tall, of slim build with short, brown hair, close-cropped at the back and sides. He had dark stubble.
He also had a prominent dark circular earring in one or both ears.
At the time of the attack he was wearing a camouflage patterned hooded jacket, blue jeans and trainers, and had earphones, a rucksack on his back, and a skateboard.

Oscar Holderer, who was 95, suffered a stroke last week and did not recover, his son Michael said.
Mr Holderer was one of about 120 engineers who moved to the US after World War Two, bringing technology used in the German V2 rocket.
They played a key role in the Saturn V rocket used in the 1969 Moon landing.
The team, led by Wernher von Braun, was part of a project called Operation Paperclip that transferred technology used in Germany's V2 and other rockets to the US.
They were originally based at White Sands, New Mexico, but moved to Redstone Arsenal, Alabama, in 1950 where they used early computers and slide rules to design the Saturn V.

Opposition members have called for Surrey County Council leader David Hodge to face a no confidence motion.
But Mr Hodge, who was re-elected as Conservative group leader on Friday, said he had the confidence of residents.
The government denied claims Surrey was offered a special deal.
The authority had planned a 15% council tax hike - which would have sparked a referendum in the county - which was then dropped in favour of a 4.99% increase.
Documents released by both the government and the council, and a leaked recording obtained by the BBC, detailed behind-the-scenes discussions which indicated ministers were offering "some extra funding" shortly before the council abandoned the proposed 15% rise.

text:
The supermarket giant said it has decided not to renew the lease, which it has held for 38 years.
The store will close on 15 August. All 225 members of staff have been told they are at risk of redundancy.
"Our priority is to do everything we can to find alternative roles within Tesco for as many affected colleagues as possible," a spokesman said.
The company said it has several Express and Metro stores in the area.
In January, Tesco announced it was shutting 43 stores across the country following successive years of falling sales and profits.

A Volvo S60 being driven by a 21-year-old man collided with a Volkswagen Golf.
He and a 17-year-old passenger were killed at the scene.
The 21-year-old driver of the Golf was taken to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary for treatment to leg injuries, which police have described as “serious but not life-threatening”.
The two vehicles involved were being checked and no other vehicles were involved.
Road closures were in place to enable emergency services to carry out their investigations into the accident.

A former owner of a Porsche club in Woking has been convicted of a £5m fraud that defrauded up to 35 people.

Girls do better than boys at A-levels (or Highers in Scotland), and indeed at every level of education.

Using techniques including wearable technology, they are looking for what are known as biomarkers - the very early physical signs of the disease. In some cases, the disease can be diagnosed in animals before the disease shows itself in symptoms. In others, the biomarkers could provide a means for treating the disease.

The goal is to identify biomarkers in cows in the first and second trimester of pregnancy. The data will be analysed by machine learning algorithms - computer programmes designed to help computers gain new knowledge by learning from data - and then will be used to help develop a new diagnostic test for cows.

Jurors in Los Angeles decided that the 2013 single by Pharrell Williams and Robin Thicke breached the copyright of Marvin Gaye’s 1977 song “Got to Give It Up,” and awarded Gaye’s family $7.3 million in damages. While Thicke and Williams appealed the ruling, they lost again in March when a federal judge upheld the verdict.

text:
Staff were informed of the proposed redundancies and reduced editorial budgets via email on Thursday.
The cuts are expected to affect journalists at the London bureau, where all six staff members have been working remotely for much of 2020.
A total of 11 positions, including some reporting positions, are to be cut by January, according to the internal email. All journalists based in the New York office, as well as several other journalists in Europe, will be kept on to work on the American edition, the email stated.
The cuts come days after Condé Nast CEO Roger Lynch called on the media giant to implement permanent remote work policies and move forward with digital initiatives in response to the financial impact caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
In June, the media giant had announced cutbacks to a number of magazines amid the pandemic, affecting publications such as Glamour, Wired, GQ, The New Yorker and Vogue.

Mullen, who won £4.8 million on the lottery in 2011, will be a director of the National League for three years.

The 49-year-old former Royal Mail executive will replace Keith Walker, who is retiring from the role after 12 years.

Walker, an Arsenal fan who has been on the board since 2001, is one of two directors to retire this summer, with Mitch Franklin also stepping down.

Trevor Birch, who is in charge of the administration process, told the National League’s website: “We welcome Keith’s successor David, an extremely experienced businessman, to the board.

Tolimir's role in the 1995 Srebrenica massacre was significant enough to justify the genocide conviction, the judges said.

But his lawyers argued his actual crimes were smaller than those of other Srebrenica defendants, and that the prosecution had failed to prove his responsibility beyond a reasonable doubt.

"Tolimir was convicted of genocide, one of the two most serious crimes known to international criminal law," Prosecutor Serge Brammertz said.

"The court's reasoning was very clear in that. It was not enough to say that some of the crimes he was charged with contributed to the massacre or the genocide, he had to have played a role in those crimes," he told reporters outside the courtroom.

Ranieri says a win against West Ham would be a big step towards the title but he would rather not look too far ahead.
"I think West Ham is the title for me," he told reporters.

"My mind is on West Ham. West Ham is fantastic because they want to win.

text:
In Vanity Fair magazine, Monica Lewinsky, 40, writes that she deeply regrets the fling.
The president "took advantage" of her, she writes, though she describes their relationship as consensual.
In 1998, Republicans failed in their effort to oust him from office on the grounds he had lied about the affair.
But with Mr Clinton's wife Hillary said to be mulling a 2016 run for the presidency, the Lewinsky matter has re-emerged in US political discourse, in part because Republicans are eager to wield it against her.
In an advance excerpt from the article released by Vanity Fair, Ms Lewinsky writes she hopes to reclaim her story and says she is still recognised every day and sees her name thrown about in pop culture and the news media.
"I, myself, deeply regret what happened between me and President Clinton," she writes.
"Let me say
paraphrased_text: Vanity Fair, Monica Lewinsky, 40, writes that she deeply regrets the fling between her and President Clinton. "I, myself, deeply regret what happened between me and President Clinton," she writes in an advance excerpt from the article released by Vanity Fair. "I, myself, deeply regret what happened between me and President Clinton," she writes. "Let me say that I am still recognised every day and sees her name thrown around in pop culture and the news media."

text:
The Hammers are due to host the first leg on 28 July, but the London club have made an official request to Uefa to switch the game to 26 July to allow their fans the chance to travel over on budget airlines.

The Hammers’ club website says: “Uefa has not yet received any formal request from West Ham United.

“The club will decide what it wishes to do, as we have in past Europa League campaigns.”

Last season’s Europa League round of 16 clash against Fiorentina was played on a Tuesday to accommodate supporters who had to travel from East London.

But Fiorentina are not in the 2014-15 qualifying draw, with Lokomotiv Plovdiv instead travelling to east London on 26 July.

However, Uefa rules state a club can request a change from the Thursday to either the previous Tuesday

text:
The Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR) produces a monthly "income tracker" for the Asda supermarket chain.
It examines spending habits and discretionary incomes across the UK.
The report concluded that discretionary incomes in Northern Ireland increased by £4 per week last month to £80.
In comparison, it found that during March, the average UK household had £170 a week available to spend after all tax and essential living costs have been deducted.
Speaking on Good Morning Ulster, Ian Boyd, a married father of two, said making ends meet is still a struggle.
He said: "I actually believe monthly outgoings are up. Nothing is getting cheaper, the cost of everything seems to get higher and higher."
He added: "Since we've had
paraphrased_text: monthly "income tracker" for supermarket chain asda examines spending habits. discretionary incomes in northern ireland increased by £4 per week to £80. average household had £170 a week available to spend after all tax and essential living costs have been deducted.

The 19-year-old also made four appearances for Leicester's Under-21 team in the EFL Trophy this season.

text:
Twenty-two people died when suicide bomber Salman Abedi detonated a home-made device in the arena's foyer on 22 May following an Ariana Grande concert.
Det Supt Jonathan Chadwick told the hearing the bomb was "designed to kill and maim indiscriminately".
Coroner Nigel Meadows said the inquests at Manchester Civil Justice Centre would be adjourned until 24 November.
The hearing was shown a photograph of each of the victims and told of their injuries as their individual inquests were opened.
Those who died were aged between eight and 51. None of the victims' families were in court.
A map of where 19 of those killed in the foyer were was also shown to the hearing.  The court heard a further three - John Atkinson, Georgina Callander and Saffie Roussos - died later in hospital.
Some of those who died

Officers in Bethesda have tried to reason with large groups who have been leaving smashed bottles and litter, but the problem had got worse recently.
North Wales Police PCSO Gareth Davies said their behaviour was having an "awful" impact on the community.
But some residents said youngsters in the town had nowhere to go.
North Wales Police has put a dispersal order in place, giving officers the power to order anyone to leave the area if their behaviour is anti-social.
"What we don't want to happen is that an individual from Bethesda is prosecuted or has a dispersal order which could have an affect on their lives in the future," Mr Davies told BBC Radio Wales' Good Morning Wales.

text:
Latest figures show 254 people in the UK have died - up from 112 last week.
But overall flu activity remains low in Scotland, with only 106 confirmed cases so far this year, according to new figures released today.

The weekly report from Public Health Scotland also highlights a rise in the incidence of acute respiratory infections in the NHS Lothian area.

A total of 550 cases have been confirmed in the area, which is up from 307 last week.

But PHS said there has been a reduction in cases of acute respiratory infections at healthcare centres in the Greater Glasgow and Clyde and Tayside health board areas.

Saad al-Din Ghiyyeh, an official in the Islamic Action Front, was shot in his car by masked gunmen on a motorcycle.
He was rushed to hospital but died shortly afterwards.

Since 2012, at least 50 people have been killed in fighting between residents of the predominantly Alawite district of Jabal Muhsin and the neighbouring Sunni areas of Bab al-Tabbana and Qobbeh.

text:
Mrs Fairhead would be the first woman to hold the position.
She denied claims the government was determined to appoint a woman, telling the Culture, Media and Sport Committee: "I felt the process was, for my mind, a standard process".
She refused to pass judgement on her predecessor's job performance.
Mrs Fairhead - the ex-head of the Financial Times Group -  said it was "public knowledge that mistakes were made" but added she had "no intention of saying anything negative".
Lord Patten, who was appointed in 2011, left the job of chairman on health grounds following major heart surgery.

text:
Steven Poole often incorrectly fitted flue connections and failed to supply and fit carbon monoxide detectors.
Before his death, he failed to supply and install a carbon monoxide detector in the property.

The HSE investigation into the incident concluded that Poole had:

- fitted a stove flue into the back of the property when it was supposed to be in the side wall of the kitchen
- fitted the flue with an insufficiently large section of ducting
- installed the wrong type of ducting and an incorrect number of bends
- not installed a flue terminal at the back of the house
- not supplied or fitted a carbon monoxide detector.

People in coastal areas, especially in Cardigan Bay, have been advised to be alert for flooding and to be prepared.
Natural Resources Wales (NRW) said the current rainfall coupled with a high tide is likely to lead to further flooding along the coast this afternoon (Sunday, December 20).
The organisation said flood alerts and warnings are in place for north Pembrokeshire, and that properties may also be flooded with large waves, debris or overtopping.

Trevor Bolton, 78, from Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, targeted eight boys over 21 years from the 1980s to 2000s. The father-of-one pleaded guilty to the offences.

Bolton abused boys he befriended at a sports centre in London and at a school in Essex.

A judge told him: “I’m satisfied that you sexually abused a number of boys over a long period of time. The abuse had a profound impact upon those boys, many of whom suffered a significant loss of self-confidence and depression.”

text:
Oyston senior attended a public meeting with members of the League Two club's Supporters Trust (BST) on Saturday.
He was heckled throughout as he attempted to answer questions from the floor at the Blackpool Hilton hotel.
Fans chanted "Oyston out" and "get out of our club" during the meeting, which lasted just over an hour.
Oyston was invited to make a rare appearance in front of supporters by trust chairman Steve Rowland.
At the end of the meeting, Oyston was escorted from the function room by security guards.
Blackpool, who were relegated for the third time in five seasons in May, have been owned by the Oyston family since 1988.
Relations between supporters and the owners have deteriorated since the club's relegation after one season in the Premier League in 2010-11.
This season, the club will play in the fourth tier for the first time since 2000-01.

text:
A six-mile (10km) exclusion zone has been paced around the farm in the village of Nafferton, within which the public are barred from setting foot.

It is understood to be the first time a security cordon has been placed around a UK pig farm, where the virus has not yet been detected.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rational Affairs has put the measure in place as a precautionary measure. Officials are concerned that a “freedom-of-movement” movement within the county could allow the spread of the disease from place to place, particularly as there is no vaccine to combat it.

Last night a team of more than 100 DEFRA vets and animal health workers was on standby at the farm and its surrounding areas to slaughter any infected pigs.

Government ministers were last night said to be confident of being able to contain any disease spread

text:
The Commonwealth Games Federation announced on Monday they were searching for a new host city as Durban did not meet criteria set by the organisation.
"Following the meeting with the city and provincial government last week, the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) confirmed that the City of Durban no longer meets the requirements to host the Games in 2022," the CGF said in a statement.
"The CGF was informed that there has been a change in government leadership in South Africa since the last meeting with the City of Durban. Following these developments, the Commonwealth Games Federation has now initiated a formal process to identify a new host city."
The CGF announced earlier in the month that Durban had been given two weeks to "demonstrate progress" on infrastructure after the South African city's bid became embroiled in controversy.

text:
GDP grew at an annual pace of 0.7%, down from a rate of 2.1% in the final three months of 2021, the Commerce Department said in its so-called second estimate, in line with expectations.

But the report said that a rebound was underway in Q1. The economy probably grew 1.5% in January-March, the Atlanta Federal Reserve said in its monthly GDPNow model estimate.

ECONOMY-USA

### US GDP growth slows to 0.7% in 1st quarter

WASHINGTON (AFP) -

The US economy barely grew over the winter as consumer spending barely increased and inflation bit, the Commerce Department reported Thursday (May 26).

Hisham Geneina was fired in March by President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi after estimating corruption had cost Egypt $67.6bn (Â£51.3bn) over four years.
He was sentenced to a year in jail and fined $2,200 but told he could avoid prison if he paid an additional $1,100, judicial sources said.

Geneina, a former judge, denied the charges and said they were politically motivated.

Rory Carroll

guardian.co.uk, Saturday 16 October 2010 19.03 BST

Chinese human rights activist Liu Xiaobo, right, with his wife Liu Xia. Photograph: Kwai Chan/Rex Features

On a warm Sunday evening in May 2000, 14 years ago this month, I met a dissident who had spent years behind bars for his beliefs. She was tiny – no taller than five feet – but the smile beneath her thick-rimmed glasses lit up the room.

She had a lot to smile about. She had just had a book published in her name. The book

text:
Greg Duffy accused Tony Fadell of "insulting" Dropcam employees who had joined Nest as part of the takeover.
He also suggested Mr Fadell had "fetishised" some of the worst traits of Apple's Steve Jobs.
Neither Nest nor its owner Alphabet - Google's parent - have responded.

text:
The words of Kenya women's national team captain Mary Kinuthia reveal the enormity of their achievement in qualifying for the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup finals.

She told the BBC: "For the longest time, I thought we were just going to be in the World Cup to make up the numbers, and even to the last minute, we still didn't believe we could go all the way and beat Burundi.

"We actually thought Zambia or Ghana were going to take that final spot.

"So yes, it is an amazing feeling to know we made it to the top 32, and we can hold our heads high and tell people that not only do we represent the country but we represent the world."

text:
The inquiry studied allegations of abuse in 22 homes and other residential institutions between 1922 to 1995.

The former residents were mainly from care and protection orders imposed by courts, or from compulsory admission. There was no one to speak up for them, and they were isolated from the outside world.

They were subject to the control of officials in homes operated by the Department of Justice, the Department of Education, the Anglican Church, the NSW Children's Court and the NSW Aboriginal Child Welfare Agency.

Justice Hughes has spent more than four years reading over 10,000 pages of evidence and listened to hundreds of hours of testimony from some of the 1,700 survivors.

The victims were not only subject to physical, mental and sexual abuse, but were also exposed to medical testing without informed consent.

For more than 70 years

text:
Dale Pryde, 20, admitted climbing over fencing before running towards Mr Wallace at Hampden Park.
He also pled guilty to behaving aggressively towards the referee at the football ground.
Hamilton Sheriff Court heard a report Mr Wallace had been left extremely frightened and distressed by the incident.

### What next

Sheriff Brian Mohan deferred sentence until next Wednesday for a report, remanded Pryde in custody and banned him from attending football matches in Scotland until then.

### What Dale Pryde said

Pryde told his lawyers: “I am extremely sorry for my behaviour. I accept I got drunk that day and that I have been given some heavy warnings from the Sheriff. I know I made the biggest mistake of my life.”

text:
Turkey's Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan warned such action by Syria merited a "heavy response".
But Syria's ambassador to the United Nations, Bashar al-Jaafari, said the "aggression" had no legal basis.
It comes after Turkey and the US agreed to train and equip rebels in Syria who are fighting both Syrian and Islamic State forces.
"In the days and weeks ahead, the United States will train and equip appropriate elements of the Syrian opposition," the US State Department said in a statement.
"We will also co-ordinate closely with our allies, including the Turks, and regional partners."
Turkey and the US have both repeatedly called for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to step down, while Russia and Iran have both defended his position.
Erdogan has long called for military action against Syria in the past and has said that

text:

Chad has refused to deploy its peacekeepers to a UN mission set up to help its embattled neighbour Central African Republic.

The Central African Republic has been wracked by violence since March, after Seleka fighters deposed president Francois Bozize.

The rebels have since mutinied, and have been clashing with rival anti-Balaka militias.

They have also been accused of raping and killing civilians.

UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon called on 22 October for peacekeepers to protect civilians, especially those in the capital Bangui.

A total of 2,600 African troops are scheduled to be deployed to the landlocked country

Pensions auto-enrolment and the impending National Living Wage are seen as factors in the dip in confidence.
However, the survey was carried out before the Budget, which was viewed as good for small companies.
"Small business confidence has clearly faltered, " said the FSB's vice-chairman, Sandra Dexter.
"Which is why the welcome small business focus in the Budget is so important," she added.
"We need a renewed push for growth and productivity, with policymakers delivering a sustained package of support for ambitious small firms," she added.
The survey found FSB members in all UK regions reported a fall in confidence, but it was most marked in London and the East of England.
Overall, Scotland and Northern Ireland were the least confident regions.

text:
Thirty-four people were killed when police opened fire on striking platinum miners on Thursday.
At least 78 people were injured. The incident occurred after the mine, owned by the world's largest platinum producer Lonmin, had been invaded by miners in a long-running dispute about wages and poor working conditions.
There was no immediate reaction from the authorities, Lonmin or the workers involved.
A police helicopter had a brief gunfight with workers and its pilot was wounded, a Lonmin employee said.
Lonmin CEO Ian Farmer said in a statement on Thursday that the company had taken steps to restore order and was "working together to support those injured in the incident."
"Lonmin also takes very seriously its responsibility to the wider community where these events took place and has made all its resources available to support the South African Police Service and the emergency services," Mr Farmer said.

David, 52, from Cwmbran, Torfaen, said he had "lost trust in everything" after so-called friends stole from him.
He blamed his mental health issues before realising items missing from his home had actually been stolen.
He said: "These people are really good at what they do. They make out they are buddies only to be in there with a motive."
One "friend" even asked David for a plastic bag to carry off items including family memorabilia and DVDs.
"I thought it was my mental state getting worse," he said. "I thought they were friends. Obviously they were not friends."

Jason Dockrill, 46, is serving a life term for the murder of 23-year-old Finnish national Suvi Aronen in 2003.
He had been due to face trial for the 2001 rape but changed his plea after DNA evidence linked him to the crime.
Dockrill also admitted two indecent assault counts.
He raped the victim in a park off Seething Lane in the City of London.
City of London Police said a routine case review and advances in DNA forensics had enabled detectives to link Dockrill to the attack.
"Plainly, having read the statement of the victim, this is a very serious sexual attack. She was in fear for her life," said Judge Timothy Pontius.
"It was a stranger rape carried out in a park and it consisted not just of rape but two serious indecent assaults as well."

text:
The Devon Greater Horseshoe Bat Project will restore habitats, protect 11 "priority roosts" and work with farmers in the Teign Valley to change their practices.

Horseshoe bats are the largest species of bat in the UK, and are also known as Devon's "flying badgers" because of their large size and distinctive calls. However, they are very rare in the south and west of England and are now a UK priority species for conservation. In Devon there are thought to be fewer than 100 of these mammals remaining in the wild, making them one of the rarest mammals in the county.

The project will take place over three years in the Teign Valley and the upper River Bovey catchment in Dartmoor, where 80% of the county's remaining greater horseshoe bats can be found.

text:
The Severn Valley Railway Society, which was set up at Kidderminster in 1965, is marking its golden jubilee with its 50th annual general meeting on November 10.

A 50-year history of the society has been published to coincide with the event, which is being held at Bewdley railway station. The event will include a buffet supper for members, a drinks reception and the AGM itself, chaired by outgoing Chairman Nigel Hopkins.

The meeting will be followed by a celebration dinner with special guest speaker former BR Chairman Richard Marsh, at the Hartlebury Village Hotel.

The SVRSoc has played a significant role in the SVR’s survival, success and growth since it was formed by railway enthusiasts with the sole aim of seeing it reopened.

Project archaeologist Matt Champion said what made the images special was they were of "medieval commoners" who lived their lives "leaving barely a mark on history".
The survey has been recording graffiti inscriptions in churches since 2010.
Volunteers use digital cameras and powerful lamps to reveal previously hidden or faded markings.
Mr Champion said: "They may just have been rough sketches of the people who made them, medieval selfies carved into the stones, or they may have had a deeper spiritual significance."

Officers say every year they receive complaints about callers who post flyers offering services such as household repairs or garden clearance.
They say many of these are either frauds or shoddy operators who are unlikely to complete the job.
This month Hertfordshire Police is taking part in Take Five to Stop Fraud Month, a national campaign to raise awareness about fraud.
PCSOs, crime reduction and community cohesion officers and staff from the Neighbourhood Watch Network in the county will be holding surgeries, attending events and giving crime prevention advice to the public.
They will be targeting vulnerable residents with information and advice to help prevent them from falling victim to fraud.
During Take Five to Stop Fraud Month, Herts Police will:
- be contacting vulnerable adults and young people in the community through face-to-face visits and leaflet drops, to offer crime prevention advice and reassurance
- increase our enforcement

text:
The 502 sq ft (46.64 sq m) public toilet block had provided ladies and gents facilities for visitors to the park. The toilets have been closed for some time and it was felt that a new purpose was required.

The toilets are built of stone with sandstone copings to the windows and were completed in 1875. They replaced a timber hut which had stood on the site since the park was laid out.

The building is thought to have been designed by the City Surveyor, Robert Benson.

It is now intended to make this building available to artists to use as a temporary studio.

Renovation

At the Council meeting on Thursday, councillors approved spending up to £24,000 to carry out renovation work.

The work includes renewing the floor, replacing the windows, and providing heating, lighting and plumbing.

A black hole is a dying star that has collapsed inward from its own weight.
The pull of gravity is so strong there that not even light can escape.
Astronomers have identified a very compact object in the center of the galaxy.
They are very good candidates for black holes in the center of our own galaxy, the Milky Way.
Scientists estimate that black holes in the Milky Way are 5-10 million solar masses.
The size of the galaxy depends on how much it weighs.
The more they pull, the smaller their size.
Our Milky Way is roughly as big as our solar system.
Black holes have an invisible boundary called an event horizon.
Once matter enters the event horizon, it will never be able to escape the gravity of a black hole, even if it is traveling at light speed.

text:
Sometimes, however, it is essential.
Chris Coleman says he and his Wales side will be driven by "desperation" when they face the Republic of Ireland on Friday - a desperation to succeed but, more specifically, a desperation to repeat the success of their recent past.
Absent from major tournaments for 58 years, qualifying for Euro 2016 - and then reaching the semi-finals - gave Wales a taste of what they had craved for generations.
And as they prepare for Friday's crucial World Cup qualifier in Dublin with their hopes of getting to next year's competition in Russia in the balance, it is a taste they are desperate to sample again.

Victory edges Golovkin closer to a super-fight with Saul 'Canelo' Alvarez.

text:
The night shift at the Lisburn factory was disrupted last week when machines became clogged; Coca Cola said it had impounded all affected cans.
The company stressed this was an isolated incident that did not affect any products currently for sale.
Police are investigating reports that a consignment may have been contaminated.
As reported in the Belfast Telegraph, the cans arrive at the plant without tops on and are then filled with the drink before being sealed and sold across Northern Ireland.
"Detectives are investigating an incident at commercial premises in the Lisburn area following reports that a consignment of containers delivered to the premises had been contaminated," said a spokesman for the Police Service of Northern Ireland.
A spokesperson for Coca-Cola said the company was aware of an incident involving empty cans at the Knockmore Hill plant.
"We are treating this matter extremely

text:
Tom McKeon was giving evidence at an inquiry probing claims of child abuse in the care system dating back to 1945.
Allegations of physical abuse made by former residents against some former staff there have been denied.
Mr McKeon said he only ever saw one incident where a teacher pushed a pupil against a wall.
Mr McKeon, who founded Les Chenes in the 1970s and worked there for ten years, said he had reprimanded the member of staff at the time and warned him such behaviour risked assault charges.
He moved on to other education jobs in the 1980s, then was head of education in Jersey from 1997 until he retired in 2007.
Les Chenes closed in 2003.
Mr McKeon told the inquiry in later years it could not treat teenagers being sent there with "deep psychological problems".
paraphrased_text: an inquiry probing claims of child abuse in the care system dating back to 1945. Mr McKeon was giving evidence at an inquiry probing claims of child abuse in the care system dating back to 1945. The 34-year-old from Leeds will not be part of the Great Britain squad for the build-up to the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, and will instead make her professional debut on 8 April in Manchester.
Adams, who has signed with promoter Frank Warren, will fight in her home city on 13 May.
She said: "My hero was Muhammad Ali. I said after watching him I wanted to box at the Olympics and turn pro."
In signing with Warren, Adams said she has found "a team that believes in my dream".
She added: "Together we can help take women's boxing to new levels and I can't wait to get to get in the ring in April and start working towards becoming a world champion."
Warren's association

text:
Crewe dominated from the start, with Callum Ainley steering in from close range to put the hosts in front.
Ryan Wintle's header and George Cooper's smart strike completed the scoring before half-time.
Orient, who have had five different managers this season, will finish bottom after Newport beat Accrington.
Crewe, meanwhile, confirmed their League Two survival with a first victory in five matches.
Just under three years ago, Leyton Orient were on the brink of promotion to the Championship, before falling to a 4-3 defeat on penalties in the League One play-off final.
Relegation followed one season later, but this campaign represents a new low for one of the English Football League's oldest clubs.
As well as the ongoing managerial uncertainty, Orient are in "mortal danger" of going out of business, according to the legal adviser to their fans' trust.
