text:
Press secretary Sean Spicer rejected US media reports that the president sounded out Mr Comey at a private White House dinner in January.
According to CBS News, citing an unnamed source, Mr Trump asked Mr Comey if he wanted to stay on, after the president asked senior aides to leave the table.
It was not immediately clear whether Mr Spicer was contradicting the original news report or the White House dinner itself, which was not publicly acknowledged at the time.
"The president has said repeatedly that he was going to respect and abide by the recommendation of Rod Rosenstein. I think in a lot of ways that that was the end of the conversation," Mr Spicer told reporters.
"I think when you see his statement on why he made that decision … the decision to make that decision was not made on the dinner with the president."
Asked whether Mr Trump asked Mr Comey to stay on, Mr Spicer said, "No

text:
Will Tuckett's take on Tchaikovsky's Christmas ballet had been due to open on 30 November in the Royal Opera House's Linbury Studio but the production has been shelved. The composer of this "dreamscape of choreographic invention", as described by the Royal Ballet website, was due to be the much-loved Sir Peter Wright, who, as dance critic Deborah Roberts observes "has been the resident choreographer of the Nutcracker and Sleeping Beauty for half a century and the company’s ballet master for 25 years".

text:
The friendly is Les Bleus' final warm-up before they kick off their home tournament against Romania in Paris six days later.

Although there are several players who will be looking to stake a claim for a place on the plane, others will be desperate not to let their reputations slip.

Hugo Lloris, Eric Abidal and Cedric Carrasso are the three goalkeepers in the squad but only two will travel to South Africa.

Lloris, Carrasso and Abidal are all in contention as well as the third-choice Franck Ribery, who also plays up front for Marseille.

text:
Sten Zvorwadza, who hopes to become the next Movement for Democratic Change MP for the city's Mbare suburb, says that the main opposition party is not the right party for Harare, and does not represent the interests of ordinary people.

“The MDC does not represent the interests of the workers, the youth and the women in our urban areas,” he said. “The workers in our informal economy need a voice. The women who are being raped on a daily basis need help. The youth who are forced to leave Harare because of lack of work need a voice.”

The veteran politician said that the residents of Mbare were fed up of the MDC and its MP Naison Dzvanga, saying he was “arrogant” and not “interested” in the problems of the city’s residents. “We are going to win this seat in a landslide, it is the only way

text:
Protesters say the bill, passed by the Senate on Saturday, will erode judges' independence and undermine democracy.
It gives MPs and the justice minister the power to appoint judges without consulting judicial circles.
The government says the move is needed because the judiciary is corrupt and serves only the interests of elites.
The bill must still be signed by President Andrzej Duda in order to become law. He has given no indication that he plans to veto it.
Since it came to power in 2015, the government of the conservative, populist Law and Justice party (PiS), has passed a series of controversial reforms, triggering mass protests.
Opposition supporters and human rights activists gathered in Warsaw under Polish and EU flags, and other banners, blowing klaxons, in a demonstration which continued after dark.
Police say about 4,500 people turned out in

text:
Xinhua quoted officials who said workers were trying to repair the pipeline at the time of Friday's blast.
Pictures of an explosion and its aftermath were aired on local TV, showing a large blaze and smoke billowing into the sky near an offshore oil platform.

East China's Shandong Province had been hit by the country's most powerful and longest heat wave in more than six decades, and some oil and gas companies had reportedly cut production due to the high temperatures and ensuing power shortages.
It was the second fire in three days after the same company reported a leak in its natural gas pipeline from a different offshore oil platform.
Offshore oil and gas operations in China have been plagued with safety concerns.
Last year, an explosion at an oil platform operated by China National Offshore Oil Corporation in the South China Sea killed 50 people and caused significant damage to the facility.
paraphrased_text: officials said workers were trying to repair the pipeline at the time of Friday's blast. it was the second fire in three days after the same company reported a leak in its natural gas pipeline from a different offshore oil platform.

text:
There is a two-year contract on offer to the 31-year-old from the Ibrox club.
The former Tottenham Hotspur player has enjoyed the best form of his Rangers career since arriving in Glasgow from Sheffield Wednesday in 2006.
Last season, he made 44 appearances in all competitions, chipping in with 14 goals as the club finished second in the Scottish Premier League.
Foxes boss Nigel Pearson has been looking to strengthen his squad since taking charge back in December.
His team came fourth in the Championship last season, but missed out on the play-offs after a poor run of form left them 12 points off the top six.
He was also linked with a move for former Rangers midfielder Lee McCulloch recently, although the player himself denied any interest.
paraphrased_text: the 31-year-old is set to sign a two-year contract at the Ibrox club. the former Tottenham Hotspur player has been linked with a move to the club.

text:
A quarter of a century ago, on a fairly typical November day, thousands of university students gathered in the Czechoslovak capital, Prague, for a peaceful demonstration to commemorate International Students' Day.
Little did they know that their seemingly innocuous protest would trigger the momentous events which would in effect end the rule of communism in the country a mere 10 days later.
That peaceful student protest on 17 November, which ended with brutal violence in central Prague when riot police blocked off escape routes and severely beat students taking part in the demonstration, led to what would later become known as the Velvet Revolution, an avalanche of popular protests, held almost daily in Czech and Slovak cities.
It culminated in the appointment of the country's first non-communist government in more than four decades and the election of Vaclav
paraphrased_text: 17 November.. a peaceful student demonstration on 17 November, led to what would later become known as the Velvet Revolution, an avalanche of popular protests, held almost daily in Czech and Slovak cities. It culminated in the appointment of the country's first non-communist government in more than four decades.

text:
On 5 March 1966 a coffin with the words "S&D died today" was loaded on to the very last train in a mock funeral to mark the service's demise.
At its height, the line linked places like Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Wells, Bath and Glastonbury.
But Michael Eavis, Glastonbury founder, said it would be "impossible" to have a "train coming through the site now".
The S&D, as it was known, was created in 1862 when two railways - Somerset Central Railway and Dorset Central Railway - merged to create a coast-to-coast line from Burnham-on-Sea to Poole.
Twelve years later, a spectacular extension across the Mendip Hills to Bath was opened carrying coal from the Radstock mines and stone from the Mendip Hills.
It also exploited the Midland Railway link, which by the 1950s saw the service stretched to its limits ferrying

It was created in 1862 when two railways merged to create a coast-to-coast line from Burnham-on-Sea to Poole.

text:
Jason Hayles, 44, of West Midlands Police, denies assaulting Clinton Copeland causing him actual bodily harm at Stechford Police Station, Birmingham, on November 17, 2013, in an incident captured on CCTV footage.

Hayles, who was a sergeant and on duty when the alleged assault occurred, denies any wrongdoing and has brought a judicial review challenge against the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC).

He also denies professional misconduct brought against him by the Independent Police Complaints Commission following a police investigation.

Mr Copeland, who had been arrested after an incident at a Stechford taxi office, claims he was kicked in the ribs and leg while on the floor by Mr Hayles.

He was left with two broken ribs and other injuries which left him unable to work for two months.

CCTV footage

text:
The £15m summer signing from Nottingham Forest fired home in the first half from Rudy Gestede's pass.
He then slotted in his second after the break, following up after Gestede's shot was saved.
Burton substitute Hope Akpan was sent off for a lunging challenge in the 78th minute.
Victory for Boro made it back-to-back home wins, while Nigel Clough's Burton remain without a point after three games.
Boro have spent about £30m on strikers this summer following their relegation from the Premier League, with Assombalonga, Martin Braithwaite and Ashley Fletcher all moving to Teesside.

text:
The 30ft (9.1m) male sperm whale died at Hunstanton on Friday after a rescue attempt failed.
It is thought to be from the same pod as three whales washed up in Skegness.
King's Lynn and West Norfolk Borough Council said the guards would stop people touching the whale or removing parts from the body.
The carcass is to be cut up and removed from the beach.
Read more on this story and others from Norfolk
At the weekend crowds stood close to the whale at Hunstanton, with some touching and stroking it.
Brian Long, from the borough council, took his son to see it on Sunday.
"It can nurture an understanding that you just don't get from seeing a picture in a book or on the television," he said.
"[But] we don't want to see people scavenging, as has happened before."

text:
Horner, 41, became the oldest Grand Tour race winner on Sunday.
The American was not at his team hotel when testers arrived on Monday, but Radioshack say he had told authorities about his change of address.
They even released an email from Horner to the testers which they say backs up their claims.
"The management of Radioshack wants to clarify the situation about the alleged missed out of competition anti-doping test of Chris Horner," said a team statement.
"The anti-doping inspectors from the Spanish anti-doping agency that were asked to do the test by the United States anti-doping Agency (Usada) showed up at the wrong hotel in Madrid, where the team were staying but Horner was obviously not to be found.

text:
The coaches have accused each other of illegal scrummaging in the build up to the potential tournament decider.
England coach Eddie Jones insists his side will be targeting an improved scrum ahead of their clash with Wales in a match that could see them clinch the Six Nations title and a Grand Slam.

The men in White have been accused of illegal scrummaging by a number of commentators and coaches including Wales’ defence coach Shaun Edwards, while Eddie Jones himself admitted his men were guilty of cheating the scrum against France in the tournament’s opening round.

Despite Jones’ comments the RFU has defended the scrummaging of both teams in the tournament, stating: “Neither team has broken the law, so this is an issue for the referee to manage.

“Our position remains that the scrum in this country is good, and it’s not in need of fundamental structural change

Wolfgang Sobotka said the 18-year-old was an Austrian citizen of a migrant background and there were indications he had converted to Islam.

The man drove a truck onto a pavement in the city of Linz and ploughed into a group of people before fleeing the scene, police said. Four people were injured, including two in serious condition.

Police launched a manhunt to find the driver and, by midday, had confirmed he was not armed and was "apparently dead".

Police said they recovered the suspect from the River Danube nearby and found the man had "shot himself", although details were unclear.

The incident, on Austria's first day of summer, comes amid heightened anxiety over militant Islamist attacks in Europe.

The prime minister was asked how she could expect their support given the 1% cap on pay rises, leaving Theresa May battling to keep the promises she made before last year's election.

She will announce that the government is backing plans to extend the scheme to 1,500 forces in all, increasing the coverage of the service.

There is a great deal of discontent with the government's austerity agenda among its own backbenchers, not least within the 1922 Committee of backbench MPs.

In the Commons, the prime minister confirmed reports that a review to increase numbers was being held and that the Armed Forces Covenant "commits us to ensuring our Armed Forces community is not disadvantaged" by service.

Six people were arrested last month in connection with the plot, the Department of State Services (DSS) added.
There has been no independent confirmation of the arrests, however.
The six suspects are said to be members of a criminal gang involved in oil bunkering and crude theft in the area.
According to the DSS, the suspects had planned to use 100,000 liters of diesel to make the 10 bombs.
The service added that the suspects had bought a Mercedes-Benz truck to transport the fuel to a location in Akuku-Toru, Rivers State, from the Aba area of Abia State.
Their plan was disrupted during a clampdown on the gang, said the DSS.

In Germany on Monday, Mr Trump did not mention refugee policy but criticised Germany and Nato for not investing enough in defence. He also complained about the price of Germany's imported natural gas. "The Germans are bad, very bad. See the millions of cars they sell in the U.S.," he told reporters. text:
The attack took place in a car park on Randal Street, Radford, shortly after 02:00 BST on 12 April.
Police have released CCTV of a man with short dark hair, wearing a blue top and light jacket, seen walking on Radford Road at the time.
Crimestoppers, the charity which is offering the reward, described the attack as a "very distressing ordeal".
Ann Scott, Crimestoppers' campaigns manager, said: "It is quite rare for us to offer a reward which I think shows the seriousness of the offence and the lengths the police will go to to catch this person."

text:
The Welsh Government backed Kancoat despite being advised it was a "high risk" venture with a "weak and inconsistent business plan".
The Wales Audit Office (WAO) said Kancoat owes the government £2.6m.
Ministers said key procedural changes were made after the "complex case".
The firm was previously turned down by the government's investment arm Finance Wales due to "unacceptably high" risk.
Kancoat was set up to coat metal strip used to make food cans and other products and was based at the former Alcoa factory in Waunarlwydd.
It had failed to attract private financial backing and asked the government for support.
It was given a mix of loans and financial support by the Welsh Government between May 2012 and February 2014.
Kancoat created 12 jobs but ran into difficulties when it struggled to maintain its supply of steel.
A separate report by administrator Gary Stones

text:
Arthur Simpson-Kent, 49, stabbed Ms Blake to death along with their sons Zachary, eight, and Amon, four.
He killed them when he learnt Ms Blake was planning to leave him and take their sons away, the court heard.
Judges upheld a decision that he should receive the most "severe punishment for his horrific crimes" on Tuesday.
Following the murder in December 2015, Simpson-Kent painted over the bloodstains in the family bungalow in Erith, south-east London, before fleeing to his native Ghana in January.
He was arrested at Heathrow Airport in February after being extradited and admitted murdering his family in June.
He was sentenced at the Old Bailey last October by a judge who said he had been left in "no doubt" he should receive the most severe punishment available for

text:
It comes as ministers began campaigning on the UK's EU membership, after the PM called a referendum for 23 June.

Ms Sturgeon said she had "reservations" about the timing and the nature of the referendum and said there was "no such thing" as an independent Scotland within the EU.

She said the SNP was the only "real opposition" to the UK leaving Europe and would oppose the Tories' "bogus" referendum question.

But she insisted there would be no second referendum on Scottish independence.

Speaking to BBC Scotland before visiting a North Sea oil platform, Ms Sturgeon said: "I think if this question is to be put to the people of Scotland, which I am not convinced that it needs to be, then it should be about Scotland's continuing membership of the EU and therefore the status quo is no change at all.

text:
The 25-year-old from Glasgow took control after the interval when the players were tied at 2-2, resuming with a break of 96.
A tight final frame was settled when McGill cleared up after potting the last red.
The win lifts him from 29th to 18th in the world rankings.
Having never been beyond the last eight in a ranking event, McGill is Scotland's first new winner at this level in a decade.
He defeated former world champions Stuart Bingham and Shaun Murphy en route to the final.
Sign up to My Sport to follow snooker news and reports on the BBC app.

Wada has extended the period during which athletes are not punished in this way from 15 days to 90 days as long as it does not exceed a 10-month period from the notification of the AAF to the date of provisional suspension.

The Rangers boss was unhappy with the award of a free-kick that led to Aberdeen's late winner last Sunday.
Warren McPheat

Gers boss Ally McCoist has admitted that Rangers deserved to have at least a point out of their defeat at Aberdeen on Sunday.

The 2-1 home loss was made worse for McCoist and his players with the second goal going against them at Pittodrie. Rangers were 1-0 up when the free-kick was given, and when Aberdeen equalised from it just before the hour mark, the Ibrox chief was unhappy.

text:
Brierley Town Council needed a £1.3m loan to cope with its financial problems after Janet Cooper was jailed for eight years for theft and fraud in 2013.
Residents voted to abolish the authority in a ballot in 2015.
Its assets and liabilities have been taken over by Barnsley Council.
In the referendum in September, about 1,200 people - 21% of the electorate - voted on the town council's future, with 983 calling to scrap it and 202 voting to retain it.
Barnsley Council said the takeover would be carried out "without any additional costs for Barnsley council tax payers".
The deal means that town council facilities, such as community halls, sports grounds and allotments, will remain open.

The Chinese company said revenue fell by 8% in the three months ending in December because of slowing demand for its smartphones and computers. Revenue in the U.S. slipped nearly 16% in that time.

“Looking ahead to 2023, with the economic environment remaining challenging, we expect the uncertainty to continue and the market to be highly volatile and complex in the near term,” said Huawei Chairman Liang Hua.

Founded by a former military engineer, Huawei has been at the center of a U.S. campaign that barred the company from using components made by U.S. companies for its high-end telecommunications equipment, citing security concerns. Huawei denies the concerns are valid.

The U.S. ban has been expanded to include chips, cloud software and other services critical to smartphone design, forcing Huawei to rely on its own chip supplies

text:
Vice-President Frans Timmermans announced a "preliminary assessment" under the EU's "rule of law mechanism".
Citizens' groups will be able to submit information about human rights abuses they allege.
The assessment will be done within six months of a request.
The European Commission said the mechanism will be a first step in the bloc's response to human rights violations, and "send a clear message that the EU does not accept the destruction of the rule of law".
European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen said in a statement: "Human rights are under threat everywhere: in China, in Belarus, in Myanmar, and now also in Poland and Hungary.
"The EU has one of the strongest track records globally when it comes to defending human rights. Yet we know the challenge we face in the 21st century is unlike anything we have ever seen."

The textile workers have been protesting and demanding the minimum wage be doubled.
Cambodia has around 500,000 workers in the garment industry, which is a key source of national income.
The workers are demanding a minimum wage of $160 (Â£97) a month. The government has offered an increase to around $100 (Â£60).
Chan Soveth, an activist from rights group Adhoc, told AFP news agency that security forces "used rifles and other things to crack down on the strikers" at Friday's protest.
Military police spokesman Kheng Tito told AFP that the police cracked down on protesters after nine policemen were injured in the clashes.
"We were afraid about the security so we had to crack down on them... If we allow them to continue the strike it will

text:
Experts at the University of Manchester also found bullying and family bereavement were linked to suicides.
They investigated the suicides of 8,200 people who had died aged 10 to 59 in England in 2001.
Suicide is the third biggest killer of people aged between 10 and 34 years in England, behind deaths from natural causes and injuries, according to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics.
The researchers said suicide was also the leading cause of death for women under 35 years old in England.
They found the most powerful predictor of a suicide in women was a previous suicide attempt, while in men it was unemployment.
Other major risk factors were a single or divorced status, being married or separated and a family bereavement, such as the loss of a close relative or a child.

The Working Group on Seanad Reform has also recommended a majority of Seanad seats be elected by popular vote.
The Seanad has existed since 1937, and its current powers include amending bills passed by the Dáil. It is made up of 60 seats, of which 43 are elected, and 11 are appointed to represent particular interests such as teachers, farmers, trade unions, etc.

The layouts seem to converge over time to a similar structure regardless of where or over how long they were built.
The study,  From the Eiffel Tower to the Burj Khalifa: the world’s tallest buildings converge in form and function, is published in the open access journal Scientific Reports.
A comparison of the layouts of the worlds tallest buildings shows that they tend to converge over time to a similar structure, with the core increasing in relative importance, and a smaller number of floors per layout.
The new study of 50 skyscrapers, completed between 1889 and 2013, found that although architectural styles change, the layouts converge over time. The tallest building in the world on the date of its completion is always the building with a more compact layout and a higher proportion of floors devoted to the core.

The portraits of David Cameron, Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg, Nigel Farage and Natalie Bennett have been drawn by Birmingham artist Annemarie Wright.
Miss Wright said she had used tweets that ranged from compliments to condemnation to create the works.
The portraits will feature in an exhibition at the Woolff Gallery in central London from 30 April to 15 May.
Miss Wright said: "Everybody has their own opinion on this general election and we live in a world made smaller by social media.
"Many of the party leaders themselves used social media so it was an ideal place to find people's thoughts."
She said the exhibition, called What do you think of?, was her attempt to take a snapshot of people's thoughts on what she said was an "exciting" election.

Ministers said they would amend pension and procurement policies to prevent boycotts and removal of investments.
The Conservatives claim new Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and trade unions had urged councils to "punish" Israel and UK defence firms.
Labour is yet to comment on the claim, but Mr Corbyn has backed boycotting goods produced in Israeli settlements.
He has also called for an arms embargo to be imposed on the country.
In recent months, Leicester City Council has boycotted goods from Israeli settlements in the West Bank - a move being challenged by Jewish Human Rights Watch.
The Labour-run council says it opposes "the continuing illegal occupation".
Leicester councillor Mohammed Dawood said in August the move "was not an attack on a particular faith but is about a particular policy."

Chic were responsible for some of Disco's most enduring hits: Le Freak, Everybody Dance, We Are Family and Good Times to name but four.

But when the band's guitarist Nile Rodgers came to the Midlands for a talk he said its members' real triumph was in changing the course of modern pop.

"What I've always said is that when we came along, all pop music was based around melody and lyrics," he said.

"It was almost impossible for anybody to be anything but mediocre because to be a genius would be to be unique.

The inquiry was announced by Attorney General Eric Holder after a grand jury decided against charging the officer.
That decision prompted street protests in Oakland, with demonstrators taking over a major highway, blocking BART trains for hours and setting fires in the city.
One demonstrator was shot dead, another person suffered gunshot wounds and 13 people were arrested, Oakland Police Chief Sean Whent said Monday. The victim in the fatal shooting has not yet been identified.
In the incident that led to the inquiry, Oscar Grant III, 22, was shot by a BART officer at the Fruitvale Station in the early morning of January 1, 2009.

She has told BBC Radio 1 that the strong drugs she needed to take to normalise her heartbeat "didn't work" and gave her an "alien tint".

The party has tabled an amendment to the Wales Bill currently making its way through the House of Commons.
The idea is unlikely to gain UK government support, although Welsh Conservative leader Andrew RT Davies has backed the idea in the past.
The amendment said the assembly should be "renamed the National Parliament of Wales, or Senedd Cenedlaethol Cymru".
Plaid Cymru's Westminster leader Elfyn Llwyd, MP for Dwyfor Meirionnydd, said: "This amendment, if passed, would enforce a simple change - that the assembly be officially named the National Parliament of Wales.
"The Wales Bill already makes provision for officially changing the name of the Welsh Assembly Government to the Welsh government.
"It is only right and proper that the institution's name also reflects its status as a full law-making body, as it has been since the 2011 referendum on further powers.
"The leaders of other parties in Wales have already spoken in favour of this change. We

The General Dental Council (GDC) said a lack of communication between senior managers is damaging the education of dental students.
The head of education at the UK regulator for dentists said the failure of some dental schools to put their differences to one side is damaging their students’ experience, The Guardian reported.
“If the schools don’t learn to collaborate and share, there will be a generation of dental care professionals who don’t see the value of interprofessional working,” Dr Mick Horton told the General Dental Council’s annual conference.
“The student experience needs to be one where they understand working as part of a team, where dentists can work alongside nurses, dieticians, speech therapists and community dental health officers.”

The road had previously been repaired but problems had reappeared.
Mr Healy-Rae said he shared local belief that "there was something in these places you shouldn't touch".
He added that the road passed through an area that was rich in fairy folklore and magic.
The N22 is the main road between Killarney in County Kerry and Cork.
In Irish folklore, it is believed that disturbing areas, said to have strong connections to fairies, could bring bad luck or a curse.

It smashed into the lunar surface about 3.8 billion years ago, forming Mare Imbrium - the feature also known as "the man in the moon". It's thought that the ancient impact, which excavated material from the moon's interior, helped deliver water and other resources to the lunar surface - some of which is still there today.

Using data from the Indian Space Research Organization's Chandrayaan-1 moon orbiter (C1MO), a new study led by Brown University researchers found evidence for the impact's shock effects on the interior of the moon.

"It's the first evidence to come from the interior to substantiate this idea that the Giant Impact may have been the driving force for the delivery of water and organic-bearing material to the moon's surface," said Jay Melosh, a geophysicist at Brown who led the new study.

The good news is that Turkey is embracing the struggle against the Islamic State group with a vigour it has never shown before; bombing them as they have not been bombed before.

The bad news is that Turkey’s war is not against IS – it is against the Syrian Kurds, and its aim is not to defeat IS but to protect it.

For Turkey, the enemy is not IS but the Syrian Kurds who now control a swathe of territory in northern Syria and are the most powerful and credible force fighting IS.

“We cannot ignore that this terror organisation (IS) exists. I believe that a lot of what is happening in Syria could not have happened if it didn’t have the support of Saudi Arabia and Turkey,” Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu told the Guardian newspaper. “This is a new kind of terrorism, they have a budget of $2bn a year.”

Research by the CIPD found a jump in the number of firms planning to hire more apprentices and school-leavers.
A survey of more than 1,000 companies found that half were taking measures to boost the skills of their workforce in response to recruitment difficulties.
A third were looking to take on more apprentices, the survey indicated.
Gerwyn Davies, labour market analyst for the CIPD, told Today: "The underlying factor is that the jobs market is very strong, that's forcing more employers to look at a wider range of applicants."

She was found just over an hour later a few miles away in Gosforth and "quickly reunited with her mother", police said.
The teenagers, aged 13 and 14, are in custody on suspicion of child abduction.
A spokesman for Northumbria Police said: "It was quickly established that she had left the store with two teenage girls who she did not know."
The force said travel networks in the city were alerted and officers scoured CCTV footage from council and retail premises in the area.

The report said ethnic minorities largely performed better academically than white Scots.
But they were more likely to be unemployed or in low-paid work, and were under-represented in senior management roles.
This was despite 40 years of legislation and equality policies.

The company said its "work was in line with the advice of Camden Council who were satisfied that the renovation works had been carried out to the correct standard".

The prehistoric bird, which was found recently in China, may have puffed up its feathers like a peacock.
The bird's feathers are "remarkably preserved", including the chemical that gave them sparkle.
The animal belongs to a group of early birds known as enantiornithines, which lived during the Age of the Dinosaurs.
All known specimens come from rocks in Liaoning, China, which have yielded numerous fossils of feathered dinosaurs, primitive birds and pterosaurs.
"Many enantiornithine birds possessed ornate feathers," said lead researcher Dr Jennifer Peteya of the University of Akron, Ohio, US.
"This new specimen shows that some enantiornithines also had iridescent feathers and unlike most modern birds, these flashy ornaments developed before the animal was fully grown."

Social Development Minister Mervyn Storey will bring the Welfare Reform Bill back to the assembly next Tuesday, along with a new implementation plan to take advantage of new powers to make changes to the welfare system.

The powers which devolve to Stormont come into effect in April, which Minister Storey described as a “huge opportunity” and which are part of a new UK-wide welfare reform package designed to encourage people into work.

The new measures include “a suite of incentives to move more people into work”, such as new employment opportunities with Jobcentre Plus and changes to the amount of benefits paid to working households.

text:
Currently doctors treating cancer have two main approaches - bombard the tumour with drugs and radiotherapy or cut it out.
The second option is very common but not always successful - because it is often also impossible to tell where the tumour ends and healthy tissue begins.
To try and combat this surgeons often remove tissue surrounding the tumour, but cancerous cells often remain, necessitating further surgery.
But a new goggle technology being developed in the US lets surgeons "see" which cells are cancerous and which are healthy, increasing the chances that they will be able remove all cancer cells in one operation.
"The technology is quite amazing - almost like having a microscope to guide your surgery in the operating room," says Dr Ryan Fields, a surgeon involved in a pilot study of the device.
In the study, patients are being injected with a dye before their surgery. The dye has

The growth rate slowed to an annual rate of 7.1%, compared with 7.9% in the previous quarter.
It is the lowest growth rate since 2012, according to the Chinese National Bureau of Statistics.
The slowdown is part of a planned government deleveraging policy. It reflects the fact that in its efforts to combat debt, Beijing has reduced its stimulus, making it more difficult for some companies to find financing.
However, analysts say that some sectors continue to show strong growth and that the economy remains in a fairly robust position.
According to a Reuters poll, economists expect the growth rate of the world’s second largest economy to fall to 6.5% this year.

The move follows mounting criticism of Momentum from senior Labour figures who have accused it of planning a purge of Labour moderates.

Ringed by mountains and set on a tiny island in Dal Lake, which is often described as the "jewel of Srinagar", the book store has 80,000 titles on offer, including books on Kashmir's history, heritage, culture, travel, religion and literature.
Although it has only been a few weeks since it opened, Gulshan Books cafe has already had thousands of visitors.
There's a reading room attached to the shop where 1,500 titles are available free to read, a cafe that serves coffee and snacks and free wifi.
"A lot of the youth can't afford to buy books because they are so expensive, so we are offering books that they can come and read for free," says its owner Sheikh Aijaz, whose family owns one of Kashmir's oldest publishing companies. text:
Deputy director David Lipton called for urgent steps to boost global demand.
"We are clearly at a delicate juncture," he said in a speech to an economic summit in Chile.
With the global economy "still struggling", he called for a boost to international trade and investment, saying: "More must be done to raise demand in an orderly way around the world."

The economy is "stagnating"
The IMF has warned the "risk of stagnation is real", despite efforts by global central banks to stimulate growth.
It believes that global economic growth will be only 3.3% this year, down from 3.4% in 2014, and then rise slightly to 3.5% next year.
At the same time, inflation is too low in many countries, particularly the US, it says.
The IMF is concerned that low demand is not being met by enough supply.

The performance, which has been widely circulated on social media, caused a stir online and has since led to some calling for the talent show to be taken off air for being offensive.

Viewers took to social media to react to the "awkward" moment and even demanded the contestant be replaced.

text:
He said eurozone reforms would allow the UK to negotiate changes to its relationship with Brussels.
Mr Hammond said the European Union needed to reform to ensure the economic bloc remained competitive, to reduce the impact of sovereign debt crises like Greece, and to allow members like the UK to remain inside.
But he stressed this did not mean the UK would have to give up its national sovereignty.
The Chancellor also insisted EU reform was possible despite the UK government having previously threatened to veto treaty changes in future EU talks.
Mr Hammond said: "I see the case for the UK to remain an integral part of that project, reformed, flexible and agile.
"To me this is not about abandoning the idea of a European union, but recognising that a different kind of relationship than is envisaged in the present treaties is possible and that the European project can be revitalised.

The National Union of Teachers conference is to vote on calls for the government's Prevent strategy no longer to apply to schools and colleges.

The conference will also vote on a motion which calls on the government to "end the hostile environment for refugees and asylum seekers".

The conference is taking place in Liverpool and runs until Monday.

The Prevent strategy is a government counter-terrorism policy which has seen the police and other authorities investigate people who they believe are radicalising or being radicalised.

But some critics say it is a "spy on the students" policy that disproportionately affects Muslim people.

The former Roma and Real Madrid forward caused raised eyebrows earlier this month when he announced he was retiring just eight days after signing for Serie A side Hellas Verona.

However, the 36-year-old has reiterated his wish to leave the game completely, saying that after failing to find a new team before the closure of the Italian transfer window, it made his mind up for him.

"I had an offer from Al-Gharafa (Qatar), but I didn't think twice about it," he said in quotes reported on Goal.com.

Glasgow's Queen Street Station handles 20 million passengers a year but this is predicted to grow to 28 million passengers by 2015. The new redevelopment programme will bring about a doubling of passenger capacity with more retail and restaurant facilities, and greater passenger comfort.

This project comprises three main elements:

- A three storey retail and commercial building at the foot of the current station
- A major redevelopment of the existing station building including roofing over the 225 yard concourse
- An extended east side train shed for nine new platforms and eight new tracks

The £170 million project will take approximately 5 years to complete.

Client: Network Rail

Architect: Sir Robert McAlpine

Value: £170,000,000

Chewy's owner left the puppy at McCarran International Airport on 2 July with a letter explaining she was leaving an abusive relationship.

Heartbreaking stories like the one of Chewy, the puppy abandoned at Las Vegas Airport, abound in the news.

This is just one of a number of recent cases where an abandoned pet becomes a news story, usually involving someone leaving the pet in a kennel or car, or at the airport.

It's also often the case that the person leaves a letter along with the animal.

These news stories are often reported without checking to see whether such behaviour really reflects how animals are abandoned in general, and whether it's increasing.

The Institute of Public Policy Research suggests if excluded students with undiagnosed problems were included, the rate would be much higher.
This figure compares with one in 50 pupils in the wider population who have a mental health condition.
The government said it would be publishing plans to improve mental health services later in the year.
The research comes as the number of fixed term and permanent exclusions is rising.
Figures just published show that last year, some 6,685 pupils were excluded permanently from state primary, secondary and special schools.
Some 35 pupils were excluded every day in 2015-16 -  five more daily than in the previous year.
Eight out of 10  permanent exclusions happen in secondary schools.
Here, the rate of permanent exclusions has increased from 0.15% in 2014-15 to 0.17% in 2015-16 - equivalent to 17 pupils per 10,000.
Overall, there were 346,000 permanent and fixed-term exclusions handed out to pupils at state-funded schools in 2014-15 -

text:
Muhiddin Mire, 30, targeted people at random during the attack inspired by so-called Islamic State at Leytonstone Tube station, east London, on 5 December last year.

Prosecutors said he suffered a “psychotic episode” after smoking cannabis, was convinced he had lost his faith in Islam, and was under the influence of IS’s so-called ‘Black Banner’ propaganda.

He said he was inspired by the killings committed by the Westminster terrorist and the Manchester bomber.

Police were called to the busy Tube station as he walked down the escalators wielding a bread knife, shouting: “This is for Syria! I will kill you” as he stabbed a stranger in the neck.

After he attacked, he told a woman that he had “carried out a martyrdom operation and would die soon.”

The internet giant said it would open the 310,000-sq-ft Dunstable site in the autumn.
Central Bedfordshire Council (CBC) said the move “will see hundreds of jobs in the town transformed into highly skilled and highly paid jobs in one of the most innovative companies in the world”.
It is set to house Google’s “first UK based research team”.
However, the council also said the search giant would not pay local tax for the site, worth an estimated £18m.

CBC leader James Jamieson said: “At a time when we need high quality, well paid jobs for residents, it is a real coup for Central Bedfordshire that Google has selected Dunstable as its European headquarters for AI (artificial intelligence).

The firm, Infrastrata, has permission to drill an exploratory well for oil and gas within the catchment area for Woodburn Reservoir near Carrickfergus.
The proposed well head is about 400m from the reservoir.
Woodburn supplies 700 Belfast streets with drinking water.
Opponents claim the well could impact on the quality of the drinking water.
A Green Party motion calling for a review of the decision to allow the exploratory well was passed by 28 votes to 15.
It expressed concern that drilling would involve "harmful chemicals" and that no strategic environmental assessment had been carried out before permission was given for the work.
The company has been issued with an exploration licence by the Department of Enterprise.

text:
That's the easy part. So far this year, 213 would-be commander-in-chiefs have done exactly that.
The hard part is everything that comes next.
Announcing one's candidacy, and making it official with federal paperwork, gets a name on exactly zero ballots in the state-level primaries and caucuses that are the key to winning enough delegates to secure the presidential nomination at the Republican National Convention in July.
Qualifying for those ballots is a state-by-state slog, with different rules and regulations for each. It takes time and money - and lots of it. Only the most organised, professional campaigns can manage the task.
For instance there's a $1,000 (Â£600) price tag attached to getting on the ballot in New Hampshire - the early-voting state that has made, and

text:
Two brilliant early goals stunned Boreham Wood and they never recovered as Gateshead recorded their first win in seven league games.
Wes York's sweet half-volley flew into the top corner after just 13 minutes and it was 2-0 moments later as Luke Hannant struck into the bottom corner from 25 yards.
Manny Smith appeared to get the final touch in a goalmouth scramble as Gateshead went three goals to the good five minutes from time.
And Jamal Fyfield put the finishing touch on the rout by delightfully curling into the far corner deep into added-on time as Boreham Wood crashed to a third successive defeat.
Match report supplied by the Press Association.

text:
Many people believed that there would be a late shift to Remain in the final days. And the very final polls to be published gave credence to this theory.

However, as the polling day dawned, the mood seemed to be turning to Leave. It was still too close to call – both sides were predicting that they would have the most votes – but it seemed very clear that one side was heading for victory while the other had failed to win.

But what exactly did it all mean?

For me, I saw it as a triumph for democracy – a clear vote from a massive 72% turnout of all votes eligible to be cast. It was a chance for the British people to take control and it wasn’t a chance that we should throw away, just because it might be perceived by some as “wrong”.

The ministry of antiquities said the chamber at the Dahshur royal necropolis, south of Cairo, contained a wooden coffin with a statue of a woman, as well as three granite sarcophagi.

The discovery was made by a team headed by Abdel Moneim Saied and Mustafa Waziri.

"The discovery is the best achievement we have made in the last years as it contains several funerary materials from different dynasties dating back to the Old Kingdom. It proves that Dahshur was not used only as a royal necropolis," Saied said.

The tombs were originally buried under a large pyramid of Senusert II in the mid-12th Dynasty. The discovery was made during an archaeological mission that began in 2009.

Mental health nurse Amanda Young is accused of administering a lethal dose of clozapine to Joshua Gafney, 22, in 2016.

Gafney had suffered from severe autism and epilepsy, and had no friends. He was also known to have a fear of needles and would run away when nurses approached him for injections.

The court in Leicester was told that Amanda Young injected Mr Gafney with a potentially fatal dose of the anti-psychotic drug clozapine despite him being underweight and having an existing condition which made him susceptible to a “deadly drop” in blood pressure.

Ms Young, 51, of Broughton Astley, denied murder and administering a poisoned substance with intent to endanger life.

Mr Trudeau underscored his government's commitment to bringing in "those fleeing persecution, terror & war".

The United States is not open to a new asylum-seeker pact with Canada and will not be joining the global effort at all, the U.S. ambassador to Canada said.

"I have always felt that the Canadian approach was very similar to our approach". "And so, you know, I'm not sure what to make of it other than the fact that there are people that want to abuse a system, abuse loopholes, and get asylum based on the fact that they may have a distant relationship or just even a family relationship to somebody that's already been here".

text:
Patients requiring emergency care in the South West were left waiting "for long periods", the Care Quality Commission (CQC) found.
Inspectors said the 111 service, run by South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust (SWASFT), put callers' safety at risk.
SWASFT chief executive Ken Wenman said the report contained "no surprises".
Click here for the latest updates on this story
He said there was no evidence the service had caused clinical harm but accepted it was "no way near what it should be".
Mr Wenman said: "The CQC report does point out that we were understaffed... it's very difficult to recruit and retain members of staff, particularly clinical staff in this type of service, and that's the focus that we're going to be having as part of the improvements that we're going to make over the coming months."

Russia has been in the spotlight since the poisoning in Britain of ex-spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, in Salisbury, which the country has denied involvement in.

The Environment Agency now says dredging will start next month

Flood-hit residents in Skipton can look forward to an improvement in their flood defences, the Environment Agency has announced.

Silent Majority, painted during the 1998 Glastonbury Festival, shows soldier-like figures landing on a beach with a large banner. The banner is inscribed with the words “The Silent Majority” and the flag of the United Kingdom. This work is a comment on Margaret Thatcher’s political campaign slogan ‘The Silent Majority’ and is a reference to public opinion in relation to war.

The work was created to coincide with a series of live events as part of a project called ‘A Nation’s Sorrow’ conceived by the British artist Damien Hirst, who was then a resident artist at Glastonbury Festival. The Yarubiya border post was captured after three days of clashes with groups linked to al-Qaeda, the fighters said, without giving any further details.

"It is now in the hands of al-Nusra," the official said, adding that the fighters were still in "complete control" of the post on Syria's border with Iraq, which they had seized from government forces on Saturday.

The fighters, who are opposed to the Assad regime and the presence of Iranian forces in Syria, said the Iraqis they were battling had fired on them and the Assad forces had shelled their positions and killed seven.

It is the second year in a row the Scottish Government has given councils permission to increase the council tax, but only two – Moray and West Dunbartonshire – are using it.
The Scottish Government says that if the councils did not hike council tax, it could lead to other vital services, such as schools and social care, having their budgets cut.

The 4.99% increase is the maximum allowed by the Scottish Government but it is possible to charge less. It has resulted in council tax in Scotland being higher than anywhere else in the UK, when taking inflation into account.

Councillors said the issue was people "deliberately feeding" the birds and the issue had got "out of hand".
Experts will advise the authority while a report said it would cost about £50,000 to erect signage and launch an education campaign..

"The kids won't have a chance because they will start dive-bombing them.

Thorsten Herdan told BBC News that the world can’t stabilise CO2 emissions without making polluters pay.
Mr Herdan, of the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy, said if renewables got cheaper still, the market would respond by dropping the coal price more.
Some of President Trump’s advisers have argued that any carbon price should be fixed at zero to reflect the benefits of fossil fuels.
But German Chancellor Angela Merkel is expected to try to persuade President Trump that the world is moving towards clean energy.
Mr Herdan said that the German government was preparing research that would reveal that business is showing huge support for a transition towards a low carbon economy.
It will be presented at the G20 in Hamburg in July, when climate change and sustainable development will be among a handful of major themes.
The G20 is the central forum for international cooperation

Strachan will take time after Sunday's match against Gibraltar to decide if he will renew his contract before the upcoming World Cup qualifiers.

The Scots are bottom of Group F with one point and next host Slovakia on November 11 before ending their 2018 campaign away to Slovenia and at home to Lithuania.

But Strachan's position will not come up for discussion if he leaves his post after the match against Gibraltar - which comes just 11 days after the 62-year-old's side threw away a two-goal lead in the 3-2 defeat to Slovakia in Glasgow.

Slater said the incident was "like smashing my foot with a big hammer".

Her fans may have noticed a sci-fi inspired theme in her recent performances and music, but now she wants to go a step further.
The performer has no interest in giving up singing - which she describes as her "lifeblood" - but said it was important to "keep educating yourself".

"I want to go and do a degree in physics - I will have to do an A-level in physics and maths first though," she said.

The 54-year-old said he was "deeply honoured... to join the distinguished list of past recipients of this award."
First presented to Richard Pryor in 1998, the award is named after the 19th Century novelist and essayist who was born Samuel Clemens in 1835.
It is given annually to someone who has had an impact on US society through their humour and social commentary.
Other previous recipients include Bill Cosby, Ellen DeGeneres and talk show host Jay Leno, last year's honouree.
Born in Brooklyn in 1961, Murphy got his break in comedy in 1980 when he joined the cast of Saturday Night Live.
He went on to become one of the movie industry's top box-office performers thanks to such hits as Beverly Hills Cop, Coming to America and the animated Shrek films.
Murphy will be presented with the prize at a ceremony on 18 October at the John F Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, DC.

The LTA says it will also take the Davis Cup trophy on a tour to 50 different venues around Britain.
The move follows criticism of the LTA from world number two Andy Murray for failing to develop world-class talent.
Britain won the Davis Cup for the first time since 1936 by beating Belgium in Ghent in November.
"We want to make a difference in capitalising on this unique opportunity to get as many kids on court as possible," said victorious Davis Cup captain Leon Smith.

text:
The Culture, Media and Sport Committee said it would investigate concerns about the public being swayed by propaganda and untruths.
The inquiry will look into the “increased use of social media to influence public opinion and behaviour and the role of disinformation” in elections and referendums.

The probe will look at how social media can be used to spread untrue and divisive content as well as the potential for foreign powers and rogue states to interfere.

It will also scrutinise the effectiveness of current legislation in tackling the issue.

The committee also wants to hear from the tech companies and social media platforms themselves about what they are doing to prevent abuse, and what more they could do.

The inquiry will include an examination of the impact of social media on democracy, the media, young people, and issues such as hate crime and self-harm.

Upper tier tribunal judge Lord Doherty dismissed the appeal against a first-tier tax tribunal decision but referred several issues back to the tribunal to decide in light of further legal submissions.

The original case concerned a client of Dixon’s, a client who had sought to rely on the legal right of a tax resident in the UK to sell their home without the imposition of capital gains tax.

When that line of argument was rejected HMRC tried to go back on the basis that the client was a UK resident because his tax affairs are administered in the UK.

Lord Doherty agreed that a tax resident, on the basis of where he or she is tax resident, can only sell his or her property at no capital gains tax cost to themselves, when they cease to be a UK tax resident for good.

But, when the client returned to the UK, HMRC said he was UK resident because his

In 2010 the presses fell silent when the Guthrie Street works, which employed generations of people in the city, were closed.
But, it will be brought back to life to house the first Dundee Design Festival.
Organisers say the May festival will be a  four-day celebration of design, marking the city's first full year as the UK's Unesco City of Design.
It will showcase design from Dundee, Scotland and internationally, through a large exhibition, talks, demonstrations and workshops.

text:
Yvonne Hegarty, a special needs teaching assistant, described the abuse she received on a fake Facebook account as "horrendous".
Maureen Curoe, 42, was sentenced at Coleraine Magistrates' Court to four months in jail.
Curoe, of Pilot Street, Belfast, was released on bail ahead of an appeal.
Ms Hegarty said an initial post on Facebook in February 2013 related to her partner, Adrian.
Several months later, a Facebook profile was set-up under the name Gillian Morgan, which contained nothing but photographs of Yvonne Hegarty, her family and friends.
She told the BBC's Talkback programme: "Below nearly every photograph was a status saying: 'This is an alcoholic, this is a drug abuser, look at her with her pupils out drinking, she shouldn't have those children in her arms.'
"It was just endless. It was an absolute assassination of my character

The city's Olympic-sized facility was opened by the Princess Royal in January 2009 and is the largest of its kind between Edinburgh and Manchester.

The club provides training for up to 350 people a week at the facility, along with classes for disabled athletes through the Sport Works Disability Club.

It also provides swimming lessons for children and people with special needs, plus it caters for recreational swimming, aqua aerobics and other social activities.

The council said that it has had to look at how it finances the club as it is not yet breaking even, adding that it "can no longer afford to provide the subsidy required to keep the facility going."

However, the authority has said it will continue to support the swimming club "in a new guise".

The swimming club has also announced the closure and said it was looking for a new home.

text:
Throughout 2016, 58,983 Southern services were either fully or partly cancelled. Averaged out across the year, this means that every time a train departed London Paddington there was a one in five chance it would be cancelled. The 159004, a class 159 train (sometimes known as the 'Sprinter'), was the single most unreliable train in the UK.

The London Underground fared a little better, with nearly one in every three trains running on the Jubilee Line being cancelled, followed by the Metropolitan Line.

The route, which runs from St Bees Head in Cumbria to Robin Hood's Bay in North Yorkshire, was devised in 1973 by fell walker and author Alfred Wainwright.
Campaigners say the walk should be included alongside the 15 designated National Trails, which include the Pennine Way and the Cleveland Way.
Wainwright Society chairman Eric Robson said the walk was a "wonderful route".
The campaign has been backed by Richmond MP Rishi Sunak and BBC presenter Julia Bradbury.
Walkers want the path to have the same prominence and national funding as the existing National Trails, which are looked after by Natural England and Natural Resources Wales.
Mr Sunak said: "The Coast to Coast runs right through the heart of the Richmond constituency and some of the most beautiful scenery in the UK.
"Hundreds of businesses depend on it and official recognition would bring a real boost

Experts at the University of Manchester also found bullying and family bereavement were linked to suicides.
They investigated the suicides of 130 people under 20 in England between January 2014 and April 2015.
In February, figures published by the Office for National Statistics revealed an increase in youth suicides.
There were 201 people aged between 10 and 19 who killed themselves in 2014 in the UK - up from 179 in 2013.
It comes as separate Office for National Statistics figures, published this week, suggested student suicides have risen to their highest level since at least 2007.
Suicide is the biggest killer of people under the age of 35 in the UK.
However, the research - by the University of Manchester's National Confidential Inquiry into Suicide and Homicide by People with Mental Illness - is the first time experts have studied the contributory factors on this

Solicitor John Owen, 79, stole the money from John Williams after being made executor of his will.
He admitted 17 charges of theft and false accounting at Newport Crown Court on Tuesday.
Judge Tom Crowther QC said Owen breached trust "of the grossest sort" and said a prison sentence was likely.
The court was told no-one knows where the money has gone after it vanished from his firm in Llandeilo.
Janet McDonald, prosecuting, said: "The deceased was a long standing client of Mr Owen and he made him the executor of his estate.
"Owen would bill for work, charging it to the estate. He would then take the money without doing any work.
"The money was then taken out of the law firm's account."

text:
Officials had previously believed the crash, in which an entire Chinese tour group died, was caused by mechanical failure.
But an investigation has found that the driver, Su Ming-cheng, was drunk and had been planning to kill himself.
He was already being investigated for scuffling with a tour guide and sexually assaulting an unnamed victim.
In both cases, officials alleged he was intoxicated, and prosecutors said the lawsuits had left Mr Su "depressed".
Minutes before the crash, investigators said, the driver poured fuel inside the bus and started a fire with a lighter.
He then swerved into a roadside barrier on a national highway in the city of Taoyuan, killing himself, a local guide and 24 tourists who were headed to the airport.
An emergency exit was also locked, trapping people as they tried to escape.
Text messages from Mr Su's relatives showed they pleaded with him not

text:
Her underlying message is that Europe spends too much on social policies and thus has no choice but to retrench.
Austerity is one of the words most associated with the Greek crisis, but it is a word with more than one meaning.
The first meaning is more austerity. There is a lot of that in Greece and there will be more to come. But more austerity is only one meaning of the word austerity, the one that gets the most attention.
The other meaning is that we will not see a repeat of the excesses of the past, or the bad old days, as they are sometimes known. This is the meaning that will have the most impact for the years to come.
More austerity means austerity in the bad sense, which can easily be associated with mismanagement. But it can also mean doing things better in the good sense. The crisis has been a wake-up call to the European Union and we
paraphrased_text: the Greek crisis. Austerity is one of the words most associated with the Greek crisis, but it is a word with more than one meaning. The first meaning is more austerity. There is a lot of that in Greece and there will be more to come. The second meaning is that we will not see a repeat of the excesses of the past. This is the meaning that will have the most impact for the years to come.

In the year to the end of March, the total number of crimes reported to police dropped by 3.2%.
There were 4,966 fewer reports of rape and 16,595 fewer reports of domestic abuse, meaning the total was 415,536.
However, a police analysis of the data found a “significant increase” in domestic abuse and rape over the past three months.
Home Secretary Priti Patel said the new figures showed the “real” impact of her crackdown on crime.
The analysis found that police recorded 83,251 offences in the three months to the end of March, compared with 61,329 in the same period last year.

Dack got his third of the season when he picked the ball up just outside the box, got his shot away first time and curled it into the bottom corner.

Brereton almost got a hat-trick in the last

Huddersfield's 13th league defeat of the campaign kept them second from bottom after 17 games.

Khaled Meshaal told the BBC the victory of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party and its right-wing allies meant there would be "more extremism".
He said Hamas was not looking for any escalation, but would defend itself.
Militants in Gaza led by Hamas fought a 50-day war with Israel last summer that left more than 2,200 people dead.
Last week, Amnesty International said rockets and mortar attacks on civilian areas in Israel during the conflict amounted to war crimes.
Hamas is designated a terrorist organisation by Israel, the US and other countries due to its long record of attacks on Israelis and its refusal to renounce violence. Under its charter, the group is committed to the destruction of Israel.

The proposal is to build the venue in St Andrew Square, which would also be used for education, conferences and public engagements.

The venue is expected to be built in stages over the next decade and will eventually take over an acre of the square, which is currently home to a statue of John Law and an unfinished obelisk.

It was designed by Edinburgh-based Page Park, which beat the late Richard Rogers, Zaha Hadid Architects, Hopkins Architects and Buro Happold.

It will also house the new National Museum of Scotland, which is expected to move from Chambers Street in Edinburgh into its new home in 2016.

The centre would be connected to the St Andrew's House building through an underground concourse.

"People pushed themselves to another level to get a result for this country.
"It was like watching a heavyweight boxer against a middleweight."
Despite the heroics of Leigh Griffiths, who lashed two free-kicks past Joe Hart in the 87th and 90th minutes, Scotland's World Cup qualification hopes remain slim.
However, Strachan said he was "too tired to think about where we are, I just want to go home".
After six matches, Scotland, on eight points, trail Group F leaders England by six points, second-place Slovakia by four and Slovenia by three.

North Lincolnshire and Goole, University Hospitals of North Midlands and St George's University Hospitals trusts have a predicted combined deficit of Â£145m.
NHS Improvement - a department set up to aid "rapid financial improvement" - is responsible for the move.
Chief Executive Jim Mackey said trusts must "keep a strong grip on finances".
He said the trusts involved were not on course to meet their savings targets, and placing them in financial special measures would help get them the support needed to improve.
NHS experts will now work with the trusts to make sure money is not being spent without proper checks and controls.

text:
Seismologists said New Ollerton, in Nottinghamshire, is the "most seismically active" area in the British Isles, and probably due to mining.
James Lawson said it sounded like "something was trying to get through".
The British Geological Survey (BGS) said it was planning to install more instruments to study the tremors.
Mr Lawson, who lives in New Ollerton, said: "It's rather surreal and my son likens it to the monster under the house because it sounds like something is trying to get through.
"There's an almighty boom followed by extra after-booms. Sometimes, the car alarm might go off in the garage. Pots might fall off the side in the kitchen.
"At first it was a little scary, you fear for your house and property, but we've learned to live with it. It's more a curiosity than a nuisance."

Frampton, 29, faces former champion Santa Cruz in Las Vegas on Saturday, after claiming the Mexican's title in a thrilling fight in July. The Manchester-born boxer says a successful defence of the title would allow him to set his own rules, as he looks to emulate fellow countryman Carl Frampton.

Frampton, a two-weight world champion, has been criticised for not living up to his potential. But the Yorkshireman now believes he has the tools to join the ranks of stars, such as Frampton, Ricky Hatton and Naseem Hamed, who have enthralled the UK.

The 30ft (9.1m) male sperm whale died at Hunstanton on Friday after a rescue attempt failed.

The whale had been spotted in the area since 14 November.

An attempt to herd the whale into deeper water failed on Friday and experts said there was little they could do to save the creature.

The mammal was found stranded on the beach at the end of the day.

Dr Richard Shears, the chief executive of the British Divers Marine Life Rescue, said the decision to not carry out a rescue attempt at night on Thursday was not taken lightly and experts had considered several other options.

Irish director of rugby Kennedy will see his side face Harlequins at Twickenham in the season opener.
The Exiles are back in the top flight after winning promotion from the Championship at the first attempt.
"We're happy to be back, but we know it's a huge, huge challenge ahead of us," Kennedy told BBC Sport.
Irish will travel to defending champions Exeter the week after facing Quins in an opening month which also features Friday-night trips to Sale and Newcastle.

text:
North Wales Police are using DNA tests in a bid to solve 17 separate cold cases of unidentified human remains found in their area from over the last 40 years.

The first of the DNA profiles have now been loaded onto a national police database and the families of missing people are being contacted in hope that matches can be made.

Detective Inspector Paul Hughes, of North Wales Police, told the Liverpool Echo : "These families deserve to know the fate of their loved ones and we would urge them to come forward if they have suspicions about a member of the family.

"The DNA profiles from the 17 sets of remains have been uploaded to a national police database that the police forces will have access to and will be able to search if they have any unidentified remains.

text:
The bank is authorised to issue Scottish banknotes, and will release the limited edition notes the year before the Bank of England puts plastic banknotes in general circulation.
The new polymer note features the Forth Bridge on its 125th anniversary.
Banks say polymer notes stay cleaner and are more secure than current ones.
More than 20 countries around the world have adopted polymer banknotes.
In 1999, Northern Bank of Northern Ireland issued a polymer £5 commemorative note celebrating the year 2000.
A plastic note was introduced in the Isle of Man in 1983 but was withdrawn in 1988 owing to problems with the ink.
Adopters of the notes include Canada, whose last central bank governor - Mark Carney - is now the governor of the Bank of England.

Critics of the right-wing Polish government have been angry at changes it has made to the country's top court, leaving it, they say, largely under government control. This week, the issue reached the European Union and its highest court.

The president of the European Commission says the top court of Poland is not in danger but it still needs to be judged.

The European Union and its highest court are now involved in the crisis over the independence of Poland’s Constitutional Tribunal.

EU President Jean-Claude Juncker said on a visit to Warsaw that if Polish authorities did not respect the EU constitution or the rule of law it would be a problem.

Mr Grainger’s family have brought a civil action against GMP, seeking damages for his death.

The delays moving medically fit patients out of hospital beds and back to their communities because of social care problems have been well documented.
BBC research published on Wednesday underlines the scale of the delays finding beds for new patients coming through hospital front doors.
From 2.7% of all emergency admissions in English hospitals in 2010-11, the proportion of patients enduring waits of more than four hours before beds could be found had risen above 11% by 2015-16.
The trend was described as "deeply worrying" by NHS Providers, which represents trusts.
All this paints a picture of a hospital system clogged up with delays throughout the process of assessing, treating and discharging patients.
Bed occupancy in many trusts is above the 85% level recommended as a safe maximum.
But the experience of one hospital trust suggests there are realistic solutions.
Sherwood Forest Hospitals Foundation Trust, in the East Midlands, was one of the worst performers in England two winters ago.

Recycling officer Tina Norman-Ross said the problems would be looked at, but overall she was "very, very pleased".
She said they had hoped to reach all of the island's homes, about 26,000, but those who had been missed could email recycle@gov.gg to receive bags or information.

She said the States had "only bought a year's worth" and it was one area they would review.

The men were taking part in the Cannon Run, a European driving tour. They were arrested on 4 June and have been held in custody since 5 June.

A spokeswoman for the Spanish National Police told Driving that no bail will be granted because the men are considered to be flight risks.

Spanish authorities have charged the four with dangerous driving, as they allegedly drove at a high speed and cut across lane markings. The 1909 Mercedes is said to have been spotted travelling at more than 120mph, although it is not believed to have been driven at that speed for the entire 60-mile journey to the hotel.

The foot, severed just above the ankle, was discovered in Weston Park East near Royal United Hospital last month.
Forensic tests revealed the foot had been separated from its owner for some time.

Forensic tests revealed the foot was a right foot and belonged to a male whose lower leg had been severed using a power saw.
The foot is white, has blue eyes and long, thin, brown hair. It is also missing all its toenails.

Police believe the leg was cut off using a power saw

Forensics also confirmed the foot, which had been severed by a power saw, had been dead for more than 11 months.
Detectives said the foot could belong to anyone and urged the public to check missing person reports if they have not seen the man in the past year.

A 49-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder and has

text:
Recruitment is underway to find an independent chair to investigate why 17 schools were closed amid building safety fears.
Council leader Andrew Burns said it is important the chair commands respect within the construction industry.
He wants lessons to be learned not just in Edinburgh, but across Scotland.
The schools, built under the same public private partnership project between 2002 and 2005, closed in April after investigations found structural defects centring on missing wall ties.
Alternative arrangements were put in place for 7,600 pupils and 740 nursery children.
Three schools are expected to reopen next week, when declared safe, five more in June and a further nine after the summer holidays.
A report put before members of the council's corporate policy and strategy committee on Tuesday gave an update on the situation and plans for an inquiry.

After about six years of courtship, the political marriage between Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta and his deputy William Ruto has finally been solemnised and consummated.
The couple now has a healthy, bouncing baby known as Jubilee.
It was born on Saturday, weighing an incredible 12kg (the number of political parties that merged to create Jubilee).
In Mr Kenyatta's Kikuyu culture, the birth of a baby boy is welcomed with five loud ululations by the women present.
Some of Kenya's leading gospel and secular artistes and comedians were on hand to raise the decibel metre, as they led the crowds of thousands in celebrating the birth.

The bomber attempted to drive into a UN camp in Ansongo town when his explosives detonated, it added.
At least 100 have been killed in the latest spate of violence.
An attack on a mosque in the north-eastern town of Ansongo on Wednesday is thought to be the deadliest yet.
A further 253 people, most of them men and boys, were wounded in the attack on the Dawa mosque when it was full of worshippers taking part in evening prayers during the holy month of Ramadan.
The Islamic militant group al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (Aqim) has claimed responsibility for the atrocity.
The explosion near the UN camp happened after local villagers, angry at Aqim, surrounded the area where the militants are believed to be hiding, local officials said.

The BBC Sport website and app will stream the live radio and TV highlights from the Open, while a daily live text commentary will provide latest scores and news from Royal Troon, in addition to blogs and videos from the BBC’s team at the championship.

Fans will also be able to read analysis, results, interviews and features from the BBC’s team of commentators, including Iain Carter, Aarti Joshi, Andrew Cotter, Ben Evans, Peter Alliss, Ken Brown, Michael Vaughan and David Pleat.

In addition, the BBC will bring fans all the latest scores and news from the other majors this week, with the US Women’s Open, the Ladies’ European Tour and the US Senior Open, as well as offering coverage from the US PGA Tour’s Barclays PGA Championship.

The Healthcare Safety Investigation Branch (HSIB) is due to begin work this autumn with a budget of Â£3.6m and will carry out about 30 reviews a year.
The MPs' report also calls for a single public inquiry into historical cases of avoidable harm in the health service.
The government says it has made legal provisions for HSIB's independence.

text:
A report by the Scottish Retail Consortium (SRC) and KPMG showed total Scottish sales fell by 2.1%, compared with July last year.
Food sales were down by 4.5% - the category's worst performance since SRC began keeping records 16 years ago.
SRC blamed the fall on wet weather, deflation and price promotions.
However, non-food sales fell by just 0.1%, which was its best performance since last October.
Adjusted for deflation, total Scottish sales decreased by 0.4%, compared with the previous July.
Clothing and footwear was the best performing category in July, with customers responding to end-of-season promotions.
While store sales in the category showed modest growth, online sales were "very strong", according to the monitor.
It said a very wet July, with 63% more rainfall than average for the month,
paraphrased_text: Non-food sales fell by 0.1% - the category's worst performance since SRC began keeping records 16 years ago. Clothing and footwear was the best performing category in July, with customers responding to end-of-season promotions.

The BBC said the show, to be recorded at Wilton's Music Hall in London, would see the comedian make "bold and often outrageous statements about the vote".
Matt Berry and Jo Brand will also appear in upcoming iPlayer commissions.

The St John's hospital ward in Livingston will only open between 08:00 and 20:00 during weekdays and close at weekends for the next three weeks.
It will still assess patients on weekdays but transfer children to Edinburgh if they need to be admitted.
First Minister Alex Salmond and West Lothian Council have criticised the temporary closure.
NHS Lothian said it was due to staff shortages.
Dr David Farquharson, NHS Lothian medical director, said: "Reducing the service provided by the children's ward on a temporary basis has been a very difficult decision to make, but the risks of not taking this action are too great.
