text:
On Monday Australia's upper house, the Senate, rejected a piece of government legislation for a second time.
This provided Mr Turnbull with the grounds to call for an early federal election.

But what is the impact of Australia's election cycle on companies, and how should investors manage this?

## The impact on earnings

The effect of a federal election on earnings is varied across sectors.

The largest contributor to the Australian stock market is the financial sector, and the banks will be affected by the election.

Banks earn the bulk of their profits from providing loans to the residential housing market. Elections tend to make people less confident about their employment and wage prospects, and less confident about the outlook for the economy.

It's common to see house price growth stall for at least a year after an election, and usually weaker housing market conditions lead to fewer people wanting to take out home loans, and the banks lose

It's an oft-repeated and oft-questioned phrase that's taken on a mythical status but the former Daily Mirror editor stands by it still:

"I've never seen a Welsh man with a gun but I've met people in Wales who've been known to want to do what Hitler did in Germany... and those people I would describe as gun-toting final solution crackpots... I was referring to them specifically.

"I would have said 'Welsh gun-toting final solution crackpots' if it came into my head but it didn't... I'm not going to apologise because I'm right and I'm justified in what I said.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said sales volumes fell 0.6%, which followed a 1.7% rise in September when sales were helped by the Rugby World Cup.
The monthly fall in food store sales was the biggest drop since May 2014.
Retail sales volumes rose 3.8% compared with a year ago, compared with a 6.2% annual rise in September.
Average shop prices, including petrol stations, were 3.3% lower in October than a year earlier.
The ONS said department stores and clothing also dragged on retail sales growth last month.
However, sales volumes in the three months to October compared with the previous three-month period - seen as a better indicator of the underlying trend - rose 0.9%.

Anthony Kwan Hok-chun was arrested at Suvarnabhumi Airport when boarding a flight to Hong Kong on Sunday. The suspect faces a total of six counts of rape, and a warrant was issued for his arrest in the city last week. Police said that the suspect had travelled to Hong Kong to work as a masseur and had met the victims at his home where he had forced them to watch pornographic videos before sexually assaulting them, the Bangkok Post reported. His next appearance in court will be on Tuesday.

A major incident was declared at the Royal Stoke University Hospital at about 18:00 BST.
Six fire engines were also sent to the scene and a major incident protocol was declared at 7.30pm.

Staff at the hospital, in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, said the incident affected “every part of the hospital”.

Two women were initially thought to have died in the blaze but both survived.

Emergency services are not looking for anyone else.

A police spokesman said 120 people were being evacuated from the hospital.

Two women in their 60s were taken to other hospitals as a precaution, said Staffordshire and West Midlands major incident team.

One is being treated for smoke inhalation, while the other is stable.

Each of them has promised, in varying ways, to settle constitutional arguments for, if not a generation, then a long time. The current Wales Bill is no exception, its author Stephen Crabb having set out in 2014 to create "a stable and lasting settlement".
Monday's House of Lords debate suggests his goal remains elusive, with peers lining up to highlight the Bill's flaws. Perhaps we should not be surprised.
Wales's newest member of the Lords, Baroness Bloomfield of Hinton Waldrist (although she's from Bonvilston), used her speech to remind peers that "the Statute of Rhuddlan in 1284 was intended to settle the government of Wales once and for all following the execution of Dafydd ap Gruffydd, Prince of Gwynedd".

A new report from analysts Deloitte says combined revenues soared by 29% to £3.26bn, and the clubs made pre-tax profits of £187m, the first since 1999.
It may mark a turning point in football finance and "a new age" of significant profitability for top clubs, they said.
League revenues were more than in Spain and Italy's top divisions combined.
And England's top division also generated in excess of £1bn more in revenues than its nearest rival, Germany's Bundesliga.
As well as record pre-tax profits, operating profits increased by £532m - a huge 649% - to £614m, and smashing the previous record by nearly £430m.

Lord Carey, who backed the benefit cap when Anglican bishops opposed it, urged the government to rethink the cuts in a letter to Iain Duncan Smith published on Saturday. In it, the former Archbishop of Canterbury says “there are simply no easy answers” to the crisis and warns that it will damage the poorest.

“The impact of the changes to the welfare system are beginning to hit, and they are going to hit harder,” he says.

“You will soon begin to see the impact of benefit cuts in foodbanks, schools, and hospital A&E departments.”

text:
What are the values that infuse it? And how did it break out of its kilted straitjacket to be shaped by the times we live in now?
If the modern Scottish identity has a birthplace, it's at Abbotsford, the country home, 40 miles south of Edinburgh, of Sir Walter Scott.
The novelist and poet, who died in 1832, designed it himself, with crow-stepped gables and Scots baronial turrets and crenellated balconies.
Scott invented modern Scotland here, summoned it from his own imagination, and served it up principally for English consumption.
Until then, Scotland had been, in the English imagination especially, a wild and lawless place that had to be subdued by force.
Scott made it safe, even romantic.
"Scott was very clear when he wrote his first novel, Waverley, that what

text:
Growing demand for groundwater is putting pressure on the resource while researchers struggle to accurately estimate the future supply.
But a team from Oxford University, UK, has developed a new groundwater forecasting technique that is a more efficient use of the resource. It uses a statistical model to estimate how much of the resource is being used, and how much is likely to be available in future.
“Groundwater supplies about half the world’s water needs,” Dr Tianyi Huang, an environmental fluid mechanicist in the Oxford University Department of Engineering Science, said in a statement.

> In dry periods, demand for groundwater increases and the levels become more depleted. In those circumstances, the water levels become lower and lower, so people start extracting at an increased rate which accelerates the decrease in the water levels. This causes a vicious cycle that leads to increased groundwater use and over-extraction in the long term.

text:
This is according to researchers from Duke University in the US, who developed decision-making games that the apes played to earn edible treats.

The scientists gave the animals the opportunity to earn the food by trading off rewards in terms of their time: in one scenario they had to choose a treat, which could be larger, but only after a delay.

The scientists studied two groups of capuchin monkeys, aged five to 15, at Duke’s Yerkes Primate Center over the course of two years and found that those that had more experience playing the game in pairs made better decisions.

These more experienced capuchins preferred the quick-but-smaller reward, and also tended to choose more frequently when there was a high chance of winning. They also chose to stick with familiar options when their original reward was taken away.

“We find that monkeys who are more experienced in this kind of game are more likely to

text:
Photographer Shirley Baker died in 2014 aged 82, leaving behind a body of work that had received little attention over her 55-year career.
An exhibition of her images is now on show at Manchester Art Gallery.
It focuses on what Baker saw as the needless destruction of working-class communities between the 1960s and 80s.
The museum held an open day in the hope of tracking down people who featured in the photographs, some of whom have come forward.
Baker's images often show families going about their daily lives, with gangs of children playing in the street.
Broken urban landscapes of rubble, junk and abandoned shops also feature widely, at a time when dilapidated old houses were being bulldozed.
Many hundreds of homes fell into disrepair in the post-war era - sometimes due to bomb damage
paraphrased_text: a body of work that had received little attention over her 55-year career. an exhibition of her images is now on show at Manchester Art Gallery. It focuses on what Baker saw as the needless destruction of working-class communities between the 1960s and 80s.

The government's proposed legislation will mean that more schools are likely to become academies.
An education bill will target so-called "coasting schools" – those that are not failing, but also are not making good progress.

Prime Minister David Cameron says the new measure will help give pupils a "life-changing" education, and it will end "coasting".

It will let the education secretary force an academy conversion on schools that have had four bad Ofsted inspections.

The plans are expected to apply to about 200 schools a year.

Alongside the government's plans for new grammar schools in "coasting" areas will mean that more schools in England and Wales are likely to become academies, taking them out of local authority control.

Two Canadian CF-18s successfully targeted an Islamic State (IS) garrison near Raqqa, Syria, the military said in a statement.
In March the Canadian parliament agreed to expand the country's campaign against IS into Syria.
Canadian air strikes against IS were previously limited to Iraq.
Canada is the first Nato country, other than the US, to strike inside Syria.

text:
Growing up in poverty on a federal housing estate in Houston, Texas, on his walks to and from school he'd go past wealthy houses in the area. They had cars with license plates that read 'BIGHAWK' and 'SNOWIK', he'd pass a mansion with a red Bentley in the driveway.

His first job was selling phone credit out of the back of an Uber, before he got a job as a telemarketer selling gym memberships. After that he worked at a furniture store, and finally got a job at an IT company, which was his ticket out.

"When I came into the job and I'm not sure if it's the same now, they gave you a MacBook Pro, and we used MacBook Pros as computers," he says. "And as soon as I was given that, I was like 'I'm getting a MacBook Pro'.
paraphrased_text: his first job was selling phone credit out of the back of an Uber, before he got a job as a telemarketer selling gym memberships. After that he worked at a furniture store, and finally got a job at an IT company, which was his ticket out. "I was like 'I'm getting a MacBook Pro'," he says. "And as soon as I was given that, I was like 'I'm getting a MacBook Pro'."

text:
Nintendo shares dropped by 17.7% after they more than doubled in value since the game's launch on 6 July.
Pokemon Go was developed by US firm Niantic and Nintendo said profits from licensing and fees would be limited.
However, even with the decline, Nintendo shares are still up 60% since the release of Pokemon Go on 6 July.
Overall, Japanese shares were little moved, with the Nikkei 225 finishing flat at 16,620.29.
Nintendo said the accounting scheme for recognising revenues from Pokemon Go meant its profits would not materially change.
The sharp drop was the biggest decline since October 1990, leaving the stock down by 5,000 yen - the maximum daily limit allowed.
The gaming company is due to report first-quarter results this
paraphrased_text: after the game's launch on 6 July. The sharp drop was the biggest decline since 1990. Nintendo said the accounting scheme for recognising revenues would not materially change.

text:
The ruling conservative Liberal Party has promised to hold a plebiscite on the issue if it returns to power at this weekend's election.

But Mr Shorten has been adamant the issue will not become the central theme of the election campaign and that Australians will decide who they elect to run the country in the coming four years, not on same-sex marriage.

He said Australia is already moving forward and same-sex marriage will be on the "backburner" of voters' concerns.

Mr Turnbull has accused Labor of being dishonest on the issue, saying Labor has changed tack after the 2001 and 2004 elections when Labor promised it would not alter marriage definitions if elected.

'it's not about you Malcolm. It's not about you Bill. It's about you Bill. It's about you Bill. It's about you Bill.

"The first time I met Steven Gerrard I asked him what he did," says the psychiatrist, who has worked with both the England and Manchester United manager, David Moyes.

"He said: 'I'm a footballer, do you know what I mean? I've got a different life. I'm a footballer and there are 11 players. But if you look up the team on the internet, it will say I'm Liverpool FC, captain. It doesn't say, 'Steven Gerrard'.

"The problem with that, of course, is that you're not seen as a complete person. The identity gets lost because everyone knows you as an athlete.

"As a psychologist, you have to go a little bit deeper than that," he says.

text:
All the families had fled their homes and were at risk of repeated human rights abuse, a spokesman told the BBC.
Civil society groups helped take the families to safety in Lebanon.
Aleppo has been devastated by three years of fierce fighting between Syrian government forces, rebels and jihadist militants.
Before the war, it had a Christian population of around 160,000, one of the biggest in the Middle East.
The refugees, who included Yazidis as well as Christians, were moved out along the only open road from Aleppo to the Lebanese border.
The operation took place over two months and amid great secrecy. Belgium is one of several European countries that have come under pressure to help Christians and other religious minorities in Syria threatened with persecution.

text:
The Liberal Democrat MP said he wanted to discourage people from having second homes which were left empty for most of the year.
Around England and Wales, Cornwall was the local authority area where the greatest number of people recorded a second address, the 2011 Census showed.
Tourism chiefs said well-used second homes brought money into the economy.
Mr Rogerson said: "You go to coastal villages, some of the towns as well, and you see huge swathes of places with no lights on at night.
"That really hits the local economy. People might spend quite a bit of money when they're there for a few weeks a year.
"But if those houses were occupied it would help the local pub and shop."
Malcolm Bell of Visit Cornwall said: "You can have a second home which is rented out for 40 weeks a year, providing revenue for the local shop,

text:
The Irish Business and Employers Confederation (Ibec) said that if Britain left the customs union, it would "massively disrupt" trade, leaving Irish firms "exposed".
It said the cash would help firms trade through "any adjustment period".
It also urged the EU to take a softer line on the UK in Brexit negotiations.
Britain is Ireland's largest trading partner, with business between the countries supporting 400,000 jobs and generating 60bn euros, according to the British Irish Chamber of Commerce.
But Ibec, which represents 7,500 Irish businesses, said the relationship was at risk as the UK government headed towards an "economically calamitous Brexit divorce" by quitting the customs union.
"If the UK insists on such a policy of self harm, a long transition period that maintains existing trading rules will be needed to allow companies time to adapt," chief executive Danny McCoy told senior EU policymakers on Wednesday.
He said that any new trade deal must
paraphrased_text: 400,000 jobs and generating 60bn euros, according to the British Irish Chamber of Commerce. but Ibec said that if Britain left the customs union, it would "massively disrupt" trade, leaving Irish firms "exposed". it said the cash would help firms trade through "any adjustment period".

text:
You might remember Ello, dubbed the "anti-Facebook", which exploded on to the market in late 2014 and is now looking to add yet more funding in a bid to further develop its service, but with a catch.

Ello, unlike other services, doesn't run on adverts as its main monetization route, instead opting for a subscription-based approach that will offer more for its premium members.

According to the Guardian, Ello has raised more than $4m to date, but it plans to expand its services and create a network of people. One of the main drawbacks to Ello is it lacks friends, like many others have, and that's something the founders are keen to fix.

text:
Tries from Rory Parata and Fionn Carr helped Connacht lead 14-0 but Treviso hit back and Jayden Hayward's last-gasp penalty ensured the home side's win.
Scores from Luca Morisi and Braam Steyn cut Connacht's lead to 14-12 by half-time and Treviso then edged ahead with a penalty try on 45 minutes.
A Peter Robb try restored Connacht's lead before Hayward's penalty won it.
Treviso's players celebrated after a victory which puts them in position to claim the European Champions Cup spot available to Italy as they move above Zebre into 11th spot in the table.
Connacht's losing bonus point guaranteed their semi-finals spot as they moved 11 points ahead of fifth-place Scarlets but Glasgow's expected victory over Zebre on Friday will drop the Irish province to third in the table.

His fourth-round victory over Rafael Nadal in that year's French Open is the only time the Spaniard has ever been beaten on clay by an opponent aged 30 or older.

And after his second-round win over Fernando Verdasco at the US Open on Thursday, Federer paid credit to Borg for the inspiration to his own career.

"To still be playing at 30, the way I do, is only through his example," the Swiss said.

"He came around at a time when I was just beginning to play. I was just starting to play tennis and suddenly there he was, this amazing player that could beat everybody.

The Football Association of Wales (FAW) apologised, citing "unprecedented demand", with strips unavailable online and in short supply in shops.
Wales are currently at an all-time high of 10th in the Fifa world rankings and are on course to qualify for Euro 2016.
In a joint statement with supplier JD Sports, the FAW said new supplies would be available within the next few weeks.
JD Sports has an exclusive deal with the FAW, which means Wales' kit is only available in its shops and on its website.

text:
The missing ball, which belongs to Dungloe Ladies GAA team in Donegal, was found by beach walker Arthur Heyes.
It was swept several hundred miles north by the Atlantic current, surviving its journey in good nick.
Mr Heyes has now emailed the club to try to reunite the team with the ball.
"Its been two or three hundred miles in the open Atlantic and yet it's in perfect condition," he told BBC Radio Foyle.
Mr Heyes and his brother were enjoying a walk along the western tip of North Uist when they noticed something white poking out of the sand.
"It's a beautiful island with lovely beaches and I noticed a ball which appeared to have been washed up.
"The thing I noticed first of all was the quality

Timothy Smith died two days later from head injuries.

He was arrested on Friday morning in north Lanarkshire.

text:
AFP report that Bale has suffered a minor setback in his recovery from a calf injury.
Bale has been out since suffering the injury in a 5-1 win against Sporting Gijon in January.
"He needs time and we need to be patient," Zidane said.
"We need Gareth to be 100% fit."
Bale, 26, will not feature at home to Athletic Bilbao in La Liga on Saturday.
"He is feeling better every day but I am not going to say that he will be back training with us next week," Zidane said.
"If he is feeling pain then it is to be expected that he might suffer a setback.
"Gareth is such an important player for us that we are not going to take any risks."

text:
But like all good cliches, there is more than a grain of truth in these typical snapshots of A-level results day.
Girls get better grades than boys.

And, while girls still get better grades than boys, this gap has closed somewhat in the last 12 months. The pass rate of males in England is at a record high at 98.5 per cent and has closed the gap to girls, who achieved a pass rate of 99.2 per cent.

This is the first time that the pass rate for boys has exceeded that of 98 per cent.

While more than four-fifths of students (85.1 per cent) have secured at least a C grade in three or more of their subjects, there has been a one per cent drop from the all-time high of 86.1 per cent last year.

Greater Manchester PCs Fiona Bone and Nicola Hughes were lured to a house in Mottram, Tameside on 18 September 2012.
Dale Cregan opened fire on the officers before throwing a grenade at them.
Mr Cameron attended the unveiling of a memorial stone at The Hub in Stockport Road in his first engagement since leaving Downing Street.
The memorial stone is less than a mile away from the scene of the attack.

text:
Ed Joyce made 112, while Andy Balbirnie was run out three short of a maiden hundred as Ireland posted 299 for eight in their first innings on day one of the first test against Pakistan.

Ireland opted to bat first, and the decision looked a smart one after Joyce and Paul Stirling posted a 96-run opening stand.

However, the pair were dismissed by part-time off-spinner, Shadab Khan, in a period of 50 minutes that saw four wickets fall and Ireland fall to 129 for four.

Joyce was run out on the pull against Hasan Ali, and Stirling, who top scored for Ireland with 53, was bowled after he got a leading edge onto the stumps.

The unidentified man was carrying several firearms when he stormed the family house in Campinas, some 100km (60 miles) from Sao Paulo, police said.
Another three people were wounded. The man killed himself afterwards.
The murder occurred just before midnight, police said. Neighbours had heard blasts but thought they were fireworks.
They were alerted after one of those injured escaped to a neighbour's house to plead for help.

text:
The agency said that political upheaval, including the recent sacking of finance minister Pravin Gordhan, was endangering the economy.
S&P also expressed concern over government debt, and in particular the expense of supporting the state energy firm Eskom.
The news put more pressure on the rand, which was down 2% against the dollar.
The sacking of Mr Gordhan, seen as a safe pair of hands and with a reputation for financial prudence, led to a 4% fall in the rand on Friday and prompted strong criticism.
His replacement as finance minister by Malusi Gigaba was part of a cabinet reshuffle by President Jacob Zuma.
However the country's deputy president, Cyril Ramaphosa, called Mr Gordhan's sacking "totally, totally unacceptable" and Gwede Mantashe, secretary-general of the ruling African National Congress (ANC), also opposed it.

Ren Bostelaar apologised for his actions but said the photos had already been posted elsewhere on the net by the women themselves.
Toronto Police is investigating but no charges have been made.

text:
Richard Maycock, who taught at Caludon Castle School, is accused of three counts of sexual activity with a child by a person in a position of trust.
The 43-year-old of Swanage Green, Walsgrave, was arrested on 14 November last year after an allegation of assault against a 15-year-old girl.
He was charged on Tuesday and is due to appear before magistrates in Coventry on 16 December.
In a statement, Coventry City Council said: "As legal proceedings are now active, it would be inappropriate for us to comment further at this time.
"The council and the school are cooperating fully with the police on this investigation."
Caludon Castle School, in Axholme Road, declined to comment.

"We had 28 days' notice," head coach Glen Chapple told BBC Radio Manchester.

text:
Jo, who spent most of her life as a man, is still hurt by the newspaper headlines describing her as a "sex swap playwright".

Jo was diagnosed as transsexual when she was 13 and is now in her 40s.

She had gender reassignment surgery several years ago and is now a woman. But she still has to fight for her rights.

When Jo was first married, at 18, she says her husband was very understanding about her condition.

But she says he was the one who ended the marriage.

Jo is in the process of separating from her second wife and she says this is because her partner is "still fighting my condition".

She says her third wife's ex-partner, an Anglican vicar, tried to get her to withdraw from the marriage.

He even asked her if she had tried hormone therapy and suggested she should try

Officials are optimistic that the city will be recaptured by the weekend.
But a spokesman for the US-led coalition has warned against complacency.
“Terrorists can be expected to continue to look for new ways to attack,” Lt. Col. Steve Warren said on Friday, urging Iraqis to maintain “vigilance”.

text:
The reigning world, European and Commonwealth champion suffered an ankle problem competing in Italy in May.
Rutherford, 30, was also one of many high-profile absentees from the British trials last weekend.
"Obviously this isn't ideal, but I am doing everything to give myself the best chance of success at the World Championships in London," he said.
Rutherford, who has only competed twice all season, is looking to defend his long jump world title at the 2017 Worlds which run from 4-13 August.
"After some really excellent training this year, the start to the season has been riddled with a series of troublesome injuries, most recently a problem with an ankle ligament," he added.
"As a result, I am absolutely gutted to say that I am unable to compete at the Anniversary Games this weekend - one of the
paraphrased_text: Rutherford, 30, is looking to defend his long jump world title at the 2017 Worlds which run from 4-13 August. "I am absolutely gutted to say that I am unable to compete at the Anniversary Games this weekend - one of the biggest sporting events of the year," he said. "I am doing everything to give myself the best chance of success at the World Championships in London," he said.

text:
"We can't contact them, they come to us," says the young man, who looks like he is barely out of his teens.

The young man is part of a group of around a dozen people in the mountains east of Lahore, in a place called Nai Sarak, where they are waiting for people on foot to pass by.

With the temperature soaring, it is important to have water, especially on this hot sunny day at 55C (130F).

"We try to get water from someone we are going to give food to," says another man standing next to him.

They call themselves volunteers, but their job is illegal, and they are not allowed to do it.

However, with 2.5 million Afghan refugees living in Pakistan, the authorities find it difficult to get rid of this illegal activity.

"If we arrest someone, we will have problems with the government
paraphrased_text: a group of around a dozen people in the mountains east of Lahore, in a place called Nai Sarak, east of Lahore. They call themselves volunteers, but their job is illegal, and they are not allowed to do it. "We try to get water from someone we are going to give food to," says another man standing next to him.

text:
Deputy First Minister John Swinney and Infrastructure Secretary Keith Brown jointly chaired the first meeting of the new Scottish APD stakeholder forum.
It includes representatives of the aviation industry, environmental groups and tax practitioners.
The move comes ahead of a consultation on the levy planned for the autumn.
Powers over APD are to be devolved to Holyrood as part of the new Scotland Bill.
The Smith Commission on further powers recommended the change.
The Scottish government has committed to halving the levy paid by air passengers within the lifetime of the next parliament, with a view to abolishing it completely when "public finances permit".
Research for Edinburgh Airport has already suggested that cutting APD in half would result in 700,000 more passengers going through Scotland's airports in the first year alone.
Mr Swinney said: "Scotland's airports are busier than ever and the Scottish government wants to see that success grow further to the benefit of passengers, business, tourism and
paraphrased_text: Scottish government has committed to halving the levy within the lifetime of the next parliament, with a view to abolishing it completely when "public finances permit" the move comes ahead of a consultation on the levy planned for the autumn. the levy is to be devolved to Holyrood as part of the new Scotland Bill.

text:
Checkout staff at Tesco in Forres have been trained to identify any special needs of customers and operate at a speed that suits them.

The new measures are part of Tesco’s commitment to making shopping easier for disabled customers by putting more support in place where it is needed.

Colleagues at the Morrisons store in Forres recently completed training, which has been rolled out to all staff across Tesco’s 1,942 stores in the UK.

More than 13,000 colleagues have so far received training and a further 27,000 have attended workshops.

Tesco’s customer training programme teaches colleagues how to provide extra support for disabled and elderly shoppers who need it, making simple changes to make the shopping experience easier for them.

This includes slowing down for customers who have mobility issues or extra communication needs.

Colleagues are also trained to provide support
paraphrased_text: special needs of customers and operate at a speed that suits them. the new measures are part of Tesco’s commitment to making shopping easier for disabled customers by putting more support where it is needed. Training has been rolled out to all staff across Tesco’s 1,942 stores in the UK.

The actor and model Gal Gadot, who will star in the upcoming Wonder Woman movie, was photographed at the set earlier.
The London landmark was festooned with union jacks, while actors in period costume and antique cars could be seen.
Roads around the square were closed off during the filming, with buses diverted, Transport for London said.

text:
The proportion of self-employed in the workforce in Wales is 13%, slightly below the UK average of 14%.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) Labour Force Survey shows that since 2012 the proportion of those who work for themselves has increased by 34.4k, from 129.3k (5.9%) to 163.7k (7.3%). Over the same period, employment in the self-employed in the UK has increased by 842.2k, from 4.0 million (13.4%) to 4.8 million (14.2%).

Over the period 2012 to 2018, the largest percentage increase was amongst the over 65s – rising by 7.7% in Wales compared to 5.5% in the UK, a difference of

Quinlan Pringle, 13, from Colchester, Essex, went to Boulogne-sur-Mer with his mother, step-father and brothers Oscar, nine, and Alfie, 14, when it all began a few weeks ago.

During the last day of their stay, Quinlan got a stomach bug so mum Gemma told him to get in the shower.

When she went to check on him later, she made a shocking discovery.

"I just went to knock the door and he didn't reply," Gemma, 40, said. "I shouted and kicked the door - still nothing. I went round to a side door and when I went in it was just darkness. I went in there and turned on a light. He was gone.

text:
Francis Paul, the secretary-general of the National Olympics Committee of Kenya (Nock), Pius Ochieng, Nock's vice chairman, and a third man, Stephen Soi, are being investigated for theft, abuse of office and neglect of duty.
The officials are blamed for a series of problems facing Kenya's athletes.
They have made no comment.
Bail for Mr Paul and Mr Ochieng was set at $2,000 (£1,530). Mr Soi had already been released from police custody for medical reasons and his bail will be set on Wednesday.
The charges against them have not been finalised and the police have a further 21 days to investigate before the men next appear in court.
The BBC's Ferdinand Omondi in the capital, Nairobi, says that athletes have complained about kit
paraphrased_text: are being investigated for theft, abuse of office and neglect of duty. They are being investigated for a series of problems facing Kenya's athletes. They have not made any comment.

text:
It took them about 50 days to walk through snow-capped mountains with donkeys carrying their luggage.
"My parents decided to move to Europe because the economy in Guatemala was bad, and they thought they had better opportunities for a better life," she said.
After 40 days in the sea, they ended up in Italy and applied for asylum there. But Italy wasn’t her dream destination, according to the young mother, who is still on a mission to get to where she really wants to go – the United States.
So she ended up in San Antonio, Texas, crossing the Mexican border through the desert in mid-June of this year. Once she was safely on the other side, she gave birth to a little girl just 10 days after arriving in the United States.
It was an experience she didn’t necessarily think about before, but one she says she wouldn’t want to go through again.
paraphrased_text: they moved to Italy and applied for asylum there. After 40 days in the sea, they ended up in Italy and applied for asylum there. But Italy wasn’t her dream destination, according to the young mother, who is still on a mission to get to where she really wants to go – the United States.

text:
If Snapchat had accepted, it would have been Facebook's biggest purchase.
Citing sources close to the matter, the Journal reported Snapchat was being pursued by others, including Chinese e-commerce company Tencent.
Popular with teenagers, Snapchat has doubled its usage recently.
According to the firm, more than 350 million images, or "snaps" are sent daily between mobile devices. Once received by users, they are erased after a few seconds.
Created in 2011, Snapchat raised more then $60m from investors last June, which valued the company at more than $800m.
However, the company has recently come under fire for claims that sent images delete themselves after being viewed.
Several hacks have been created that allow users to save snaps, posing potential privacy issues.
paraphrased_text: it would have been Facebook's biggest purchase. The Journal reported Snapchat was being pursued by others, including Chinese e-commerce company Tencent.

text:
The Public Accounts Committee said the department had admitted its 10-year plan may cost at least £5.2bn more than the £163bn forecast.
It also raised concerns about the MoD's assumptions that its funding would increase over the coming years.
The government said the committee's concerns were "overstated".
Defence Secretary Michael Fallon said the equipment plan, which runs from 2014 to 2024, was "realistic and affordable".
David Cameron has come under pressure from many of his own Conservative backbenchers to commit a future Conservative government to meeting Nato's target of spending 2% of GDP on defence.
The government has said a post-election spending review would set defence expenditure after 2016.
In a report published on Friday the cross-party group of MPs welcomed the "progress" the MoD had made in "getting to grips" with its defence budget
paraphrased_text: it may cost £5.2bn more than the £163bn forecast. It also raised concerns about the department's assumptions that its funding would increase over the coming years. Defence Secretary Michael Fallon said the equipment plan, which runs from 2014 to 2024, was "realistic and affordable".

text:
The workers were legally barred from leaving because they had left the firm before completing their contract terms.
The company has agreed to withdraw all cases, including 21 it had filed against workers who had left the firm before the end of their contracts.
On June 8, a court in the port city of Tianjin ordered the 21 to pay the contract termination fee and return property issued by their former employer.
The cases involved 21 workers, three of whom were women, at Beijing Huawei Technologies, a subsidiary of the global leader in consumer electronics, which is facing an international boycott campaign launched by workers at its factories in China and Mexico.
Seven of the cases are being taken forward by a labor activist, but the 11 others have been settled.
The Huawei employees say they will also challenge the decision at Beijing No 1 Intermediate Court of Appeal after the trial.

text:
A bronze plaque was unveiled at Maesteg Hospital on Saturday following a march through the centre of the town in Bridgend county by former pitmen.
The hospital, built in 1914, was originally run by the Red Cross and cared for injured soldiers as they returned from World War One.
It still provides healthcare today.
Staff past and present joined patients and the community for the unveiling of the plaque in Market Square.
It was paid for by the hospital's League of Friends which wanted to mark the contribution made by the mining community.
The League of Friends also funded a second, replica plaque for the foyer of the hospital.
There was music from Cor Meibion Maesteg a'r Cylch, Maesteg Children's Choir and the Curtain Up Youth Theatre and former miner Ian Isaac will share the story behind the hospital and plaque.
paraphrased_text: a plaque was unveiled at Maesteg Hospital on Saturday following a march through the centre of the town in Bridgend county. the hospital, built in 1914, was originally run by the Red Cross and cared for injured soldiers as they returned from World War One.

text:
During Mr Trudeau's campaign, he criticised the Conservative Party's approach to child care benefits.
He had argued that rich families didn't need taxpayers' help.
Two nannies were hired as "special assistants" at the prime minister's home under the Official Residences Act.
The positions were approved last week by the cabinet, though the nannies will be paid for their work from 4 November - the day Trudeau and his cabinet were sworn in.
Conservative party member Lisa Raitt has labelled the use of nannies as "hypocritical" and said that the positions should be funded by Trudeau's salary.
Mr Trudeau took issue with the Conservatives' focus upon child care benefits and income-splitting tax credits.
"In these times, [then Prime Minister] Mr Harper's top priority is to give wealthy families like his and mine $2,000," said Mr Trudeau on
paraphrased_text: two nannies were hired as "special assistants" at the prime minister's home under the Official Residences Act. the nannies will be paid for their work from 4 November - the day Trudeau and his cabinet were sworn in.

text:
The five-time Grand Slam winner, 28, revealed on Monday that she tested positive for meldonium in January.

Sharapova was handed a two-year ban from the sport by the International Tennis Federation (ITF) in June, after testing positive for the drug in January. The five-time Grand Slam champion was given a two-year ban from the International Tennis Federation (ITF), which was reduced to 15 months on appeal, after the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) recommended a two-year suspension. The ITF later announced that they would appeal against the decision.

The former No. 1 player was cleared to play in tournaments in May, but her ban was not lifted until September, when WTA Tour commissioner Steve Simon announced the ruling would be reversed. It was the first time Sharapova had tested positive for a banned substance in over a year.
paraphrased_text: Sharapova revealed on Monday that she tested positive for meldonium in January. text:
Magnolia Ward, at Summerlands Hospital, is set to close on 12 July, a spokesman for Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust said.

According to the spokesman, a “significant” number of inpatients are now able to return home under the community treatment order scheme introduced by government in April.

This scheme will allow people to leave hospital and be treated in their own homes instead of being detained in the hospital.

The number of patients at Summerlands Hospital is now 18, from a peak of 60.

Anne Maclean, director of operations, says: “Closing Ward Magnolia is necessary to make sure we can offer the best quality of care in the best environment for patients and staff.

“This also gives us more capacity for more people to be able to live safely in the community. Our team at Summerlands has been working really hard to support the recovery of
paraphrased_text: Magnolia Ward, at Summerlands Hospital, is set to close on 12 July. a “significant” number of inpatients are now able to return home. this will allow people to leave hospital and be treated in their own homes. number of patients at summerlands hospital is now 18, from a peak of 60.

text:
But many residents are concerned it could create too much pressure on the town's infrastructure and lead to major traffic problems.
The town, which is located in southwestern Virginia and lies in the Blue Ridge Mountains, has an area of about 324 miles and a population of about 2,500.

## A New Development

This proposed development, in the town's largest section (Giles County), is a 1,000-acre piece of land that contains three subdivisions. The subdivisions are located within the boundaries of Giles County, which has been known as the "Heart of Appalachia" for years.
This area is located at the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains and includes some of the most scenic areas in the United States. It is known for its natural beauty and abundant wildlife.
The county contains some of the most diverse geology in the United States.

text:
Evans, 25, was convicted of rape in April 2012 and jailed for five years. He is due to be released in February next year.

Following the news of his conviction, he was sacked by Manchester United and suspended by the Football Association, while the club he was with at the time, Oldham Athletic, were fined £10,000 by the Football League and Evans was handed a two-game suspension.

The 25-year-old has remained away from the public eye until appearing in court on Thursday.

He was accompanied by two friends as he arrived at the Crown Court at Minshull Street. He is due back in court on November 27.

His legal team were unable to comment when asked by Press Association Sport.

Gavin Riley, 28, attacked William Gibb in the 47-year-old's flat at Elizabeth Street, Greenock. Riley, who suffers from personality disorder, had been living at his father's flat in the town. The court heard Riley's father had contacted Mr Gibb because of the "problem with Gavin".

Procurator Fiscal Depute Emma Brown said that as they were leaving Mr Gibb's flat Riley grabbed him by the neck and headbutted him.

She said that when they were in the communal hallway Riley started punching Mr Gibb to the face and upper body.

As he struck Mr Gibb, Riley shouted: "You're dead man, you're dead."

text:
Caroline Gardner said there was a risk the authority would need a government bailout, despite receiving more than £24.3m from ministers since 2012.
She also cited problems around a new IT system for financial issues at NHS 24.
Ms Gardner said failure to launch the system successfully meant costs were now running 73% over budget.
In her report, the auditor general said NHS Tayside had received more than £5m from the Scottish government this year to alleviate pressure arising from staffing and prescription costs and hitting performance targets.
But she added: "As well as the need to repay this support, the board has set an unprecedented savings target of £58.4m for 2016/17.
"At the same time it is forecasting a potential deficit of £11.6m and does not currently have plans in place that fully address this gap.

Prof Ramakrishnan shared the 2009 chemistry Nobel Prize for discovering the precise structure of ribosomes - the molecular machines that manufacture proteins inside all living cells.
He will succeed geneticist Sir Paul Nurse in December 2015.
The society's council met on Wednesday to confirm the appointment.
Prof Nurse took on the role in 2010 and will step down after the customary five-year term.

Edna Atherton was 88 when she fell from the platform suffering broken ribs and a cut head at Birkenhead's Hamilton Square station in July 2015.
She had tried to board by holding on to the doors when a warning alarm sounded, the jury was told on Tuesday.
Martin Zee denies being responsible for her injuries at Liverpool Crown Court.
The 33-year-old, of Coronation Road, Runcorn, Cheshire pleaded not guilty to a charge of endangering the safety of railway passengers by wilful omission or neglect.
The jury was shown CCTV footage of the moment the train arrived at the station.
It showed Mr Zee leaving the back of the train and walking to the wall of the platform to check all the passengers had got off and on the carriages.

text:
Criminals are faking airline tickets and accommodation adverts, and selling bogus package holidays, according to the City of London Police's National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB).

The fraudsters have been advertising tickets for sale on well-known websites at prices well below the cost of buying directly from the airline.

According to the NFIB, they are then contacting victims who have paid and giving them fake airline tickets, which contain fraudulent booking references and barcodes. The criminals also provide fake documents confirming their hotel bookings.

Victims have been encouraged to pay for all these costs, as well as airport car parking, to ensure their holiday goes ahead as planned.

In some cases, the fraudsters have cancelled the tickets or hotel bookings, and the fraud has only been identified when the victim arrives at the airport or destination.

The NFIB's fraud alert said that fraud
paraphrased_text: faking airline tickets and accommodation adverts, and selling bogus package holidays, according to the NFIB. The criminals are contacting victims who have paid and giving them fake airline tickets, which contain fraudulent booking references and barcodes. the criminals also provide fake documents confirming their hotel bookings, according to the NFIB.

text:
Achilleas Kallakis and Alexander Williams, both 44, were sentenced to seven years and five years respectively, at Southwark Crown Court.
Between 2003 and 2008, they duped the banks into lending them the money to buy properties and a super-yacht.
Kallakis used the money to buy Bentleys, a plane and helicopter.
The trial of the two men - both of whom had previous convictions for fraud - took four months.
It was the second time they had faced this set of charges relating to the two banks.
Their first trial in 2011 was brought to a halt when one of the two men fell ill.
The two men operated from offices in Mayfair in London where Kallakis pretended to be a property tycoon and Williams posed as a financial consultant.
Ronan Duff of the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) said: "This was an audacious, persistent fraud that

text:
The former British soldiers known as the Chennai Six were jailed for five years in India in January of last year for firearms offences committed in 2008 – despite them having diplomatic immunity for the actions at the time.

In a fresh twist, the case has been heard by India’s Supreme Court, who today found them guilty, but said the six would be able to appeal.

“We’ll do whatever is necessary to get them back to the UK,” Prime Minister David Cameron said after the verdict.

But he declined to say whether they could apply for compensation, as they have threatened to do, and would not answer whether he would be taking his case to India’s president.

“There are two different levels: first of all I’d say the president of India has the power of mercy. He could choose to use it. That would be the first place we’d go,” he said.

text:
Scientists plan to send the long-range autonomous vehicle under the sea-ice of the Arctic - from one side of the ocean basin to the other.
It is a journey of at least 2,500km - and while nuclear subs might routinely do it, the prospect is a daunting one for a battery-operated research vehicle.
The trip could happen in 2018 or 2019.
“It represents one of the last great transects on Earth for an autonomous sub,” said Prof Russell Wynn, from the National Oceanography Centre, Boaty's UK base.
“Previously, such subs have gone perhaps 150km (horizontally) under the ice and then come back out out again. Boaty will have the endurance to go all the way across the Arctic.”

text:
The bank now expects growth in developing East Asia and the Pacific to be 6.5% this year and 6.4% in 2016, down from an earlier forecast of 6.7%.
The latest estimate is even lower than growth of 6.8% last year.
Major development banks have recently revised lower their growth forecasts.
Last month, the Asian Development Bank said slowing growth in China would drag down the developing region's growth to 5.8% this year.
The International Monetary Fund also flagged in September that slowing growth in the world's second largest economy posed a threat to the global economy.
"Developing East Asia's growth is expected to slow because of China's economic rebalancing and the pace of the expected normalization of US policy interest rates," said the World Bank's regional chief economist Sudhir Shetty in a statement

The attack happened in Kenilworth Rise, Livingston, at about 23:00 following a disturbance involving a number of people.

Emergency services attended and found a 37-year-old man with a serious facial injury, which is thought to have been caused by a weapon.

He was taken to hospital for treatment and police believe he may have been slashed.

A 27-year-old man was also injured, suffering from a facial injury and minor head injury.

Police are treating the incident as a serious assault and are appealing for information.

A Police Scotland spokeswoman said: "We are keen to trace anyone who may have been in the Kenilworth Rise area at the time or who may have been in the vicinity of a white car on this road."

A scheme to resettle unaccompanied children around the UK starts in July.
The government has agreed to take in more child refugees, including from the EU and 3,000 children and relatives from the Middle East and North Africa.
The Local Government Association says the number of spaces councils will make available will depend on funding.
At the moment children are looked after where they arrive, largely in Kent or near Heathrow airport.
Deputy leader of Hillingdon council, which cares for children who arrive at the airport, David Simmonds said: "Unless there's additional funding in the system we'll need to see either increases in council tax to pay for supporting refugee children or we'll see local councils cutting other services."
From July, the government will provide more money to support newly arrived unaccompanied refugee children: £41,600 a year for those under 16 years old.

The index, the UK's leading measure of share prices, has been rising steadily since the middle December.
It marks the eighth record in 10 weeks, the most since 2000.
Economists say the FTSE 100 Index has moved up due to the falling cost of a barrel of crude oil, the rising value of the pound and hopes that the UK will continue to see an improved economic recovery in 2014.
The Index has risen from 6,014.43 at its lowest level on 26 November to 6,667.6 at its current trading price.

text: The official Communist Party watchdog also promised to prosecute Zhao Xinwei for "serious discipline breaches", which generally refers to violations of Party discipline. In August 2019, Xi Jinping promoted Zhao to be a vice chairman of the party's Central Discipline Inspection Commission, the highest-ranking anti-corruption agency. The Mancunian Way in Manchester has been partially closed since it was damaged by heavy rainfall last summer.
The key commuter route is totally closed for a full inspection until it reopens at 06:00 BST on Wednesday.
Manchester City Council said closing it over the weekend would have added to congestion caused by a music festival.
But Greater Manchester Chamber of Commerce rejected this, saying: "To think that the disruption would be less on a weekday than at a weekend, even allowing for the Parklife Festival, just doesn't stand up or make any sense."
Commuter Nathan Yates said a 10 minute journey from the Broughton district of Salford to Ancoats in Manchester took him two-and-a-half hours.
"It was horrific, a total nightmare," he said.

Mr Udaltsov is charged with organising "mass disorder" during a protest in Moscow in May 2012. He was arrested in October before being released.
The leader of the Left Front coalition has rejected the accusation, saying it is an attempt to discredit the opposition to President Vladimir Putin.
If convicted, Mr Udaltsov faces between four and 10 years in prison.
It is the first time that a Russian opposition activist has been placed under house arrest, the BBC's Oleg Boldyrev reports from Moscow.

First year students will now return to the unit, following the reintroduction of third and second year placements.
Betsi Cadwaladr health board said there would be "dedicated support" for staff and students.

"The contract is signed and it will be announced very soon," Petrov told Reuters after a Formula One test at Portimao.

"I think it has been very well negotiated and I am very pleased with the result."

Petrov, who last year was the third of a trio of first-time drivers to make their F1 debut with Renault and whose season ended abruptly when he crashed out in Canada, had been working on the new deal since the year ended.

The colourful light show could be seen in Scotland and Northern Ireland, but was also spotted as far south as Anglesey and Oxfordshire.
The Northern lights happen when electrically-charged particles from the Sun enter the Earth's atmosphere, and then burn up creating the lights.
If you didn't see the Aurora Borealis you may get a second chance, it's likely to be visible on Monday night but only to those who live in northern England and Scotland.

Jack Phipps, 53, was admitted to hospital on 22 June after an incident in Harefields in north Oxford. He died from his injuries on 1 July.
Police have carried out a post-mortem examination but are still continuing to establish the cause of death.
A 48-year-old man from Oxford arrested on Wednesday on suspicion of murder is still in custody.
Senior investigating officer, Acting Ch Insp Ailsa Kent, of the major crime unit, said: "Our thoughts are with the family of Mr Phipps at what must be a very difficult time for them, and we are offering them support."
She said her team were "still investigating the circumstances of this incident" but appealed for anyone with information to come forward.

text:
The memorial spire and walls of remembrance are the first significant development in the creation of the International Bomber Command Centre.
Lord Howe, Minister of State for the Ministry of Defence, cut the ribbon.
The ceremony, presented by historian Dan Snow, was attended by 300 of the remaining Bomber Command veterans.
Mr Snow said: "This is Bomber County, Lincolnshire is Aviation County. Aircraft were made here, pioneered here and flown from here during both world wars.
"Aviation is inextricably linked with Lincolnshire and it is exactly right that the memorial is here."
A number of flyovers by different aircraft were organised for the occasion, including the last flying Vulcan, a Blenheim bomber, two Tornados, three Hawks and the current MacRobert's Reply.
The memorial spire was designed by Stephen Palmer of Place Architecture, and is higher than the Angel of the North.
It is 102ft (31.09m) tall - the wingspan of the Avro Lancaster

The decision provoked strong criticism on social media and in the forums of Valve's Steam game service.
Mr Newell said Valve was keeping an eye on the early days of the system to make sure it worked well.
One early change would give mod makers more control over what they charge for their code.
Mods add all kinds of extras to games, including weapons, armour and pets. The most ambitious add new enemies and even entire levels.
"Our goal is to make modding better for the authors and gamers," wrote Mr Newell in the Reddit Q&A. "If something doesn't help with that, it will get dumped."
He said one of the first changes would be the introduction of an option that lets mod authors put a donate button on their code. In addition, Valve would also stop deleting discussions about the issue on Steam forums.
Prior to

Margaret Murphy's husband Andrew died in 2014 from leukaemia. His immune system was left badly weakened after he got Legionnaire's from compost in 2008.
She said stronger warning labels could avoid more cases of the infection.
The Scottish government said current evidence suggested labelling had no impact on the number of cases.
The Growing Media Association, which represents compost manufacturers, said the risk of infection remained very low.
Between 2008 and 2013, 16 people in Scotland contracted Legionnaire's disease from compost. Two of them died.
Andrew Murphy, from Lanarkshire, was the very first Scot to contract the infection in 2008.
He was not a regular gardener, but purchased a bag of compost to try his hand at growing tomatoes.
He planted them in his conservatory, with his four-year-old granddaughter nearby. A couple of days later, he

On 1 October, the woman reported a sexual assault which she said happened near Ashbourne Road in Derby.
Following an extensive investigation, police confirmed the attack had never taken place.
Det Ch Insp Sam Slack from Derbyshire Police said all reports of rape or assault were thoroughly investigated by the force.
"It is always disappointing when a large amount of police time is wasted on reports such as this," said Det Ch Insp Slack.

The case of British nurse Pauline Cafferkey, who remains in a serious but stable condition in hospital in London, is a timely reminder of how little is known about the lingering after effects of the killer virus.
The World Health Organization says there's only one other well-documented Ebola survivor who has suffered severe complications after recovering from the virus, American infectious disease expert Dr Ian Crozier.
He was originally infected in September 2014 while treating patients in Sierra Leone. He was sent back to the US to receive treatment in a special Ebola unit in Atlanta. He left the hospital in October, after being given the all clear.

The Cardiff Capital Region City Deal will see £734m invested in the Metro transport scheme and £495m on other projects across the area over a 20-year period.

Cardiff, Newport, Rhondda Cynon Taf, Torfaen, Bridgend, The Vale of Glamorgan, Monmouthshire and Merthyr Tydfil have put forward proposals to create 25,000 new jobs by the year 2026, while the region’s economy will have grown by 30%.

The investment will allow Cardiff and Newport to become a “world class city-region” and the “gateway of south east Wales” according to the region’s report.

Comedian and broadcaster Rob is the only original host to have stayed with the show since it first launched in 2002 and has presented the show for 23 out of 25 series so far.

The victim received two pictures of an unknown man's penis on her phone via Apple's Airdrop sharing function.
Lorraine

# Woman receives pictures of stranger's penis via Apple's Airdrop - here's how to prevent it

A woman received a picture of a man’s penis on her phone after he sent it via Airdrop on Apple’s Iphone.

The man had no idea that the picture had been sent to a stranger’s phone and the woman hadn’t even known what Airdrop was.

Lorraine viewers took to social media to share their own experiences.

A police car had its windows smashed as Mr Trump spoke inside a hall in the Orange County Fairgrounds in Costa Mesa. Some 2,000 demonstrators from around Los Angeles marched to the speech site and clashed with police near the fairgrounds.

According to the Associated Press, the crowd broke glass at the main entrance of the hall, broke a police vehicle’s windshield, smashed a news van and piled burning newspapers and garbage on the street. A group of police officers retreated into the fairgrounds as the protesters approached the building, and they fired pepper spray at them. They are a 317-unit development in the Athletic Stores building on Queen Street and an 11-storey, 380-unit development on Little Patrick Street.
The Athletic Stores scheme will involve retaining the building's facade and demolishing and rebuilding behind it.
The Ulster Architectural and Heritage Society had objected to the scheme.
It said a facade retention approach should only be used as a "last resort".
However, the planners said that "on balance" the approach was appropriate and would not cause harm to the area's overall character or appearance.

The government cut subsidies in the summer because the £7.6bn budget had been exceeded.
Ministers say they are committed to protecting the climate.

The former Burton boss was replaced by Gianfranco Zola at St Andrew's after more than two years with the Blues.
Rowett, 42, left Birmingham seventh in the Championship, only outside the play-off places on goal difference.
"I am extremely disappointed that my time as manager of Birmingham City has come to an end," said Rowett in a League Managers' Association statement.
"I felt we were only halfway through the project and I strongly believed we were on course to achieve our objectives."
Birmingham lost 2-1 at home to Brighton in their first match under Zola on Saturday.
"I would like to take this opportunity to thank the players, fans and everyone at the club for their support and hard work during my time at Birmingham City," added Rowett.
"I wish them well for the future and look forward to my next challenge in the game."

text:
MPs voted by 334 to 292 to accept changes made by peers, meaning the planned constituency shake-up will go ahead

MPs have backed plans to reduce the number of members of parliament by 50 – with only 22 constituencies set to lose their MPs.

Under the revised plans – which were proposed by Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg – the number of parliamentary constituencies will drop from 650 to 600 with an additional three MPs being elected.

The changes will also see the country gain an additional 20 constituencies in Scotland, three in Northern Ireland, one in Wales and 11 in England outside London.

The proposed changes – which will see MPs’ pay drop from £81,932 to £79,468 – received the backing of MPs by 334 to 292.

“After I finished school, I had a job that paid US$150 a month. I never had a fixed contract,” she says.
